unique_questions: Anything else? - Would you add any other ideas, including from your perspective as a California resident?
Share what has been working - Examples
Share your idea - Primary problem and ideas to solve the problem

subthemes.name: Remote work and return to office

comments.content: As a tax collecting agency, it is way too easy for people to lie, cheat and steal to avoid paying taxes. There is nothing more frustrating than being a law-abiding taxpayer, and watching people take advantage of the system and steal more in tax revenue in one year then I will likely earn in my lifetime.  People just start new corporations or other entities and ultimately have no personal responsibility after not paying any taxes for several years.  The system is way too easy to take advantage of and it very demoralizing to watch it be abused decade after decade and all they would have to do is make it easier to go after known cheaters and remove some of the protections corporations or other entities have and hold the owners responsible for cheating.

I’ve worked on several initiatives aimed at reducing waste and improving efficiency in state operations. One example involved streamlining the internal administrative operations. The original workflow had multiple redundant review layers, causing delays of up to 30 days. Using process mapping and stakeholder interviews, we identified non-value-added steps and consolidated approvals, cutting the turnaround time by 40%.  In another case, I led a Kaizen event to improve customer response times in public requests for service. By analyzing call center data and applying root cause analysis, we restructured the triage process and introduced a simple decision tree for frontline staff. This reduced call escalations by 25% and improved first-contact resolution.  These projects not only improved service delivery but also empowered staff by giving them tools to identify and solve problems on their own.
I saw this on a coffee mug: "The meetings will continue until we figure out why no work is getting done."

More wind and solar power, more (not less) nuclear power, including small modular nuclear reactors local to the supported city, undergrounding powerlines, more use of nature-based solutions to wildfire risk (e.g., goats to clear undergrowth), finish the high-speed rail, fix our crumbling infrastructure (roads, bridges, dams), encourage tiny homes (1BR) through tax breaks to developers to address the housing crisis, State Agency/Tech Sector partnership and integration - have the tech sector try to solve our recurring and wicked problems.

One of the most enlightening books I've read recently was 'Poverty, by America' by Matthew Desmond. In it, he points out how, while well-intentioned, so many government programs are not being used by those who need the benefits most because they are too difficult to navigate or confusing for people to use. This creates an impression among low-income folks that state government is AGAINST them, not for them. This creates a self-perpetuating cycle of distrust between the very people who would most benefit from our services.   We need (not in order): 1. Data: Identify unused gov't services 2. Tech: Provide a unified, easy to remember, accessible access point to connect people with services 3. Reform: Review all public benefits we provide in California from a modern, poverty reduction point of view, at every level, and flag those services that may need legislative reform so we can make recommendations to legislature.  4. Project management: Task force to address poverty (different than homelessness, and not meant to replace current efforts there) in California. 5. Marketing: Make combating poverty our primary focus, drill it into every state department at every level looking for ways to address, including inter-agency efforts and private sector-style promo to draw people in. Almost like a rebrand.  This would be a huge lift but when we have so many services, so many people struggling, plus such a negative impression of gov't, it seems like it would be a win-win-win for everyone.

In private sector, folks expect that gen AI and other LLMs will make work more efficient therefore contracts are baking in 1-5% reduction year over year in allocated costs. We often bake in inflation but don't expect efficiencies from new tech etc when we reprocure. I would recommend that our contract template includes an expectation for efficiency year over year from our vendors.

Reduce taxes and regulations for everyone, which will spur more companies to stay in California, thus creating more jobs and eventually more state income tax revenue for the state. Really too many people in state upper mgmt. A lot of the positions are either redundant or useless. Need to consolidate. State workers going back to the office doesn't seems cost efficient, unless the work requires it. It's just more tax payer money spent on unnecessary rent for office space when the work can be done at home.

"bulk" training procurement by state department. For example, if I want to take a HAZWOPER course as a staff at an agency under CNRA, I have to go out and individually procure the training through my departments procurement protocol, which is slow and cumbersome.  If CNRA could contract and offer trainings that a large percentage of staff may be required to take, staff would simply have to sign up through some interface, rather than every staff person or department having to individually procure the training.  Due to my workload and the cumbersome procurement process, I have avoided taking trainings that will advance my ability to support the state in emergency situations, in this case.

I have begun working independently, with feedback from my team, on standardized procedures for "evaluating" the local inspection agencies (county and city "Certified Unified Program Agencies") my unit oversees. Prior to this, no such procedures were being used to my knowledge, resulting in inconsistencies between each "evaluator" in the unit, and unnecessary effort being spent every single new evaluation trying to figure out and remember how each analysis was completed. While this project is still incomplete, I believe this suite of procedures in its early stages has already helped to increase consistency between staff and reduce training times, and increase training effectiveness, for new staff.

Redundancy and outdated procedures.  It's 2025 and some of the state's procedures need to be revisited and revised to reflect the modern era.  I have worked for three different agencies in the last 8 years or so and I can say that all of them could be modernized in some way.  We need to pivot away from using fax machines, storing paperwork, accepting the lowest bid possible (you get what you pay for), things like that.  California needs to invest in it's self.

CALFIRE receives massive amounts of funding to manage/treat vegetation on State lands for fuel reduction/fire management purposes . They are experts in fire and fire fighting, but not experts in vegetation management. Public agencies that own and manage land (including State Parks) should receive the funding to manage/treat the vegetation on their lands. These non-CALFIRE agencies have the expertise to manage vegetation to meet fuel reduction goals while minimizing harm to natural resources and natural processes.
Totally agree
What would help this is if everyone adopted abstracting their environments into code. That way we could all work under a common language and share ideas and solutions.
Would love to see broader incentives or discounts for state employees. Or internally more recognition of employees and the services they provide the residents of California.

Our state prison system - the California model is a great foundation but many of the prisons lack basic services for rehabilitation (groups, etc.).  This only happens by scaling up staffing.  Also, homelessness - we need a lot of affordable housing

We have so much knowledge in our heads but not out for coworkers to see. We are currently working on leaving what we know and have done for coworkers to read so if one person leaves, the whole system does not go along with them. This has been a self-guided thing, would be good to have a better state-wide example of how to do this most clearly and effectively, plus something there for state-wide processes.
Telework is a great way to attract amazing new talent that the government would otherwise miss out on just because of where someone lives.
Conduct a survey of all State employees to identify what training they are interested in that would assist them in promotions or just doing their jobs.
I agree. The amount of documentation can be cut down and the processes can be simplified.
Please make improvements to the DMV process. At the very least, DMV staff should not be taking lunches at the same time. Also, can there be some online/ Zoom/Team video appointments.

The SavingsPlus managers at CalHR recently improved the Target Date Funds. They swapped out a proprietary group of TDFs that were larded up with expensive, underperforming actively managed mutual funds and replaced them with a TDF series comprised entirely with index funds.   If the CalPERS board would just do the same -- replace its expensive, poor performing actively managed mutual funds and private equity with transparent and low-cost index funds -- the CalPERS portfolio would also improve its performance, benefiting employees and the public.

For agencies with rulemakings, it would greatly improve efficiency if we have a more modern way to notice service lists about workshops, events, or other provide other critical updates that isn't just copying from an excel spreadsheet into email. It's inefficient and hard not to make mistakes.

I would like to suggest opening up the possibility for state employees of one department being allowed to use another departments empty/vacated locations for alternative onsite days.  As an example, a telecommute employee working under a hybrid plan and living a distance away from their respective home office, could use a hotel cubicle in another state office closer to their home for an onsite day.  Just a thought for using those unoccupied office locations.  Consideration would have to be made for Internet access, but most all state offices have that capacity already.
something needs to be done about housing costs in this state. Id love to see a ban on corporate ownership of single family homes.

Please procure a proper off-the-shelf timesheet system. The PDF chart that gets signed, then sent to the supervisor, then to the attendance coordinator to store a copy, and then keyed into a DOS-like terminal is wild.
Utilizing technology to work smarter not harder.

The primary problem I have seen across my time working state service is a lack of training and skills development among staff. Instead of refining our skills, and engaging in external trainings, we depend upon internal practices that are often out of date with the professional working community elsewhere in the natural resources management world. This lack of training and skills development puts staff at a disadvantage when it comes to modern approaches to natural resources management projects, in addition to increasing the amount of time it takes to convey processes among ranks.
Communication, especially between different state departments. Employees that are not performing to the standard are not reprimanded and their workload falls on everyone else.
Supporting, embracing and strengthening telework for CA employees

I develop and lead trainings to support the understanding of new processes. I have successfully developed a community within my various projects that support change and a willingness to execute at the program level.  I also develop both technical resources (such as databases, websites, articles, etc...) and procedural documents to support ongoing education and personal development to foster a willingness to take on new tasks.

Primary problem: I would like to see more Leadership Training.  I understand there are mandated hours of training (and have taken them) which covers management resposibility, performance management, understanding union representation etc.  I think tangible leadership skills would also be helpful.  Leading a team (of any size) can be overwhelming and staged training that covers various skills and topics would help any leader. Solution:  I would have a learning path that needs to be completed in one year - since that is typical probation period.   The learning path would have a series of trainings that cover soft skills as well as the content currently covered.  I also think having a buddy that you could stay in contact with and bounce ideas off each other would be helpful so it is an ongoing type of training.

Managing my time and focusing on my job as a state employee ensures that I am using the state's time efficiently. I contribute to process improvements for California resident and nonresident taxpayers to file and pay their correct amount of tax in a timely manner.

A recurring concern I encounter is the continued reliance on paper documentation in environments where the vast majority of records are already managed electronically. In many cases, hard copies provide little added value, yet we continue to utilize paper and intra-office mailing systems for processes that could be handled securely and more efficiently through our encrypted email systems. The ongoing costs of paper, printing, and postage are considerable and present an avoidable expense.

I'd like clearer communication from the state over employment/HR concerns. The recent agreement with SEIU left me confused over what actually was happening to my paycheck, and neither the state nor SEIU were helpful in determining that. I also received a promotion-related NOPA around the same time that was similarly opaque, and spent many hours back and forth with HR trying to figure out what the contradictory statements attached to it meant.

I think the State of California’s agencies should stop overcharging each other for work/services that are supposed to benefit our citizens. Our agency leases buildings from the Department of General Services (DGS). Anytime anything needs to be updated or fixed the quotes for a solution are usually 3x-5x the cost and 2x-3x the timeline for completion of work versus hiring a private company to do it.     Example: A few years ago a loading dock door’s heavy duty motor reached its end of life, and our landlord (DGS) quoted us upwards of $25K to replace it with the same exact model. I researched the exact motor, and the part alone was $2.5K.  We’ve got to figure out a better system as a state.

Experience, & dedication is the key. Passing the experience, motivating & open mind can continue to transform & upgrade us.   I would share my knowledge & experience with my colleagues. And stay open to suggestions.

As a Californian and state employee, I am most troubled by the ongoing homelessness problem in our state. In order to entice billionaires to stay in the state (and continue to fund our state government with their income taxes!) we need to do a MUCH better of making housing accessible to every Californian.  Recently, I used Sacramento County 311 to report a homeless individual who was encamped near my house and abusing alcohol to the point he might have died in the summer heat. I am happy to report that someone from the County cleaned up the encampment and removed the trash. However, I have no idea who was responsible for removing the encampment, or what became of the homeless person. To improve our state, I would like it to become common practice for citizens to report encampments and homeless residents AND be able to know what organization responded to the 311 report, and the where the homeless person was taken, and what services they were offered.

I have been working dealing with Contractors and we required from them to submit a breakdown of their bidding amounts.  If they were to submit to me a breakdown of any project that I am doing at home,  I paid close attention to the cost and figured out cost of materials and Labor.  I can go online or go to the hardware stores and see the items prices.  I have experienced many times in the State do not pay attention to the cost given by contractors and as long as we, State, have the money we approve the Contractor to start work.  I was asked in a survey about improvements that we can recommend and I mentioned about that way we put a price on a project (estimate).  The following year it was a requirement for us to show how we came up with the Estimated Cost to do the project- Breaking down all the work and cost.  Someone created a database of cost and we started using that database without much thought and my opinion it became worse in coming out with estimating the cost of a project.  The project cost is inflated 60 percent more to make sure we have enough money for the project-  meaning still do not know what we are doing.  If someone comes to my house and give me an estimated cost to place a lighting pole, trench 100 feet, dig a foundation, add a breaker.  Do you think that I can get a quick estimate by going to lows, Home Depot? Yes!  State estimate Cost $65,000 My estimated Cost $17,000

It's not a simple problem to fix, but I think it cuts across many Departmental efforts which would save money and lives.  I think we need better Public Transportation.  The desired outcome: less traffic and congestion, fewer auto accidents, and reduced emissions.  I know for example it would save quite a bit money and Staff hours in DHCS, a seemingly unrelated Department, if we can reduce the number of auto accidents occurring in CA.  It's also known that the majority of DHCS funding goes to paying for medical services, so any opportunity to reduce serious injury will also provide state savings.  Beyond that, better public transit can reduce costs of living for Californians, promote better public health outcomes, aid CalEPA's mission, and hopefully in the long term also make Caltrans' job easier, with hopefully less travel infrastructure needing maintenance.

I saw the comment on training. We are modernizing our training to be less historical and more practical. Daily we work to create a searchable database to make it easier for our employees to get to the answers we need.

One primary problem I would address is the fragmentation and inefficiency caused by too many oversight agencies in California’s government. This creates delays, redundant processes, and unclear accountability.   My solution would be to streamline oversight by consolidating overlapping agencies and functions. I’d also push for performance-based funding, tying legislative allocations for system upgrades to measurable outcomes like reduced processing times or improved customer satisfaction. This ensures that public resources are used efficiently and that upgrades deliver real value to Californians.

Staffing has been a real issue for a lot of the departments. I know when I wanted to apply to be a state working nobody wanted to tell me how the process is done. Now that I been working 4 years in the department, I noticed that across the board hiring and retaining workers is a challenge. For the interview process if people don't show up, they are unable to go lower in the tier to hire candidates that didn't score high but are willing to work. Also people go out on injury for months at a time leaving areas understaffed. They are unable to put a temporary person or hire a new person while that person is on leave. This leaves the rest of the team overworked and unhappy to be doing several people's job. Also moving up we have meetings 1 a year about moving up but they make no effort to communicate with the people interested in moving up. I had communicated several times, and it seems they are always on vacation. I think upwards mobility is a myth. Also when issue's arrive with payroll leading to Sacramento someone is always on vacation. The next person in line usually does not want to be bothered and will not cover their shift unless absolutely necessary. I feel like there needs to be oversight and accountability. Alot of  California's need jobs but without proper instruction to score higher on test, or show how to apply. Or move the people up from lower positions they been working for years we cannot have a flow of employment.
Upfront and clear communication. Also, creating accountability.

Low morale is the biggest killer of efficiency.  Low morale is caused by at least two things: 1) not listening or respecting state workers; 2) bad management/unfair division of labor.  When policies are implemented that do not effectively consider the potential impacts on the lives of civil servants, such as RTO--state workers will lose all drive to do good work.  Why work hard for a system that does not care about you and won't listen to you?  Poor leadership has the same effect.  Managers can get stuck in their ways and refuse to rethink processes or challenge other policies/processes that are clearly inefficient--even when their employees are expressing the need for change.  When employees are able to live and work comfortably (by being paid a fair wage, have a good work-life balance, be able to work in safe environments, like their homes, free from distracting co-workers and racist/sexist/inappropriate conduct), and when they see their management step up and be good leaders (by listening, pivoting when needed), that is what will improve efficiency!

I believe that we (state) can be more fiscally sound when purchasing items/or making contracts required for operations- day to day, emergencies, etc. I feel that the contracts that we put out into the communities are being price gouged by the bidders. Also if contracts are not adhered to, we still pay the amount the bidders originally stated. (IE, Construction issues, delays, costing more than originally bid for) I think that the end product after a project is completed is also not up to par more often than not and then the State (and its entities) Has to pay more money to have it fixed either by the original contractor or by a new contractor.  What about charging for delays? If a contract for construction takes longer than originally planned (by the bidder) then they are charged per day/week/month extra.  If a contract cost more than originally planned for (by the bidder) than the bidder eats the cost, not the state and the tax payers?  I know some of these options are not viable but there are ways to help save the taxpayer and the state overhead on projects and contracts.

The primary problem I would address is inconsistent/unfair in the hiring practice. For example, mid/senior management with no prior state service experience, skills or knowledge matching the job description getting the job whereas internal candidates are overlooked. I understand there are some positions that are elected positions in the state. Majority of the positions are filled with who you know basis rather than merit based.  The idea to resolve the problem is to have regular audits on hiring processes for all the state departments. There should an oversight by the California State Auditor's Office.
Working for the State Parks means I am below the poverty line in California. How can the State expect loyalty when my salary completely inhibits me from ever buying a home in California?

Revising the classification system for the modern work force. Many of the classifications are outdated or don't include current roles. It can be challenging to recruit talent without more specific classifications.

Combating State worker burnout and abuse at the hands of poorly trained Supervisors, I propose stricter sanctions on supervisors, better training for both, and all employees adhering to a code of conduct.

We seem to be dismissing the importance of educating the public AHEAD of a problem.  We are very reactionary.  After they have a problem, we have call-centers staffed with huge numbers of State workers trying to solve their problems one-on-one...individually.  How much of that could be addressed more efficiently by educating groups of business owners and individuals on how to do required tasks before they've made a mistake?  One State worker could educate hundreds rather than less efficient one-on-one help.  Once the public has made a mistake, we have huge numbers of State workers to try and collect a penalty or interest.  Wouldn't it be more efficient to just try and educate them so they do things correctly in the first place?  It makes one wonder if the State has become RELIANT upon penalties and interest and can't afford to give those up?

Exactly! Using the option to Telework would increase the pool of qualified candidates, allow people to live where it's more affordable, decrease traffic congestion, eliminate the need for public transportation, etc.  Maybe also allowing job sharing for some jobs like OT jobs, so women with kids can work part time, still have benefits, and take care of their babies.

I work at a department that is efficient and effective in executing it's mission. It is mature when it comes to business processes.  Repeatable Processes are well documented and managed. I am available to chat privately (non confidential) in a smaller setting.

Right? We have Agency telling us to use plain language to explain the statute but Legal telling us only to cite the statute and not even paraphrase because anything that changes the meaning creates liability.

California Government is just to big and the "pieces" don't talk to each other. The California State Law Enforcement Union  represents  over 10 different work groups ( Special Agents, ABC Agents, CHP Dispatchers, Fish and Wildlife Wardens- to name a few) none of these groups have anything to do with each other and they are not efficient. the cost of all these work groups should be reduced and where they can eliminated.
It almost makes one think there are cases in which efficiency is not politically expedient.

Employees need a way to communicate with upper management of the department without fear of reprisal. Our duty statements say to alert the department of any programmatic problems, but negative feedback often does not make it past the first line of management and so nothing is improved. An anonymous communication tool would help employees feel heard without having to file a whistleblower complaint.

I worked at California Department of Water Resources (DWR). The department depends on accurate, timely data to manage California’s water, yet many workflows remain manual, siloed, and slow. For example, the current processes for generating critical data—like ETaw used in water budget calculations—span multiple teams, take up to 12 weeks, and involve redundant steps such as manual file transfers, duplicated analysis, and outdated tools. These inefficiencies limit transparency, slow responses to urgent requests, and create inconsistencies across programs.  I proposse Land and Water Use Cloud Pilot aims to address these bottlenecks by demonstrating how a modern, cloud-based data stack can streamline workflows. By automating repetitive tasks, integrating land use and water use analyses, and leveraging scalable platforms such as Google Earth Engine and Snowflake, the pilot will reduce turnaround times, improve collaboration, and ensure results are both accurate and transparent.  This proof-of-concept will show how moving from fragmented, manual systems to an integrated cloud environment can cut processing times dramatically (e.g., reducing ETaw delivery from 12 weeks to 4), while laying the foundation for broader adoption of modern solutions across DWR. Ultimately, this approach strengthens our ability to conserve water, respond quickly to partners, and deliver high-value information to millions of Californians

I agree. This "if you ride it, we'll build more" attitude serves no one. They need to invest in the infrastructure and make it practical for real people to use. I used to be able to take light rail to and from work, but the decrease in service hours, the extended wait times, frequent outages, and frankly the sheer filth on the light rail cars makes it unfeasible.
I make sure my department runs effectively by making sure the products that we produce daily are safe and not compromised.

I envision state agencies that are rooted in integrity and liberated from the shifting winds of political whim—where decisions are guided not by expedience, but by enduring principles of equity, stewardship, and service. In this vision, public servants are empowered to act with clarity and courage, supported by structures that honor truth over trend. Technical guidance flows freely, communities of practice thrive, and the work of governance becomes a sacred trust—not a partisan tool. I believe that when we anchor our institutions in wisdom and accountability, we create space for justice to flourish and for every policy to reflect the dignity of those it serves.

A large problem is the manual redundant processes for state mandated reporting. State entities must report quarterly and/or annually to oversight entities. Many of these reports are manual excel spreadsheets or PDF documents that incorporate/reiterate information already available to the oversight entity, putting an undue burden on the workforce to reproduce . Processes could easily be streamlined with a shared platform for reporting and monitoring. Workflows could be automatically initiated at a set frequency to ensure timely updates are provided by the entity in accordance with requirements. Data could be prepopulated for ease of completion.

Too many managers. I don't understand why we need 4 levels of managers under the Executive Officer. With all of this management everyone is always blaming the level above them. If my department questions something new that is being implemented or we don't agree with it, our direct supervisor blames the person above them and so on and so forth. It's really discouraging and a waste of resources to have that many managers.
Just make sure state workers pick up the phone and treat public like they are our neighbors.
I will say more job opportunities, less furlough and PLP.

I focus on doing what is right for the business making sure the call center is always available with no service impact, so staff can deliver great customer service while staying within budget. By streamlining telecom inventory and validating hotlines, I help ensure reliable, cost-effective operations that support both employees and Californians.

Ironically, I was distracted when I was responding to this comment yesterday (while working in-office) and lost my response.  Just as ironically, several of my comments are exactly what has already been shared by other participants.  And I think that says something about issues that cross all departments and definitely should be considered priorities: -streamline procedures/processes and remove redundancies or low/no value steps - flatten the organization; excess overhead is a waste of taxpayer dollars; staff are hired for their stills and experience so let them do their jobs - allow staff with technical skills to offer and implement more technical solutions even if for the short-term; while there may be future plans to develop an enterprise solution, those longer-term solutions can take years and short-term solutions earn their one-time cost in reducing man-hours in the meantime - normalize/standardize process/procedure documents particularly if you have several units that work with similar procedures (or rules, regulations, best practices, and so on) - cross train, cross train, cross train - establish a statewide directory of contacts listing special skills of each individual (if approved by the contact and the contact's supervisor) as a support mechanism for those needing help/guidance in that skill - ensure new employees receive full circle training; provide them with the appropriate internal resource so they aren't compelled to look for support from other agencies/staff

Communication between departments is lacking and there is often a silo effect. Meaning each department operates in an isolated fashion and lacks cross-departmental interaction. This often leads to inefficiencies, errors, duplicate efforts, a struggle to resolve issues, and failure to learn from each other.  It would be wise to implement more cross-functional teams to interact and collaborate on projects. Our leadership teams can model collaborative behavior and encourage cross-communication. Also ensuring that we are sharing information whenever possible, so that all teams are aware and included in decisions.

Yess!!! Upper management and executive staff keeps growing but the people who do the work doesn't. If they are going to promote and create more projects, there needs to be more staff to go along with it.

Purchasing is way too complicated. most purchases have an added staff processing (staff processing) cost that is expensive to tax payer and overall uses time that could be doing something more productive.

Around 12 years ago I convinced my managers that we need to cross train all the pharmacy technicians to enter physician's orders, and not just the select few that were always being used.  We went from having four technicians that enter to now having over 14 that enter orders, and our productivity has improved greatly from this.   We now utilize each employee to a higher efficiency, and sick calls are more easily managed.

I have worked in my current role with the state of California for 5 years and have directly contributed to improvement in our workflow as well as efficiency. By utilizing digital tools such as Adobe i was able to significantly shorten the time it takes to review applications in our board.  As a lifelong California resident i take pride in my customer service interactions and have consistently received exceptional feedback from our voluntary surveys offered to each applicant.

The amount of taxpayer money spent on state office space is staggering, especially considering most work can now be completed remotely. Even without considering working conditions or what's best for the state employee (although I think telework supports those, too), utilizing telework dramatically reduces overhead costs with no negative impact to work product. Many departments reported improved efficiency during the pandemic with 100% (or near 100%) telework. Telework also improves recruiting, as departments aren't limited to candidates local to Sacramento and can effectively and efficiently hire from across the state. With finances growing tighter and tighter every year, telework is an easy way to address budget shortfalls in a way that unions and employees will also support (as opposed to layoffs and furloughs). I could talk about management inefficiencies, obtuse procedures, and other issues all day long, but this inefficient use of taxpayer dollars is the problem which has the most obvious and straightforward solution that will have the most significant immediate impact.

I think being able to cut the middle man has been useful. There have been times where I have mentioned to leadership if having that many signatures is really necessary when it comes to the Chief/Warden and gets vetoed a lot anyways. Being able to go directly to the source has been beneficial when leadership is open to direct communication.
Even 30% seems to high...

I have implemented a scanning process to make the board more efficient, going green which also saves money, and online process to help stream line. Make simple and to the point desk procedures in order for anyone to understand even for those that know nothing of a process or program.

Telework is highly effective for retaining state employees, saving taxpayer money (as demonstrated in the August 2025 California State Auditor report), and reducing carbon emissions—a priority consistently emphasized in state climate policies. The State of California recognized these advantages when it touted telework's benefits during the pandemic and confirmed no loss in productivity during that period. Given these facts, it should be made more widely available and implemented whenever possible for all state employees.
RACI and DACI is something I was introduced to and I don't know how we live without it in other departments. It could cut down on so much duplicate efforts statewide.

From my perspective as a Californian and state employee, I believe we can strengthen government services by: Expanding digital tools so routine transactions (like licensing, claims, or payments) can be handled online without delays. Building a culture of accountability and care inside state service when employees feel supported and trusted, they can serve the public more effectively. Additional Idea – Psychological Safety One area that could make a major difference is strengthening psychological safety in the workplace. From my own challenges, I have seen how difficult it is when employees don’t feel safe speaking up about concerns. On the other hand, when supervisors and leaders model openness and there is a strong support system in place, employees feel empowered to raise issues early, collaborate more effectively, and focus on delivering excellent service. Investing in training and systems that reinforce psychological safety would not only protect employee well-being but also improve performance and service to Californians.

Cost of Living in our state. There is a real gap between wages and/or benefits and housing / utility prices. Young adults just entering the workforce, low wage earners, people who cannot work due to disability and older adults leaving the workforce simply cannot afford a basic standard of living.  We need to pay better for typical "blue collar" jobs, put money into paid apprenticeship/internship positions and target high school students not on the college path for those positions early, and last, put less money into politicking/campaigns and more into more subsidized housing. Set limits on the monopolization of companies that buy up properties and airbnb/vrbo type companies only to have properties sitting empty for long periods of time. Incentivize commercial real estate holders that have empty buildings to convert to shelter/housing units.
Fi$CAL...is my primary problem!  It's just so hard to teach our purchasers to use!

It would be beneficial to provide a lower capital gain rate, which would help attract and retain start-ups rather than providing them with an incentive when the start up is successful and they are ready to proceed with IPOs.
I'm finding that the leadership within my organization hires management that does not know the agency, its goals, and processes. We, as staff, have to train our managers.

Our goal as State employees should be the most effective use of tax payer dollars - also a perspective as a California resident. The allocated funds for a cause should be primarily used for that cause (e.g. building affordable housing) and not for mountains of bureaucracy oversight.

Additionally, anyone involved in hiring needs to be trained to avoid discrimination practices and to ensure inclusive hiring practices. Without such measures in place agencies open themselves up to legal and reputational risk which decrease productivity and efficiency.

I’ve worked on improving efficiency by encouraging better communication and coordination within our team. For instance, I set up regular check-ins to make sure we were aligned on priorities and deadlines. This helped us catch issues early, and complete projects on time with fewer last-minute changes.

I have seen many issues such as management not having good leadership skills, or knowledge of the duties their employees should be doing, along with bad organization and communication. All managers should be trained and efficient and regularly evaluated on this matters as it can really have a negative affect on staff.
No, I'm just excited to be a part of this community.

If you suspect that a person is not in need of certain benefits or abusing state funds or benefits, there should be some hotline that Californians can call. It should be publicized everywhere. I tried to report certain abuses like the abuse of medical and EBT and was ignored when I knew the person should not have been entitled to such benefits.

The state does not provide sufficient/adequate service to rural areas, forcing people to drive HOURS to get help with problems. Many regions/residents do not have reliable Internet access so people can't get help online.   Also, the state needs to increase the Unemployment Insurance tax rate, or wage cap, we are one of only three states that hasn't raised it since 1983.

Allowing staff to do more things on their own, without need for technical support. If there is a simple, but common task that someone could be taught and allowed to do, it saves everybody time by allowing that person to take care of it themselves. There is a compromise between security and convenience with the tradeoff being that individuals can now solve their own problems quickly without needing to wait for somebody else. Simple example is password resets. Many public products offer self-service password resets where is emails you. There are a lot of systems that don't allow that and require reaching out to a helpdesk instead, possible waiting hours for someone to manually reset it.

Open communication with your employees. Roundtables to discuss expectations (that they have of you as a supervisor or that you have of them as a subordinate).  Uniform training so that everyone gets the same information, open sharing of information that applies to the job.

California has many managers within the state government. However, there are few leaders amongst the managers from my viewpoint. And the staff of these managers have no voice. This causes both the management and teams members to stagnate and lose sight of serving the public; eventually many work environments become stressful and toxic.    My idea is to one: give the voice to the team members as this forum does, but allow them to rate their managers or supervisors yearly. Two: measure the amount of turnover on a yearly basis under the tenure of a manager or supervisor. Managers, could be put on yearly training assignments where they can serve in different state organizations. Based on the metrics after 2 or 3 years use the metrics to determine if a manager is effective. If a manager doesn't prove to be effective after this tenure they should be released, re-assigned or demoted. If they are measured to be effective, can they can then be assigned to a permanent position but can be re-evaluated after another 3 years.  This is the basis of my idea. Currently, when a person occupies a managerial seat, there is very little to prevent them from becoming a bottle-neck to progress and there's nothing the team can do about this. I've seen millions of tax payers dollars go to waste because of this scenario. I have seen many managers who are micro-manage out of fear and ignorance and the staff is at their mercy which is a moral killer.  There is no perfect system but we need new direction

As a Californian, one of the biggest problems I see is the inefficiency in how government work is structured. Too much emphasis is placed on rigid rules about where employees sit, how many minutes their breaks are, and other political battles, instead of focusing on improving programs and actually saving money. For example, cutting back on telework only forces more cars onto the road, increases congestion, adds to air pollution, and wastes time and money on commuting and parking. It lowers employee satisfaction and productivity. A better solution is to invest in flexible, results-oriented work structures. Telework should be preserved and expanded where possible, with clear performance metrics and accountability built around outcomes rather than physical presence. This reduces costs tied to office space and commuting while allowing employees to devote more energy to meaningful work that directly benefits Californians.

I believe sometimes there's too much gatekeeping even within a department. I understand that sometimes things need to be on a need to know basis, but if my team creates a form that can be useful for other teams, why not just share it? I've found so many times that asking other units to provide information or resources that even within the same division they are so reluctant to do so. I also understand that different departments have different duties and have to keep track of their own programs, but whenever I've worked with other departments on projects it always feels like we're working independently and in competition with each other, not as if we are one: the state of California with one goal. What I do to combat this is I share as much as I can without getting in trouble, but also within my department, if my team creates forms or processes that can be useful to other units, I share it with other fellow units so that they can use it too.
Quality of work performance.  Hold employees accountable for quality of work and quantity of work.

I'm responsible for establishing and maintaining departmental policies and procedures, which provides numerous positive benefits not only to the department, but also for staff. Up-to-date policies and procedures improve efficiency, enhance compliance, and provide a more consistent work environment. Most importantly, they act as a foundation that guides daily operations, reduces risk, and supports long-term growth by ensuring everyone is aligned and accountable.

Almost everyone I work with agree that while teleworking, we all performed better and had a more dedicated, happier and healthier staff.   Now with RTO morale is in the toilet, job satisfaction and dedication is almost non existent.   Those that are required to be in the office do so because they HAVE to and are not willing to work ANY time that is beyond their quitting time, whereas while teleworking, most of us are encouraged to work longer hours till the job is done because we are thankful that we get to work from home.   Better working conditions = happier, more dedicated workforce.

Adults with no insurance may not have access to all vaccines they are eligible to receive. Some ideas to bridge the gap include a proposal to subsidize vaccines and make them accessible to all, at no cost, regardless of insurance status so long as the person has lived in California for at least 12 months.

There are too many regulations, rules, and statutory requirements that state employees have to keep track of to be in compliance within their respective areas. It is impossible to keep track of all the changes - a smart portal where an employee could submit their need, and receive a list of all the measures that need to be met would be helpful.
We are having issues with staffing firefighting crews in CA; we should explore exclusive use fire crews as we do with Firefighting helicopters.

We print thousands of pages of digital documents to put them in a box and send them to a contractor who we pay to scan the physical printouts and give us back an external drive of the scans so that we can then load the files into a digital database. It's absurdly wasteful.

It's time to move forward...one of the things I have seen again and again in my previous office over the years was receiving bids to digitize files.  Every year my office would get multiple bids, however they would never actually accept the bid and move forward.  Here we are years later (in 2025) and there is still a huge file room (which costs the state money in space and supplies) and none of the files have been converted digitally.  This is a waste of employees time and state funds and resources.  And for what?  To appear as though we're doing more work?  This just takes away from the ongoing deliverables and projects that are much more crucial than the entertaining the fantasy of desiring to actually move into the digital age with most of the rest of the world.
I would like to see less taxation on those with lower income and more affordable housing that does not exceed 30% of net income.

The homeless population has gotten out of control in most major cities, here in California especially. We also have closed down several prisons' trough out the state. It would be possible to reopen those institutions as a place for the homeless to sleep with running water and toilet facilities. the recreation yard could be used as a farm for growing crops and there is other building the state could use for schooling, drug rehab groups, church outreach. Social workers could have sessions and classes to help. This could be on a volunteer basis and prioritize homeless veterans.
Here! Here!  Teamwork efforts and conviction over superiority mentality from leadership is a game changer.

A colleague created an onboarding curriculum for new staff that come to our team. The entire curriculum suite is expected to take about 6 months to go through and is self-paced. We also assign two peer mentors.

I think hiring and transfers of incumbent staff and managers should be overseen by upper level of human resources to prevent knowledge stagnation. Our agency have hired and promoted within the same office for 2 decades and our policy and practice is stale and not sure if  it is even HR-policy compliant or cost effective. Our internal management has stated that they 'are the law' , not even complying to the RTO guidelines or accounting for  absent management time .

I have provided help in obtaining information on how to register and correct sensitive information required after a major event. I often share my own work and outside life experiences as applicable to illustrate how the public may benefit from different courses of action or how system users may in turn better help the public.

Legacy and proprietary software systems used within the State create layers of inefficiency and encourage patching of broken systems rather than identification of better alternatives. The State becomes trapped by sunk costs as it is hard to tabulate the real value of employees and stakeholders time that is lost to using inefficient systems.

Micromanaging has to be the biggest problem. My department has supervisors that got promoted more of who they know over knowledge. These type of people constantly are in people business because they don't understand what is going on. If we train our staff correctly they should be able to do their jobs without constant supervision. As a veteran, this is how it was done in the service. Train your staff fully, communicate what needs to be done, then let them do it. These steps are missed in my department as people don't know the job themselves so they cant train the staff nor can they trust that they get the job done without a boss over their shoulder.

We need to reduce hurdles to efficiency.  I have staff that work overnight and the lighting in the building is broken.  I can either go through facilities and get bids and have multiple companies deny working with me because they didn't get paid the last few times by the state, or I can work through the DGS process (getting two levels of approval as well) to buy a new lamp through small vendors that meet criteria and spend a fortune on a lamp.  Both of these options take a ton of time to process, which reduces my efficiency as a supervisor when I could run to home depot and buy a new bulb or even a new lamp in 15 minutes and save tax dollars money both in my salary and the hardware's cost.

I streamline communication and ensure that my customers can reach me by different channels (phone, email, chat) and I respond within 24-hours, unless I am on vacation, which is not often.  If I am out, I follow-up as soon as I return.

All of California's departments should be sharing training resources for efficiency, consistency, and to save money. Rather than each department purchasing their own training resources contracts, there is one contract that provides them for every department. The more licenses there are being purchased, the higher the discounts are.

A primary problem I would address is the gap in support for Californians who work hard but earn just above the eligibility limits for food or housing assistance. Many working families face food insecurity or risk of homelessness because their income technically disqualifies them from aid, yet their wages are not enough to meet California’s high cost of living. To solve this, I would propose expanding tiered or “bridge” programs that provide partial assistance on a sliding scale rather than an all-or-nothing cutoff. For example, a working family over the income limit for SNAP could still receive reduced benefits to help offset grocery costs, while rental support could offer temporary subsidies based on local housing markets. Additionally, strengthening public-private partnerships with nonprofits, food banks, and community organizations would stretch resources further. By reimagining assistance as a continuum of support, rather than a strict threshold, we can help stabilize California’s working community and reduce the cycle of crisis many families face despite being employed.
Preach it, sibling!

Particularly "all staff" meetings, anything that can be shared via email or pre-recorded video, should be distributed that way. Meetings should be reserved for collaboration and input gathering. Efficiency saves time and money.

Streamlining and applying an all-digital timekeeping and payroll process, removing paper from the equation. Currently, hand transcription of attendance and payroll wastes many hours of state employee time across departments.

A primary problem I would address is understaffing. At the district where I work, we have been chronically understaffed for as long as I've worked here and long before I started. Presently, we are short two supervisory managers that are needed to help direct key program areas and many full time positions in our district remain unfilled. At the same time, we are told that we need to provide the same, if not higher level of service to the public. This leads to existing staff being worn beyond thin working multiple jobs and duty statements that do not accurately reflect their workload. The situation just feels like a crash happening in slow motion with me as a rank-and-file watching it happen with little that I can do about it.  If I had a magic wand that could easily change things, I would focus on ramping up hiring and retention. I understand there are budgetary considerations, but it is not possible to recruit and retain long term employees if our district does not have any growth opportunities for seasonal staffing. An overreliance on seasonal employees seems to be the crutch that my department relies on, forcing interested seasonals to endure years of attrition and competition before landing a permanent position.  By retaining more long term employees, they will have a better chance of learning how state systems work and managing them efficiently and effectively. Longer term, this will be more sustainable than relying/spending on technology centered "efficiency" campaigns.

We lack uniformity in knowledge and training. We need more of the philosophy of "when you learn, teach". Open communication, current and updated training, updates to critical work equipment are essential.

From my perspective, continuing to support and expand telework for eligible state employees would be a great step forward. Not every job can be done remotely, but for those that can, telework has proven to boost productivity, ease traffic, and lower emissions. It’s also a change that benefits everyone in California, not just state workers.
These are all great ideas!

I think it makes sense to have clear regulations that are not so subjective. Any choice to build something or not, to pursue a project or not, has tradeoffs. It feels like we over emphasize the potential for doing something to have an adverse impact but we deemphasize the potential for not doing something to have an adverse impact. I'd rather we set a clear rulebook for how to build things, pursue and provide the data necessary as a State to make that rulebook clear and easy to understand, and then frequently assess how the rules have been effective or not at achieving the outcomes set by decisionmakers/policymakers.  Subjectivity also leaves room for unjust application of the law but it admittedly does help tackle complex issues that sometimes just need a good judgement call.
I strongly believe in remote work and think that we are all happier and healthier for telework, while saving a lot of money for the state!

With 23 years working for the state I have noticed state workers do not have passion for what they do. Those who run state departments just do it for the money and power but not for love or passion for what they do. I was told to promote to make the change happen but the I realized that no matter how many time I promote there is always someone on top who works “by the book” not looking outside the box to see what is best for the the public and the employees.

The public needs to know we are doing are a good job through our front-end service workers. Certain departments have improved their customer service times exponentially because it was their direct focus.

I proposed an ideal to my franchise tax board department to address the issue of Spam. The situation is when a taxpayer calls in and asks for a call back 90% of the customers do not answer their phone. Because franchise tax board callback shows up as Spam on the everyday taxpayer's phone. They are not going to answer it. So when they call back again and hold for 2 to 3 hours, they are angry, upset. And you do not get things done. Except for addressing their anger. I spent four hours on this proposal because I thought it would help all of the state of california and it has gone nowhere.But the anger of the taxpayers wanting to know why leave a message when you do not get any calls back?I think this is nonproductive.And this is causing a serious backlog and more people holding.Because we cannot address this issue of spam.Basically.I believe you would have to go to the fcc and have them.Do something with our telephone to where it does not show as spam.When we place outbound calls, it seems simple.But no one is listening

As a Californian, one issue I notice is the amount of ongoing road work happening at the same time across different areas. While I understand maintenance and improvements are necessary, it often feels uncoordinated and can lead to long delays, wasted resources, and public frustration.

There is a need for more transportation options to schools and workplaces. For working parents, especially those whose children attend schools outside their designated district, lack of transportation creates a significant challenge. Additionally, in many communities, there are limited or no affordable transportation options from home. As a result, valuable time is lost commuting—time that could otherwise be spent more productively at work.

I have streamlined some processes within a department I was a supervisor because there were multiple people who were completing the same job at the same time. I have noticed that throughout my whole time in State service, this is a major problem. I also wanted to make sure that there was transparency in my department between management and staff.

Because the state hires positions, rather than people, there are often almost no opportunities to promote in place. Someone will take an SSA position, become competant enough at their work to do the work of an AGPA, and the only way for them to do that is to go to some other job, often in a different Agency, to become an AGPA. WHen they do so, the original Agency loses all of their investment in that person. It should be MUCH easier and common place to convert a high-performing employee into the next level classification while staying (and expanding) in their current position.
I feel there should be less "red tape" to cut to solve issues.  Permits take time to be ratified because of lawyers and special interest groups
More training and more time allowed to managers to do their work. Allow for appreciation for employees. Employees feel not appreciated

As a California resident, I would like to know my government is working as LEAN and efficiently as possible without wasting my tax dollars. By doing this, such as using updated technology to streamline processes, provide quicker turnaround times, reduce duplicate manual menial tasks, and provide better onboarding and training, California becomes more robust, efficient, and nimble. This also gives the State of California more focus on supporting recipients quickly - and can even place more staff in those areas of need - instead of managing a cumbersome bureaucracy, outdated systems, inefficient technology, poor communication, and delays in getting up to speed with new hires.

When it comes to Non-Industrial Disability Insurance (NDI), why can't excluded state employees file all claim paperwork online like SDI? There is so much room for error to rely on paper mail and CalHR to manage a disability claim for a individual staff.  SO much gets lost in the paper trail and having to chase down emails, attachments and snail mail with vital health information. The current workflow requires claim participants (Patient, Physician, etc.) to MAIL in claim documents, those documents are then processed by hand and an email exchange happens between CalHR and EDD. room for error includes rotating CalHR staff and EDD staff, lost documents in email, PII shared via email, having to resubmit paperwork due to error and extending the time to receive benefits, etc. The EDD claim system in digital for Californians and some State staff. Why not make it digital for ALL Californians and CA State staff? Save time, money, heartache for staff and make it digital!

A glaring example is the fact that the DSH does not have an electronic health record.  In this century, it is inexcusable that a system this size does not have a modern way to document and share medical information.  Yet, this process has been in the hands of SAC for over 10 years, with no progress.

I would really like to see more transparency about why things are done the way they are and making the human element visible. This means explaining that certain things may be done slowly because of understaffing and underfunding, where fully staffed/funded agencies are successful, and when things are done slowly in order to be deliberate and thoughtful in order to be successful long term rather than provide a quick fix. Inversely, when a quick fix is just that, and that there are long term solutions being worked on. To update the mental image of a state worker. The public image is that of a lazy person procrastinating filling out their paperwork, when in reality there may one be a single person who is responsible for processing that paperwork...for the entire state. When I explain this to friends, they're shocked and often way more understanding of public servants after that. I'd like to see more windows into the humanity of these agencies.  I'd like to also see more promotion of these public sector jobs, their importance and what they provide to local communities, etc. We need to move away from thinking about budgets like pie chats and graphs and more like people in buildings, who work all day to improve the public welfare, pushing those numbers (and dollars) towards the most good possible with the current information/resources (hindsight is always 20/20 and we're always looking to improve), and who are regular people, neighbors, and support local communities.

Hiring.  Why is it that I can look at a list of interview candidates, and guess with good accuracy who will be offered the position- before the interviews occur?  Why is the new contractor for equipment maintenance coincidentally the husband of the supervisor?
California is a blessed progressive state.

There is an old saying that bureaucracy provides stability--it certainly can be bloated but I think it's a good thing and typically keeps things rolling when new administrations come on board and start making broad, sweeping changes....oh, wait?

More automation across state agencies. Many manual processes still cause delays for residents who often wait days or weeks for information that could be delivered instantly with the right technology.  One approach could be requiring agencies to identify and automate high-volume manual processes. Additionally, California could incentivize in-state technology companies through tax breaks or partnerships to help streamline government operations. This would not only improve customer service but also strengthen collaboration with California’s tech sector.  Ultimately, real measurable improvements for residents come down to funding and resources. With proper investment and clear accountability, the State can modernize services and better meet the expectations of Californians.
One of the problems that I see as a state employee is team building. I feel that team building should happen more often than it has in my department and this will lead in trusting our team together.

yes  have an old vehicle that's designated to scrap or crush for office work, lawn work, dump runs etc. field office supports the maintenance department guy on getting a p-card to buy maintenance stuff .and or supplies

We need make the state contracting process more efficient. It takes forever for contracts to get approved, slowing down our ability to improve our systems and respond to changes in the public domain/markets.  We need to reduce the review time by removing unnecessary bureaucratic red tape and setting stricter deadlines by when we can expect to hear back on our RFPs.

It's so hard for young people to get ahead without the support of their family - which not everyone has. Smaller class sizes, financial literacy incorporated into our curriculum, affordable housing for older teens and young adults, and job training programs would be an amazing investment in allowing young people to escape from poverty.

I applied for my job early last year and when I was contacted about setting up an interview several months later, I had forgotten I had ever applied for it!  I also find it extremely hard just to find other positions within CalHR that I might want to apply to or get updates on.

I have found the State's technology is severely lacking in many areas. Simple things like completing timecards, requesting leave and determining how many hours of leave you have accrued require the employee to access three different databases, and even these databases do not reflect real-time, useful information. I have worked as a County employee in CA, and even the County had real time leave data that could be accessed easily by the employee. In my current employment, I have to track my time, by five minute increments, in one database, I have to add this information to my Outlook calendar, and I have to note it on my timecard. I am hoping there is way all of these databases can be integrated so that we are not spending so much time across multiple platforms to track our time working for the State. I also feel that during the mapping process with the Organizational Improvement Office, OIO, best practices should be shared with all department employees as they are working through their mapping and not at the very end once they have mapped all of the processes for the entire division. This would allow for immediate changes and streamlining to occur, instead of waiting for two years or more for the mapping to be completed before the results are released to the department. Change and innovate as we go, share the knowledge and best practices as soon as it is identified so employees can save valuable time and State money.

I would like to address recruitment and retention issues from within the public sector. Lately, public sector workers have been losing important benefits that are used to attract high quality talent and leadership. Using tools like work from home flexibility and remote work will allow state units to attract top talent from sectors that are reverting back to RTO mandates.

Over the past 2.5 years, I have been working with a multi-disciplinary team to create a centralized platform that will allow our department's geographically dispersed staff submit information about events happening in their parks. It has been a slow-going design project, but we're hopeful that the centralized information submission process for staff will result in a one-stop website that will allow Park visitors to easily find events and activities happening in parks near them or in areas they plan to visit. We have not gotten to the "more effective and efficient" part yet, but we're playing the long game to get there.

I appreciate my manger on a regular basis likes to ask us question such how we can improve our processes or working materials. Asking for input and feedback on a habitual basis is a great thing because it allows us the ability to pivot and/or incorporate recent lessons learned in our internal business processes or materials. We also have templates and workflows that mitigate our opportunity costs. I also appreciate not being micro-managed. Respecting our integrity, expertise, and competence to get things timely is very important.

I know we're not supposed to make suggestions about HR or pay matters, but honestly, it is *really* hard to survive in California on a civil servant's pay. I am a single person and I live in a coastal community where my salary from the state is considered "low income," so I can qualify for certain services designated for low income individuals. I love the work I do for the state, but I don't feel like my talent and expertise is valued, so I question how long I can really continue working for the state. A lot of non-profits pay higher for my line of work.

State owned and leased properties that have publicly accessible parking lots should have solar panels and EV chargers installed for use by the public. We need to meet the needs of expanding EV users, in addition to meeting our state greenhouse gas reduction goals.

Our research office operates using agile project management principles. Employees are empowered to present innovative research projects, and the manager's job is to a) ensure projects are in alignment with the CO mission and then b) clear obstacles and make connections to enable project completion. It makes the job exciting, the results impactful, and the whole experience fulfilling

I would like CDCR to look for management skills and abilities when hiring or promoting people to management positions. It seems the state tends to promote people into management roles who may be good workers or supervisors but lack management skills or training. A lot of the errors and roadblocks encountered by my peers and myself could be attributed to poor project planning or management principles. One glaring problem I routinely see is the lack, or even refusal, to have stakeholders involved with project planning. (Just a hint, stakeholders are almost never management employees.)  I think looking down for answers, properly identifying stakeholders in projects, and management staff learning how to manage would greatly help California.

The Department of Industrial Relations has a Unit called CFOI (Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries) for California. It is a deep dive into occupational deaths going back many years.    Our title says Engineer, but we don't do any of that with this data.  An Engineer would evaluate the data of many years of deaths and attempt to do the greatest good for the greatest number of people who are dying.  We don't do much of that.  Take a look at our annual plans - they are mostly activity based (we will do x inspections, turn them in in y time, etc.), and other political activity such as that.   Engineering is not that.

The primary problem is that we cannot combat the public perception of being a bureaucracy when we only pay lip service to transparency. It's one thing to have information posted to a web site, but it's a data dump unless it's descriptive and explanatory to everyone accessing it. For one example, if there is a process that may take 60 to 90 days, such as obtaining a license or certification, have it clearly explained why there is a range of expected time. If people understand the process better, they become less frustrated with it. They may not like it, or agree with the decision, but at least they know that it was a deliberate decision made by actual people and not arbitrary or rubber-stamped.

I feel the same way about my own experience as a new(ish) employee. Finding our resources on our own isn't the easiest, but it is expected. I believe a more comprehensive directory is needed, as well.

Each work location I've been in, I find old policies or procedures that need to be updated. There have been a lot of forms and records that I've been able to automate locally. There are jobs now that used to take an entire shift to do, now we get it done in seconds.

There should be an agency liaison for every state agency and every board, bureau, or commission within that agency, who can be relied on to facilitate information or communication between agencies. Our office has overlapping responsibilities with other agencies, but we often hit a wall trying to find the appropriate person to assist with an issue. It's a nightmare.

Sharing information and knowledge across departments. Everything is a part of the state, its one central embodiment, but everything is so segregated in a way that hinders our ability to serve the publics interest on a meaningful level and reasonable timeline. The biggest idea I would have is to allow ECOS and PIMS access across entities in a "view only" capacity for HR departments. Why can I not do employment A01 verifications myself here for someone in another department? Why can I not see applications provided from a candidate in ECOS to another department? Perhaps they had attached transcripts there that could save 10 days to get here.                Another issue I'd like to address is the use of different documents across state entities. Many processes, policies and procedures begin with guidance from CalHR and the State Personnel Board (SPB) but each department then adapts that guidance using its own forms or supporting docs. This results in inconsistencies across departments. Establishing a standardized process that starts with CalHR and SPB guidance and carries forward uniformly would promote consistency, fairness, and equity across CA.

I have created employee instructions manuals for roles I have been in, to pass down to those who would come into the role. I have tried to create legacy pieces such as these to ensure, where there is a lack of training or the training is not pragmatic and effective, that instructions are clear, readable, and useful across the board.
I agree completely! It's a huge waste of (hu)man power to fill out these redundant forms because it's "easier" to just create new ones than improve on an existing system.

Poor staff/employee performance, excessive departmental fraud, and excessive waste of state/government funds! We currently have two - three departments/entities who handle the same duties and responsibilities, while some even work from home, where some of these departments require a physical presence in order to complete their actual job duties or patient care!
Can we change the EAR form back to how it was. When you could write the #4 and HR would do the rest. So simple. Missed dearly.

I think that the state would be well served to do a statewide desk audit, to ensure that classifications are appropriate for the work being done. There are MANY positions out there that have been "upgraded" for what I like to call "social promotions". People are promoted instead of Positions based on the work being done and technical skills required to support the mission of the department. Once a position is upgraded, it is very difficult to get it downgraded again when the person moves on, because there is a general perception that more money = better staff. This is not the case. I have seen staff in very handsomely paid positions doing the work of an AGPA. It is also devastating from a succession planning standpoint, because everything becomes so high level that there are no entry level positions to feed the higher-level vacancies. As a result, all new hires are new to the department, and no institutional knowledge is maintained as the more senior folks leave for even further promotions.  Not to mention that the more positions are upgraded inappropriately, the more expensive it is to support. This cuts into programmatic funding meant for carrying out the mission of the department. Unfortunately, this is not a for profit enterprise. We don't have the authority to give financial incentives for loyalty and hard work.

Agree that Exec Leaders should be encouraged to work with other leaders. This is a problem in my office. Our Exec Leaders (previous and current) seem incapable of creating partnerships or relationships with leaders above them, let alone other offices and agencies that are relevant to our work. They cannot get information or help that we need. It has absolutely impeded some of our work.

During Covid times, we have proven that institutions can telework and get the work done.  If allowed to telework a few days a week, that would allow us to work more efficiently without interruptions from walk ins.  HQ staff has also proven this to work so unsure why institution staff are not allowed to follow use for certain positions.  If we were classified in same position as HQ staff, the recruitment and retention of those positions at the institutions would be better.

We tend to lose the most skilled workers becasue the state offers very low wages. When the state tries to to push for a lower quality of life for state workers, such as RTO, we lose even more good workers. This seems like a very bad strategy because we end up losing our best people and often struggle to fill the positions. The state as a whole, including the citizens, all lose when this happens. If we want the best workers putting in their best efforts, we need to make them feel apprectiated and valued. The "pizza party" to make up for low wages is not a good strategy.
And to add insult to injury, CalPIA seems to be constantly "expanding" their footprint, not by developing new internal competencies, but by leasing out inmates to other companies.

The modus operandi at the state is "quick fixes" and treating the symptoms of problems rather than getting at the root cause. So, we end up with broken systems covered in Band-Aids rather than systems that work.  We need to really look closely at what is happening and make changes- slow down to speed up. First fixing our support systems and then our mission systems. Usually, you would want to spend all your time and effort on the mission, but you cannot make the mission process (why the department exists) better if the process to make the mission process better is siloed and broken. For example- if it takes 2 years to fix a typo on an external form, how do you expect to do any larger improvements for the customer experience or streamline the process for internal stakeholders? This is the reality of my current job with the State.
