I led the effort to make our organizations IT systems, devices and data much more secure and cost effective.  I implemented an IT enterprise architecture which guides work priorities, spending and services provided.  We implemented mobile computing (laptops, WiFi, VPN, cloud services, firewalls, policies, etc.) that allow employees to me more flexible, efficient and secure.

I have made desk references and how to guides for all of the positions, including mine, under my supervision. This way if I am not available or they have a question, they can reference back for training. Our oncoming clerical had no training programs and I was part of a committee that has now produced an online clerical training. This program must be completed by all clerical within 90 days. This training teaches and tests the new employees their roles and responsibilities. It is also available anytime to re-do, if they want a refresher.

I’d like to see more accessible, easy-to-understand reporting on how taxpayer dollars are being spent, especially at the local and state levels. Tools like interactive dashboards or annual summaries could help residents feel more informed and engaged.  Given the high cost of living in many parts of California, I think it’s important that tax policies and public programs take into account regional differences. For example, expanding tax credits or subsidies for housing, childcare, and transportation could make a big difference for working families.  I’d love to see more opportunities for residents to provide input on budget priorities, perhaps through participatory budgeting or community forums. It would help ensure that policies reflect the diverse needs of Californians.

The biggest hurdle is the length of time it takes to implement plans and/or strategies for change and the lack of consultation or corroboration with the staff who actually perform such duties are not included before the policies or plans are implemented.

Ability to post jobs with multiple locations and allow folks to have headquarters from multiple sites has dramatically increased quality of talent pool. Strongly support this approach wherever feasible.

A primary problem I would like to address is the severe lack of communication. There are a number of reasons why there is a lack of communication, such as superiority complexes within management teams, lack of guidance from management teams, fear of retaliation, lack of adequate training, and so on. Because of this lack of communication, it is often hard to collaborate with one another, thus leading to frustration and complicated work processes. Also, it is greatly discouraging and prompts employees to put in minimum effort rather than their best effort. Communication is key in many aspects of life, especially work. If communication were more present in the workplace, employees would feel less stressed and more rewarded for the work that they do for the state of California.

Agreed. There is a lack of leadership. And leadership should come from a place of servitude not from a manipulative, micro-managing, or bullying mindset.   There's no perfect system, systems are not meant to be perfect they are meant to be progressive.

Problem: Allowing managers to interview candidates only creates favoritism in hiring, favoring those they want in a position and excluding other candidates.  This has been going on for years and it needs to stop immediately.  Solution: Have an independent panel interview candidates to exclude favoritism. Since the independent panel do not know the candidates and can focus on hiring qualify candidates only.

There is bias for external stakeholders. It seems certain entities/external stakeholders are given preference and better treatment. We need to level the playing field. We have oversight entities that constantly call out bad actors and yet, our departments continue to fund them because leadership chooses to. This is inappropriate and undermines the work of state employees who do oversight and hold those accountable.

The procurement process is complex and difficult for contractors, business owners, and employees to understand.  A review of the procurement process is needed to remove unnecessary forms, protocols, and monetary spending limits that have not changed with inflation.  These issues have had the indirect result of hindering necessary purchases for needed services and repairs that keep our facilities open and operational.  It has also resulted in the loss of business opportunity for many business owners and local communities that rely on government contracts.

Additionally, the people at CalHR are often not educated on the job being hired for. I heard a story once of a person with a masters degree in anthropology being told they didn't meet the minimum qualifications for the archaeologist exams because the person at CalHR didn't realize archaeology and anthropology are essentially the same degree. I have sat at event tables to recruit for my department and it's always awful hearing so many people who sound incredibly qualified saying they didn't get a position because an exam wasn't offered on time, or they didn't understand list eligibly, or (one time) that they passed the exam but their score got posted to a different CalCareers account. There is no reason for it to be this hard.

If there's one comment to take to heart from all this, I hope the higher ups see this one. It's a simple change that we've already implemented that saves taxpayer money, protects the environment, attracts talent, and modernizes CA government. Undoing this step forward for CA State Workers is regressive, myopic and illogical.
I think the performance review form Std 638 could be simplified and used as a coaching tool.

To improve efficiency and accountability, state government should pair top-down evaluations with structured bottom-up feedback. Currently, employees are reviewed by supervisors, but managers rarely receive input from the staff and programs they oversee. This creates a blind spot: how can managers become better leaders, improve efficiency, and address challenges if they never hear from the people most affected by their decisions?  Once someone becomes a manager, the department’s instinct is often to protect them from criticism. While meant to support leadership, this practice can unintentionally foster waste, fraud, abuse, and inefficiencies. Without meaningful feedback, even well-intentioned managers may not know what needs to change.  A balanced system would introduce safe, constructive ways for staff to share input—such as anonymous surveys or 360-degree reviews—while preserving fairness and professionalism. The goal is not blame, but growth: identifying strengths, addressing weaknesses, and building stronger teams. This feedback loop would improve trust, strengthen programs, and ensure managers are as accountable as the staff they supervise.
Information about the services and benefits reach only a portion off the State's demographics, including job openings and service application process.
Perform an audit on empty ofc space.  Consolidate/ combine complementary depts.

Embrace new ideas and be willing to try new things in for the sake of streamlining processes. sometimes what has always been done is no longer the most efficient way to do things. My manager gives me the freedom to try new ideas to help our team be more efficient, if it works out, we adopt it, if it doesn't it's not a big deal. also having management that is supportive in helping the people they manage achieve their career goals and get to where they want to be.

The problem with my Agency is that they don't allow subordinates to make suggestions or come up with ideas. I have stopped giving my opinion or ideas because they're always shutdown. With previous management ideas and comments were always welcome. Help streamline the process by going paperless on the document intake, but not anymore.

I’d push for performance-based funding, where agencies must show measurable process improvements and return on investment before receiving additional resources. This ensures upgrades are strategic, data-driven, and truly benefit the public. A major issue is the excessive number of oversight agencies, which creates duplication, delays, and inefficiencies. From a Lean Six Sigma perspective, this is pure waste. I’d advocate for consolidating oversight functions and holding the legislature accountable for funding only those upgrades that show measurable process improvements. Fewer layers, clearer accountability, and smarter investments lead to faster, more effective public service.
Yes, the bureaucracy is excessive and results in things costing more than expected.
Misappropriation of funds and the lack thereof for California Department of Fish and Wildlife and the hiring practices of the department

It would be important to teach employees how to speak truth to power, as it were.  We are often in positions where we are not heard, not consulted, and not valued.  Yet, we are the front line, in the trenches and know what is going on with the work of serving Californians.  Teach us how to speak to closed ears, to gain attention, and be heard will go a long way in state service becoming more effective.  How can we navigate the politics and still keep our shirts (and jobs) would be very useful.   Seems I can hear leadership laughing.  However, if the purpose of service is truly important, then we need to be taken seriously.  Leadership gets what leadership allows.  It may be time to shift what leadership allows.  Ty.  Peace,

The only way to fix homelessness is housing first. Prior to the State, I worked directly w/ homeless people. Many would even out if given a stable place to live. The "bootstraps" mentality doesn't work when there aren't any boots. Also, what's better, people languishing on the streets in front of our tourist attractions, or the streets being clean because people are housed?   FAQ: Why can’t they work? - Many do but don't make enough for rent - Many are disabled & can't work fulltime/at all. SSI is not enough to cover housing. Many are veterans who lost housing. Section 8 list is years long - Many are elderly. Some are formerly “normal” people who lost everything in 2008 before they were going to retire & never recovered - Some have criminal records which hinders hiring - Job market is bad right now  FAQ: Why can't they just go to shelters?  - Shelters break families up bc many are separated by gender, so some families prefer to stay together in their cars or on the street - Curfews. Need to be in by 8 pm and out by 6 am, which is hard for working people - Easy place to get your stuff stolen - Not always accommodating for disabled people  FAQ: Why are they on drugs/alcohol? - Some are actually not, they have MH disorders that can look like usage - Some use uppers to stay awake because of theft, assault, etc - Some just like to use, but we shouldn't not help bc of this. Why do we judge use among poor ppl, but look the other way at silicon valley tech bros using coke & ketamine?

Yes, I definitely see the fear of managers to ask clarifying questions, to those senior to them, much less try to make any significant changes.  They just push it down and we have to guess the what, why, and how of directions from above.

I wish that all departments were on the same instance of Microsoft so that we could more easily share files and collaborate. Maybe we need some more SharePoint architecture training to make sure our systems are set up in a way that makes then functional and not a barrier to working collaboratively.
if the state were a business it would be out of business he waste fraud and abuse is unbeivable from the top down.

As a California resident and employee, we don't make enough money.  We are barely making ends meet and I fear for the future of those coming behind me.  Taxes, gas, and everyday essentials are continuing to rise.    We need something in place where we can get help.  Maybe creating different events for the state employee.  Rideshare programs, picnics, nutrition and wellness.  I know there are services out there but maybe something that is more hands-on.
Regular check-ins with Team, having that regular contact on projects, tasks, etc. to ensure that the work is moving forward.
More fully remote positions to save taxpayer money

Make telework flexible and based on operational needs as determined by first line managers and staff. A one size fits all telework model (RTO 2 or 4 days per week regardless of operational need) is not appropriate for most technical positions that can be done effectively from home, is wasteful of taxpayer dollars, and decreases employee morale, all of which impacts public service. Having a one size fits all telework model is also bad for retaining talent. We need technically proficient staff. If talented staff can telework full time with better work life balance and greater physical and mental health, and be treated with respect in managing their workload in the private sector, why would they opt to work for the state where we are treated like we can't be trusted to manage ourselves or allowed to telework based on operational need?  Who wants to work for an entity that frames the need to be in office as "because teachers and janitors have to report to a job site everyday so should all other state workers". This approach disrespects the life choices that folks have made regarding their career path. A teacher and a janitor are aware that their work involves reporting to an offsite office daily, whereas technical careers or those that do not require direct face to face with the public should be allowed to telework based on the operational needs of their position. Flexible telework fosters trust, is just as effective for collaboration, and more cost effective.

I appreciate that the Governor has been visiting the Central Valley, Inland Empire and North State.  Anything we can do to get out to communities outside of LA and Bay Area and to include their voices in stakeholder work will make our state better as a whole.  When I visit with constituents outside of major urban centers I learn so much and hear new & different perspectives.
We are spending more and more money every single year without fail. The state is extremely inefficient with our tax money. We should be trusted to spend our own money how we see fit.

The state's hiring process is difficult to navigate and may prevent candidates from applying. It also takes too long. Qualified candidates may be hired elsewhere before an agency is allowed to make an offer.

One of the guidelines stated that we should not discuss telework or return to office policies; however, I noticed that others have posted about it already so I would like to add my request as well. As a state worker for more than 25 years I have enjoyed working in person alongside my peers and building relationships with people that have shared the workload struggles, so I am not arguing against the benefits of having in person collaboration. However, through the years my family situation. Currently, my greatest need would be to have an option for those of us that are caring of very ill and elderly family members or that have other family situations that make it difficult to commute into the office to be able to be exempted from the in-office requirement. We have programs like Paid Family Leave that allow for paid time off to take care of family members, but the needs of aging or ill family members do not always impede our ability to meet our workload commitments and do not meet the requirements for PFL or an RA request. Personally, leaving my mom in the care of a stranger so that I can travel 50 miles to go sit in front of a computer is a big mental, emotional, and financial burden that doesn't make sense when the workload doesn't demand it. Please consider it. I know there are many state workers that would greatly benefit from having an option.

I think homelessness is a huge issue. There are many different organizations that work to provide support but no one actually making significant change. We need an overarching solution. People don't become homeless overnight, and they won't get out of it overnight. We need to have a 2-pronged approach. 1st - before someone becomes homeless, we need to have a program that would allow them to access grant funding to catch them up and keep them from becoming homeless. It's far less expensive to catch someone up than to pay for all of the services they will need once they are homeless. 2nd - once someone becomes homeless, we need the ability to get them into mid - term (1-2 year) housing with wrap around services to ensure they can have their physical/mental health needs addressed, get or increase their employment, find childcare if necessary, and save money. During this time, they should also have access to financial literacy education, job training, and if needed, drug treatment programs. Waiting until someone has exhausted all options and is sleeping on the street before "helping them" by providing them 30 days in a motel, is only perpetuating the problem and keeping people in poverty.

Providing a detailed and department wide Contract Manager training. We need something like that statewide. It should be mandatory for anyone managing contracts so that they are aware of what they are expected to do. What the duties are for the contract managers versus the contract analysts.  How Contract managers can set up a budget, track invoices, and develop a scope of work.   This is provided for Contract analysts. There are options through DGS, but the messaging isn't out there to provide the training needed for most Contract Managers to be successful and compliant.

The S90 or Rejection of Probation code needs to be modified so that it reflects two possibilities: an actual rejection and an employee exercising their mandatory right to return to their former agency.  During the time of probation the supervisor/manager is evaluating the employee, but the employee should be doing the same thing and determining whether the agency is a good fit or not for them or not.  The employee should be able to switch without any negative impact if the agency is not a good fit.  At present, the code S90 is seen as negative, but there needs to be a way to distinguish what actually happened. It should be noted that the order and decision are not always in the Official Personnel File (OPF) and are based on the agreement or settlement between the parties involved.
Using technology to streamline repetitive case management tasks.
Clean up our streets.

Please consider the process of awarding a construction contract on state-funded projects. The current process of requesting a lump sum bid and then awarding to the lowest bidder has several problems and ultimately costs the state more money and time in the long run. The contracts team needs to create a database and flag contractors who have defaulted, been previously terminated from a project, or have a track record of poor performance. We have been awarding projects to the lowest bidder without being given an opportunity to determine whether that contractor deserves the right to work on a project. If we can establish a resource to the project managers and contracts team to vet through contractors, we should be able to disqualify a bidder due to poor performance, despite being the lowest bidder. The current process in place is actually costing the state more money and time to handle a poor-performing contractor. In addition, bids are requested as a lump sum. This is problematic for several reasons. Once we award a contract to the lowest bidder, we have no way of knowing if that bid actually includes all the requirements of the contract documents. As the process is currently set up, it is the responsibility of the contractor to ensure their bids cover the scope, however in several cases, the contractor ends up misinterpreting the scope and/or missing essential work. Better communication is key and can set up a project for success in the long run.

It takes an extremely long time to hire new staff. The budget change proposal must be submitted by May of the prior year and the actual hiring won't happen till the next year July. This is an extremely long timeframe and slows down the state's ability to respond quickly to staffing shortages. There must be a way to allocate a position once a need for it is determined.
Lack of career advancement. Worked for state for 3 years so far haven't had any meeting nor advice from mgmt nor HR regarding "take these steps to seek greater career with the state"
Yes, the new initiative to make insulin more affordable in California is great. We need to work towards making healthcare less expensive for people.

We have managers that would prefer to duck suggestions and just keep working the process.  It really doesn't change.  I have Lean Six-Sigma training and it is baffling that we can be deep in backlog with no interest in fixing a process.

There are too many review steps in almost every government process. This usually happens because of errors in the process which lead to management wanting additional review to ensure there are less errors. When errors continue to happen, the review level continues to escalate. This results in leadership thinking their staff are unable to complete the task correctly and frustrating staff on the "moving target" or unclear expectations caused by various style preferences from different reviewers. This leads to requirements for staff to create additional documentation such as summaries, cover memos, and routing packets to navigate the higher management level reviewing the work. It is extra, non-value added work to explain what the work is why they are approving it. I recommend lowering the approval level to the lowest supervisory level who knows the program. This will reduce turn-around time for requests, improve customer satisfaction (since they get whatever service we provide sooner), increased confidence in employees, and better morale for teams. Additional levels of review do not eliminate errors, but instead increase them due to different standards between different levels of reviews. Instead, find out why the errors are happening and fix them at the source. This can be done easily between supervisors and front-line staff.

California does tax it's citizens more than many other states. I am a 3rd generation California Native and I love this state. It has everything anyone could want. But living here is expensive and easing the tax burden by creating better efficiencies within our various government departments could go a long wat in helping to ease the tax burdens.

There should be "affordable" housing downtown that average working people such as state workers can afford.  There are many state employees who would like to live downtown, whether working hybrid, in office or remote.  Businesses could be supported 7 days a week, rather than relying on state worker schedules (Mon-Friday 8am-5pm).

"...one of the biggest problems I’ve noticed is the lack of proper training and clear guidance for staff, especially when it comes to understanding their roles, responsibilities, and how to grow within their careers."  Currently, in our department, new hires have much higher qualifications than many of the mid-managers who won't share the necessary internal memos to perform on the job.  Some new staff leave to another department with disillusionment  about the agency's negative reinforcement methods of  handling complaints that we have lost talent.   I  strongly agree that mentorship programs or cross-division shadowing is a great idea to develop stronger and cohesive work force.
more affordable housing, gas and less taxes. Encouraging WFH for companies to reduce cars on the road and a better work/life balance.
I find that the processes become more important than the outcomes and we may want to focus more on principals/outcomes and guidelines to achieve that versus tasks and processes.

We can increase efficiency and effectiveness in our work by getting out of our silos both within agencies and across agencies. For example, we can be more efficient in our work and at the same time make it easier to be a business in California by streamlining reporting requirements across the environmental agencies. We can help distribute funding and make it easier to get funding by having one funding arm per agency instead of multiple groups. We could also expand our our community support efforts by encouraging remote work and embedding state workers in communities across California instead of concentrating all jobs in a few small areas, like Sacramento.

At my agency, a group of employees with an interest in how to improve the way we process permit records and data has grown as more new hires with training in data analysis and, frankly, a more contemporary perspective on how things can and should be done. What started as a few meetings on how to tackle a specific kind of data need has grown to a larger effort with IT. A culture that encourages people to take on projects that improve the agency's mission and freedom to pursue those projects so long as you're willing to do the work (a "do-ocracy") has fostered innovations. We're just limited by resources and sometimes know-how - it would be even better if there were ways to connect and learn from other departments, share tools, etc.
Reddit has a CA Employees users forum. You can ask questions there.

We have too many state agencies solving the same technical probelm for their individual agency. This is an inefficent use of resources and public funds. If we know that all state agencies need to maintain and submit certain information (i.e., time tracking, STD 200) why don't we create a statewide solution instead of each agency developing a solution?  We need to centeralize technology and systems that are used across the states. Create a central code repository that we can share across state agencies.

Executive Leaders/Managers should be subject to 360-like, anonymous reviews and required to implement changes proposed in those reviews that could result in better processes and procedures. A simple thing like having less meetings (because so many are unnecessary and add to the bureaucracy), or delegating responsibilities more effectively, or identifying and establishing SOPs to resolve gaps. Again, this review should be required. Even well-intended leaders/managers can be blind to their short-comings or lack self-awareness or act defensively when given critical feedback.

I disagree.  What frightens me most about Telecommuting is that people are only thinking about how it benefits them now.  It is the one thing that is harming our environment and community the fastest, and nobody seems to be paying attention. Think about it.  People that telecommute can live anywhere else in the world and buy up property that at one time was very cheap.  The remote places and small, quiet, serene towns that some of us love to drive through and visit, will soon not exist at all.  During Covid, I lost half my friends and family who have moved across the country to buy up property that was once inexpensive due to Telecommuting.  Now I don’t see them. Property is now being bought up in droves, which has brought up prices of homes at an astronomical rate.  At this rate, perhaps in as little as 20 years, all those remote places will be gone and the big cities will be unlived, hazardous and unkept.  You think it helps the environment because people don't drive, you are wrong.  People have time to shop online get things delivered to their homes, they no longer support their community like they once did, and that means no more stores or restaurants, and all of those boxes and packing material, where do you think it goes?  And I know for a fact that Telecommuting means you are not as productive.  When I visit a friend who telecommutes, he watches TV with me and takes care of his kids and dogs, goes shopping, etc. and I wonder what work he really gets done. Its harmful.

I'd like to see all state departments prioritizing/resourcing the organizational development related work that we are tasked with as mission critical.  Far too often, effort such as strategic planning and business planning, State Leadership Accountability Act reporting, risk management, workforce and succession plans, engagement surveys and activities, change management process improvement, etc. fall off the plate as soon as something else is considered more important/critical.  It is often left to one area of the organization, delegated to staff as other duties as required (without proper training), and can even be sent to outside vendors.  If this work is required and important, then let's give it the priority and resources necessary to be successful and meaningful to the work we do in state service.

Two primary challenges I’ve noticed in my workplace are the lack of standardization and the amount of repetitive, manual work. Like others have mentioned, inadequate training resources, limited access to information, and redundant forms often slow down our ability to work efficiently. To address these issues, I’ve taken initiative by using Microsoft Office tools (SharePoint, Power Automate, Power Apps, etc.) that are already available to us at no additional cost to the state.  Here are some of the steps I’ve implemented:  1. SharePoint Site Development -Centralized and standardized all forms required for my role. -Used Power Automate to auto-fill redundant fields, reducing repetitive data entry. -Migrated resources from local drives to the cloud in compliance with IT policies, improving accessibility and collaboration.  2. Interactive Training Resources -Built a Wiki page to consolidate and standardize the training I’ve received from management. -Created step-by-step work instructions with embedded GIFs (instead of static screenshots) so employees can visually follow the process in real time.  By streamlining processes and digitizing resources, I’ve helped improve efficiency, reduce errors, and make information easier to access—all while keeping costs neutral for the state.
Additionally, many spaces are not ADA accessible. Upgrading spaces is costly and time consuming.

The ineffectiveness of California State Government to solve problems is frustrating.  State Government seems to have no idea how to solve any problem anymore.  Even if a solution existed, the approval process is almost impossible to navigate through.  Solutions to all problems are being thwarted before they can even being tried.
Thank you for bringing this to light.
Absolutely the same here

Extend light rail from Sacramento to Woodland, Davis, Roseville, and ElDorado.  This would help commuters whether they work for the State or private sector and reduce congestion on area highways. It would also help if it went to the airport.

Create program manuals that outline roles, responsibilities, and shared information to ensure everyone is on the same page. Basic systems thinking and project management but did this in spite, in opposition of my supervisor. Eventually they realized it was helpful.

I’m truly excited and pleased to see the ongoing classification consolidation efforts, which effectively leverage the skillsets and experience needed to perform essential work. However, I believe there is still room for improvement. It appears that rank-and-file employees are becoming more protected, while exempt and at-will positions are becoming more volatile and undermined. We should create competitive job offerings that modernize outdated processes and mindsets, while enhancing our government’s reputation—but in a way that restores productivity, trust, and integrity.

One of the challenges that needs further analysis is the replacement of staff when they move on from State Service. In most cases, departments are unable to fill vacancies until after the position becomes vacant. This leads to an exodus of knowledge and expertise from the department that is not easily replaced as it often takes years for an individual to become fully proficient in their role, establish connections with others and gain career long learning. While this practice may lead to salary savings, it creates a knowledge deficit which then leads to efficiency loss until such time as the individual staff person learns the position and becomes proficieint and beyond. If departments had the ability to hire replacement staff while the existing staff person was still present, the knowledge transfer would be more streamlined, and the institutional knowledge can be much more easily passed on to the new staff member. An in-between step might involve the creation of desk manuals for new staff to access however these will not necessarily impart the same level knowledge as the in person tutelage of the out-going staff member.

Lack of training in all staff, including management.  Abuse of time because documentation on staff takes years, and years, and is a lot of work.  Promotion of incompetent staff, because they are great talkers.  And because their opf  is clean due to the fact that managers do not want to be the bad person.

The contracting process is broken. Californians want government to have easy to use online tools, one-stop-shop permits, data access portals, and to use the latest technology to make people's lives better. Both IT and non-IT contracts are cumbersome and require navigating gate keepers who do not understand agency needs. If a project is deemed IT by contracting personnel, my agency will simply not move forward. If a contract gets flagged for the PAL process with CDT, the contract is dead, and we will never resubmit. Money lasts 3 years, and the PAL process can take that long, leaving no time for the money to be used on the intended project. Further, getting non-IT contracts through DGS is time-consuming and cumbersome with little added value, decreasing the time for the money to actually do work.   My suggestion would be to loosen up contract oversight on the frontend, actually provide training to staff, and provide more resources for auditing and enforcement of contract rules and ethics on the backend. In this way, SME staff will be trained on contract creation and execution (which is currently not the case) and can quickly get money out in flexible ways, taking advantage of as much of the 3 year money lifetime as possible, while knowing that they must strictly adhere to contract rules or their money will get pulled back and contracts will get cancelled. If you want staff to move fast, and use technology, this has to change.
Less taxes.

As a california resident I know the streets are dirtier in south central compared to other locations. Its like the trash men doesn't make regular rounds in worse areas. Also the homeless encampments are out of control. I think we should give them no options they either live where we want them to live, give them opportunity to fix themselves with work programs or go to jail. A lot of people on the street are breaking the law with robbing, violence, drugs. Or have family members get fined if there family is on the street. Or incentive to take in family members on the street by giving family money for them. To keep them off the streets some has to be accountable. Their needs to be some oversight on the mechanics working shops they overprice all their work with no oversight. Prices need to be posted for work and they should be unable to charge higher.

California is in a housing crisis. To make California's government more effective in responding to this crisis, I suggest that State properties be reevaluated to see if entire properties or portions of properties would be suitable for housing conversion. For example, the agency I work for has a large open parking lot adjacent to its office building, all of which is State property and near public transit. Could we maximize the use of this open parking lot by moving the parking space underground and building medium to high density housing units on top? Could there be a public-private partnership so that the State continues to own the land but leases it to a private developer so that the State ensures its needs are met? I know some transit agencies are converting transit parking lots into housing developments. Akin to some school districts, could we dedicate a portion of new housing to State employees at a discounted rate to attract and retain State employees?

In my own audits, setting firm deadlines for taxpayers to provide books and records has helped me move cases forward quickly and effectively. Clear expectations keep both sides accountable and prevent unnecessary delays. Combining this practice with faster internal collaboration would allow audits to progress efficiently while maintaining fairness and transparency.

It doesn’t make sense to require the same paperwork for every purchase when the information and compliance status haven’t changed. The redundancy creates excess paperwork, slows down procurement, and adds unnecessary administrative burden for both us and the vendors.  Additionally, requiring a signed RFQ seems redundant when the vendor is already providing an official quote on their company letterhead, which inherently serves as their formal offer.  A more efficient approach would be to have vendors complete these forms once per year, or only when there’s a material change to their status, rather than for every individual quote.

The Problem California’s current model for investigating and prosecuting insurance fraud is fragmented and inefficient. The Department of Insurance (DOI) houses the Fraud Division, a law enforcement unit operating within a regulatory agency. Simultaneously, $80.9 million in annual grant funding is distributed to county District Attorney’s (DA) Offices to prosecute fraud cases. This dual structure presents several challenges: Conflicting Missions: Regulatory agencies prioritize industry oversight and collaboration, which can conflict with the enforcement and prosecutorial roles of law enforcement. Operational Inefficiencies: DOI lacks the infrastructure, procurement agility, and legal support systems typical of dedicated law enforcement agencies. Jurisdictional Gaps: Only counties receiving grants can pursue fraud cases, leaving many areas underserved and creating geographic inequities. Short-Term Incentives: Grant-based funding encourages quick wins over long-term, complex investigations. Ethical Concerns: Financial incentives tied to prosecutions raise questions about the impartiality of justice. Recruitment and Retention Issues: DOI struggles to retain investigators, many of whom leave for better opportunities at the Department of Justice (DOJ). The Proposed Solution The proposal recommends transferring the DOI’s Fraud Division (163 peace officers and 75 support staff) and the $80.9 million in grant funding to the California Attorney General’s Office.

One of the primary problems I would address is the state’s resistance to fully embracing telework, despite clear evidence that it benefits both employees and the public. For decades, Californians have struggled with long commutes, congested freeways, and poor air quality. As a state employee, I see firsthand how commuting drains productivity, raises costs for workers, and contributes to pollution that affects every Californian. Forcing employees back into offices undermines efficiency, increases taxpayer costs for office space and reimbursements, and contradicts the state’s own climate goals.  The solution is simple: expand and normalize telework as the default option whenever the duties of a position can be performed remotely. This requires modernizing policies, investing in secure technology, and measuring performance based on outcomes instead of physical presence. Employees should be trusted to deliver results, and in my experience, productivity and responsiveness actually increase when telework is supported. By keeping more workers at home, California can cut emissions, save money, and provide faster, more effective services to residents. Telework is not just a perk. It is a strategy that addresses climate change, budget efficiency, and the quality of public service all at once.

As a state employee, that is focused on cyber security related issues, the primary problem I would like to address is the state not properly addressing Data Sovereignty. As it stands a majority of the data collected, generated and used by departments is physically hosted and stored with third-party companies. Companies who have issues of their own with keeping themselves out of their customers data. Although we have contracts governing how they handle this data contracts alone are not enough to protect citizens from the fallout should these companies' data centers become compromised. The sole responsibility for governing and protecting California citizens data rests with the state and its civil service. My solution to this problem would be for the California Department of Technology restart it's program to create a state cloud. The technology to do so has come a long way since it's last attempt and there is opportunity to recruit recently laid off tech workers into the civil service to support such a project as well as opportunities for more smaller local technology companies to engage in contract work to support the open-source software that will underpin it all. This would ensure that California data is protected and guarded by Californian's as well as California leading the way in Data and Technology governance.

Problem: Inefficiency and Redundancy California state departments often operate in silos, with structures built on highly centralized approaches. This creates disconnection across agencies, leading to duplicated efforts, wasted time, resource, and limited collaboration. As a result, departments struggle to share knowledge, coordinate resources, and work toward common goals, reducing overall efficiency and effectiveness.  Solution: Proposed Solution: Foster Collaboration and Shared Resources Shift from siloed, centralized structures toward a more connected, collaborative model. This can be done by creating cross-departmental working groups, shared digital platforms, and standardized processes that encourage transparency and knowledge sharing. By streamlining workflows and pooling resources, departments can reduce redundancy, improve efficiency, and deliver more consistent and effective services to Californians.

Right now, ASL Interpreters in California state service are often managed by people who don’t understand the profession or the needs of the Deaf/Hard of Hearing community. This creates mismanagement, inconsistent access, and unnecessary strain on both interpreters and the people they serve. A practical, immediate step would be to require each state department that employs ASL Interpreters to have an ASL Interpreter Coordinator—a position held by a qualified interpreter. This model already exists in the State Schools, where interpreters are managed effectively by someone with lived professional expertise. Expanding that model across departments would ensure proper support, accountability, and better access for Deaf/Hard of Hearing employees and clients. Longer term, California could take a bold step by creating a Department of Language to house and organize all interpreters statewide—including ASL, Spanish, and other languages. This would centralize resources, guarantee professional management by people who understand the work, and ensure that language access is treated as an essential public service. Importantly, this would also allow interpreters to be shared across departments, so that if a DMV office (for example) suddenly needed an ASL Interpreter, the Department of Language could quickly dispatch one. This approach strengthens equity, efficiency, and accessibility across the state.
The top income earners need to pay a higher percentage tax and reduce tax for the middle- and lower-class residents.
Budget deficit

Creating and soliciting contracts seems inefficient. I am not a supervisor and haven't had to go through the process, but all I hear from people who do have to fill that role is it's challenging. We may find a vendor that the District likes to work with but you can only use them for one job. Or one of their subcontractors didn't fill a requirement (veteran owned business) and so the whole project falls apart. It is not efficient.

More rail and public transportation options connected all of California not just within the cities. We may have to start thinking about ourselves as our own standalone country pretty soon with the way the federal government is currently heading.

I think there is a growing disparity between new and old offices where employees in new offices have access to free amenities that others do not. DGS owned/managed buildings with Gyms should be accessible to all state employees.
Creating tracking systems for my participants. Creating ways of ensuring that follow up happens by utilizing TEAMS or Outlook or AWARE.

One issue is about growing the competency of our workforce. We tend to have a lot of staff, but few people doing the vast majority of the work. This is not equitable and leads to burnout and potential loss of talent. True staff development would help this, along with formal mentoring programs, and more opportunities (with less bureaucratic hoops) to have temporary training and development opportunities, or the opportunity to partner with non-State agencies to temporarily work in the field, etc. We need staff to understand the big picture, be engaged, be empowered, and be prepared for advancement.

There are several departments under the Health and Human Services Agency that serve the same individual.  It would be helpful and cut redundancy if all the departments could share one data system.  The idea is to have one database with one record for each individual served.  This would allow the departments to better coordinate care and services.  This could potentially cut the intake process and waiting times as data may already have been collected.   It would also help cut down the number of times an individual has to share their information.  I understand that California has the Open Data Portal, but not all departments participate and that is to report deidentified data.  A solution to solve this problem could be to require all departments to participate in a shared data base, sharing information and working together to have the most up to date information.  Departments could also potentially share the cost of creating such a platform.  This could potentially eliminate some of the separate database changes taking place at other departments and modernize older systems.  This could also help HHS comply with some of the new CMS Final Rules by allowing cross reporting and by making sure each individual is only counted one time.  I would love to hear other solutions.

the complexity of the state contracting process, particularly when Dept. of General Services is involved. DGS can deny authority and services to Depts. and then we are accountable for failing to meet our mission. There is a consistent lack of understanding about what is required to manage large tracts of land and run fish hatcheries. Rather than serving a purpose (not wasting CA resources), contracting rules create impossible barriers and inefficiencies to acquiring tools and services required to meet our mission. Suggest giving more expansive authorities to Depts while simultaneously doing a better job writing clear policy and statute directives to assist Dept staff with making decisions that are functional and legal.

The need for remote work nationwide.  My restricting state employment to California and an in-office requirement, we are immediately limiting the ability to recruit the best and the brightest.  Although California is a great place to live, we exclude individuals who would be great assets to the state, both in mind and talent, if they don't want to relocate.  This creates an unnecessary barrier to recruiting the best, which only helps our state succeed.  My suggestion would be to identify classifications and areas which require unique and specalized skillsets and expanding the ability of those classifications to have more flexible remote work option.

I would like to add to build a veterans affairs hospital for people here in Napa.   So that way the Veterans who live in the North Bay could also get treatment and there would be patient escorts willing to push the veterans and make them happy.

I feel that our online resources are not very senior citizen friendly, or even ADA compliant. There are so many options, so much small print, and all the information can be overwhelming. I have actually brought it up to our IT department and even informed them of our website not being ADA compliant, and I was unfortunately just brushed off. I warned them, they will end up having a lawsuit, especially since there is a new law requiring the ADA compliance.

Over-regulation is the major issue making it difficult to achieve work in this position. This includes environmental regulation, contracting manuals, procurement manuals, and hiring regulations. My idea to deal with this is start with a fresh piece of paper to write clear, streamlined regulations. The current system of amending through legislation is ineffective.

The cost of onboarding and training new staff is much higher than most people know. Great onboarding and training practices saves California residents money and improves the services different agencies preform.  As a California resident I would like to see better experiences when I use California agencies.
I second all of this and particularly the 360-feedback for managers. ALL managers, including executive level (chiefs, deputy chiefs, etc.).

I applied to nearly 100 State Jobs before I was hired. Of those applications I submitted, I'd estimate over 75% netted in ZERO follow-up communication. Indeed, I almost never received any follow-up communication for positions I was invited to interview for but was not hired for. It seems that the norm is to expect a mountain of work from applicants but then to repay that with an intensely disrespectful and disheartening silence.
If there isn't more money to give to state workers, we should "expand the pie" and think about other benefits to give them instead, such as telework, alternate work schedules, additional PTO, etc.
Consistent training across multiple offices within the same department.  Greater collaboration to reduce redundancy

My team is fully crossed trained and have a back up (the back up has a back up too) for when they are on vacation or sick. When a member of the team has a planned outage they provide a list of pending items, what they are waiting on, and any contact information for the pending items to the whole team. The back up works the pending items as the necessary information is provided or updates are made. When the peer returns the back up provides a summary of what has been completed and what is outstanding.  The back up usually gets extra support for their peers to ensure nothing is missed. This is a win-win for everyone because the person that is out gets to enjoy their time off, work doesn't stop, deadlines aren't missed, when the person returns they are able to return without the stress of playing catch up, and the peers that are working know when they take time off they get the same benefits. This works when you set the expectation from the beginning and you take the time to cross train your team and if you have documented processes. Duties are rotated on a quarterly or semi-annual basis.

As a long time, State employee and manager, I would like to see a more streamlined approach to purchasing and hiring.  The processes are constantly changing and many times when there are "Statewide contracts" (an example would be tires), there are not enough "official locations" to make the contract viable or easy to use. We could be more efficient if DGS would delegate that authority lower to each department or at agency level.  Same with hiring processes.

I strongly agree that we do not have the capacity to return to the office. We have faced more challenges, especially since meetings are required but we don't have enough space to host them. Furthermore, it is also disturbing when someone is having a Teams meeting in their own cubicle while others are trying to work.  Commuting also further hurts traffic congestion and air pollution, and it flares up inflation, which is not good for Californians.  Not to mention the additional resources, such as new equipment and leases, that we would need to return to the office, which would only worsen the fiscal deficit.

Public works and environmental projects often require multiple permits and notifications from different agencies—each with its own application process, timelines, and conditions. This fragmented system wastes time, creates conflicting requirements, and makes compliance tracking burdensome for project managers and contractors. I propose a statewide, centralized permitting portal where applicants submit one unified application describing project scope and location. The system would:  Automatically identify which permits and agencies are triggered.  Generate a single project ID to track progress across agencies.  Push project information to agencies in their required formats.  Host shared communications, map uploads, and condition tracking.  Consolidate agency conditions into one coordinated, conflict-checked permit package.  Enable online fee payment in a single transaction.  This platform would streamline environmental compliance, improve inter-agency coordination, reduce redundancy, and ensure consistent, transparent permitting for all public projects statewide.

I recently applied for and was offered another position in a different classification in my department, but I also knew I was going on maternity leave soon after. It was extremely complicated trying to figure out which position was more beneficial in terms of FMLA/SDI vs NDI/paid family leave. It makes NO sense that something like maternity and parental leave varies so drastically depending on your union and whether or not you are in a supervisory role. I would like to see more parity across positions, with at least a month of maternity leave prior to your due date (with the option to telework full time even before then) and 6 months of paid leave across the board.

Often, we tend to continue with outdated practices without periodically reevaluating the process for efficiency. I recently eliminated redundant and duplicative steps and incorporated an electronic aspect to the process to improve response times. We have received very positive feedback from the affected parties. I was very surprised of how many steps I was able to eliminate to achieve the same result in a faster time.

Honestly, we really need an updated, super user friendly, accessible Calcareers site. We need an app for it as well. I know we hire a ton of really capable IT folks and developers and I bet experts in that field would have a ton of great ideas on how to make this happen.

I believe the direction of CDCR will infuriate the public by the state policies enable the negative behavior inmates perpetrate on each other and to staff. The enabled behavior contributes to higher recidivism rates and does not prepare inmates for when they become discharged. It is disheartening to see bad behavior bombarded with wasted resources for inmates versus hard working citizens and their needs.

Teleworking has helped me be more efficient as it allows flexibility to balance work and home. I am much less stressed from commuting and dealing with the hassels of public transportation, excess time consumed, racing deadlines. Therefore allowing me to be more focused on actual work and providing excellent service.
Get community involved in the work done by the State.

The primary problem I see is a complicated state government apparatus and body of state laws that do not reflect the true interests of Californians as well as they could. To address this, I would recommend a dual effort to map out / simplify the functions of existing governmment agencies, and to educate Californians about the structure of state government and these functions so that the government and the people will be more in-sync with each other.

I've worked in the private sector and I'm shocked by how antiquated and labor intensive our travel approvals, travel booking, travel expense reporting processes are.  It takes hours to wade through all the layers and forms and rules.  And extensive pre-approvals have us losing out on lower cost flights, early bird discounts, and hotel blocks at higher cost to the State of CA.  We used concur in the private sector and things could be done in close to real time.  If the time my small department spends on limited travel is magnified across all departments and agencies it's a huge loss of time and productivity.  The CalAters site is so slow and even says on the front screen plan for several minutes to even open the page.  I believe CA, with our technology and innovation can do better in a digital world.

The State has too many levels of managers/management that have no primary responsibility other than managing people. This creates a bottleneck of work that needs to be reviewed by multiple people who aren't directly involved in the work and often do not provide value-added feedback. Additionally, having managerial positions takes away a position that could be filled by an analyst or specialist. With the rise of technology like Teams and DocuSign that make it easier to work collaboratively from different locations, we no longer need the number of managers that many departments have.
as a CA resident: free parking, safer public transportation, safer streets

The budget appears to be the primary problem with California, as state employees are expected to take pay cuts and furloughs to offset budget deficit. State employee pay and benefits should be protected. Overspending should be compensated for by those who overspend. Accountability is a virtue, and California should adopt it as a standard operating procedure.
I was just reading today about a study showing that almost half of workers have better working relationships with their AI tools than with their supervisor!

I agree. In my 36 yrs of service, I've noticed one thing. Good Leadership is lacking. if you happen to get someone who is a great leader, you got lucky. We tend to train staff then just hand you the keys when you promote. This missing leadership directs not only completed work but set great expectations related to most of what is said here. It addresses issues like racism, sexism and harassment and directs the attention of the teams to completing the tasks at hand. I'm not talking about DEI but instead understanding that ALL employees are needed to get the work done.

It is challenging to give too much autonomy to any department when it comes to statewide issues, such as recruitment practices, policies and administrative programs, pay systems, etc., when we are all ONE EMPLOYER. It leaves a lot of room for error when we are all subject to the same laws and regulations but are allowed to interpret and apply that interpretation differently. It would be most helpful to actually have our CONTROL AGENCIES truly control, provide THEIR interpretation to laws/rules/regs that should be applied across the board, and have them develop the statewide policies (not just as a model) and practices that are most defensible to create standardization and consistency across agencies.

The primary problem I'd like to address is modernizing our technology and streamlining processes. Coming from private sector, I was shocked to find the very manual processes due to  budget constraints and inability to invest in system to streamline processes (e.g. HRIS)
Instead of selling those state-owned properties, get rid of leased properties for those departments that are public facing. Getting rid of leases will help to fund additional staff members.
The primary problem is the state trying to take away telework. Telework is proven to work, productivity is up and morale from the staff is high.

For HQ departments that process paperwork for all the districts, there should be more training offered to the districts on how the process/procedures works. The policies keep changing too quickly, so the districts who had people trained a long time ago are working off old information and passing that down to newer employees. It could be online sessions or onsite training, but somehow the districts need a better way to be updated.

There is also a lack of sufficient break areas in many offices. For example there may be some kitchens on each floor but they can only fit 1-2 people when there could be over 100 on that floor. There is a "common break room" for the whole building that can maybe accommodate 20-30 when there are thousands of workers in the building.  This causes workers to not have appropriate breaks away from their desk   as intended by the law.

Make more transactions/tasks accessible via online forms & scanning documents to a state website.  This will cut down on parking & space requirements to handle crowds of public customers and can free up staffing to either work from home or use remote workers far away from the actual worksite and/or work 24 hours varying shifts reviewing documents online instead of just 8-5 in physical office. For example, aside from the actual driving test the DMV could accept scanned documentation for all other transactions. The federal government for passports allows private businesses like UPS to take photo for applicants, could just take step further & allow approved businesses to scan photo as well instead of crowds standing in line at DMV.

To reduce stress in the workplace, I would look at alternative methods including creating "green rooms" - rooms filled with plants and special events in collaboration with other organizations like a "puppy pen".

As a Californian, my concerns are:  Taxation- getting to be out of control for those in upper income ranges. Does a wealthy family who has had generational wealth they worked hard far, really need to give half their money in taxes?Water- is it being protected? Our parks and natural resources- are they protected? Agricultural land- who is advocating we protect?  who is overseeing the agenda of small towns that are allowing urban sprawl just so they can bring a target to their town, at the loss of thousands of farming acres.  If you work or live in California, you love most parts. And you see many parts that need stronger advocating for, many many more than I have listed. We have dedicated our families and a big chunk of our resources ( $) to live here, what can we do to make it liveable for US?  ps. I forgot one other idea: I think that all the agencies should open their parking on the weekend and after business hours to the public to park FOR FREE.

I think having TV commercials or radio spots to promote the State Parks would be a good idea.  Maybe something with social media or creating a community group of State Park Enthusiasts would work too.

Job Positions on Hold    Problem:  Some positions have been on hold for months and years, and managers give them to their favorite people; they do not advertise the position —they give it to a transfer employee.   People who can apply for that position are having their opportunity taken away because the position is not advertised and given to transfer employees. These transfer positions are not the exception; they are the rule and are being abused.   Solution:  Transfer employees and current employees should be able to apply for the available position. No favoritism should be allowed in job positions, and they should be advertised.
Direct supervisors working together with subordinates as a team, teamwork mentality instead of superiority complex over staff. Morale is better and productivity strengthens from it.

I'm all about helping our team grow and unlocking everyone's potential. Right now, our department is seriously missing the mark when it comes to developing talent. My boss hasn't really been stepping up to guide and mentor people who could be future leaders. It feels like we're stuck in this old-school management mode that's more about checking boxes than actually developing people. I'm pushing hard for a different approach – one that's all about building real leadership skills. We need to focus on helping people connect, understand emotions, and level up their professional game. Imagine managers who can actually spot what each team member needs to grow and thrive. This isn't just about training; it's about creating a workplace where people feel supported, challenged, and excited to bring their best selves to work. By investing in our people like this, we're not just checking HR boxes – we're building a team that's flexible, motivated, and ready to crush whatever challenges come our way. It's time we stop managing and start truly leading.

One of our biggest problems within state service that affects (likely) every service and product we offer is - Leadership. The way our duty statements are written and who we prioritize within the hiring process often promotes individuals into leadership roles with very specific (often niche) knowledge, but frequently lacking leadership skills (like compassionate communication, relational intelligence, teambuilding, conflict resolution, creative intelligence, etc). I would suggest two things: Add new AGPA roles (e.g., AGPA 1, AGPA 2, etc) to allow for growth within analyst positions and reduce the need to transition into leadership for monetary purposes. The same is likely true for other position types. And I would also institute better leadership development programs. What we offer now is below minimum standard and/or often suggestive in nature - you "could" take X Course, but why do it when you're so busy. I would like to see distinct and explicit development programs, mentorship opportunities, and a clear progression path that tracks which leaders are not only learning these skills but applying them, and then make job opportunities for them to succeed and evolve within their career. I think with better leadership a lot of the bureaucracy, bottlenecking,  communication, and problem-solving issues we face would likely "get better" on their own.
Bureaucracy, too many hands trying to get involve (stakeholder) in a small issue.  Look at the High Speed Rail project.

The lack of personnel. We have last many positions within our unit as the positions were abolished. We are expected to the same amount of work, if not more and we are poorly compensated in comparison to the private sector. We constantly loose employees as they look for elsewhere as they’re compensated more in other companies.

I believe that the processes that are currently in place with DGS are far too cumbersome and require too much time to work through. I believe we need to streamline processes and work towards getting things done rather than figure out what road blocks can go up to slow down the process.

Do we have access to a translation service? I have been trying to make our signage more understandable to more Californians, but have been having to scrounge for native speakers in various languages (Russian and Dari specifically).

Postage and shipping costs. When we are able to provide resources electronically with confirmation receipt, we can eliminate mail, i.e., Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA), California Family Rights Act (CFRA) and Pregnancy Disability Leave (PDL), Workers' Compensation (WC). This will save the state budget in time used, paper and postage used, and shredding the resources after they are saved electronically.

I believe that there are many rules and regulations to protect the environment. It is my opinion that many of these regulations are duplicative and difficult to understand. Additionally, I do not believe that state workers in some of these regulatory positions have the proper support and guidance to protect the environment. I have continued concern that state agencies are top heavy and have excessive amounts of management staff that are disassociated with the day-to-day tasks. Additionally, political will is often lacking in the higher levels of management to enforce regulations as they are intended. I think the public would be disappointed if they truly understood how water was regulated in our state. I think that we need to have a real discussion on how regulations will be applied to all equally, to be most effective at conservation on a statewide level.

Creating and maintaining a "desk binder" (paper in the old days, OneNote now) of the plethora of mini-activities that are done in the office, from daily routines to yearly audits. Processes can change rapidly, with all this new technology, and training materials are notorious for getting stale.

It’s so expensive to live in California. So many things, like licensure for example, are so much more affordable in other states. I am a licensed psychologist in California. I pay $850 to renew. I got licensed in Virginia for only $200. That’s just one example. The price of gas is another. It’s so much cheaper in other states. Car registration is another example.

Flatten the organization. Multi-tier mgmt hierarchies tend to result in excess procedural steps thereby slowing the overall process. Eliminate "red tape" where none are needed.  Review steps in a process to assess value in the overall procedure. If step(s) don't serve a legitimate purpose then the procedure should be tightened up to improve & fast track the execution of the procedure. In short, streamline by investigating the overall process for value & timeliness. Pare down where there are redundant or no-value steps/processes.  If there is an opportunity to automate a process/procedure, empower knowledgeable staff to explore/implement solutions even if there is an intended enterprise-wide solution targeted for deployment downstream. There is value in short-term solutions which, until a potential future large-scale solution is implemented (which can sometimes/often be unavailable for years), can greatly reduce considerable man-hours that would otherwise be necessary.  Create bridges between units that share knowledge, require similar experience/tools, feed information across units, present opportunities to consolidate & standardize output either for internal or public use. There are current silos of units that have very similar processes but are handled/implemented differently. Normalize processes across these silos.  Establish inter-division training plans to retain staff expertise. Grow/support internal advancement plans based on org job forecast. Hire from within.

Well stated.  Most workplace challenges are not confidential and should be shared with the entire team.  Supervisors who aren't inclusive or pretend things need a top-secret clearance usually lack leadership skills and/or mentorship to guide them on better emotional intelligence when critical thinking.  The best way to improve something, is to ask people to poke holes in it.  By being open to fail points, you can avoid some of them versus running straight into them because you didn't seek help from those with experience different from yours.

Agreed! Current public transit infrastructure is inadequate. It is not frequent enough, often delayed, and can sometimes be dirty and unsafe due to lack of monitoring and cleaning. Having more non-police officials (such as crisis intervention teams) would be helpful. Public transit is chronically under-funded, which makes it difficult to make it efficient, reliable, and safe. Additionally, there is a need for more light-rail and high-speed rail since busses are typically very slow.

Automating processes where applicable to reduce reliance on contractors and antiquated ways of performing more complex tasks. One example of this is software releases. Understanding modern software development life cycles and implementing continuous improvement/continuous delivery practices allows our agency to get functionality to the citizens of CA more quickly and with less bugs.

Ways to upgrade and repair all old infrastructure in CA State Parks.  Ideas: 1. Engage private sector for sponsorships/donations 2. Privatize certain aspects of CA State Parks (housekeeping, contracting, entrance station/fee collection) 3. Remove the 5 levels of internal review and approval prior to submitting to Control agencies for authorization and approvals
I have done this as well and loved the outcome, had some push back from staff that dont like change but it made such a difference in the end.
I think CEAs should have to take leadership/mentorship classes to make sure they know how to lead and manage respectfully.

We have done additional spreadsheets to compare against entries in CalJOBS for years. Either it works or it doesn't work. Recently additional spreadsheet info has been added on. This is causing way to much angst in trying to help job seekers. Management even stated it was about process not outcomes. SOLUTION: audit CalJOBS, focus on entries there to eliminate duplicate and triplicate work. Focus on outcomes and hiring.

It sounds like your meeting was a Chief's update rather than a stand-up. For those who haven't heard of this term, sometimes called a scrum, a stand-up meeting is intended to allow for a team round robin of updates focused on the day, a check-in to identify opportunities to collaborate or assist in problem-solving the work happening that day. It's from the IT world where work items are broken down into small tasks that are completed quickly i.e. daily. This is not always the case with other types of work.

California’s government must recommit to a centralized IT strategy—one that prioritizes shared services, specialized expertise, and fiscal responsibility. The current decentralized approach, where individual departments manage their own IT infrastructure, is inefficient, costly, and misaligned with the state’s legislative intent.  Many state agencies were created to fulfill specific missions—public health, transportation, education, and more. Yet today, these departments are investing significant time, energy, and capital into building and maintaining their own IT systems. This diverts focus from their core responsibilities and leads to duplication of effort, fragmented infrastructure, and inconsistent standards.  The California Department of Technology (CDT) was established to solve this problem. Assembly Bill 2408 and the resulting Government Code provisions laid the foundation for a centralized IT model—one that consolidates services, reduces redundancy, and enables departments to focus on their primary missions while leveraging CDT’s expertise.  Despite this mandate, many departments continue to operate isolated IT silos. This not only undermines the intent of AB 2408, but also wastes taxpayer dollars and slows statewide progress. The result: overlapping systems, inconsistent security protocols, and missed opportunities for innovation.

As a state employee for more than 15 years, I would like our employer to highlight the work state workers do with the focus on changing the public perception of State Workers.  We work hard for the citizens of California and often dedicate unpaid time to ensure those we serve are receiving the care and attention required to prevent disruption in the services we provide.  In times of extreme hardship, we work long and exhausting hours without complaint.  State workers are of value to California.  A campaign to lift up the heroes that work for California, highlighting the  great workers that support our state is needed.

The State and particularly Sacramento has the opportunity to be a model for other states and levels of government, but to accomplish this we need to reduce the barriers keeping motivated and innovative people from applying and getting state jobs.  In particular, I have seen how the cumbersome process of verifying MQs for folks coming from the private sector causes us to lose out on great candidates and discourages others from trying at all.

A more efficient way to spend small amounts of money. There are multiple ways for me to spend my budget, and some of them are quite quick and painless - so I know it's possible. But just to order pizza requires a whole process and huge packet of forms. The pizza place even has to sign a form certifying they aren't associated with Darfur. This makes sense to spend 20 million dollars. But a few hundred bucks for pizza? There should be an easier process for small purchases.

I had both a valid real ID and CA DL.  Upon time for renewal of these, I received 2 separate renewal notices which could be processed via mail BUT I wanted to combine these into one and was unable to do so without a DMV visit.  I had to make a DMV appointment and go through the process of getting a real ID again by providing all the appropriate paperwork although I already had a valid real ID. Would like to see the option of  1. combining valid forms of identification  2. if offered renewal by mail for separate forms of IDs, these IDs should be able to be renewed via mail if combined 3. not needing to provide documentation again if there is a valid ID

The state is composed of various departments that are very small in size and often must contract out to provide obtain basic services internally or externally. These contracts can include interpretation/translation, website maintenance, a/v services, cabling, etc. Sometimes staff are stretched thin in smaller offices with various responsibilities because there is not enough personnel to cover issues that a team in a larger organization would do. There is so much time spent in bringing on external providers in addition to the cost of services as well as recruiting for staff turnover due to burnout. The state could better coordinate services across departments under a certain size reducing costs and providing adequate support for staff and the public.

Hiring is a primary problem, first in the length of time it takes to hire and in the merit hiring process. I would propose using an AI system with CalCareers to connect key words in the application packages (resume, SOQ, app) to the desirable qualifications. They system could then screen applications and redact information like names and places of employment before apps are released to managers. This has been discussed as a manual process but most HR shops do not have the manpower to implement, so AI would provide a more effective and affordable process.

When publishing OTA decisions, include key regulations or issues addressed in the case title. This would help auditors research faster and avoid the need to click through and read every decision to find relevant guidance.
There is NOT a good management or leadership development program in state government.
Make the workplace a prosocial and positive environment instead of leading from what seems to be going wrong.

Employee morale has significantly dropped over the last three years as the state tries to implement a one size fits all RTO solution, in the midst of multiple PLPs, rising benefits costs, older retirement ages, and low pay increases that do not keep up with the cost of living in California. State employees want to be more efficient and help California budget issues but doing it on state workers' backs is only going to drive out good, marketable employees.
