Consider implementing all department surveys to assess productivity, collaboration, efficiency, and department needs when making decisions about RTO. Transparency on actual costs of RTO- DGS and CalHR's responses in the budget subcommittee hearing that there was essentially no way to know the costs was disingenuous and disrespectful to state employees. Assessments for cutting costs to programs for people who do not work or unused/unmoderated social programs, before cutting pay of hard-working state employees.

When executive leadership genuinely cares about employees (regardless of what classification/positions) and take into consideration of everyone's feedback, it truly makes a big difference in the positive morale and buy-in from staff.  On the contrary, if executive leadership is only saying the right things ("lip service") and not backing it up with action, then it actually further contributes to the low morale of staff.

When we moved recently finding a Doctor that was taking new patients was extremely difficult.  There doesn’t appear to be any requirement for health providers to keep their websites updated as to their Doctors and their availability.  The Dr. offices usually blamed the carrier and the carrier said they were never informed.  Some Dr had moved health groups up to 3 years prior with no updates.  Maybe we could make the update at least an annual requirement and award a “patient service excellence” award to health providers who keep their websites updated!
This is suggesting using Lean Six Sigma Process Improvement for examining the processes within organizations.  Great idea!  CalHR offers courses.
Say "no" more often. If "no" was said more often, the organization could focus it's effort on more value ad business. Most often a "yes" is given in order to avoid political backlash.

I would support the use of imminent domain on large parcels of land in urban areas that property owners allow to sit vacant and underutilized. They should be force to develop it or sell it to someone who wants to do something with it. There has been a giant pit along K street in Sacramento for decades, it's ridiculous that there is no interest in developing it for something like a nice park, a dog park, a farmers market, an basketball court, anything other than an empty trash filled pit.

I would like to see the State of California use less paper, and decrease the cost of printing out reports.  Other costs to consider: maintenance of machines, power used to keep printers online, building space to archive documents. One way to solve the issue is to leave the already printed files alone, and start where we are now, creating a file system on the one drive that other teammembers can assess.

It would be great to see our department invest in technology that would ultimately save money for taxpayers long-term. We have a lot of systematic jobs in the state that can be automated which would reduce the need for so many positions. Because our department is not revenue driven, we often have outdated technology that does not allow us to automate our processes.

Allow staff and managers more flexibility to conduct business efficiently when it comes to procurement.  We pay far too much for equivalent supplies and services due to the policy set in place of who we can purchase from.
When a team works well together it can make things more effective or efficient. Management that treats their team like they are adults and doesn't micromanage creates trust within the enviornment.
Telework has made my job more effective and efficient. I notice staff morale is at an all-time high and so is the work. Productivity is high because of telework.

Before the pandemic, many administrative hearings were required to be in person. Since videoconference hearings became available, the vast majority of parties have chosen to utilize them. This allows individuals to take an hour or two off work instead of an entire day and avoid having to find childcare because they can participate from home. People save significant time by eliminating the need to drive or fly to a hearing, in addition to the carbon emissions from those trips. This change saves average Californians and small businesses hundreds, if not thousands, of dollars.  It also saves the state money. California agencies that pay for hearings no longer have to reimburse participants for the time and mileage spent traveling to hearings. If there is a default, those costs are completely wasted. Agencies that shift to remote offerings can make a substantial impact by reducing travel costs and minimizing waste, particularly important in our current fiscal climate.

Executive decision making. Control agencies create guidelines, guidance, guardrails, etc., but then allow each Department to interpret it differently. Why is hiring easier at one agency than another? Why can a contract with CARB get executed in 2 months and a contract with Caltrans takes a year? They cite the same contract code, DGS rules, etc. but have completely different interpretations of the same thing. How is that possible?  What's the point of this guidance or having a control agency if there is no standardization across the State.

Less political optics and more measurable actions towards delivering better and efficient digital services. We can look at the Ukrainian DIA app and efforts to digitize a whole government as well as GOV.UK that was able to consolidate all digital information and services.
Automation of what used to be a paper based process.  Server migrations from legacy systems to modern systems.  Cloud migrations.

I think team member retention would be improved if there was a parking stipend that coincided with the area in which the employee was required to work. For example, parking rates in the Sacramento area vary from $125-200 per month. This additional cost is impactful to employees. Public transportation is not always feasible nor safe.

In my career with the state, I've always been surprised as to how different departments use different tools to do the same thing. Similar to the FisCAL effort, which shows how hard this can be, all departments should be using the same software and tools for things like personnel and HR information, web site content, and project management (SharePoint).

We performance manage low performing employees out of our system the way that private employers do. This makes us a weaker organization as a whole. I have worked for the state for 6 years and my direct supervisor has been here about 50% of the time. The rest has been spent on LOA. Bad for morale, bad for business.

In a nutshell, understand what is already in place creating new solutions. There is so much overlap between agencies that creates a great deal of duplication and confusion. This is actually pretty simple. Do your homework first. Know all stakeholders, internal and external. Create meaningful engagement upfront. I have been a state employee for 25 years and worked for 4 agencies. I have been through a great deal of change, often mandated by legislation. The implementation is always an afterthought. Implementation is essential to success. Employees in the trenches too often are not identified as stakeholders, their expertise overlooked. This is not good stewardship, and all too often results in program duplication and implementation failure.

I've been with the same department for 11 years, before that, I served in the military for 25 years. The primary problem I see has been the use (or lack of) technology.  There are so many things that would be more efficient if technology was utilized. We manage millions on excel spreadsheets, which I find unbelievable and a risk. When new technology is procured, the IT branch decides what to turn on or not and it's one thing at a time.  For example, we have two IT units, one oversees Outlook and allows us to use CoPilot, but the unit that oversees Teams, won't allow us to use CoPilot.  It makes no sense. I wish I had a solution to recommend.

The primary problem with state services is a lack of expense consciousness. Because government is structured to focus on a need being met, there is little interest in ensuring that the need being met is done in an efficient and cost effective manner. Agencies are punished for not spending all the money allocated to them because the next year, their budget gets reduced. This creates a use it or lose it mentality, and less concern is given on whether we are being good stewards of the public's money. To solve this problem, policies must be set that reward agencies that save the government money rather than penalizing them by reducing their future budget.   Another problem is that state agencies do not talk to each other.  We are all under the State umbrella, however, no collaboration or connection opportunities exist to be able to compare notes. Most agencies face similar problems and the ability to discuss possible solutions or even understanding what other agencies have done to address their problems is a missed opportunity.  There is no where that allows us to see the organization structure, duty statements, or reports completed by other agencies. There is no directory to reach out to other agencies and collaborate.  I would create a state agency directory and a policy would have require state agencies to comply by sharing their organization charts as well as contact information to other areas.  I would restrict access of executive leadership to only executive leadership.

Finally, I believe it’s time to fundamentally rethink how government employees work—and how government itself operates. The old blueprint no longer fits the realities we face today. We need to reduce redundant frameworks, streamline operations, and encourage departments to consolidate and collaborate across silos. Efficiency shouldn’t be a buzzword—it should be a mandate. But this isn’t just about internal reform. It’s about reimagining the physical footprint of government. Many office buildings now sit underused or entirely vacant. These spaces represent an opportunity—not a liability. By converting surplus government buildings into affordable housing, we can breathe new life into downtown economies that have long depended on a steady flow of government workers.This kind of transformation would not only address housing shortages but also diversify and strengthen urban centers. It’s a chance to shift from a government-centric downtown to a community-centric one—where people live, work, and thrive in more dynamic, inclusive environments.

let go of old tech that is no longer serving the community and actually use taxpayers money to use the current tech available instead of a large employee base in IT who are just not anywhere close to competing with the private sector.

Because of the high cost of housing around cities where most jobs and government offices are located, there is substantial inequality of opportunity for many Californians who cannot afford to live in metro centers. By shifting to remote offerings, such as the ability to participate in hearings and government decisions by videoconference, we can ensure that people who live in more distant (and often more affordable) areas are given equal opportunities to have their voices heard and contribute to shared goals.  Remote offerings further align with California’s climate goals, avoiding tons of CO₂ that would otherwise be generated as Californians waste time and money driving to formerly in-person meetings. Videoconference offerings also help us include Californians with disabilities who may struggle to join us in person due to challenges with transit and accessibility.   Since the COVID-19 pandemic, many state agencies have vastly enlarged the group of individuals who can participate through the change to remote and videoconference meetings and hearings. This conversion to a more accessible meeting style should be expanded so more people can benefit.

Another issue that I have observed as a state employee over the past 11 years is the overall difficulty with hiring staff. The process from start to finish from application to final decision is incredibly laborious and complicated, and likely prevents hundreds of people from applying for state employment. Moving forward it would be in the state's best interest to streamline the application/hiring process to the highest extent feasible to support having the highest amount of job applicants to hire from. This process would enable the state to hire and maintain the best available applicants available for potential hiring.

We are great at analyzing bills, writing guidance, etc. but not as great with meaningful and successful implementation of policies. Education on policy implementation would be helpful. Also, State-sponsored or subsidized education programs with an agreement to stay at the State for a certain number of years, could improve the workforce.

Telework has been working not only for state employees, but also benefits all Californians. By reducing the need for in-office attendance, California has been able to reduce traffic, emissions, and pollutants all while increasing employee moral, efficiency, and potentially reduce the need for the exorbitant office leases which leads to reduced costs for the state overall.

Most departments operate in a silo and frequently are doing work that is duplicative and/ or serving the same populations.  The CA Climate Initiative came closer to changing this. CA Jobs First is getting at that problem, but may not make it to the finish line when the administration changes. There is no CA tracking mechanism or over arching council that holds that type of knowledge. There is No system in place to make sure that anyone trying to do workforce development knows what each department is doing in that area or if multiple departments are trying to attack affordable housing all departments have a mechanism to get information. All these programs exist but I have found so many state employee have no idea. Then employees approach their departments with a "novel" idea to address these types of examples above and a whole new program is started including money being put toward it, when it exists somewhere else.

The first thing I noticed when I became a state employee was how behind the times everything is. The modern world utilizes technology wherever possible. We should aim to do the same.  The state needs to rid itself of antiquated processes, procedures, technologies, equipment, etc. As the nation's leader in technology and innovation the State of California should focus on improving these things across all areas of business. We should be using electronic/virtual options wherever possible. Allow ECH/ACH/EFT payments to vendors. Use electronic communications. Strive to reduce wasteful spending on office and storage space by moving to a more modern virtual space. Revamp our websites to make them more user friendly and improve functionality. Provide more training to all state employees on the various programs and technologies that exist to improve communication and efficiency. Using modern technology would not only improve processing times but would also save the state and taxpayers money by reducing waste of paper, ink, office supplies, postage, time, space, and environmental impacts.

There need to be more opportunities to promote-in-place, allowing people who have gained expertise in their Agency/Department to stay, rather than forcing them to look for another job in State Government in order to be able to promote.

The primary problem I would address is homelessness. I have several ideas to fix this problem, and they can be implemented in stages. First and foremost, make it easy to build affordable housing. Recognize that homelessness is a housing problem.   2nd, Prioritize the people who just slipped into homelessness and have potential and will to come out of it. Help them to come out permanently and join mainstream.  Right now, I serve as board member for HART of Folsom, and we are proud to have reduced Folsom's homelessness by 10% this way. 3rd, go deeper and help people that are homeless longer and probably will never come out.  Build shelters with services for them and make rules to humanely require them to take those services. Those rules might curtail some of their freedom, but they should know that it's cost to pay for not being able to come out of homelessness by themselves.   Finally, to do all this work, encourage and fund the non-profits directly from the state so that the rules are uniform. One positive side effect is that more non-profit jobs are created this way. Each city and county having its own rules and managing and distributing funds will only create more red tape and confusion and dysfunction. Re-organize the current machinery and people work under one state agency with simple and uniform set of rules.
Lack of effective communication and transparency from management to staff and vice versa.
Additionally, punitive management styles are not flexible or inclusive opening up legal and reputational risks. Both risks reduce efficiency and productivity.
more training and accountability for all classifications and levels of staff
Let's continue to improve our processes and embrace technology that reduces direct human contact and allow everyone who is able and willing to work from home, both in the public and private sector.

Less talk and more action. Take for example Highway 50 construction or the bullet train. Let's be efficient and effective in what, how we deliver services, products to Californians. Remove the political agenda.  Give Californians what they truly need and not because of someone's legacy.

Education has the same problem.  Some of the management at HQ have never step foot into an institution, let alone see the daily operations, but create policy and guidelines that are difficult to implement.  An effort to collect staff feedback could help solve some of this issue.

Over my state career I have been employed by more than one agency, and across the board this problem exists.  The lack of procedures, resources and training references on the varied applications utilized by differing state agencies to achieve assigned task.  Specifically in the Human Resources capacity, there should be agency specific recognized and adhered to manuals and procedures for reoccurring task.  The processes contain too much grey area, and it cause errors and penalties.

What works is when employees who aren't trained are allowed to figure the job out for ourselves which results in more efficient completion of tasks. We know the job best, we know how to keep ourselves safe. Micro-managing is a killer of efficiency.

Special housing rates for State employees. You either have to be marries, have a roommate, have a second job, or rent to live in California. As a state employee, there is no way to own a home without some help from the government. Even if it's just when the government sells of plots of land they don't need anymore. Throw us a bone.

I agree with you on excess bureaucracy being a major hurdle. What really resonates with me is Ezra Klein’s idea of bottlenecks. I think we should go further and intentionally assign “bottleneck detectives.” Their role would be to find the unnecessary hurdles that don’t add enough value for the work they produce. Each team could have a benchmark for eliminating a certain number of these barriers every year. That way, we’re not just adding new checks and requirements—we’re also systematically cutting the ones that no longer serve a purpose. It would keep oversight in place while making sure the real work doesn’t get buried under endless forms and hoops.

Why are we being stuffed into cubicles like sardines because they don't have the proper space to accommodate full time work in office? If this is the case, they should not expect us to be in the office full time. We should continue working from home permanently and not go into the office at all. Especially the employees who work more than 50 miles from their office. The state hired people with the intent to be hybrid work and now want to take it back. No work is getting done for those in the office. I get 10x the amount of work done at home than in person.

I recently completed Lean Six Sigma Green Belt training and worked on a process improvement project to reduce defects in one fiscal process area. Not only did we identify root causes & solutions for the process, but we got to work in cross functional teams to learn the bigger picture of workflow. We came out of our silos. We heard from the customer. Team members demonstrated a genuine curiosity about what was happening in other sections. Learning was happening as we were studying the process.   Projected fiscal savings for the project was estimated at $13M. Some of my team's fiscal resources have been streamlined and simplified. This greatly reduces our customer's time performing fiscal processes.   Soft savings include better work-life balance for many of my internal sections / units who often need to work evenings / weekends due to process defects.  One of our developed solutions recently supported another work group with understanding the fiscal workflow and related terminology.

I wait until the afternoon mail comes before putting the inter-department delivery envelopes back into outgoing mail,  that way I am using LESS envelopes instead of simply putting the envelopes in outgoing mail after the morning mail is finished; wait for afternoon mail, stuff the envelopes, then put into outgoing.
That is not a centralized policy. Our department pre-loads transit cards. Once my balance is low, I go to the website and click the button to re-up my card.

Problem: In many state departments, including my own, productivity is often hindered by rigid processes where documents must pass through multiple layers of review—sometimes six or more—before finalization. This not only delays critical deliverables but can render documents outdated or irrelevant by the time they are approved. Additionally, there is a noticeable gap in collaboration and communication between subject matter experts (SMEs) and executive leadership. This disconnect often leads to a reactive environment where teams are constantly putting out fires instead of proactively identifying and addressing potential issues. Solution: Introduce a tiered review system that empowers mid-level managers and SMEs to approve routine documents without requiring executive-level sign-off. This would reduce bottlenecks, increase accountability, and allow leadership to focus on strategic priorities. Implementing digital workflow tools with built-in version control and approval tracking can also enhance transparency and speed. Establish regular cross-functional strategy sessions between SMEs and executives to align on goals, anticipate challenges, and co-create solutions. This would shift the culture from reactive to proactive, encouraging innovation and long-term planning. Additionally, investing in leadership training that emphasizes trust in employee expertise and decision-making can help break down hierarchical barriers and build a more agile, responsive organization.

I developed a spreadsheet to improve project scheduling and cost estimating. Currently, it is used in District 8, but I hope to transform it into a web-based application to enhance project delivery statewide.

I would like to see state workers treated as equals to every other job. We get paid significantly less, yes because of our benefits but its disproportionally less. Rather then using us to make up the deficit of the governor, how about they learn to budget. OR how about all California's pay for the issues, not just state workers. Our 3% raise was taken, and we were given 5 hours off a month. Someone please explain what we are going to do with 5 hours off a month when we cant afford to go anywhere since we didn't get our raise, and cost of living here has gone up way more than 3%. State workers are not the private checkbook for the governor.  Our unions our weak, and scared to fight!

Telecommuting. Make employees come back to the office. I know many state employees that work for different agencies and they "work" from home. They also brag about raising their kids instead of working, mowing their lawns, their supervisors not assigning them enough work to keep busy, napping during work hours, shopping during work hours, being on vacation during work hours and not using leave credits.

my main problem i would address is to continue to minimize our website to make more friendlier for example ID me. I love the pizza effect we have with edets. I would love to see more offices with claim reps in them to process claims as well.

I have worked with a lot of helpful people, and am particularly thankful for the veteran experts with incredible depth of knowledge of the systems. I think some people, especially those people close to production processes, are very active and on top of things constantly.   Personally, I am trying to solve some imminent problems with our modernization effort. I am grateful to have received a lot of help from other teams and I am trying to personally solve some of the difficult problems I've identified, such as the lack of a complete end to end testing environment or the lack of business requirement parity on various modernization flows. I think it is crucial we solve these problems now before many critical SMEs retire, taking their knowledge with them.
Regular in person meetings! Remote work is effective and should not be eliminated, but having a couple of days in the office to interact as a team is super productive.
The budget crisis shouldn't be on the back of state workers, we took this job, we do our work and get punished for nothing we've done but for the mismanagement of the state. It's infuriating.
Telework has increased morale and decrease burnout.

There needs to be a better process for getting duplicate pay warrants issued. I often have employees waiting a month or more just to receive a replacement warrant. I like Cal Employee Connect but I think they could add functionality to it, giving the employee the ability to request their own duplicate warrant directly with the SCO.
Not giving clear instructions on websites
After conducting the survey, examine the results and determine what training is feasible that could be created by that State agency or another State agency.

IT projects typically follow one of two methodologies -- waterfall or agile. Waterfall is great for smaller projects when one can reasonably estimate the scope, time, and resources needed to complete a project. Agile is better when two of those items are a little fuzzy because the project is large, but it's the only way to get the project to succeed. I have seen projects fail because state control agencies attempt to run projects one way while the department they are overseeing wants to do it the other way. First, CDT needs to have clearly defined approaches for both methodologies. Second, as part of the pre-work (e.g., FSR part), there needs to be an open discussion between CDT and the organization that is undertaking the project about which methodology should be used for the project to level-set expectations. Finally, as part of the FSR process, CDT should insist on receiving an entity-attribute diagram for the data that is passing through the system, so that they know that the IT team understands what it is that they are trying to build. All three of these points will reduce the risk of IT project failure.

A primary problem is the number of antiquated and inefficient statewide processes still in place across departments. Many workflows remain manual or paper-based, which slows productivity and increases operational costs. The focus would be on leaning out these processes through digital transformation—replacing outdated systems with streamlined, automated, and user-centered technology solutions that improve both internal operations and public service delivery.

As someone who does a lot of state purchasing I believe that Cal PIA and the purchasing system around it creates massive unnecessary cost overruns that in turn not only hurts our budgets but also the wallets of the taxpayers. I understand the original intention of Cal PIA but I believe their reach has extended to far. Because of this many of my hours are spent trying to get purchasing waivers or thinking of way to get purchasing waivers because purchasing through Cal PIA would cost me up to 10 times the amount that a state certified small disabled veteran owned business might cost me. To fix this I believe we need to look at what Cal PIA currently produces and remove any items that are not at least closely competitive with these outside businesses prices.

I respectfully disagree. 2 days a month was optimal. My in-office days are a distraction and my efficient, head down, focused work is accomplished when I am not there. We all have different duties, so this may not apply across the board, but my work involves a lot of screen time, concentration and creativity. A downtown office is less conducive and I get less accomplished every day I'm there.
I would like to adjust the process for accepting contractor bids as a client agency to allow for more oversight for specialized projects.

Primary problem is communicating complex ideas and regulations that we work on to the general public. We need to figure out better communication channels and messaging, as well as ways to better process and organize the voluminous information that our state agencies process.  Possible solutions: exploring AI tools and technology to help organize, summarize and message complex ideas and processes to the public.

Southern District has a desk manual for operations Associates. We have several new Associates who are coming onboard in early September, so we have been updating the desk manual. Each Associate has been assigned to update a section of the manual. I think the Seniors specifically made sure that the section we work on this go-round is different than the section we worked on the previous go-round. The goal is for the desk manual to be a resource that makes it easier and quicker for new Associates to learn what their responsibilities are, and how to do them. And also provide a resource whenever an Associate needs to do something they don't do often.  Working on the section that I was assigned helped me understand that process better. Although no one looks forward to working on their assigned portion of the manual, the desk manual decreases snafus, and makes it easier for us to be both more effective and efficient.

I agree our department is the same way, candidates app goes to sacramento, they approve who we may interview, we interview then send back to sacramento who would like to hire, then they decide out of that whom we will hire. It takes 1-2 months to get it all said and done by then we call the applicant and their response is often thank you but I have already found a job.

Bureaucracy. Red tape. Lack of ways of measuring and awarding productivity.  Lack of organizational efficiency - too many layers of management (all the way to agency level and beyond), creating unnecessary communication and miscommunication issues, let alone time wasted digesting all the communications.
Yes!! Siloes are so inefficient.
HOUSING IS SCARCE WHEN COMPARED TO THE POPULATION - WE NEED A CONCERTED LEGISLATIVE APPROACH TO ADDRESS IT.

What I have seen work best is moving beyond discussions and actually implementing ideas. Measurable results for state agencies require significant projects, supported by proper funding, a strong project team, and effective project management with government oversight to ensure deliverables are met.  In my department, I have participated in several such projects that enhanced both customer service and internal processes. For example, we improved how customers contact us, streamlined the way they receive information, and even developed tools that anticipate and provide needed information before customers realize they need it. These enhancements not only improved efficiency internally but also provided a better overall experience for Californians interacting with the department.  At a more practical level, I have also seen opportunities to improve efficiency by making better use of tools we already have, such as SharePoint, Excel, and OneNote. Often, staff lack training or examples of how to apply these tools effectively. Within my team, we began using SharePoint as a case management tool and OneNote as a shared notebook to store and share information. These small but tangible steps have helped streamline collaboration, improve knowledge sharing, and reduce inefficiencies in day-to-day work.

For improved state government efficiency, I’d suggest waiting until the AI hallucination rate decreases before implementing AI into state work. As an example, Microsoft Copilot has a hallucination rate of 27% and some specialized technical models have up to 60-80%. While policy requires double checking AI output, it is incredibly inefficient and embarrassing to have to retroactively correct published AI-generated hallucinations. I have used Copilot for non-work purposes, but these inaccuracies make me extremely hesitant to use it for my work, which involves data analysis and coding. Why should we as state workers trust AI output when there’s a proven record of hallucinations?

Overall, I think the state training program is woefully inadequate. The two-week new supervisor/manager training is a waste of time and doesn't cover most of what managers actually face. There are so many leadership development and coaching programs in the private sector that could benefit state employees, like Harvard Business Review or Stanford. Lareg companies often have leadership development tracks. VSP, for example, has two types of tracks you can enroll in -- one for those wanting to become executives and a second track for those who want to be subject matter expert leaders (but not necessarily an exec). They provide mentors, hold classes, and you feel encouraged that you're proactively growing professionally.  Employee management training, specifically, is reactive instead of proactive. I've worked closely with performance management units to discuss personnel issues and sent emails or disciplinary plans for their review. Rather than being trained ahead of time, before issues start, I'm stuck with escalating issues waiting for PMU to review emails and provide guidance. And then their guidance changes frequently depending on what they've recently experienced in court. It's immensely frustrating.

I have requested access to AI with staff members that have that resources to case note the meeting to have more time to meet with other clients that might have to wait longer to meet with me from weeks to days.

I would like to see more funding go towards rail transport. Sure, we have the bullet train that will be built by the time I have great-grandchildren, but cities could benefit from smaller rail projects much sooner!

The State Governments' resistance to innovation, technology, and change. COVID-19 forced many state governments to automate outdated processes however we are still behind. Why doesn't state government spear head the forefront in innovation? This statement is inclusive to a majority of departments not all (i.e. departments that still utilize paper time sheets). California state departments vary greatly on the spectrum of technologically adaptative, there should be a baseline. California is known for its innovation it's time we embrace the technology we have and collaborate with our citizens (i.e. Google, Tesla) creating government contracts.
Lack of training for new employees.

I am writing a process and procedure guide for everything my team does, because "ask so-and-so" is not a procedure. Also, "so-and-so" eventually retires! I have also streamlined some of the processes under my purview to eliminate redundancy, updated our forms to meet current needs, and developed an online file sharing site for our team, eliminating the need to store any paper files for our unit. I have turned some older paper processes into electronic ones, eliminating the need for submitting "hard copies" to request our services. I am continually looking for ways to improve access to our services and designed our external SharePoint page with this in mind, to provide resources to our staff in the most efficient ways possible. I share my ideas for ways to improve and often don't accept "that's just the way we've always done it."

Many of the challenges California faces stem from the high cost of housing and rent. This has been exacerbated by landlords who are not responding to market signals and who keep rent prices high, even when units sit vacant. California desperately needs a statewide vacancy tax, along with stronger measures to break up real estate monopolies that are driving up costs and making it harder for residents to find affordable places to live and start businesses.

We absolutely need more frequent, safer public transportation. If it weren't for telework, it would take 2 hours and 34 minutes via 2 buses and a train to get to my office (which was closer when I joined the department but moved during the pandemic). That's absolutely ridiculous and impractical to expect anyone to endure a 5 hour commute every day. I'd also love to see more clean energy incentives. I recently looked into getting solar for my home and would be happy to feed extra energy into the grid to make it cheaper for everyone, but after everything was said and done, with current incentives, I would pay more for solar than I would for my current SMUD bill. We also need to nationalize PG&E. They are doing a lot of harm in their pricing to our constituents.

I would address telework as the priority issue for CA state employees. The CA State Auditor stated in August 2025 that a one-size-fits-all telework policy does not work for employees or the state as whole. As a state employee whose work is entirely conducted online, I'd love to see CalHR and department management prioritizing a telework schedule. It allows me to get my work done in a timelier manner and prevents carbon emissions from commuting and powering office spaces. I believe it would also allow the state to be a more competitive employer and retain employees long-term.
Some continuity between different agencies
Improve the training process by increasing tuition reimbursement for licensing and certification.

Go electronic/modernize, we have so many papers/forms that we're buried in what's become garbage paperwork no one will look at ever again. The state's meditech software scheduling appointments isn't the same as CPRS that the federal VA uses so appointments are getting lost not being synchronized, if they could be 1 program all facilities use then would be more efficient. There are communication sheets from months/years ago we're told to save yet no one looks for them, it would be more efficient to scan these documents into a hardrive for storage instead of using up space on nursing stations already crampt.

Agreed, similarly job advertisements are far too wordy and some do not allow applying online, so it discourages would be applicants that can apply to multiple other jobs in the time it'd take to apply to 1 state job.

I've noticed problems with engagement in one's work. I've seen employees "work the system" to take lots of time off or get out of certain projects/duties. Some employees seem very bored and unmotivated, and as a result put out mediocre work. One way to improve this would be focusing on colleague relations, i.e., allow or encourage people to socialize and create a sense of community in the office (within appropriate boundaries, of course). If we all knew each other better personally and/or professionally, people may feel more motivated and part of a team that puts out good work. As someone who is newer to state service, I know this is difficult and often discouraged for a reason; however, allowing an environment where a lack of communication and respect for coworkers to flourish is detrimental.

As a Californian and state employee, one idea I would add is the need for stronger accountability in leadership. Many employees see innovative, research-backed proposals—like expanding remote work, modernizing hiring, or streamlining processes—dismissed not because they lack merit, but because leadership defaults to outdated practices or prioritizes optics over efficiency. This discourages staff from raising ideas and reinforces a culture where “do as you’re told” outweighs evidence-based improvement.  I also believe the state should re-examine how closely it aligns with corporate pressures. For example, enforcing return-to-office mandates to mirror private sector demands undermines both efficiency and equity, especially when research and state audits clearly show that remote work saves millions in costs, improves productivity, and reduces emissions. It is difficult for employees to trust in California’s commitment to innovation when decisions conflict with the very data the state commissions.  From my perspective as a Californian, a government that models fairness, inclusion, and modern workplace practices builds greater public trust. Investing in remote-first policies, skills-based hiring, and leadership accountability would not only improve the employee experience but also deliver better outcomes for the people of California.

The Administration DEFINITELY needs to take a look at all the reports that DGS requires of departments.  Every month it seems like there's another report that's needed, that requires tons of research and data collection from staff and facilities all over the state.  What are they used for?  They are very labor-intensive, and it seems like a lot of these reports just pull and compile information DGS already has in their fleet and facility databases.  Some of these reports, like the sustainability roadmap, take SO much time.  It probably costs each department at least a couple staff worth of people just to handle DGS' reporting requirements, and these are resources that could otherwise be providing services to taxpayers and fee payers. DGS should make a list of all the reports they require, do an analysis of what each one is used for and whether or not there's even a benefit, see where some can be consolidated or can be taken over by DGS since they already have the data, and then free those resources up so departments can better serve the public instead.

my co worker ordered me a standing desk about 8 months ago, and just received her third update on the delay in it arriving due to "manufacturing issues"....now it's expected in MID NOVEMBER! I could have just ordered an inexpensive one from Amazon or Costco! UGH

Also, leaders/sup/managers should manage employees by results and workload. This will help leaders to stay in touch while employees work remotely. They need to have biweekly regular meetings with staff to gauge workload, what results they have delivered, if they need help and why. Also need to develop better listening skills to listen to their employees. Leaders should empower teams to deliver success.

Data suggests that there is a lot of taxpayer dollars that could be saved by fully embracing as much telework as possible, while simultaneously consolidating the amount of physical space and building leases the state takes up. I would love to one day see the state consolidate multiple departments into something like the FTB campus, freeing up space by making telework the default work type for any position that does not require work to be done in office. Embracing telework in this way opens up state jobs to many more Californians all across the state rather than just people that live in a couple metro areas, it would reduce carbon emissions and traffic, as well as lower the cost of road maintenance in those areas, as well as be a huge benefit to the all employees. The FTB campus also has lightrail access, as well as a free parking lot, which would be a cost savings to employees who currently work downtown and have to pay for parking. the money saved from things like this could be used to help departments balance their budget and we would be able to better fund things that actually benefit residents of the state.  I know this is an incredibly lofty idea, and would require a lot of planning, but I think it could provide a great deal of savings, and would make jobs with the state more appealing to most people. if we as a state are committed at being the best, we need to embrace forward thinking tactics, not stick to "what we always have done"
Building SMART goals and providing clear RACI for all staff reporting to me.

Outside of pay. I would say the biggest problem is policies being made by people who have not done the position or did it when it was first introduced so they do not understand why certain policies do not work. Those making our policy and procedures should be do on-the-job training in the positions that they are making rules for every 2-3 years. This will help them with having actual hands-on and relevant experience to know why certain procedures cause unnecessary and additional work, that is to no benefit of our consumers and participants that need assistance. I would also say the lack of training when coming into a role.

The most prevalent issue that I have witnessed since becoming employed by the state is how poorly employees with disabilities are treated during the reasonable accommodation process. From my experience as an employee and union steward, it seems that disabled employees are treated like a burden during the reasonable accommodation process, especially if they are requesting telework. In most cases when the employee's doctor is recommending telework as a reasonable accommodation, departments will do anything to delay or deny telework as a reasonable accommodation. Departments have continually been allowed to ignore and violate the ADA, EEOC, and FEHA policies and regulations and oppose doctor's recommendations for appropriate reasonable accommodations.   As a whole, the state needs to hold departments accountable for following appropriate policies and regulations pertaining to reasonable accommodations. More timely processes and procedures should be implemented. It is unreasonable to allow each department's EEO unit/section 90 days to investigate themselves, while not providing an employee with a disability their recommended reasonable accommodations. A more consistent and streamlined approach needs to be developed to help support California's employees with disabilities to better provide them more equitable and inclusive work environment when working for the state.

I have personally streamlined numerous processes within my organization to make it easier for State staff to manage a program as well as easier for the public to access resources/services.  Honestly, it does take a lot to reimagine a process, in both time and staff resources...but, I find that most of the time, my department at least, isn't willing to commit the resources to the effort unless there is some grant for funds (usually Federal grants) and/or public pressure (usually bad press) to do so.  Without one or both, it is all about maintaining the status quo.

As a funding opportunity, I believe state agencies should be eligible to qualify for grant funding secured by other agencies. Many state departments serve sensitive populations and often rely heavily on the state general fund to support expansive services. While some grant funding or federal revenues are specifically designated for these sensitive populations, strict requirements sometimes prevent state agencies from qualifying directly. To address this, it should be encouraged that state agencies partner through interagency agreements to collaboratively fund relevant work where applicable.
I would like to see more efficient and safer public transportation. I would make the change to take public transportation if I felt safer.
uphold and strengthen progressive taxation. let those who have the most pay for services that uplift and empower everyone, so we can all be stronger, safer, and more productive together.
Recent advances in cutting the green tape like the Statutory Exemption for Restoration Projects has been helpful in getting restoration projects in the ground faster.

Agree. Every position I’ve had - severely lacks procedures or documented processes. Or they exist and are extremely outdated. Makes it so much more challenging than necessary when a lot of those never get updated bc staff don’t want to stay with the stress!

Majority of meetings could have been emails with project updates; instead, we are pulling employees off the project to sit in a meeting to hear everyone else's updates.  Instead, project leads should provide weekly reports with updates to the director or deputy director. This minimized the downtime where people on projects could be more productive.

I feel that the state should pay their employees better. I know fulltime employees, and even a manager who have had to live in their car because rent was too high. I know several employees who have to rent places with roommates' because rent is so high. There are as many as 8 people in a three-bedroom apartment. I also know several who work multiple jobs, sometimes two or three jobs in addition to their full-time employment with the state. That is just insane to me. If a state employee is working full time, there is NO reason why they should not be able to make it on their own.

Several problems really. But, the first is the integration of newer technology into the workplace. Each State agency has individual IT departments without a centralized, standardized model for operations. Yes, CDT exists, but they have limited control over which systems each agency uses. This minimizes their ability to provide statewide solutions to tech-based problems. It also means that each agency is essentially trying to solve their tech problems independently, sometimes without the necessary expertise to do so. This same idea applies to HR departments. Each HR department is under the guidance of CalHR, but often do things their own way. That lack of standardization causes issues in the short and long term, as policies and procedures are often more at the whim of senior leadership, without a larger strategy, and can even, at times, be in conflict with CalHR expectations. In both the CDT and CalHR cases, having these agencies be the owner of all IT and HR positions that are effectively deployed to other State agencies could resolve the lack of standardization across both critical functions. It ensures that every position receives the same base training for their respective fields, and even centralizes the hiring process for thousands of positions, freeing up other State agency partners to focus on their individual mission areas.

One of the simplest ways to immediately make government run more efficiently, is to institute full-time telework across state agencies. This would increase efficiency by enabling the ability of employees to get more done, decrease greenhouse gas emissions from personal vehicles, and save the state money by getting rid of excess office space.   Many state agencies also make the claim of wanting to increasing employee personal wellness, job/life balance, and spending more time with family. Full-time telework would solve these issues, and many similar ones as well.   It's time to move forward and embrace new ideas, and more efficient ways of doing things. This takes courage and leadership from the top, which has been in short supply these last few years. Full-time telework is an answer to more government efficiency at all levels, and California should act as the bellwether for all other States to follow on this issue.

A major problem in California’s state workforce is the inefficiency caused by outdated hiring and workplace policies. Rigid minimum qualifications and slow/ouutdated HR protocols block many talented candidates with modern skills from entering public service, which limits innovation and slows progress.  An even larger issue is the state’s approach to workplace flexibility. Despite state audits and extensive research showing that remote work increases productivity, saves the state millions in office space costs, reduces emissions, and improves work-life balance, some leaders continue to enforce return-to-office mandates. This is hypocritical for a government that speaks of innovation, equity, and efficiency while ignoring evidence that remote work achieves those goals more effectively than traditional office models.  To address these challenges: First, modernize hiring by replacing outdated minimum requirements with skills-based assessments and streamlined digital applications. Second, adopt remote-first policies that align with research and fiscal responsibility, prioritizing cost savings, efficiency, and fairness for workers. Third, strengthen protections against retaliation and ensure leadership training emphasizes equity, accountability, and inclusion.  By modernizing hiring and committing to evidence-based remote-first practices, California can move past outdated systems and demonstrate it is serious about equity, innovation, and effective public service.

-efforts to standardize plain/clear language communication -centralized data efforts -collaborative networks and peer learning (forums or working groups across regions/agencies)  -simplifying forms to make it easier for people to access service
I've updated our documentation and clarified parts that were confusing, streamlined parts that were overloaded with too much information.
Finishing reports despite ill-advised or supercilious edits from a dozen reviewers up the chain of command (aka: peanut gallery critics). :)

I feel a big problem is the lack of collaboration with other state agencies about processes that need improvement. I feel like we work in silos, and it would help us all tremendously if we could share more information with other agencies to find out ways that may work better. One solution could be to have forums where people with similar responsibilities/titles could meet and help one another.

Encourage collaboration and cooperation using TEAMS, (perhaps), across ARU's to ensure uniformity. It takes too long to get an answer while on VCC from management. There is a closed-mindedness that says everything must remain under the control of the ARU instead of Department-focused responses.

Outdated systems. Easier access to new technologies and platforms to streamline. Get outside of the paperwork, into automation. Yearly mandated training for employees for Microsoft Excel, Word, SharePoint, Adobe.

As a manager, we have to remember to value our staff as well as our customers. Sometimes this can be lost in the statistics of the job, showing that measures haven't been met. I have tried to find a way to make it a positive outlook instead of consistently negative. Staff should feel motivated to provide the utmost customer service since our customers are the public. That can be hard for some that constantly get negative attitudes from the public and then negative evaluations on productivity. At Fiscal Year-end statistics, I have compared the prior year statistics to the recently completed year and show the improvement in percentage of reaching our goal instead of just the negative comment that we didn't reach our goal again for another year. I think this helps the staff stay engaged and motivated to attempt to meet the goal in the coming year.  There is always a reminder that we are a public service agency, and we are here to serve the public and educate them on the information they need.

I have discerned that CDCR Case Records tasks can be defined and governed by four accuracies: 1. Accuracy of Legal Document Review 2. Accuracy of Data Entry 3. Accuracy of Penal Code Compliance 4. Accuracy of date calculation.  This provides a framework for correctly assessing each task, correctly identifying the pertinent information, and correctly applying the information.

Forms, processes, systems, and software are extremely outdated. Suggesting the State maybe have one large contract with Microsoft or a vendor for supplies that way we all have access to the same quality of resources.

Really listen to the feedback you are receiving from this engagement. On the topic of telework especially, state worker feedback has been abjectly ignored and shut down. It makes me skeptical that this request for feedback is coming from a place of actually wanting to hear out our concerns and learn from our experience, and more from a public relations perspective. It looks good to those on the outside that you ask us for input, but if it isn't put to practice, it will only further contribute to our disillusionment with state service. It is very sad because I chose this line of work because I believe in state service, and I want to help, but the system is breaking me.

1. The program Fi$Cal struggles to operate under large loads. It needs better infrastructure support to the amount of users that operate this program. 2. Increase the size of the IT force throughout the state. With so much of our jobs requiring the use of computers, there are too few IT specialists to manage the needs of everyday users.  3. Allow for POs to be pulled back from dispatch to correct errors that were not caught right away. 4. Create a blanket waiver for over per diem on hotels during emergency responses for incident personnel.

We need more protection against fraud. There are too many people who abuse our generous social programs such as EBT and SSDI by falsifying their applications. I've seen people say they live elsewhere and pay rent so that their benefits are more than they should be when in reality they live with a relative for free.
Stop hiring incompetent and unqualified people in government positions.

I agree! Policy  and procedural information should not require jumping through hoops to obtain an answer for employees Knowledge should be shared, not hoarded. I do find there is a lack of mentor programs for the State. I requested a mentor years ago and have yet to receive information about mentorship options in the Department of Consumer Affairs.

The issue is case notes it takes too much time and it is hard to write down everything that took place.  Resolution: Give all QRP Counselors AI through Microsoft Teams and Zoom to listen to the meeting and draft a summary of the meeting what took place and what was the conclusion of the meeting. Counselors can proof read the summary make any changes then attached it to AWARE. It would save alot of time for the counselors and will give us time to do other important things such as meeting with more clients and make it more efficient to provide services to clients.

Include an implementability and cost impact assessment for all regulations before they are passed.  I've seen too many regulations get passed without much thought into how compliance can be achieved or how staff are to enforce the regulation.

This comes from the top. When you have engaged leadership (not to be confused with micromanagement), it truly helps.  For example, reframing that the people we serve are customers has been incredibly inspiring. The State does not need to market, per se, to get people to use their products. On the flip side, the State does not have to measure or iterate on an existing product. So that means we fall into the "we've always done it this way" problem.  Leaders who want their departments to meet the expectations the public has in their personal lives leads to innovation. If you can order food on your phone, turn on your camera with an app, certainly, you don't need to use Microsoft Edge on a desktop to fill out a form or print a .pdf to get your needs met.  Also it's important to seek ideas from the boots on the ground staff. They are working in lock step with customers and have already identified the needs that won't be met with a traditional RFP approach.

This is an issue in my division specifically. My division schedules in-person hearings upon request, which requires staff to travel hundreds of miles at the cost of $300-500 in travel expenses. Oftentimes, the public does not show up, wasting the staff member's time and needlessly costing the state hundreds of dollars in travel fees. Eliminating this in-person hearing requirement would be a simple solution to save time and money.

Remove the layers of hierarchy. I think it is possible to work in more of a self-managed team (shared leadership, distributed responsibilities, etc.), but in our current environment the various levels of hierarchy discourage taking on "more" responsibilities when the pay levels are so different. I think that if the levels of hierarchy were removed, teams would be open to working as self-managed team by starting to think and operate as a collective (vs. as individuals) - establish how decisions within the team are made, how conflict or tensions are resolved, how strengths are leveraged, how feedback is given, etc.

I believe that California's state workforce is encumbered by extremely hierarchical structures that impede its ability to adjust to change. Bad ideas come down at the speed of light. Good ideas float up and die at a glacial pace.  I'll also echo an additional comment I see. Many leaders at the highest level act out of fear rather than a collaborative effort towards improvement. They seek out numbers that validate their priors and generate reports that make themselves look GREAT... even if the ultimate endpoints of service are stagnant or getting worse.

More flexible public transportation.  Real income tax is about 42%. That what I see discounted from each of my check. And from whatever is leftover I pay many other taxes at general stores, gas stations and any other services. Taxation is outrages.

Lack of "Promotion in Place" opportunities. I completely understand the need to be transparent in our hiring practices. I just understand why there is not a career path available though promotion and good standing. Why does an employee who deservedly has worked towards the next level up, have to leave their department or agency to chase that next position instead of just having opportunity to promote? In my opinion, it seems to foster more job- hopping and loss of talent for agencies, where  retention would be a lot higher. just my thoughts for today :)
Yes, I have seen there are some efforts to improve processes or tools but they are not sufficient. We need to more.

One of my biggest daily hassles as a state worker is the dearth of parking in downtown Sacramento. Construction of new parking garages instead of more new buildings for those who cannot rely on public transportation would go a long way for many!

Poor communication is a huge problem.  Managers sometimes have zero training on how to effectively manage and communicate with their employees.  And the example and leadership really needs to start at the top.  Managers shouldn't be throwing curve balls and wrenches into things when they are not really, fully involved.  You should come in like a lamb and leave like a lion, not the other way around.  The latter causes confusion, chaos, frustration, and the former cultivates respect, efficiency, knowledge, and experience.

At this time, I have found it difficult to make meaningful changes within the state workforce because many ideas to improve efficiency are rejected at higher levels, and staff are often told simply to follow existing processes. While I have identified opportunities to streamline work and improve outcomes. Such as supporting research-backed remote work policies and digital process improvements. These efforts have not been implemented due to leadership decisions.  Although I may not have been able to directly change the system yet, I continue to look for ways to highlight data, share solutions, and advocate for approaches that align with research and employee needs. I believe that with leadership support, remote-centered practices and modernized processes could significantly increase efficiency, reduce costs, and improve services to Californians.

Email is overutilized for so many workflows. It is inefficient and hard to keep track of ongoing processes. Just having a simple to build form/document submission workflow with real time tracking data would be huge.

One of the primary problems I see in California government is that our technical infrastructure is outdated and creates unnecessary barriers for both employees and the public. For example, many departments are still relying on PDF forms for timecards and approvals, which slows down processes, increases errors, and limits accessibility. To solve this, I would prioritize modernization of internal systems by moving toward cloud-based, user-friendly platforms that allow for real-time updates, digital signatures, and mobile access. This would save staff time, reduce administrative burden, and increase efficiency across departments. Another major issue is how state departments communicate with the public. Too often, forms, notices, and websites are written in dense, bureaucratic language that can be confusing. I would recommend shifting toward plain language communication across all state agencies, making information clear, simple, and accessible to all Californians. Alongside this, we should invest in practical resources like website tutorials, FAQs, or short instructional videos (e.g., YouTube walk-throughs) that guide people step-by-step in accessing services or filling out forms. Additionally, California has many departments that offer overlapping or complementary services—such as the Department of Rehabilitation (DOR) and the Department of Developmental Services (DDS), which often work with the same populations but in different ways. Stronger cross-department collaboration.

As a state employee and Californian, I see the need to better support both our workforce and the public. For employees, expanding telework, ensuring fair classifications, and raising pay would strengthen morale and retention. Taking away telework would displace thousands of Californians who moved further out to afford housing, so maintaining it is essential for family stability, workforce retention, and the quality of service we provide.  At the end of the day, unhappy state workers lead to unhappy Californians and supporting our workforce directly improves the service and care residents receive.

Excessive programming, projects, and the associated encumbered funds. Over the years I've seen much waste. Some in inescapable since ideal systems don't exist.  But I do see: -funds encumbered for staff or programs that go unstaffed for several years. -Projects and programs and their associated spending that are "good ideas" but do not support greater objectives or strategies. -Overfunded projects and programs that don't seem to bring value to Californians when compared to other underfunded programs that do bring value. -Frivolous last minute spending to justify retention of "Use it or Lose it" funding resulting in acquisition and storage of unnecessary and useless materials that ultimately get thrown out years later. If a program has no need of the money, it should be let go for other programs that do have need.

Every year we lose homes to wildfires and these losses are preventable. We need to mandate home hardening and defensible space including zone 0. There will be strong public outcry but often the hard thing and the right thing are the same. This will be costly and we need to provide funding for those who need it to accomplish this. This doesn't mean the $100k it may take to fully harden a home, but the low cost retrofits that are most impactful, on the order of $2-5k. Fuels reduction and prescribed fire are great and can have beneficial impacts to suppression efforts and ecosystem health, but if we need the money from somewhere it should be taken from there. Of course it's sad when the wildland burns, but if there is no loss of life or property most folks won't be too heartbroken. Work in the home ignition zone is what will have the biggest impact. We won't lose 0 homes, but the losses will be greatly reduced. This is a fixable problem, we just need the will to mandate it. There can be a timeline of multiple years to reach compliance if that will make it more palatable, but this needs to have teeth behind it.

From my perspective as a California resident, a key focus is ensuring that state resources are allocated in a way that prioritizes legal residents and taxpayers. Careful management of public funds can help address challenges related to jobs, housing, and public services, ensuring that resources are used efficiently and benefit those who contribute to the state economy.

An issue I've noticed is that rather than improving on already existing legislation/regulations/rules, we create new ones. I think it would be more effective and clear to all involved if we edited our previous work rather than creating new places for people to find information.
Better management evaluations and hiring.  I would make a way for staff to evaluate them, if too many negative evaluations, they are not put into place.

One of the biggest things we are lacking are processes.  I just recently came into a position where a program has been in existence for decades and had no processes yet is one that is a critical part of what we do.  One individual has been running it for over 15 years and had gotten complacent because they have had not oversight not because there was not the want but because there is no bandwidth. I came in, did a deep dive analysis and put together a way to revamp the entire program, build new procedures that would benefit not only HQ but also the field.  We are implementing it as we speak and with that the employee who has been doing the work has a fresh and new hope on what this program can be.  It just takes someone taking the time and effort to learn about what is working and what isn't and put things in place to ensure the success in the future because bottom line is, we are all moving on and going to different places and we want to make things better than what we found them.

Having an overreaching library policy for the Dept of State Hospitals - right now we have a limited policy at my particular hospital and no consistency among other state hospitals. The policy does not address the types of books to buy nor is there a lead librarian among the state hospitals to reports patron statistics to.

Training the team and workforce to utilize lean six sigma methodologies to reduce waste and improve efficiency. It's an expensive investment for departments, but one that can foster a culture of continuous improvement and have positive outcomes for the populations we serve.

The biggest problem I have encountered as a state employee has been the lack of accountability or actions taken for toxic management. I have now been in two units where this was a problem. In one there was a mass exit of employees who had been there for a long time (including myself), and in the other, they had extremely high turnover, most employees using return rights and not staying more than six months. Exit interviews should be conducted for every employee, no exceptions, and taken seriously, with actions being put in place to retain future employees. In the first scenario, losing the long-term staff put a massive workload on those of us who stayed, causing a decrease in moral and a loss of historical knowledge, which lead to more staff leaving. The management's poor behavior continued and because no changes were made, the work environment was extremely toxic. In the second scenario, the manager was an extreme micromanager who would single out and belittle staff, frequently teaming up with another manager to gang up on a single staff member. I know these scenarios are not unique, which is why I believe exit interviews for each and every exiting employee are essential, but only if they are taken seriously, good or bad.

Invest in people, not flashy products backed by multibillion dollar marketing campaigns.  As Silicon Valley pushes their ideas of innovation and visions of the future, I can't help but feel that the basics are being ignored. Sure, there are a lot of things that can be automated with better software and the pursuit of efficiency, but we have fundamental issues that have hardly been addressed and papered over in the pursuit of an overly idealistic future driven by marketing and the unending quest for financial profit.  Particularly in this moment where students of all ages are leaning on AI to complete basic coursework, we are at a critical juncture for ensuring future generations can think for themselves. How can people govern themselves if they cannot arrive at a conclusion through their own thought processes?  Let's focus on improving the fundamentals before jumping onto bandwagons.
Make all payments issued by the state including state employee pay, electronic.

California is much better than the Federal Government was at trying to keep up with technology. As an individual who utilizes this technology to provide products to an internal audience, I am thankful for the state backing technology. Additionally, there a very few folks who do the same job as me, so ensuring that I maintain open lines of communication with those folks across the state is vital to work being done in a coordinated effort.

Creating policy and procedure overviews for a body of work, along with desk manuals for completing specific tasks, has helped new hires A LOT. This has cut down training time from 1+ years to 3-4 months before a new hire is ully up to speed and doing completed staff work.

I would like to see more collaboration to streamline convoluted processes between Department of State Hospitals and CalHR.  I would like to see staff's willingness to remove large barriers to increase results i.e. update minimum qualifications for positions. I would like to see, if there's isn't already, a time commitment to update MQ's. i.e. every 5-8 years.

I know the laws and constitution drive our legislature but are they aware of the impact on the budget and department that will take on implementing the program or service needed from the bill(s) they pass?
I think clear communication is a challenge, with the bureaucracy and so many scared to say the wrong thing so nothing is said instead. It really limits efficacy.

I agree completely. There are jobs that for sure can be done remotely and yes large amounts of money can be saved. The trouble the many of these posts is that they are only thinking of how to make their day better. Remember, the job we applied for did not list in the duties, taking care of kids or shopping. After 36 years of state service and raising 3 kids, there are sacrifices that are always made. After covid we became a society that has been taught that my life comes first. You're not paid for that. sorry.  State service is like all other industries that relate to service. You give to make others' lives better through helping or doing for someone. Lastly, someone mentioned that they work and those who don't should be dealt with. you are completely right whether in or out of the office. Unfortunately, it is much harder to see the non-work time outside. This is why many people are known to have 2 jobs during the workday or just playing. Thanks all.

Most of my calls and emails from the public center around one main issue - so I had to determine early on WHO I can farm these to that can take care of and respond quickly. This has been working pretty well. If the public were to contact this department directly they could be waiting for weeks (due to workload and volume).

Under the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act (WIOA), every state has to set up not only a virtual labor exchange system, which in the case of California is CalJOBS, but under Title I, a One-Stop Center, which in California are the America's Job Center of California (AJCC). AJCCs provide many wonderful services to the public including connecting jobseekers and employers; case management on job-related services such as resume writing, job applications, interview preparation; on-the-job training and apprenticeships; secondary and post-secondary education attainment; veteran services; assistance to migrant seasonal farmworkers; and, much more. Unfortunately, whenever people ask me what I do for a living and I tell them about the services we provide, they are oftentimes shocked that all of these services even exist. When I tell them I work for the EDD, they automatically think I work for the Unemployment Insurance Branch or Disability Insurance Branch. The primary problem is that I don't think the state does enough to spread the word of our programs and the AJCCs and their purpose. The idea I have to solve this problem would be more advertisement whether that be pamphlets throughout state buildings or TV advertisements. I haven't really thought about the logistics or cost of all this. I just think that there needs to be more information given to the public.

I believe we could do better when it comes to employee training, from the onboarding process all the way through the employee's career. Providing more classes that are free would help during these financially challenging times for the departments. I also think CalHR should have oversight on this matter to ensure employees are able to take advantage of the training that is available while also providing career guidance tools. Setting a minimum threshold for training hours per employee, per year, could help with this goal, along with creating a Career Support website full of tools and guidance. More education will result in better retention, a more educated workforce, and a reduction in sick hours because employees will feel supported and enriched. This will all lead to more production within the tasks that are required to run the state, which will save the state money over time. You see this in the private sector, from which many of us came from.
More public transportation options: fewer cars on the road allows for improved air quality and a healthier environment for all Californians

I previously was CA Police Department Records Specialist and took time off for adoption and when it was time to come back to the work for I wanted to use some of the skills I have learned at the PD and felt that the DMV was a good fit as i used the DMV records on a daily basis.   I have promoted to SMVT and now am able to share alot of my customer service and tech skill with my co-workers to help them either understand how to communicate in a better way or how to search and understand records that they are reading in a more effective way, thus improving customer service from our department as a whole.
I totally agree with you. I just wonder if this platform will actually ever effect change to the State's longstanding culture of self-promotion. Is the State too big to change?

As a California resident, one problem I see is that many Californians see State agencies in a negative light. To address this issue, I believe agencies need to be a little more transparent and also staffing issues seem to be a concern with the public as well.
