I also, utilize agencies for personal needs as required, and I notice that alot of the agencies have a negative attitude toward the public if they are not educated on what options or needs they need addressed, that being said, the state workers are not very transparent in explaining or assisting the public in that regard.

One factor contributing to this is that a small agency will be funded at the level it needs to carry out its core mission, but then there are dozens of mandatory auxiliary roles, so they've got one person wearing 20 hats and not really understanding many of them very well. Certainly there are some like the Ergonomics Officer where someone couldn't really do it remotely, but why in the world does each department need its own HR shop to do data entry when employees can submit address changes and withholding requests through CalConnect?
Working together as a team.

As a field inspector, I ask the State to consider satellite office provision and telework arrangement. Commute consumes energy and time in Southern California. One hour forty five minutes one way is not sustainable. In order not to lose experienced field inspector, please keep some flexibility on reporting to office in the coming 4-day a week schedule. Management can design a mechanism to evaluate employees' work and performance by quality and quantity of the field work, case load, etc.
Have provided direction and guidance on fuel reduction/modification actions to achieve fuel reduction goals while also benefitting natural resources.

Allowing individual departments and work teams to make their own decisions about telework would significantly boost recruitment, retention, morale, and productivity. Per the Aug 2025 report released by the California State Auditor, it would also save taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars and reduce the state's carbon footprint. Enabling staff at all levels to work from home allows staff to avoid expensive commutes and devote more energy to their work and families. As a manager, my observations have been that in-office work has done nothing to boost productivity among my staff and only hurts morale. If the state wants to operate at its highest capacity, it needs to recruit the best staff from across the state.  The best way to do this is to empower individual work teams to make their own decisions about telework.

To some extent, bureaucracy is "baked in" to our current legal system: the governor is elected and is answerable to the electorate, so while he delegates many things, the largest ones have to go through him for approval to implement. Volunteering is working without pay.  It allows the volunteer to participate in something they are interested in, find purpose and might even be passionate about. We can fill the empty space in government buildings with college and university classes instead of expanding physical space on campuses.  It would allow students to work closely with professionals in their chosen fields of study easily.  It would allow employees to learn current practices and skills in their positions. There could be an organization created of representatives from each department learning about each other, building relationships and working together on specific projects.

Government should design public programs to help communities respond to the needs of their own community members, rather than government programs replacing the way individuals rely on community.  Therefore, every public program should rigorously evaluate the extent to which programs, and the public resources they administer, strengthen real connections between communities, families and individuals who are in need.  One area of policy this idea could be applied to is homelessness services.  Every homeless person has people who love them and want to help them, but there is often no safe way for family and friends to stay connected and engaged.  Government spending should always start from a place of prioritizing ways that it can strengthen/rebuild a vulnerable person's connectivity to their family and community. That could include creating pathways for a caring family member to make financial contributions to a family member struggling with mental illness or addition that are dedicated to housing, to food, to pro-social activities.  Or to create safe environments that are dedicated to helping people in a mental health crisis reconnect to people who love them.  People only heal in the context of community and belonging.  Our programs should prioritize paying for things that rebuild those actual connections.

As a Californian and state employee, I’ve focused on improving efficiency and expanding our department’s reach through inclusive and community-based engagement. One example is how the supportive leadership of our Region Chief has allowed our team to strengthen recruitment efforts in historically marginalized communities. By having the resources and approval to participate in outreach events across the state—not just within our immediate jurisdiction—we’ve been able to share our message more broadly and connect with a wider, more diverse pool of prospective employees.  This approach not only promotes equity and representation in state service, but also makes our recruitment process more effective by reaching individuals who may not have otherwise considered a career with our department. Through these efforts, we’ve built stronger community relationships, enhanced public awareness of our mission, and created new pathways for Californians to serve their state.

I would like to see less concentration of jobs up in Headquarters. Southern California's needs are very different than Northern California and we need boots on the ground down here, like our own trainers, investigators, EEOP units, Civil Rights departments, etc. I would like to see to see a Division for every agency concentrated in SoCal. I find it difficult in my agency when training or investigations have to be funneled up through HQ and it creates a funnel of backlog to complete a request. We deserve to have our needs met as well.

The specifics of how the law is written would make a difference. I'm not saying that the state should not be a part of solving that, but it seems like there is always some ridiculous loophole where a government acquires a dump property, pays to fix it up, then is forced to sell at a loss or something. Lets have none of that.

The public perception of state service. It needs a glow up. Look at Meta's recruitment page, or Apple's, or Google's. It's a whole different feel. The psychology that's applied to tailor that feel is wholly different, hits different, and carries a different message. Just a step above public view of the DMV.

In my Department, it is not uncommon for it to take a year to refill a vacated position, leaving the work of the position either un attended to or (more often tan not) the responsibility of another employee who already has their own full workload. This also contributes to burnout.
Better public transport between major cities.  Not being able to take a single train from Sacramento to Los Angeles seems like a joke.  Why is a bus involved?
Much tougher regulation on private companies across all industries. Rent control. Stronger worker protections for all. This is California, we can be better.

At a broader statewide level, I believe that a universal statewide department cellphone app should be developed that cross-registers all state-required permits and licenses applicable for a business owner to operating in the state of California.  The purpose of creating a universal statewide department app is because each department has different information from the business owner. For example, one state department is notified timely that a business has closed or moved to a new location, yet another state department was never notified.  the unversal app solves this problem by streamlining the changes for all departments at once.   Also, the purpose of developing a universal statewide department cellphone app is to ensure  1. Efficiencies in collecting state revenues yet simplifying the process for a small business owner to register for state permits and licenses specifically related to their business.  2. Creating a universal database for state departments to track data.    Then, I would like to see that a QR code is then created for the business owner to use to easily identify themselves and could also be used for all the state permits and licenses held by the business owner.    Account changes to any state permit and licenses like an address change could be handled through this app and that the changes are in real time or within 24-hours.
I would say management in CMF does not communicate well and needs to follow policy more.

Onboarding and employee information access should be much more streamlined and centralized. For current state employees, perhaps combine CalConnect, myCalPERS etc into a central portal for state employees so everything from pay to leave to personal file to pension status would be in one spot with one login. It'd be like your state profile.

I like to say I prefer Towers to Silos since it makes for better cross-work with other skill areas. Towers have doors and windows to reach across lines. Silos are meant to keep things stored inside. Don't be afraid to reach across divisions to generate the best workable ideas.

Telework works! Legal residency and fear of deportation is a rising fear amongst many Californians. I would want to address helping non-citizens gain citizenship and/or permanent residency. If possible, I would implement a system that allows official business with the public to be conducted safely through email, text notifications, and secure online portals. This approach would provide instant communication, ensuring that more people especially those without stable mailing addresses can be reached quickly and reliably.  By transitioning to digital access, the public could view, complete, and submit forms electronically rather than relying on traditional mail. This would significantly reduce printing and postage costs, streamline processing, and enhance overall efficiency.  Number of the individuals my department serves are transient due to unstable housing, making electronic communication far more effective than mail. Allowing technology to replace paper-based processes would not only save government resources but also give the public greater control and faster turnaround times when submitting information. Printing and mailing forms require multiple steps and personnel, consuming unnecessary time and resources that could be better allocated elsewhere. For some people,  unnecessary delays and wait time for benefits can be quite catastrophic and we must at least explore a better process so that we can serve the public better.  Perhaps a more obvious one is simply finding a way to increase staffing to reduce backlogs which is significantly impacting the public my agency serves. Staffing shortage is very concerning.

A primary problem is the lack of data integration between state systems that serve California's industries. Businesses are often required to submit the same core information, legal name, address, corporate filings, to multiple, separate departments. This creates a fragmented and inefficient experience for them and for us. This data silo effect forces state employees to spend significant time manually reconciling information from different sources, increases the risk of data entry errors, and prevents us from having a clear, holistic view of industry interactions with the state. Solution:My ideas focus on creating a "submit once, use many times" data architecture through two main initiatives: A Unified Business Portal: We should develop a single, secure online portal to serve as the primary digital entry point for any business interacting with the state. A company could manage its profile, permits, and filings in one place, and that verified data would automatically populate across all relevant agency systems. A Standardized Data-Sharing API: To support this, we need to build a modern, secure Application Programming Interface (API). This tool would act as a universal translator, allowing our diverse departmental systems, both legacy and new, to communicate and share common data automatically and securely, eliminating the need for redundant data entry. To make this actionable, we could launch a pilot program integrating the systems of two or three key departments to prove the
This!!

Yes, I have seen opportunities where services could be more effective and efficient, and I’ve also tried to model that in my own work. For example, I’ve dedicated personal time to developing a proposal to modernize our departmentwide data infrastructure. I approached this both from the top down—by contributing to department strategic action to re-writing data preservation policy—and from the bottom up—by building user cases that demonstrate practical benefits. On my own, I’ve developed scripts to streamline workflows and integrate processes that were previously manual and siloed.  At the same time, I’ve found it challenging. My proposal for a modern data stack hasn't really 'caught fire' there. In fact, you could say it backfired on me. It didn't ignite innovation; instead, it felt a bit more like – drawing trouble to myself.  Things have pretty much stalled out. It's been a bit frustrating, to be honest – sometimes my ideas get totally sidelined, or I end up doing really repetitive, manual tasks that feel like a step backward.  It’s clear that breaking down silos and advancing modernization is larger than what can be achieved in my current role alone. Still, these experiences reinforce my belief that a more integrated, cloud-based approach would significantly improve efficiency and service delivery across the State.

The state exam for Deputy Labor Commissioner I and II are too much the same and it is not right that you have to take the exam for each position I or II.  These exams are very time consuming and one exam should be sufficient for both I and II.

There are a few, there are multiple examples of administrative layers that have created massive expenses which are intended to provide savings but do not.   Office of State Publishing. The mandate to pay more for a lower quality product is counter productive. The savings does not equate to the personnel and infrastructure expense. We can produce superior products for less in private industry.   Prison Industries, the requirement to purchase furniture from them at often prices exceed 300% more than the same higher quality item for elsewhere. We are forced to pay $700 for a $60 office chair. If it’s more than 10% over a competitor price for like item, we should have an automatic exception from the requirement to purchase from them.   Small Businesses. State mandated purchasing for high price items also causes appalling markups to costs. Though it may support small business it costs the state an exorbitant amount of money. Because of procurement limitations this essentially forces the state to pay 15-80% more for a product if it’s above $9,999. Our procurement limitations/rules create a massive expense to the state.   DGS auto inspectors. Again this one is staff and infrastructure overruns. In all of my years they have never assisted in saving any money, never disproved of any service. It is my opinion that they do not provide commensurate savings to come close to their cost to operate.

Totally agree, too many Chiefs. As the line providers, we’re constantly being scrutinized on every aspects of patient’s care. The autonomy is almost gone. Maintaining cultures where everyone is given meaningful work and a sense of accomplishment. I've experienced this and witnessed this at three different departments where people are not in hurry to get things done, and/or the opposite where managers keep work for themselves and don't delegate. If you look around and everyone is on their phones, there is a problem - low expectations or not given enough work.   My experience is that if you are stuck in this situation, the only remedy is to move on and find another job, but switching State jobs is no easy task. Promoting and transferring should be much easier, but that is a different post.

Working remotely has huge benefits to accomplishing my important work. I've started my position post pandemic, and the office I've been assigned has 2 other coworkers, which makes the many meetings I have untenable. I cannot concentrate in my office nor can I provide my services with two other calls in the background. Often, I meet with tribals and it feels disrespectful not to be able to give them the privacy they need.   Working in my office also drastically reduces my quality of life. My childcare is in the opposite direction from my office making pick up and drop off a burden. My quite home office allows me to concentrate on work and lowers the stress of my job because I can get my work done. I am healthier because I'm comfortable exercising at home and can make my own lunches.   I joined the state during the pandemic and I have never had trouble building relationships and collaborating with my coworkers. I've successfully been mentored and mentored while working remotely.   I believe that returning to the office will decrease my productivity and that of my fellow coworkers while increasing our stress.

Bring processes and products into the 21st century. No one should be filling out a paper timesheet. No process should require wet signatures.   Similar, software licensing. May be cheaper for the State to have a MS Office license, instead of individual agencies or departments having licenses. Same with ArcGIS, timekeeping software, or anything that multiple State agencies use.   The legislature should also take a close look at what reports they are getting and what they still want. There is an overemphasis on reporting, and many of those reports may not be relevant anymore.   Reform the hiring process. Exams are outdated and do not determine whether someone meets the minimum qualifications, HR does that. The exams often can only be taken over 12 months. What if someone is just a month short of meeting minimum qualifications, but they have to wait a whole year to take the test again? That does not seem fair or equitable. Make it easier to apply for positions. It is so cumbersome.

Making sure employees dont have concerns about financial mistakes costing them money back to the state through their paychecks. Rebuilding our local and statewide economies.    - Strengthening our education system    - Creation of new products, markets, businesses    - Creation of newer good-paying jobs and careers    - Lowering taxation across the board    - Creation of educational financial aid programs to help people who financially struggle to make it possible for them to achieve a good-paying career.

In the private sector, there are roles (IT Business Analyst) that sit between IT and the business that help identify opportunities to advance the mission via improved technology tools and/or processes, and serve to translate the business needs to IT and the technology constraints/opportunities to the business. This role has been absent in my government organizations, and as a result I see a reactive IT force and outdated tools serving the public. Agencies/departments should have such a role to proactively identify opportunities to better meet the mission/serve the public via technology tools; coordinate implementation, drive efficiency, overcome silos, and save on costs. One example: CNRA purchased a GovDelivery contract and negotiated so that all departments could use it - great! But when DPR (Parks) communications adopted it, they did not identify other needs within DPR which was using at least 4 different email services, and they didn't set it up well. The public was signing up for GovDelivery mailing lists that were never used, and some that were being used (i.e. State Parks Commission comms) were still being managed in an Excel spreadsheet list copied into Outlook (yikes). It was poorly implemented and misused because there was no role responsible for identifying the department-wide needs, developing an implementation plan, executing the implementation, training users, and staffing a department-wide administrator to manage the product after launch.
Considering of the cost of living in California, State Employees are experiencing compensation issues

Inefficiencies as a result of red-tape put in place be legislators that require us to take the lowest (overpriced) bidders instead of training staff to complete the work or hiring staff who have the requisite skills to meet California's needs. Also, inefficiencies due to the de-centralized nature of running administrative tasks, including human resources.

As a new state employee, one thing I have noticed is the lack of trust between leadership and analyst level staff.  There are so many steps to complete the most minute tasks, and those tasks seem to be complicated because leadership makes it complicated.  The strict hierarchical approach - at lease from my experience - has just created fear and insecurity about performing daily work.  There isn't an open forum to freely share ideas or talk about new ways of doing things.  We are relegated to a desk manual that is incomplete and doesn't actually allow anyone to think creatively.  I have been assured that every department is not like this, but I have also been told that I work in one of the best departments - so does that mean it's worse out there??  I would LOVE to see more flexibility, mentoring from leaders, allowing for mistakes, and basic access to leaders so we can ask how they got to where they are in the organization.  We look to our leaders for support and guidance.  When they only effort they make is to remind us about our timecards, that's not actually leadership.

We have a terrible habit in State employment of withholding info. There is ZERO reason that anyone working with or on a case to have all the information. Everything should be visible, and we should have better and more ACTUAL training
Or cancel them all.  Meetings are rarely useful.  Especially re-occurring meetings.

One of the primary challenges I see as a Californian and a state employee is the culture of leadership that often relies on the mindset of ‘I endured it, so others must as well.’ This approach can create stagnation, where old practices remain simply because that is how things have always been done. While this may maintain stability, it can also limit innovation and discourage growth among both workers and leaders.  I believe that true leadership development means breaking this cycle and fostering a culture where leaders are empowered to challenge the process, question outdated methods, and seek improvements that benefit both employees and the public we serve. By emphasizing open communication and a willingness to innovate, we can build leaders who not only draw from their experience but also strive to leave systems better than they found them. For me, ‘challenging the process’ is not about disregarding tradition, but about ensuring we continually evolve to meet the needs of Californians with greater efficiency, safety, and accountability.
inefficiencies due to outdated technology and resources. In my department so many processes are still paper and hardcopies that could be streamlined to computer-based technology.

The Performance Management process is too cumbersome for managers. Managers need to be able to effective and efficiently discipline staff that are not meeting expectations. Due process is absolutely essential, but it should not take years to terminate an employee. This is very inefficient.

Procurement is unnecessarily slow and tedious and filled with a litany of rules and subjective opinions on how to do business. It is quite inefficient to get things done and, when you can finally move on the work, you are left to deal with the lowest bidder. These practices are not in the best interests of the people of California.
Absolutely! We need across the board upskilling in a variety skill areas, including but not limited to leadership, conflict management, communication, AI, critical thinking, inclusiveness, and more.

Problem: 80/20 rule with staffing. 20% do the majority of the work, 80% do bare minimum.   Solution: Radical, trailblazing idea to overhaul state service and incentivize employees at all levels. Throw out what you about state service entirely. Clean slate. Ready? Here is the concept: Departments have employment bands. Imagine layered cake - at the bottom is entry-level band, then above that is the supervisor band, the analyst band, manager and, chief band. That is it for positions. Each band incorporates all jobs for those positions. Every 8-12 weeks, staff can rotate to another job - let's call them "missions". To move up a band, you have to complete X number of missions and have led X number of missions successfully. Every employee must complete at least 2 missions annually. This kills silos, creates an innovative and growth mindset culture, creates competition, provides constant learning and gamification, etc. Each mission you complete you get a deliverable in hand to show the work you did with a score for your input. There is a list and those with the most missions and missions led, with good scores, are at the top, a constant changing leaderboard. This leaderboard is used to decide who moves up a level when there's an opening. Pay scales with tenure, not position, so you could decide not to move up a band. Folks would need to be focused, quick learners, with high accountability, excellent collaboration... tune in to my next post to see how we find these employees!

Data sharing. I understand there are all kinds of legal/privacy hurdles we would have to overcome but if someone, including myself, is approved to view all kinds of FTI as is, there is no reason we shouldn't be able to pull data in other departments may have access to in order to make better analytical decisions about our own projects. Just as an example, if I'm working on an analysis to determine how a certain enforcement action may be disproportionately impacting certain subsets of California population, I can examine my own department's data but I cannot compare that to data about California's entire population, so I end up having to look for outside resources provided by private or non-profit sector groups where I can't confirm reliability. That is crazy. If I am working on a data analysis re: insurance settlement payouts, I should be able to easily access information collected by Dept of Insurance instead of having to do a Google search.

Educating myself, so that I can educate others. Making sure that my answer is not "Because that is just the way it is" and taking the opportunity to thoroughly explain to my fellow employees the reasoning behind policies/procedures.

Moving off the network drive and working in SharePoint. Better tracking, better version control. Drives me crazy when people attach files for review via email. Put on SharePoint and send me the link to review. We can then all collaborate on in real time and there's no question of if this is the correct version.

Housing! Housing! Housing! As a civil servant, I do not earn enough money to even afford a 1 bedroom apartment where I live. It would be amazing if the state could build more housing for low-income people who work full time, like me!   Allowing people to telecommute is good for the environment, reduces traffic, and increases a department's ability to fill positions. I don't telecommute myself, but I think telecommuting should remain an option. If more people could telecommute, that means they can live anywhere. Spreading out the demand for housing outside of the Silicon Valley, Sacramento, and Los Angeles may help decrease the overall prices in those already congested areas.   The state already owns a lot of land. Build work centers (hoteling?) for state employees in different areas where housing is cheaper. Build employee housing at places like Napa State Hospital to attract good candidates and keep them. We have a high turnover and our employees commute from all over. Our campus is beautiful and we already have our own police and fire department. Build little cottages that employees can rent for a decent price!  Or, provide housing subsidies for state employees who do not earn enough to afford rent in high cost areas.
Streamlined processes, reduced paper for environmental purposes and better record storage and access.

I have seen a lot of wasted taxpayer money due to the lack of modern technology and practices, as well as the state's refusal to create a space to save millions of dollars by allowing their employees to have a right to work-life balance. Many city and county agencies are far more advanced, provide healthy work-life balances, and provide proper training to management. The little bit of training provided is toxic and our managers are taught poor leadership behaviors. We as adults, are treated like children and are not allowed to have a work-life balance because management uses unfounded information to justify saying no to its employees. We have been told by our management that we are all replaceable and are not valued as employees and this is very disheartening. For our commissioner to feel that way about his staff is demoralizing. This message from the commissioner and management is not going to motivate us or drive performance. As a state employee, I previously valued my work, my team, and the contributions I make every day. Mutual respect would create a healthy work culture, but unfortunately, this attitude from management is creating the opposite effect. No state agency is exempt from the law and exempt from transparency.

Yesterday I attended California's 175th Birthday Block Party. I thought it was an awesome idea for the Capitol to host that type of event for the community. It would be great if we could continue the tradition and invite state employees along with the public with more advance notice/communication. It would be a fun way for state employees to network with each other and the public as well as promote all of the great services/hard work we provide. I think it is a great way to boost morale and pride working for the state. It would also be nice to have a speaker or a special guest come out as well to showcase California's talent!
Yes, less taxation and more affordable housing would make California more affordable for many, especially recent college grads and low-income residents.

State government often has excessive bureaucracy and administrative hoops. Examples include multiple forms and years of work to replace a vehicle, needing to work through multiple layers of staff to get approvals for things, or spending dozens of hours of staff time just to make simple purchases.  Much of this is expected for large organizations, and is cliche in its predictability, but nevertheless these inefficiencies hinder state employees ability to get their work done efficiently and slow responses to public needs.  Often the extra forms, steps, etc are in place to prevent fraud, waste, and abuse, but have the opposite effect in needlessly wasting resources.  An effort to consolidate processes, particularly around purchasing, would be very helpful.

I agree with the above two comments. I find two days in the office valuable to build relationships with coworkers. However, we do not need to be in the office fulfill our job duties or collaborate within or across teams because of the technology platforms at our disposal (Teams, Sharepoint etc.). A statewide decree for all state workers to RTO more than two days a week does not make business sense and fails to recognize the diversity of work that state workers do.
Accountability. We seem to create more unit/position to monitoring the problems instead of being creative, and hold the staff/management accountable.

I'm reading the comments and recognize some of the suggestions mentioned have been used at one time or another based upon the direction of the exec staff at the time.  I was sharing my vision of California State government equating it to a large corporation with consistent processes connecting each department within it with a friend who then corrected me in responding with each department is a company and they operate independent of each other.........which is what we have.  I think we can do better.  A member of the church I attend complained that they sell a publication to several state departments and they have to complete several forms from each department who is interested in purchasing their publication.  Lean Six Sigma is a good continuous improvement methodology tool as well as, total quality management and there are others that might be worth looking into. The State had an external directory and call center.  I like the idea of a Resource Hub for all employees.  We had an Innovation lab at one time.  Be great to have a Statewide lab and Statewide Resource Hub for all State employees.  Mentorship programs come and go. Cross Training that includes T/D (an opportunity to work in a position for training and development for a period of time) should be required of all departments.
Lower our gas taxes and stop chasing businesses out of the state by over taxing them.  Start cutting services rather than giving people more.
My office does this and I had never experienced it before. A new manager instituted it and it's been really useful so far.

It does take some time to network here. it can take a few years to get your head wrapped around who does what and you feel more impowered once you get a good network of likeminded working in the same direction folks. The good news is I have found far more good hard-working people in state service than not. There are a lot of really great people in state service who really care about their work.

Our leadership often makes reference to discussions happening on the CA State reddit page. I think it is helpful for staff across the state to have a platform to come together and discuss the experience of working for the state. I hope we continue to listen to actual feedback from employees and act on it.

Engaging in a working group with other state agencies, departments, and boards to quickly create a process to assist the public in accessing a suspension of laws in response to a declaration of emergency.

When I arrived at my current department, I helped my boss update all of the templates to better capture the information and tracking that we need as a unit and a division.   I am also working to update the email settings distribution system for a state-wide committee that I co-chair. This will enable us to access analytics about communication and participation rates throughout the membership.  On that note, the new executive over my division is focused on data-driven analytics, which I believe is critical to understanding problems and solutions when it is (critically) analyzed in conjunction with qualitative data.
Convoluted processing of everything (contracts, grants, hiring, purchasing). Instead of making it a way to ensure funds are being used correctly, it results in tons of wasted time and money.

I can share some general examples of how state employees have successfully improved processes and customer service:  Streamlining Application Processes: In some departments, employees have worked to simplify and digitize application processes for various licenses and permits. This often involves reducing paperwork, implementing online submission systems, and automating routine tasks. These changes can significantly reduce processing times and improve customer satisfaction.  Implementing Feedback Systems: Establishing robust feedback mechanisms allows departments to gather input from the public and employees. This feedback can be used to identify pain points and areas for improvement. For example, some agencies have introduced regular surveys and suggestion boxes, leading to actionable insights and subsequent process enhancements.  Cross-Training Employees: By cross-training employees, departments can ensure that staff members are versatile and capable of handling multiple roles. This flexibility can lead to more efficient operations, especially during peak times or when there are staff shortages.  Adopting Lean Principles: Lean principles focus on eliminating waste and optimizing workflows. Some state employees have successfully applied these principles to reduce unnecessary steps in processes, leading to faster and more efficient service delivery.  Enhancing Communication Channels: Improving communication channels between departments and the public can lead to better servic
Downsizing State agencies.  Combine like agencies and departments.  For example. Cannabis could be merged with ABC.  Stop creating new departments and agencies.

One of the issues that I have noticed is a lack of cohesion in local services versus state services.  In understanding both entities are connected with the claimant, we should work better together and have systems that support a unified effort in providing services.
Silos within and across organizations are contributing to inefficiencies and decreased productivity. Also, silos create openings for legal risk.

So many people agree with this because it's common sense & we wouldn't run our households this inefficiently but unfortunately the ones that makes the decisions don't think this way. In my agency they're creating another dept just to oversee another dept, it's ridiculous!
The State could do more to enforce recycling in public spaces. There is also area for growth on installing solar panels and upgrading charging stations throughout state-owned buildings and property.

i was selected, along with staff of all ranks from across the state, to work on a special project that streamlined in-office tasks, communications with our clients and vendors, and created a way for interested people to apply for our services on our external website. it was a very involved and intensive project that we worked on for years. The execs asked for our 5 year plan. great advancements were ahead, saving so many staff hours!  ♥ it's still in use, however, out of the blue, our executive sponsors shut it down.  just stopped any forward improvements, and still, will only allow us to fix what breaks.  it was heartbreaking for those of us who spent 50% or more of each workday on this project.  It's still going strong, but it could be so much more!

Utilizing shared smartsheets or logs to track/manage hiring packages. Allows for real-time updates without the documents getting "locked" when someone else is using them. Also taking advantage of the TEAMs ability to create a space to meet and add documents that can be updated by the approved users.

The job can sometimes feel isolating, even though there are so many departments.  And when we work in our district offices, you can start feeling like we are in a little bubble of our coworkers. It would be nice to see more state run initiates to get us to connect in-person. To get us to feel we are part of something larger than ourselves.

There are a lot of duplication within the State. Too many people are serving in the same capacity to do the same job. I also feel that it takes too long to onboard someone into State service. There are many people who want to serve the State but cannot wait 6 months to a year in order to get a job. I feel that once people are onboarded, there is a lack of training because there is no one who can train that person on the job they are expected to do. There needs to be a transition period when one person is leaving and another is coming in to do that job for the new employee to be properly trained in all aspects of their job duties. There also needs to be consistency throughout the State in the expectations of a job.

In my role, at a manager level, I don't focus on making services more efficient, per se. That isn't in my direct scope of work (although it may be in other's scope of work). In my role, my goal is to increase the quality, thoroughness, and the thoughtfulness of the work product. One small way that I have done that is to build a rapport with my staff, operate out of kindness toward staff, collaborate across teams, investigate all options, work to increase innovation and ingenuity, and also ensure that public facing products are high quality.
People working together, and having help if you are stuck on something.

To make California’s government more effective and efficient, we need to prioritize human connection in the workplace. By creating safe spaces, motivating our employees, developing their skills, and consistently reminding them of the value they bring, we empower them to become the best version of themselves. When employees feel valued and cared for, they perform better, contribute more meaningfully, and help build a stronger, more effective government. I believe in dreaming big, staying positive, and starting small, because small actions often lead to the biggest impact.

Miscommunication (or inefficient communication) slows down and delays public work. Creating shared email group and databases can help speed up notifications of newest updates, however it is up to the individual employee to keep up with and update fellow teams.

My ideas involve process improvement. Where are the bottlenecks in the processes and how can we resolve them. First, there should be increased access to information both internally and externally. Information is power and when we equip individuals with knowledge they may be able to solve problems.   Next, reducing crime and fraud in the State systems. Implementing systems similar to those in the State Fund Special Investigation Unit (SIU) throughout the State in other agencies to spot fraud. Finally, looking for what areas we depend on the Federal Government and begin to reduce that dependency. Chart specifically where we receive the Federal Funding and begin to systematically self fund those areas. If we are not able to self fund look at reductions or creating alternative structures. As the 4th largest economy in the world we should be able to accomplish this task.   Lastly, we need to create a State Insurance model for homeowners, auto and business insurance. We cannot be held hostage to national carriers that cherry pick and can chose to come and go from the California when it suits them. We can model rates and create programs that lead the way of the future in insurance modeling.

For State contracting, it is challenging when the Department of General Services has not provided any templates for contracts and solicitations. There should be standardized templates that state employees in a buying role can use for their contracts and solicitations. Similar to the CMA Model Template that the CSU and UC universities use. It's a required template used for all contracts and grants with CSUs and UCs. DGS should develop standard templates for contracts and solicitations that can be used by all departments. This would streamline the contracting process tremendously. It creates uniformity, and will increase the review and approval process by departments internal processes, as well as DGS' Procurement Division and Office of Legal Services. It would also impact the prospective contractors that are interested in bidding on our solicitations. If I build an RFP today, it likely looks drastically different from another department's RFP. The content may capture the same info - however, where the information might be found in the solicitation, and the formatting of the solicitation, would be drastically different from others. RFPs can be hundreds of pages, and can be overwhelming for contractors. A standardized contracting template, and a standardized solicitation template for things like RFPs and IFBs - would save the State time and money across the board. DGS, as the business manager for the state, should implement these templates in partnership with other teams.

Many agencies also lack reasonable promotional pathways that allow employees to stay in one location rather than having to "move to move up". So there is no opportunity for these experienced employees to train up a replacement, because there is no entry or journey level position who can learn the ropes. Instead, the person with the wealth of knowledge retires and then their replacement is hired months after they leave and has years of catching up to do with practically no guidance.

Amen! I just posted a comment about this matter! I can go on and on about the waste I see on a daily basis at my current facility/employer! We have 2 or 3 departments that are all tasked with completing the same mission and still fail...my example is just 1 of many and that starts with the grounds/landscaping duties/responsibilities! We have state employees (landscaping), patient work crews, and also the CCC who all are tasked with caring for the facility grounds but we still have a overgrown weeds/plants/trees, and trash/debris all over out facility! That's a wast of money and this is only addressing 1 department!

One way I’ve improved efficiency and service is by fostering strong communication and teamwork through shared meals at the station, such as breakfast and dinner. These gatherings allow the crew to check in with each other, delegate tasks, address needs, and build a supportive environment, which helps ensure daily operations run smoothly. On the public-facing side, I prioritize engaging with the community by visiting local businesses, being available to answer questions, and maintaining a visible presence. This approach builds trust, strengthens relationships, and helps us better understand and serve the needs of our area.

From my perspective as a Californian, I would like to see housing innovation that supports smaller footprints and community-centered living. Imagine villages designed around a farm or lake setting, where residents benefit from shared green space and sustainability. These communities could also incorporate city-based services such as foster animal programs, elder health care, and farmers markets. By integrating housing with local services, California can create more accessible, affordable, and vibrant communities that reflect both our environmental values and our commitment to quality of life.
As a state employee I would not be able to afford housing if I lived in an urban area such as the Bay Area. Affordable housing and increased wages would help all Californians.

As a California resident, I would like to see the following sometime in the future: less taxation on lower income, safer and more efficient public transportation, affordable housing, higher accessibility to jobs, and less redundant rules and regulations.

Do not require return to office. I find it a great benefit to have my team all throughout California representing our great work, interacting with communities and spending their salaries at local businesses. We are a rich and beautiful state and our workforce should represent all those living in rural, mountains,  coastal and urban communities.

I have been tasked as a delegate within the process and have created a spreadsheet tracker that could be applied to all the districts fielding the same types of exception requests which would add to the tracking and accountability of the individuals working on approving the exception documents but in order to improve the process as a whole bigger change is required from the top down approach. Starting with Headquarter taking what we are all saying and doing something about it rather than just accepting the status quo.

This is a great idea, to have supervisors evaluated based on the quality of work and the work environment of employees beneath them. Who is keeping management accountable for perpetuating this culture of fear and apathy?

The State purchasing and spending rules have not been updated to modern and realisting thresholds.  This creates an incredible burdensome and bureaucratic process for staff to accomplish our mission.   Purchasing limits need to be updated and then an annual COLA applied to keep them modern.   An example is still considering $1,000 a public works project.    $1,000 does not go very far for facility repairs.

Since the RTO order went out, the morale and the dedication of the employees have hit rock bottom.   My idea is to NOT have a mandate but rather make it based on the needs of the job. If a job can be performed fully remotely, then let those employees work remotely.   Those that are allowed to work remotely are more engaged, happier, more dedicated as their life / work is better balanced and this is also good for the environment as there are less cars on the roads.   Also maximum remote work helps hire from a larger pool of candidates which allows us to have more educated and qualified candidates and can hire the top talent, which is a major win and an asset for our state. Especially when it comes to professionals

I think technology and our internal workflows need a major overhaul. I started in January 2025 and was utterly shocked about how far behind we were compared to the rest of the country with business operations. I think our offices could greatly benefit from project management software and/or real customization of our software to makes us more efficient. Our office can't take any other payment other than checks, which sounds crazy to most of the public who walk into the office.  I see a lot of filing and literal paperwork happening in our office and we waste so much time "looking for files," which I feel is a waste of taxpayer dollars when we should be able to find what we need and do our jobs. And while it is great that we have a lot of long-time tenured employees in our ranks, we also need some major training overhauls once these updates are implemented.   I also think training when I started was haphazard at best. No one explained and has not since explained how to properly navigate our manuals, or how to navigate the legal language used. This also deeply surprised me as someone new coming into the state. My expectations was that their training would be top notch. Myself and it sounds like many before me had to teach themselves many topics. Our offices could benefit from streamlined training programs when folks start their positions. Not just about how to be a supervisor, the only training I got, but how to do the actual job and workflows, manuals, concepts, etc.

Guidance and access to the guidance and processes. Also, the lack of knowledge sharing among subject matter experts (SME) or not knowing who the SME is.   Example: We need to obtain signatures from our chain of command for approval of an item. Sometimes the need for wet/real signatures is required and sometimes electronic signatures are acceptable.
Continue to document the processes and keep the information current.  Kudos for your efforts to retain institutional knowledge.  :)

Management should foster an adult-adult relationship with staff and support and train staff on the concept of internal customer relationships, which is when one staff receives work product from another staff. The reason is that this environment ultimately better supports external customers. Management should remember that it is their job to ensure staff have the tools and information needed to get their jobs done. Sometimes staff are so bogged down keeping up that they are not current on tools and information. There should be a method for control and release of information to help ensure information is current and only the most current is available for use. Structure minimizes chaos and is sustainable.
Wow! Awesome. Great job!

As a California resident, it’s disheartening to hear negative perceptions of state workers. I take pride in being part of the workforce that keeps California running, and my goal has always been to help others. I've worked in healthcare, law enforcement, and now transportation, and each role has given me a better understanding of the diverse needs of our communities. I believe improving public trust starts with showing that we care, follow through, and serve with integrity. I’d like to see more efforts toward transparency, clearer communication with the public, and better training for frontline employees. As a resident and employee, I’m committed to delivering services that reflect the values and expectations of the people we serve.

I think every department/office/unit should have someone who answers the phone and can talk with constituents to either answer their question or direct them to the right person or another agency. We answer our phones, and people are always so grateful and somewhat surprised. Then we refer them to another office that maybe isn't so helpful and doesn't have a person answering the phone, and they are disappointed.  I know I personally get very frustrated going through phone trees when I have to call a retailer or other service provider. State agencies are supposed to serve our citizens and we should do that gladly and always. Phone numbers (and emails) should be up front and easy to find on all state websites.
I would love to see us get a raise!

Promote good managers who support their team and does not micromanage them.  Find a way to support the people who are the face to the People.   Good training programs for newer employees, help people to find ways to promote and good managers make for good morale.

Public transit could be vastly improved by expanding our light rail and bus routes and funding additional maintenance for both.   I would also love to see more single family homes built instead of even more apartment housing. We need affordable options for those who want to purchase a home that are not gigantic 5 bed 6 bath McMansions with no yard to speak of.  Bring back smaller homes that are not apartments or condos!

Let's address the budget shortfall and why the state worker has to suffer with loss of wage increases.  My concern is that the branches of the state are not getting wage cuts just the state worker.  Let's make this fair across the board.

I have worked closely with managers to modernize processes and workflow, including pivoting the office toward email vs. fax communication.  I have also reworked processes that were old, outdated, and redundant by reviewing the old process, identifying the issues in the process, rethinking the process, and then testing it out in actual practice to be sure that it adheres to what we're targeting.
Please stop balancing the budget by furloughing state workers. We have never kept pace with COLAs, more money can be saved by reducing red tape than penalizing state workers time and time again.

I would like to see clarity returned to remote work options for CA State Employees. I know the uncertainty over return-to-office mandates has caused me additional stress and uncertainty. The promised work-life balance was a big reason I chose to work for my department.

In my job I have two supervisors. One person promoted from in the department but under a different career and one promoted from within the same career and the difference is night and day. Person who promoted up the same career field, listens to subordinates, takes in what they are saying, looks for and applies what the policy says to do and includes you in the process. The other person, who worked for the same department but in a different career field, asks questions, waits for about 3 words to come out, cuts you off and tells you to do it their way, whether it is within the policy or not. Communication is key. The first supervisor might not know all the answers but takes time to make you feel included and you needs/concerns were met while getting the correct answer. The state needs more leaders like this.
The legislature must rebuild the rainy-day fund or risk state insolvency.
Improving processes and new ideas are not welcomed.  I was laughed at for suggesting an improvement.

The State of California does not have competitive salaries and lacks in keeping up with the cost of living or industry standards when it comes to pay, equipment, software updates, and work-life balance. Many State Departments cannot fill vacancies with qualified employees, because they can earn more in the private sector or with city and county municipalities. We to improve the States image, be more competitive in the job market, and convince prospective employees on the of working for the State of California.

I help set up internal systems within the Berkeley Branch to optimize efficiency with service delivery. Communicating effectively with all team members has been critical. I am empathetic and compassionate when serving the public and I remind consumers of the policies and procedures of DOR when applicable.
One of the challenges in California is that residents often don’t feel government is transparent or responsive to their needs, especially when they face delays or can’t find clear information.

Since joining the State, I’ve encountered significant resistance when trying to introduce more efficient and effective practices. Coming from the private sector, I brought fresh ideas and a results-oriented mindset, but the reception from the Department and Branch has been far from enthusiastic.  Many individuals seem deeply resistant to change, clinging to legacy processes even when they no longer serve the mission. It often feels like trying to push a rope uphill—effort without traction.  For any meaningful reform to take hold, management must embrace and model a commitment to efficiency across all levels and tasks. Without unified leadership and a shared vision for improvement, efforts to modernize how the State of California operates will struggle to gain momentum.
Yep why do we have to complete mileage logs when the vehicles have telematics installed.

It is crazy that we have to pay to drive to the job that pays us. I know we get free/subsidized public transit, but that only helps if the public transit goes where we need it to go in a timely fashion.

The SCO Payroll Portal has been great and it could be better. Timesheets need to be digital. I know some departments still use physical timesheets, we need to move forward with new technologies to make our HR more efficient.

Orgnaizational Structure. There seems to be overlapping of leadership in layers, with multiple director level positions in addition to the main Director of an organization.  In some cases, program directors oversee division chiefs while also maintaining separate subordinate staff. This may lead to duplication of responsibilities, unclear lines of accountability, and inefficiencies.  That increases admin cots, slow/hold up decision making, and create confusion about roles and responsibilities as well as drawing resources away from direct program support.  Recommend consolidating director level positions. Redefine the scope of program directors and focus on strategic guidance rather than duplicating operational oversight. Basically, simplifying the leadership structure to operate more efficiently, reduce overhead, and strengthen the ability to focus on its mission.

State employees should be able to give evaluations on their supervisors. Many supervisors are clueless on whether they are doing their job effectively from the people that work under them. Employees are stuck just commiserating and vent amongst themselves while the supervisors are blind to their weaknesses and ways they could potentially improve.
A significant amount of our department budget is not reaching the proper consumer.

Yes, law enforcement units operating within regulatory agencies present many problems for law enforcement employees. This sounds very similar to Investigators at the Department of Health Care Services, who I learned are required to refer healthcare provider fraud cases exclusively to the CA DOJ for prosecution, harming County DA relationships. I heard Investigators in regulatory agencies (and probably others) work in programs that do not want them to exist, and the program's actions/lack thereof, have not led them to believe they are desired or valued. They also stifle their speech and do not solicit honest feedback. Regarding efficiency, these referral workflows are incredibly inefficient and take months just to pass the case over. Some cases get stale by the time they are delivered then a DOJ agent has to read the case and perform duplicate work to resume investigation.

CalPIA and OSP both regularly cause my projects to run over-time, over-budget, and under-value. Neither has any incentive to provide competitive service to the state. Setting aside cost and quality, their noncompetitive customer service experience costs taxpayers intense amounts of wasted staff hours. Any time I email OSP or CalPIA, even with a basic inquiry or status update request, I now budget a 2 week turn around before I can expect to hear anything in response. On a recent project, a private consultant had a California based publishing company produce a run of sample items for us in less than 2 weeks. To get OSP to produce the exact same item I have been waiting for 4 months with no end in sight, and I expect we will pay 2-3 times the cost.

If management doesn’t take plain language and human centered design courses I’ll scream!!!! I can’t take the time to re-read all these confusing jargon emails and be normal about it. Save that for the courtroom! It’s crazy making

One problem I'd like to address is the amount of unnecessary traffic created by work that could be done digitally. Every day, thousands of unnecessary extra cars are on the road for tasks that don't actually need to happen in person, which adds to air pollution and street/freeway congestion. This not only harms the environment, but also makes commuting harder for workers whose jobs truly require them to be on-site, like public safety or field staff. By improving and leaning into digital systems and tools to promote remote work, we'd cut emissions, ease traffic, and make it easier for essential employees to get there where they need to be.

I have been with this department for almost twenty years. I make suggestions to leadership and assist field staff on a regular basis. I return most email inquires within 24 hours. I provide training as needed to vendors, staff, and even management when asked. My experience is an asset and it's appreciated for the most part. I also point out our areas that need improvement.

As a Californian state employee with expertise in enterprise architecture, one primary problem I would address is the slow execution of projects due to repetitive and lengthy approval processes. A key improvement would be to implement a "Smart Approval Framework" that leverages a centralized repository of previously approved use cases. This system would use metadata tagging and AI-driven similarity analysis to identify when a new request closely matches a previously approved one. If a match is found, the system could auto-recommend fast-track approval, reducing redundant reviews.   This would not only accelerate execution but also promote consistency, reduce workload on review boards, and encourage reuse of proven solutions—ultimately driving more agile and responsive public service delivery.

To make workflows and services more effective, I start by mapping the current process to fully understand how it works today. This helps identify gaps, redundancies, and opportunities for improvement. Once those gaps are clear, I prioritize the areas that can have the greatest positive impact, and then design the future state around those priorities. For example, in leading the upcoming migration of the DHCS website from SharePoint to WordPress, I created a detailed journey map of the contributor workflow. This revealed where contributors were experiencing friction, such as redundant review steps and inconsistent remediation processes. By documenting these pain points, I was able to propose streamlined workflows, standardized training, and clearer content governance, improvements that will make the publishing process more efficient and the website more user-friendly.   Improved Version: Whoever is leading this effort should begin with discovery, connecting with department heads to understand their goals and priorities. From there, work together to build a shared vision for the future of California. Once that vision is established, you can integrate the issues and solutions identified from the ground up. This creates a two-way approach: bottom-up insights from staff and top-down alignment from leadership, which can then be captured in a cohesive diagram of the future state.

It would be great to increase the outreach to new state hires, as well as create more incentives for residents to join State service. Often private companies pay higher rates and the cost of living in our state is so high. Sometimes it seems like we are pricing ourselves out of the job market.

as a state employee and working for CDCR, I fell we don't let the inmate population grow as if they were outside in today's environment, for example not letting them make their own medical appointments within the institution so we can cut down on the appointments within the institution. CDCR Officers are also expected to become Office technician when Officers sole responsibility is security and to make sure the inmate is accounted for, not check in and out after their appointment with medical. I believe if we as a department ran the medical areas as they do outside of the prison setting, we would be moving in the right direction.  CDCR also does not provide inmates vocational classes (i.e. HVAC, plumbing, etc.), so they can go out into today's society and excel. expand to job ready programs that way inmates can get a job once getting out and then we can offer more job fairs for inmates as well.

We need to find a way to make State government more efficient. I’ve seen more and more rules, regulations, oversight, and impediments added over the course of my 20+ year career. We need to be allowed to do our job, yet it seems like at every turn there is a roadblock— from hiring, to purchasing, contracts, etc.  All these regulations are not making us better, more honest, or more effective. We have to find a way to reduce the oversight and allow us to do the jobs we were hired to do— to benefit the public and gain their trust
More staff, boots on the ground, perhaps a new look to attract new staff for everyday duties. A possibility update why you would like to work at Parks.

In every position I have been, the 998 timesheet is an incredibly un-user-friendly document. This is a document that we all must use regularly, and it is so inefficient in its current condition. As I am not an accounting or Excel expert, my only idea to solve this is to RE-DO it so it is as clean and simple as possible. A bit of work on the front end would decrease enormous time on the backend.

As a state employee, I see one primary problem in the way new employees orientation is conducted. currently, NEO often requires multiple stae employees to physically present material, which uses valuable time and resources.  This approach could be modernized and made more efficient.  My idea is to fully diitize the onboarding process.  Core orienation content could be presented throug standardized, prerecorded modules that employees can watch, ensuring consistency across the state.  to keep it interactive, new employees should be able to submit questions digitally during the session.  a designated proctor could collect the questions and forward them to the appropriate department for follow up by way of email.  This solution would save both time and money.
More public transportation and affordable housing. I see some much new construction of housing in my area, but it is not really affordable.
I am a clerical employee and feel we are deeply underpaid for the amount of work we do in comparison to say a hearing officer who is paid far more.

California government spends money on things that do not improve our lives.  For example spending billions of dollars on a high speed rail line to no where and not adding traffic lanes to I 5 and US 99.  We are Californians and our cities are not designed for rail service.
Modernizing services to Cloud based, improving front end interfaces to make them more intuitive.

We are desperately under-staffed and it is difficult to keep people with institutional knowledge. Often the next promotional opportunity is in another district or another agency, which leads to loss of specialists. It takes a really long time to learn everything about a region, or just about how a particular agency works and which laws our particular work is governed by, and it slows everything down so much to lose that.

One of the biggest problems I've seen is centered around adoption of technology.  When FISCAL was rolled out statewide by the Department of Technology, the Department of Technology was among the last to adopt the program themselves.  The should have been among the first departments along with finance, to adopt the program, fix its flaws and learn it themselves before rolling it out every other agency.

One of the primary problems as a state employee is being subjected to the whims of ever-changing political climates. It often feels like state worker's voices are ignored by those who hold our future in their hands. Example: RTO to appease landlords despite evidence that it is a waste of time, space, and money. Solution: Listen to state workers, believe the data, stand behind your employees. I believe that California is consistently at the forefront of progress for many causes. It is what makes me proud to live here. We should focus on the big picture ahead of us. What do we want our world to look like? I would like to see a world that is fighting against climate change. A world that challenges the existing 40-hour work week status quo. I would like to see a world that utilizes technology to better the lives of human beings instead of increasing profits. How can California lead the way to that world? TELEWORK.

The state is pushing departments to contract with and purchase from small businesses and disabled veterans, which is great.  However, there should be a different set of requirements they need to comply with in order to do business with the state to make it worthwhile for them. We try to contract with SB/DVBE vendors but they don't want to do business with the state since it requires them to have a $1 million insurance policy.  That's a super expensive cost for them to do business, so how are we helping them by requiring this and telling them we're giving them an advantage?  If we want to help them out, DGS really needs to look at how that can be done. It's unfortunate that government gets in the way of them being successful when at the same time government is bragging about how much they're helping them.

Go Biz's Tracking Energy Development (TED) Task Force has been enormously successful at getting new electric generation resources on the grid in a timely manner. Their coordination across multiple state agencies is a best practice model.

One of the most difficult things about working for the State as a healthcare employee is having decisions made at headquarters in Sacramento that directly affect the lives of the people that I serve, often to their detriment, made by individuals who do not ever meet our clients or understand what they need. Decisions made by a top-down hierarchy often are made with administrators or managers in mind, and I think it should be the other way around. The primary role of a state worker is to serve the public, but often I feel that I am following regulations that are contradictory, don't make sense, or are needlessly burdensome at the expense of my clients for the sake of placating headquarters. I would want fewer top-down decisions; for leaders at headquarters to spend more time at the worksites they direct and oversee, to interact with the people who live there, and to pay closer attention to their needs and input; and more open communication from our leaders about what they are doing to address the concerns that we and our clients bring to them. Another piece that I think deserves a review is the State's policy of going with the lowest bidder for purchasing. Oftentimes, we get what we pay for, and products and services from the lowest bidders are also the lowest quality. There at least should be another metric we go by in addition to price, such as taking into consideration product reviews or how responsive a vendor is to customer needs.

I think policies and technologies need to keep up with the times. We are quick to adopt hot political topics and policies, but when it comes to implementing change that can benefit everyone, and likely even save money in the long run, we're not allowed to do it. There's a growing double standard on the needs of the state.

I have noticed many managers do not have a touchstone for what they do.  They do not have a structure for decision making and do not have a written process.  When a process changes, the information is dispersed word-of-mouth, take your own notes, no email.  It's like managers are chasing plausible deniability rather than efficiency and uniform process.  We have processes that make no sense AND what's worse, when a senior employee moves on there is nobody to explain a process - because it was made up of whole cloth or because it is genuine and correct but not written down.  I know there are other units that check our process to a point they never seem to notice these issues.

Problem: Public comment was received via telephone, mail, and email. This made it nearly impossible to fully review before the public meetings where decisions would be made.  Solution:  Implemented an online form to allow the public to submit public comment, and making it much easier and more efficient for our team to review public comment before moving forward.

Allow “regional” managers to approve purchases and services.  The multi step processes we currently must go through at the field level to conduct business all end up having to route through to several channels before we get a green light from top management.  Give managers at field level operation the tools and authority to ensure business can continue uninterrupted.

My program has procedures and desk manuals for every process. In all my years of service, I have never worked at another department that had desk/training manuals to help new hires. Manuals and procedures are updated regularly. Procedures are housed on our intranet, and desk manuals are in our shared drive. They also come in handy as reference materials when the SME is out of the office and their backup needs a refresher for completing a process.

I regularly see our Department turn to consultants to fill holes that should be part of our core competencies. This leads to cost increases, but even more troublingly it leads to a gradual loss of institutional capacity.

Please stop trying to change the world at the cost of being a Californian.  Our Smog laws and environmnetal Laws are not matched or adheired to by the rest of the Planet yet we continue to spend more and pass stricter laws upon Califonians to improve the world when the rest of the country is not participating.

Yes, require at least one meeting per month as a complete "team" (full unit meetings); I work in a unit here just the "leadership" meets to discuss the more significant issues. Analysts and other rank-and-file have gone a year without being included as a "team" in any substantive discussions that impacts operations. Many State departments consider AGPA's as important SMEs for these discussions. Not my Unit. There are the "leaders" and those with no voice-- hard to consider oneself a 'team member' when your job status has been exiled to silence.

training is great, but useless without accountability. I think often times people KNOW that what they're saying is inappropriate, but the current culture has embolded them to speak their deep dark thoughts as if they're acceptable.
I see examples of utilizing online resources instead of forms, mail, and appointments.

There is zero training for QRP's. Not even a 10-minute video.  We have huge case loads and come from different disciplines and yet no two offices do the same thing. Alignment and modernization is crucial for the success for DoR and aligned training is crucial.

The state faces many problems that telework could help alleviate. The state of CA can be a more attractive employer. We could lead in the space instead of trying follow the trends of the private sector. We have a completely different responsibility to the people we serve. Our "profits" are our efficiency and how well we manage our budgets and tax dollars.  We could lower cost, by reducing footprints. We can reduce environmental impacts by reducing commutes. Department should evaluate work and task that could be done via telework and in person.   With a concerted effort, managers can be prepared, trained, and supported. Expectations can be clear and departments can maintain flexibility.   In Person activities should encouraged, scheduled, and deliberate in with goals such as increasing collaboration/comradery. Trainings, in person-meetings, etc. should have the appropriate facilities available.   Finally, I think there should be more data available to make better decisions. Surveys for staff and managers to find gaps. Departmental specific dashboards etc.

I'll admit I'm no expert in organizational governance, but it has always struck me how fragmented CA's agencies/departments are. I think it's important to have decision-making independence for some kinds of agencies e.g., it might not be a good idea to have a Commission regulate itself, but does the staff need to be as separated as they are today? Maybe it should be easier to work on projects or tasks across agencies so good ideas can spread more quickly and agencies can have a better understanding of what their partners do and how they do it. This might be more true for the departments and agencies working on building things or managing natural resources.

Communication between supervisors and employees is a huge issue with every department I have worked in. There just does not seem to be ways to build as a team within when supervisor's don't take an active role in being personable and approachable to their employees.  Also, "suits & ties" at headquarters need to stop making decisions and changing policies when they haven't taken the time to get to know the issues and successes of the employees and supervisors. Administration should be focused on true employee wellness, not just making it look good for the public's eye. Part of that means being personable and truly transparent with staff members. Find out what they are really dealing with in their departments/fields.

Fragmented implementation, outdated solutions, and missed opportunities for system-wide transformation. Establish a technology procurement review board with cross-functional teams, cx strategists, and operational experts who evaluate not just on cost but scalability and integration, with user-centered outcomes. Existing systems are no longer effective.
I agree 100%!  Communication is key and we should strive to move forward as a team with no 'gate-keeping' of information.

I’d like to see the state make better use of the tools we already have access to at no extra cost.
