Since every employee has Microsoft Office tools available, we should focus on using these to improve our work instead of spending tax dollars on custom proprietary systems that could lock the state into expensive, long-term commitments.

One of the biggest issues I have seen in my service time is the fact that we are such a reactionary institution rather than a proactive institution.  It has been one of my longest and deepest frustrations from my time in rank-and-file to my time in management.  I would like to see us spend more time engaging with our employees from the top down and having thoughtful discussions on how some of these problems can be solved rather than allowing just the executives to make them.  I was an executive and having sat in that chair, I am well aware that we do not have all the answers.  It is the boots on the ground individuals that have so much to add to how we can be ahead of the game in some of these budget issues, RTW, and other critical issues we are dealing with.

The hiring process from the perspective of applicants can be quite complicated. Candidates often face numerous requirements when applying to state positions, which may discourage some qualified individuals. Removing the exam requirement could potentially attract more qualified candidates and streamline the process for all involved. This change could also lead to savings in time, resources, personnel, and finances over time.

Providing Better Customer Service: I supervise a team of 8 customer service representatives. I am part of Customer Service Center that is second to none at the State and Federal government level! This department has excellent track record for proving excellent customer service to Californians. I am constantly involved in daily continuous training meetings with my staff to better serve Californians.

We could also benefit from express buses that stop less frequently. Los Angeles has some of these and it was very efficient to travel across a main vein. Would love to see expansion of this in other cities in addition to rail.

Over the years I have identified two major inefficiencies in stat service: siloing and mismanagement. Siloing leads to duplication of effort across state government. When we conduct duplicative engagements with external audiences, it wastes their time and makes clear that we aren't coordinating internally the way we should. Collaboration and breaking down silos would lead us to be more efficient and make better use of expertise within and across agencies and departments.   Mismanagement is another very common problem I observe in state service. There are very few effective managers who support and empower staff to do their work effectively. Others are either totally checked out and non-responsive, or are some of the worst micromanagers I have ever encountered. So many times I see the state put forth goals for improving state service that ignore these issues. Hiring the right people won't matter if they don't get the support they need to do the work. Managers and supervisors need training to help them develop self-awareness, recognize signs of mismanagement in themselves, and grow to become supports rather than barriers for their staff.

Hiring - anyone who has already passed an exam and proven themselves eligible should not have to retake the exam/have their eligibility expire. Anyone who is already a state employee and qualifies based on years of experience for the next classification should also not have to take the exam to be put on the eligibility list, they should automatically be added. For example someone with 1 year as AGPA should automatically be on the eligible list for SSM1, someone with 1 year as SSM1 should automatically be on the eligible list for SSM2, and so on. It doesn't make sense to have to retake exams year after year for classifications you already qualify for.

I would like to see California reach out to a outside entity such as Texas and find out. How do they handle the unhoused situation and put it into action? We consistently throw good money after bad. And nothing is resolved.

Need a state-wide, electronic portal for reporting timesheets. Some departments are still submitting Excel spreadsheets filled in by hand, which is a very time-consuming process. People also have to learn new timesheet reporting processes when switching positions/departments - if it was standardized, this would be much simpler.

I think any sort of housing benefits would attract more people to be state workers. It could be a lower down payment percentage or something else. The generations nowadays are unable to afford housing, especially in California, and were sold the American dream that if you worked hard, you could afford a house. They're all disillusioned at this point and don't feel the need to work hard and contribute to society when the system isn't working for them.

Within California State Parks, there are ongoing issues with qualifications/hierarchy that creates ripple effects. The state has tried different ways to organize the hierarchy but what we really need is a park manager in charge of each park and the programmatic leads giving guidance for each programmatic area. What we have now are people doing multiple jobs to fill needs. Since that isn't recognized on their duty statement, they are not recognized on paper for it when applying for other positions. They also aren't recognized for it with any pay increase. This creates a very low morale and discourages people to stay within state parks, as they aren't recognized for the work they had to do to keep operations going. So many parks operate off of nonprofit partners, meaning ones without them are left with very few staff working far above their pay. It also creates a huge discrepancy in parks with areas with wealthy donors to nonprofits and parks in low-income areas.

Centralizing the state peace officer investigative positions into the AG or CHP would save Californian's money, allow for a greater variety of assignments, and be more consistent with models in other states.

I work for a very small department of a large State Agency with many different departments.  There is very little communication between the departments.  Improving communication could reduce duplication of effort.

I agree that a desk manual is needed.  A way to simplify the access and update to such a manual would be to provide an electronic version via Wiki or SharePoint site which can be modified/updated easily and made available to targeted audiences.

The core issue I want to address isn’t just about telework policies—it’s about a deeper, more entrenched problem within government culture: the tendency to default to “business as usual.” There’s a persistent inclination among leadership to repeat the same processes simply because they’re familiar and easy to enforce. This isn’t innovation—it’s inertia.  Take the push to return employees to the office four days a week. That’s a straightforward directive, but it sidesteps the harder, more meaningful challenge: making departments truly more efficient. It’s easier to mandate physical presence than to rethink workflows, modernize systems, or confront outdated bureaucratic habits.  The pandemic was a once-in-a-generation disruption that forced us to reevaluate how we work. It showed us that change is possible—and sometimes necessary. Yet instead of building on that momentum, many agencies are retreating to old norms. That’s not just a missed opportunity; it’s a failure to evolve.  The most urgent transformation we need isn’t logistical—it’s cultural. We must shift from a mindset of comfort and repetition to one of curiosity, accountability, and continuous improvement. Real progress begins when we stop asking, “How do we get back to normal?” and start asking, “How do we build something better?”

I have been a state employee for 20+ years and have seen many Bills passed without the resources and input by Program(s) required to implement the Bill included which causes ineffectiveness in implementation process and results in an increase in cost of staff time and cost to the regulated communities.  I had the privilege of providing input to the language in an Assembly bill in 2019 to the legislative team, which created a more robust Bill that Program was aware of and knew ahead of time how they could implement it in a more effective manner and outlined any resources that would be needed to do so.    To solve this problem I think that the authors of these Bills should do a exploritory process to get a better idea of the Program(s) their Bill would be effecting and have converstions with a Staff member(s) to have language the is clear and implementable, which makes it easier when the Bill is passed for Staff to implement.

Improper leadership is the biggest hurdle.   Often those who are selected to lead us are unqualified, hold old and rigid mentalities, are afraid of change and won't even entertain possibilities, are mediocre at best.

With the return-to-work order at a time when EVERY freeway going into and out of Sacramento is under major construction causing an increase in congestion, Teleworking and/or staggered work hours could help reduce the environmental impact, improve safety, and can greatly reduce the stress of commuting.  Public transportation is not always an option in outlying areas. Teleworking has proven to have a increase in efficiency and sharing workspaces can save money on overhead costs.  In addition, the increased costs of commuting will prevent most household budgets to frequent local businesses surrounding work locations.

In a decentralized department, stronger program management and tracking systems, greater process standardization, and more comprehensive leadership training (beyond online courses or webinars) would add significant value. Reducing the expectation for employees to be ‘jack of all trades’ would also help ensure that backlog work is addressed more effectively and that staff can focus on their core responsibilities.

Return to office has been a massive waste in taxpayer dollars and employee time, even the two day a week mandate. We should not be attempting to prop up downtown businesses and real estate portfolios of people who donate large amounts to political campaigns on the backs of the taxpayers and state employees.   As a state that prides itself in technological innovation and leading the way to fight climate change we should be mandating telework as much as possible. The rule should be if you don't need to physically do something in the office (open mail, hand sign/deliver documents) you should be working from home.

System software is often very outdated and we either can't access or can't *afford* to access updated software that will allow us to work more efficiently. Processes often seem cumbersome and disjointed. An example of this is submitting a travel reimbursement claim through CalATERS. I can only create part of my claim in the outdated Java program, but then have to email or mail all of my receipts and documentation. We are also in desperate need of access to quality project management software (such as Monday or Asana). There are many more examples. The outdated software we are required to use slows our work flows and wastes valuable staff time.

Leadership: The executive leadership team does not have the best interests of the department in mind.  Nothing kills a team faster than a leader who doesn’t trust them.  Leaders—your people aren’t there to make you look good. You’re there to make them successful. Without them, you don’t have impact. You have a title. Lead with trust. The results will take care of themselves.  There is misalignment, miscommunication, trust, and a continued need to break down the silos. Also, for women in leadership: women should be lifting up and celebrating the successes of others. There is a lot to be gained from learning from others.  Lastly, leaders, managers, supervisors: do not elevate yourself on the backs of others.
Right? Thanks to term limits, corporate lobbyists have stronger subject matter expertise than the legislators.

I would love there to be free trainings available on how to use Microsoft power bi. It's such a powerful tool but does have a learning curve. I think data dashboards are really helpful for making data driven decisions.

Modernize the civil service hiring process to be more equitable, including an examination of underpaid and unprotected non-civil service seasonal and part-time help. Address the strict, rigorous, confusing, selective, lengthy, maze of procedures that leads to possible civil service employment.

Direct supervisors who know their staff's capacities and trust them to carry out their duties has been the most effective dynamic I have witnessed as a state employee. While it does depend on hiring the right person with the needed skills, knowledge, and abilities, no process or method will be effective if employees aren't empowered to carry out their duties independently and with necessary accountability.

This is specific to the California Model of incarceration.  The California Model is not about money and it is not about modifications.  The California Model is about mindset! Change the mindset of the leaders and, through the principle of Extreme Ownership, we can collectively change the mindset of the staff and the incarcerated.  At this time, insufficient effort has been made to change the mindset of the policy makers and stakeholders at the top, so, as a result, we will never success on the front lines.
I feel the organization I work is so "top" heavy, which creates siloed departments within the organization and constant miscommunication and confusion.

Return office policy should be adapted to allow full-time telework for classification or roles that are not required to be in the office. This would expand the ability to recruit statewide, allowing for an improved competitive hiring process.
Antiquated procedures like time keeping/payroll which still use various systems across Departments, ranging from Excell spreadsheets to external systems.

Telework. I had a job officer that paid significantly more and was located closer to where I live when my current position was offered to me. I chose my current position because of the remote option. Telework offers the flexibility many employees desire. It also draws a larger and better pool of talent.
Using a database that is accessible statewide and to the public.

Grants - If I was running a business that $100,000,000,000.00 in debt, the last action I would take is to just give out free monies. Our Grant programs are horribly wasteful and inefficient where 50% of the funding often goes towards administration.
Greater work-life balance being taken into account can help motivate employees to work harder and achieve more. A revisit to the RTO mandate might be in order.

We need to improve iir K-12 public schools. Educators should be laid more. Schools should be fully supplied with everything they need to twach our kids. Parents and teachers should not have to go out of pocket to pay for school supplies.
I would love to see better wages for the cost of living that increases every year.

Doing the tasks with sincere efforts and going above and beyond the scripted job duties. I also see the hiring process is not conducive to picking the smartest people for the posted jobs. It is more artificial than a genuine selection of the candidates.

Training and transparency. As new employees to the state we do not know why, what, or where. If staff were told what we are doing, why we are doing it, how it affects others jobs, where each department is and the roles that each one has, it would bring a clear understanding of our job and how best to interact with each department

I have written procedures for various work queues in my department, eliminating the unnecessary steps and excessive language. Proper guidance provides better customer service through effecient work practices.

I have worked for the state for 15 years, and I love my job.  However, the most challenging part of my career was in my previous position.  The red tape was a nightmare.  Our team would propose ideas to improve patient care and/or provide education to staff, but we faced so much resistance that most people eventually stopped trying.  The culture in my last position within the state was the main reason I decided to transfer to my new role, which is a complete contrate to my previous experience.

I find that managers are frequently covering for their lack of knowledge and have no idea of where to get resources or are afraid to be found out.  They effectively need clergy or a "safe space" that can share actual process and facts to them without fear of being found out.  When people do not understand words, they can't simply be removed from instructions and carryon - this is happening and affects citizens.

In order to make things more effective with my consumers I provide better services by active listening, positive communication, focusing on the problem and finding solutions by maintaining a positive attitude.
I think the largest problem is keeping up with work orders and maintaining the highway. We have more requests than we are able to handle.

I work in one of the many Legal departments. I receive in service of process. When someone sues the department and its employees, it is codified in law that each person/department gets a copy of the document.  Just last week, I had an individual name/sue 30 different people. So per law, each one needed a copy of the over 500 page document.  We need to change the law so that we can take electronic service. That way instead of piles and piles of paper (where I scan in only one copy) and distribution happens electronically. What a waste of paper and human effort. I have heard the law needs to be changed. Okay, let's change it! This effects every legal department in the state and also anyone else who serves papers on anyone in any law suit.

The state spends millions of dollars a year on office space throughout the state. Allowing and promoting telework throughout state service will allow for that money to be freed up and spent on more pressing issues that affect all of California like homelessness, housing affordability, and lack of affordable healthcare.

Living in CA is expensive! I truly believe if you can work fully remote, let your staff do so to save money and manage their work/life balance. I have great staff who get more done than when they go into the office. If going into the office is truly for morale purposes, have it be one day a month where the entire building comes in to have everyone meet and do a team building event and not necessarily work. Then have an outing to do events in the community or eat out to support businesses.

Full time telework for all state workers. If any agency or department wishes to deny telework, it should be supported by verifiable data. If there is a legitimate need to report in office, the reasons should be specific to the state worker and their department, division, branch, unit, etc.

We need to implement solutions to minimize transportation costs and burdens. This includes continuing to offer telework, reducing parking rates and preventing spikes, accounting for parking at new government buildings, offering more public transportation opportunities, allowing for flexible work schedules, and maintaining and expanding our transportation infrastructure.
How can you take care of a child and do a full-time job? Particularly if they are under 5-7 years old?

It would be good if the GO considered the Leadership skills of appointees prior to appointing them. Or having a training program for them to complete on leadership. I've encountered several directors over the years that literally hide from staff because they don't know how to lead and answer tough questions. They don't have firm opinions or leadership skills to engage with their teams. They see themselves as 'too important' to mingle or engage with the line staff. You cannot lead of they do not follow... we need to add a degree of inspirational leadership to the qualities of our appointees.
1. Communication with lower staff. 2. Streamline process to cut out unnecessary review.  3. Empower lower staff to make decisions.

I would like to standardize templates and basic duties across agencies and departments.  Having to relearn the job that you were already doing elsewhere because the culture is different is inefficient.  Provide a standard writing style guide for Contracts and Procurements across the state.   Invest in a statewide procurement solution that all departments have access to. A way to track work, control who edits, and route for approvals. Maybe even tie it into the signature processes.  Something that would work for an analyst working in a small shop under 10 people as well as the large departments of thousands.   Ensure consistent and appropriate levels of training. This promotes the transferability of skills and ensures a baseline for promotions.  Provide information on how analysts can successfully promote through the ranks. Workforce development stops with Executive Assistants, Secretaries and Office Technicians. Analysts and other employees would like assistance and a clear, step by step process for how to promote within the state.  Offering Interviewing training as a part of the career growth.   Offer advanced analyst positions above AGPA or Research Analyst that does not require moving into management. Often people are subject matter experts, but that does not always transfer into leadership capabilities.
I am excited by the amount of departments who want to start using plain language. It's so important that we write clearly and without jargon.
Utilize shared spaces (e.g. Teams, WhatsApp, Slack) to communicate and collaborate with others.

A mentor program for first year or new employees who come into state service. Learning how the state functions, how long it takes for certain tasks or forms to be implemented can be daunting and confusing. Having a mentor or buddy to walk new employees on what to expect would be a great way to increase turn over and have employees engage with each other in meaningful ways.

I was responsible for the successful replacement and decomission of my department's main legacy application which collects near 200 billion dollars annually. This system was reaching end of life with no support so had to be replaced. As the project director, I planned, managed, executed and successfully deployed a Cloud solution to replace the againg applications. In doing so, I also identified new source of revenue which has been saving taxpayer $100,000,000 annually.

Where does the individual take responsibility? The government is not responsible for success, just equitable access to the opportunity. Education is of the utmost importance, parent involvement is paramount, job opportunities need to exist, and a realistic examination of the skills an individual has to offer the market can't be overlooked. Give a man a fish, or teach them how to fish... a lot of people don't like fishing.

Yes, the work that I can do from home compared to working in the office has only become for efficient reducing paper, reducing storage of records and becoming more streamlined.  increased Our management trust in and believed in telework and it has only helped us, from having a better candidate pool to choose from when hiring, to retaining our employees, to reducing the cost of rent, to reducing commute traffic, sparing the air
Prepared my own training for my new staff. Created samples to share with auditors, so they are not spinning their wheels on how a workpaper is supposed to look like.

As a 3rd generation Native Californian and a proud State of California Employee I love this state. It has everything one needs. Rich culture, beautiful scenery, beaches, mountains, deserts, farmland and numerous other rich natural resources. We are truly one of the most unique geographic regions on the planet. But all  State citizens pay dearly for the privilege to live here. Creating a more efficient government (cheaper but effective) and reducing the significant tax burden we all face would be a very welcome change.

Yes, but - I've seen where the SME jumps to the contractors because of the better pay, then the backfills don't actually know how to do the job, so they have to hire the contractor to get access to the SME.

I see this as well. Many old school management styles or dynamics can happen when we have this kind of mindset. We are adults managing other adults. We should avoid any kind of parent-child dynamic, which seems to be a more old school way to manage.

One problem I've observed is cultural. I think many people say something is "not their problem" and so we end up in a tragedy of the commons situation, where nothing is anyone's problem. In truth, I think each team needs to exercise greater ownership over the problems we can all see. Furthermore, I think people need to be willing to accept more responsibility when systems go down or when problems occur.
The staff I support have minimal resources, so i make every effort to provide as much as I can.

The telework audit showed that $225 million could be saved at the current two day in office schedule. If we were full telework, we could probably save even more. That money isn't chump change and could be used to better fund our infrastructure. Isn't the purpose of being efficient also being fiscally responsible to avoid deficits?
I think as state employees we need trainings available about microaggressions, cultural sensitivity, and professional communication.

I would like to focus on improving the basic needs which are shelter, safety, and community.  if California can just focus on providing affordable shelter and offer appropriate residency rules and quality education, everything else will far into place. We do not need to divest our attention to so many citizen or geographic specific issues.
Tax the rich more and give us public transportation

As a unit wildlife biologist working in the Bay Delta Region's Wildlife and Lands Management Program, one of the biggest problem areas I see comes down to a lack of staff, training, and resources to be able to effectively address the public's needs surrounding human-wildlife conflict education and response. For example, we typically have one biologist assigned to cover 2-3 counties in the Bay Area. That single biologist is responsible for managing thousands of acres of CDFW lands, responding to human-wildlife conflict incidents in the counties they cover, AND monitoring/studying various taxa of wildlife, whether it be threatened and endangered species on our lands or game species. The vast majority of the time, we receive calls from the public about injured wildlife or smaller wildlife that are stuck in netting or fences, etc., and we do not have the level of staff or resources to address such calls. Which leaves the public asking: "If animal services won't address this and you guys can't address it, then who will?" To which the answer is, sadly: nobody. We used to have temporarily funded conflict wildlife staff who could help address such calls - and we do not have them anymore - and our wildlife and public affected by such wildlife suffer the consequences - and it doesn't make the Department look good when we aren't able to address such calls on a more regular basis.  We also need to have a much better presence on social media and spend more time educating the public
Agreed! Plus "need to know" supervisor club slow things down when the lower levels are trying to get things done and don't have adequate information to complete the task efficiently.

Doing more work with less money  The "padding" of HQ and Regional office staff, as an employee at an institution, we have hiring freezes, but these offices are so "top" heavy and certain positions seem unnecessary in the scheme of things.
Having agenda before every meeting and cutting down unnecessary meetings.

I am not sure what department you are in but mine has a mentor program. I didn't know about it when I first started until I asked upper management. It has been a great program, and I put all my starting OAs in this program. I too wish that CalHR had the classification information. I have learned to network with others to get that information. Working in hiring, I do understand that just because someone is an OA and their next step would typically be OT doesn't mean that they don't qualify for an SSA or AGPA, skipping steps or maybe even a whole other possible route of executive secretary or way more. With this being said, I think this is why there is not what we are seeking. I think it would be too broad of a spectrum, especially since there are so many different qualifications for each position. I have been asking for years and have gotten the run around by multiple agencies. I would keep asking questions, network with others, speak to other people in and out of your department. Maybe speak to your department manager about your concerns and see what can be done about it. I always encourage my employees to come to me with their concerns, with a solution and be the change. We can always develop and be a better agency but without voicing it, we will never get better. I wish you the best in your career as a new state employee.

As both a State worker and a lifelong California resident, I would like to see hybrid work (majority telework) become the norm. California is known as a leader, and removing telework after it has improved our lives, the economy, and the environment is a huge step back.

One of the most powerful examples I witnessed during the pandemic was how it compelled our workplace to evolve. Faced with unprecedented challenges, we didn’t just adapt—we transformed.  We accelerated the digitization of our processes, shifting away from paper-heavy workflows and outdated systems. This wasn’t just about convenience; it was about survival. By streamlining operations and cutting through layers of bureaucracy, we empowered teams to do their jobs more effectively and with greater autonomy.  We also introduced flexibility for employees—something that had long been resisted. Remote work options, flexible schedules, and trust in individual accountability led to a noticeable boost in morale. People felt seen, respected, and more engaged.  Perhaps most importantly, we reimagined how we communicate within the department. Barriers broke down, silos dissolved, and collaboration became more fluid. These weren’t temporary fixes—they were foundational changes that made us stronger, more responsive, and more human. But unfortunately, all this under threat with mindset of we have go back to office and return of the old way of doing things mindset

I would cancel the high speed rail project immediately and divert the funds (if legal) toward improving the metro transit systems in California. For example, get BART extended to Vacaville, extend the SacRT light rail to Roseville, improve Amtrak service, etc.

Before we can provide lasting solutions to houselessness, we have to address the immediate problem of housing the unhoused. I see sprawling self-storage businesses that contain hundreds of garage-like storage rooms. It seems to me that these could be converted inexpensively to provide temporary, secure housing for people living on the street. Once in these converted shelters, service providers could be contracted to provide healthcare and social services to the residents. The state should consider purchasing some of these facilities and converting them into shelters.
I went to a training by Dept of Rehabilitation for inclusive hiring practices and learned so much. When I was interviewing, I was shocked that no one knows them or implements them.

Data exchanges between the departments and agencies are working well as pretty much everyone involved are recognizing their value. I am currently in DHCS and working in data acquisition part of CalAIM program.
I'd like to see some collaboration and think-tank style experiences between departments and across government to solve problems - like houselessness, or access disparity.

Yes, custom-built fiscal management software was built to manage contracts at my old department (Department of State Hospitals) to manage medical contracts and HIPPA -protected payments that worked really well (it was designed to replace a Microsoft Access Database that aligned w/ the legacy CalSTARS system).

Each team under a Sup or Manager or Leader should have a dashboard chart that shows employee turnover rate under their organization. These leaders should be measured based on turnover rate. If management and leaders are doing a good job, coach, grooming, motivating and addressing issues, turnover should be low.
Another problem I see is some workers are not serious with work. They do not communicate with peers

Great observation. The purchasing process needs to be streamlined and more efficient. The processes are archaic and cumbersome. It takes forever to train someone and the state spends more money in bureaucracy then on the actual item it is purchasing. We spend a dollar for every dime.

The hiring process for Park Interpreters is absurd. Interpreters must take a "test" that does not gauge interpretive skill. Analysts that do not understand what interpretation is then grade this "test" and qualify people for a job that is the opposite of analytical. Interpreters benefit from a varied background and utilize many artistic skills and abilities to convey an impactful interpretive message. Limiting qualifying degrees to science and history fields makes for a less diverse interpretive team and misses opportunities to connect with a diverse audience. Interpreters should be consulted for the interpretive exams, as this is not an analytical field, and an analyst will have no idea how to properly grade or qualify interpretive skill.

I feel like I put up with the same mindset continuously. The managers came from other departments and don't understand the work - they learned not to rock the boat and they will just stay afloat.    Suggestions are put in a drawer and we are told "they are being examined but he hasn't gotten back to us"

At our office every month we process 20 credit card statements, hard copies must be printed out and each including several pages of the same boilerplate we've been attaching for years now!!! The waste saddens me.

As a resident of California, I'd like to see the State doing its best to replicate European countries. From work hours, to medical care, and public transportation, we are in a position that could lead to very successful programs statewide.

As a seasoned CA employee, I see waste/fraud in the use of licensed BU 9 classifications. I would recommend an audit of all BU 9 duty statements to determine if a license is actually required to do the job.   I say this because I have seen the state increase the use of "licensed" BU 9 staff when a license is not necessary to complete the work. DGS' Division of the State Architect, the Building Standards Commission, and the Office of Sustainability, as well as CalTrans previously hired non-licensed employees to complete the work that does not require a license.   However, in the past decade these Departments/Divisions/Commissions have stopped using classifications that do require a license. The problem is that the work required by these entities can be completed by a combination of licensed and unlicensed staff, but by hiring only licensed staff, the state is wasting hundreds-of millions of dollars.   A licensed architect/engineer gets paid (after benefits) $250k/year or more. An unlicensed person doing the work that doesn't require a license gets paid $150k/year. Multiply that $100k/year savings by the thousands of staff at DGS and CalTrans that are paid for their license but don't perform license-level work.  By hiring unlicensed staff to do the unlicensed work, there is also an opportunity for the state to recruit and maintain staff.   But STOP paying licensed BU 9 staff to do work that non-licensed staff can do. It will save the state at least 1/2 a billion dollars.

Modernizing procedures and turning legal forms into plain language so that access to justice isn't hidden behind jargon. It makes it better for Californians, but also for those processing the paperwork. When people understand, the whole process goes smoother, even if the reason you have to fill out the form is frustrating. This doesn't mean dumbing things down, but thinking about them deeply to make sure we convey exactly what we need and removing any excess fluff. This takes a lot of thought, because it requires us to question why we are doing something, why we are asking other people to do things, and whether the current process really gets us there, in practice and not just in theory. It takes more work upfront, and can take some convincing, but it's really just applying a "measure twice, cut once" mentality to work. I've seen staff workload get lighter as a result, freeing them to do more in other areas (especially ones they're interested in). I work with a historically difficult demographic and I've seen these methods systematically repair our relationship with this population, making our work easier, but also allowing us to build on those improvements. Improving processes and providing better customer service, when done mindfully is a circle.

When I came to work here, there were people who had been here (in our HR Department) for 20 or more years. They did things their way, and did not like change. New people would join the team, and their ideas would be shut down. People were trained by people who thought they knew what they were doing, but never even sat down and read the law or bothered to do research. Proper training and an open mind are essential to growth and progress.
This is a great opportunity for all of us to make positive changes. If we don't address the gaps as we see them, who will? Let's keep our Golden State, Golden. Thanks.

"Interdisciplinary" Collaboration and Communication.  Engage "interagency" and other outside agencies/entities' participation and collaboration to address previous and current tasks, issues, problem-solving, etc. through meetings and discussions to reach a common and/or time-tested solutions.  This eliminates previously failed endeavors and duplicative work.

It is time to update old platforms and systems. There is no reason Fi$cal should be so hard to navigate. We need a more user-friendly system with drop downs and not tabs within tabs within tabs. The systems in place are hard to navigate and to learn.

Having all documents in one central location with a retention criteria embedded, which enables a more efficient way to retrieve documents and ensures HIPAA and security compliance via the electronic document management system my department uses.
Coming from Private industry, the comradery is such a fresh and welcoming difference to the gatekeeping I have experienced in the corporate world.
Plus, the deductions are about 1/3 of your paycheck.
When I started with the state, my supervisor apologized for giving me Meets Expectations, saying that the Execs would not allow Exceeds Expectations on probationary reports.

In my career as public employee I have worked for different state departments. I have noticed there is a huge difference in the type of software and hardware that is being provided. In some departments I have had to purchase my own ergonomic equipment due to budget issues. As part of title 8 make changes to the ergonomic program where departments are required to have a separate fund for office, and ergonomic equipment. Including software programs that can assist employees improve completing their essential duties. Increase awareness in workplace bulling and harassment. Make it a mandatory yearly training and provide more resources to employees to encourage reporting.

We are still using some tools and technologies in the State Government that are very old. There are numerous innovative technologies available on the market that can be integrated into the State Government's business, enhancing efficiency and effectiveness in delivering services and projects.  Explore possible innovative technologies on the market, conduct risk analysis, and take intelligent risks to implement them within the State Government. Start with some pilot projects, and if they prove useful, implement them across the State Government.

I initiated discussions that engaged higher-ranking executives. After identifying the key issues, I received approval to procure modern software tools to enhance our digital data collection and sharing from the field and office, benefiting everyone. I also prioritize continuous learning and make efforts to share that knowledge with others. It's amazing what we can accomplish if we take the time to learn how to use the tools we currently have. We need to have the approval to exchange this knowledge, which is not always afforded. I also created a SharePoint website for our specific division, which had no previous internal online presence. The site is used to publish and maintain information uploaded by anyone, creating an encyclopedia on how to accomplish our work. It's "grassroots" actions like this that are most effective, but can be stifled at times if the idea(s) did not originate from management.

Since COVID there has been a lot more automation of what used to be paper processes. Also, State websites and dashboards have improved, making it easier to find and use publicly available data and information.
Outdated technology has been a big obstacle to improving efficiency. Employees are often working on multiple systems and performing duplicative work.

In a previous role, I helped streamline the legal review process for marketing content. By tracking common legal edits and building a searchable database, our team reduced review time by 5–7 business days. The database empowered content creators to avoid recurring mistakes and improved overall efficiency. To keep it effective, we updated it three times a year, ensuring the process stayed accurate and relevant.

Good managers make for a good department!  Managers who value people who contribute and do good work, hold everyone accountable for their work, and still do their best to provide a positive and supportive organizational culture for all of the staff.
The high speed rail is an embarrassment.  California needs to cut back on regulations and be pro-business/development.  What a waste of time, manpower, energy and money.

Purchasing. We are required to purchase certain items from CAL PIA. Many items are much more cost effective to purchase from a local retailer even after the potential savings from purchasing from another state agency.  Also we are restricted on whats available.   Allowing a credit card purchase at a local retailer with supervisory oversite could potentially save a large amount of money, allow for better products and faster aquisitions.
Our triage lines we need to be consistent across every state agency
Similar problems arise from having EEO Officers report to departmental directors. Creating a centralized authority assigning investigators to departmental complaints would reduce this issue.

I would like to continue addressing the need for Californians with lower incomes (e.g., main source of income is Social Security) to have easier access to quality assisted living care when needed. My ideas for helping with this would be:  - An Assisted Living Navigator who can personally work with individuals and their families to help them take the steps needed to access funding for care.  - A one-stop portal (one-doorway) to allow individuals and families to make the linkages necessary to access funding for care. For example, an individual who qualifies for Medi-Cal and Medicare who wants to qualify for the MasterCare assisted living program needs to work with county Medi-Cal, their insurance, and a healthcare organization, and MasterCare to enjoin their insurance to access benefits.

It would be more efficient and successful in the medium and long term to use of state dollars for housing or direct cash aid to homeless and stop spending on money of "sweeps" that simply move around the people living outside and enrich companies that throw away peoples' belongings. Additional funding could be allocated from current law enforcement budgets while reducing the need for law enforcement ito manage/intervene unsuccessfully in these situations, therefore reducing their budgetary needs.

A "Save My Place in Line" System for All In-Person Services. The Problem - For services that require an in-person visit, like at the DMV, residents often must take significant time off work to wait in a physical line, sometimes for hours. This is lost time and productivity for the public, and it creates crowded, stressful office environments. The Solution: Implement and standardize a digital queuing system for all high-volume state service centers. Using a mobile app or website, a Californian could join the line for a specific service remotely. See their real-time estimated wait time. Receive a notification when it's their turn to head to the physical office. This tool-based solution respects the resident's time by turning hours of passive waiting into productive time they can use at home or work. It makes the experience vastly more efficient and user-friendly.

I wrote a manual for my project that was originally intended to just help me learn and remember the procedures, but it's become a team reference guide that we are constantly adding to and updating. It's been extremely helpful in getting new staff up to speed and has been shared with supervisors and project management to help them understand work that analysts do. My project team meets monthly to talk about ways to make our project more effective and efficient. We sometimes will review documents together and make edits in real time so that we all agree with process updates.
I think events, social media posts, and in meeting recognition acknowledging staff work goes a long way towards creating a sense of teamwork, support, and appreciation.
As a California resident, I would like to see us all treat one another much better.

Issue 1 - Lack of software and interface training for new and existing employees. Solution 1 - Make software training and tool updates easier to find and advertised. This includes Microsoft products and new tools.  There are tools out there we don't know about which can be useful as changes come, or new tools are available.  Issue 2 - Too much internal Spam. Solution 2 - Set standard subject lines for Department/Statewide emails to better filter them to email folders. E.g. use "Job Posting" at the beginning of the subject for any kind of new or backfill positions being advertised.  Issue 3 - Reasonable Accommodation (RA) process. Solution 3 - Allow 1st or 2nd level supervisors/managers to determine RA approval, and not have it go to headquarters.  IF denied, then the employee should have the option to push it up the chain.  HQ is a bottleneck and some folks have to wait 6 months or more for approval.  Issue 4 - Inflexible Telework Solution 4 - Allow more flexibility of telework schedule by having 1st or 2nd level supervisor/manager to determine viability of telework for the position and the schedule (required in office vs. remote time), instead of one size fits all coming from headquarters or statewide.  Issue 5 - Most forms not e-sign ready Solution 5 - Convert electronic forms to be e-sign ready instead of requiring convoluted procedures to "flatten" them.
Created procedures and templates to create uniformity among reports, emails etc. This cuts down on time, and ensures that everyone is getting the same information.

Flexibility for those employees whose jobs include after-hours duties. If employees are willing to work evenings and weekends when needed, having a supervisor that allows them to flex time helps boosting morale and supports job permanency.

Individuals who are hired to carry out a responsibility should have the authority to do so. Excessive oversight and approvals make delegating responsibilities useless and lead to hiring more people who are unable to actually do their work and to delays in processes and product delivery.  Employees at all levels should be empowered to take initiative to carry out the responsibilities of their role and be held accountable for their work rather than placing responsibility and accountability only in those at the top of the chain of command.
We have streamlined a lot of process at work too. It's nice to have training for staffs to perform better work.

Solve the compaction issue so people with experience will move up. It is not conducive to have a rank and file employee to have a higher salary than a manager. This is bad for morale and encourages people with less experience to apply for management positions they are not ready for.

Geopay is so overdue for those who commute long distances because they cannot afford to live in the counties or communities they work in. We also desperately need better housing and public transportation solutions - more affordable, accessible, and person-centered.

I would address the issue of need vs. waste.  I would suggest a questionnaire aimed at what resources were utilized, what resources were not utilized, and what resources were needed.   I would allow employees to verbalize if a particular resource is not needed and is thus wasting state funds.

Hybrid and telework environments have been extremely effective. Removing the ability to telework has caused a significant shift in morale. Taking another look at that, and how it could be more equitably applied, would be a good thing.

One thing that’s really helped improve our effectiveness is using a external SharePoint site to manage aspects of our program work and how we connect with our counties. Our external site has streamlined how we collect deliverables, track performance measures, and coordinate with local partners. Instead of juggling emails and scattered files, everything is organized in one place—report templates, meeting schedules, contact lists, policies and procedures, and scopes of work. It’s made collaboration smoother, reduced delays, and helped ensure everyone is aligned on expectations, deliverables, and timelines.

If a department of areas within a department are going to restructure/reorganize their structure they would be looking at staff strengths to determine where they may be moved to and/or they should also be consider an employees seniority within the department.  Moving employees around to have duties that are not a passion or strength is toxic for the work environment.  Picking favorites and moving them where they want is also toxic.  HR should have processes in place to discuss concerns from employees when they receive new duties.
CA State Government can model the benefits of remote work on reduction in commute traffic, less office space needs, improved morale and better work product.
I would like to see an effort to have independent audits for effective use of PYs for departments.

Use modern and efficient software. All of our software is outdated and convoluted and causes a profound waste of time, both for employees and the public. Refine the way we contract software development or purchase software.

This is not an issue for me, but State Workers should not have to pay for parking. State Workers should have a pay dedicated to paying these fees. It makes it very difficult to for them to get to their job's sites. There should be dedicated and safe parking for them.

As a risk manager, engaged in cross division conversations about risks, mitigations, and successes.  This was a significant step to breaking the silos within the organization and encouraging cross division engagement.

Bias Elimination Through Automation:  RAG (Retrieval Augmented Generator) systems make decisions based on explicit criteria, not writing quality. This is a LLM (Large Language Model) utilizing only documents that have been curated. Consistent application of standards regardless of reviewer mood or workload Transparent decision logic that can be audited and explained  Cost Reduction Through Intelligence:  80%+ of applications would never need a review by a human, dramatically reducing staff costs Human reviewers focus only on genuine edge cases requiring judgment Real-time feedback eliminates multiple submission cycles  Outcome Focus:  The system learns from actual grant performance, not just compliance Evidence-based interventions get prioritized automatically Continuous improvement based on what actually works for students, data would drive decisions.  Practical Implementation Notes:  Start Small: Begin with one grant program (maybe Perkins V) to prove concept and refine algorithms Data Integration First: The auto-population from existing systems is crucial - RAG works best when it has complete, accurate data Change Management: Frame this as "freeing staff to focus on helping districts succeed" rather than "replacing human judgment" Transparency: Make the AI decision logic completely visible to districts - they should understand exactly why they were approved/denied
Oversight over intelligent automation and AI. Problems involving this new technology may bring the government operations to a standstill.

Telework solves so many problems and I would like to see it be made permanent rather than live with the constant threat of it being taken away. What problems does it solve? It reduces state expenses, improves morale, makes state hiring more competitive, helps the environment, helps families, provides a highly desirable work-life balance, streamlines communication amongst coworkers, fosters innovation and creative thinking... I could go on and on. I can think of many problems I would like to address but telework is above them all and serves as a solution to most of them.

The primary problem that I would address is the homelessness and more advocacy for people with disabilities. The ideas that I have to solve the problem that I shared would be building more homeless shelters for people in the state, and having more advocation for people with disabilities here in the state as well. Plus the lack of training and guidance for staff.

I work for the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR).  One of the largest financial burdens of this department is the amount of movement made for inmates (i.e. transfers from one prison to a different prison).  Specifically, when an inmate's mental health level of care is changed to a "higher" level of care (i.e. to EOP, ICF, Acute, MHCB), the inmate is transferred "short-term" to a different prison.  This transfer takes multiple Correctional Officers driving across the state to take the inmate from Point A to Point B.  As the Mental Health level of care is temporary, they are transferred back (or to a new prison) within a short period of time.  The same inmates are transferred many times throughout the year, whenever their Mental Health changes.   In my opinion, it would be cheaper, more cost effective, and more efficient, if each prison had the appropriate staff at that prison to treat that inmate's mental health level of care. So... don't transfer the inmate from Point A to Point B multiple times; keep the inmate at Point A, and have on-site staff treat the inmate.    This would be a huge cost savings.

I love that mentorship idea! I work in a Sales office, in a non-Sales role and I'm jealous of their mentoring they do in groups of 3 on "ridealongs" to visit retailers, newbies shadowing veterans.   I'm an OT at a DO (division office) and came from the private sector so in the beginning I tried to set up a group chat with the other 8 OTs at the other DOs across the state, thinking it'd be a great resource for info and advice but somehow it never caught on. Silo-ing is predominant.

As an examiner, I worked with my colleagues located in Southern California to develop a suggestion box. Another examiner and I would collect the suggestions of our colleagues anonymously (because I believe some feared retaliation) and present them to upper management. This was discontinued because (I believe) the Upper Managers perceived this as a threat. Examiners were collaborating division-wide and providing constructive criticism and feedback and the "Managers" were threatened. As I consequence, I noticed we haven't had a division meeting since. Or, at least there hasn't been a division meeting where I was present.
The lack of collaboration between and within departments. I see overlap in projects but no collaboration.

There are many ways in which we can boost morale that need to be taken into consideration. Employees should not be paying to park to work. At my office, if you are lucky, you can find a spot at the lot that charges $8 per day. Some offices have a parking structure that charge $300 per month. We already pay with our time to commute, we pay for car insurance, we pay for gas, and to pay to park when we have to return to the office is a financial stressor for many employees. There are additional hidden fees of employment besides what is already taken from our checks. We had to pool our resources to replace the microwave, we pay for our water, the coffee, replacement of kitchen appliances, and mandatory holiday gatherings. We are told we have to attend team building events, but we are expected to pay or make the food and decorations. We are asked to give for food drives, for fundraising, for birthdays, and potlucks, and we give and give and give... I don't want to break even when I work after paying for food, gas, parking, and stocking my employer with appliances because we won't be able to heat or store our food otherwise. Morale isn't low because we lack a talent show. I don't want a party; I want free parking and free cold water.

More recognition programs for staff that go above and beyond. I understand that the state is in a deficit and can't give us the pay bumps that we all want, but there are other ways to show that our work isn't going unnoticed. Acknowledgment goes a long way.

As a CA resident and taxpayer, I would like the state to not spend $225,000,000 on unnecessary, wasted office space - use that money for something positive that would benefit the state, or pass the savings on to taxpayers.   I would like the state to ditch outdated policies that contribute to increased pollution ergo increased healthcare costs.   I would like the state to embrace 21st century policies that support families and work-life balance.
Management could take the time to talk with their team and create a safe space for suggestions on what is working and what isn't working.
Would like to see more long-term entry level positions or job extensions. It's difficult to promote and grow within my position when I have a limited term.

I feel we need to seriously improve our public transportation system.  It should be SAFE, clean, reliable, and better monitored.  Right now, I don't feel comfortable using it and driving isn't always a better option due to limited parking.

Rigidity! Combined with Variability... I think that are so many great things about being a public servant in California. That said, we are often hemmed in by overly rigid departmental policies that are too variable within the regulations that guide state administration. I think the regulations provide ample framework for control agencies to tell departments that their policies do not align. I think too often we allow great variability that becomes a liability when someone finally takes a department to task. And yes, I have examples/receipts.

Problem: Each department that has public-facing programs has its own database and systems to identify and serve people. A person must provide repetitive information to each department they interact with (e.g., FTB, DMV, EDD). Each department spends time and money verifying the identity of each person they interact with.   Solution: Create a centralized portal & database for the public to access all of the services provided by the state. A person gets one access point to see what's going on with all of their different interactions with the state. The departments get a source of verified people to whom they can provide their services.

Explore revising or eliminating core business hours to reflect new emerging technological capabilities and consumer preferences. A lot of consumers are unable to contact state agencies for services between the hours of 8AM-5PM due to work. Additionally, a lot of state employees would like the flexibility of an earlier or later work shift. Allowing agencies to offer both a day and swing shift would benefit both California consumers and employees.
Bring in honest feedback from the ground up.  Let it be safe and constructive.  This platform may be a good first step for that.

I feel the biggest problem I have experience is the higher ups in management/executive staff have no idea how their decisions affect staff. It seems they don't really care either. They make changes with no notice or input. Then they make staff wait For them to tell us how we can or can't make these changes in reality. I believe surveys/emails with input should be actually listened to and taken into consideration. Management should be required to learn how we actually perform our daily tasks.

To support the state's language access initiatives, as much as we have a bilingual certification process for state employees there should be a process to certify biliteracy too. In order to ensure the quality of state-issued written communications, the state needs a formal process to vet state employees for acceptable writing skills in target languages. Being bilingual is not the same as being biliterate, being bilingual is easier.

From a hiring and recruitment standpoint, I believe the state should explore implementing relocation stipends and location-based incentives in areas where compensation does not align with local housing costs.  For example, the Communications Operator classification in Siskiyou County currently offers the same pay as in San Diego County, despite the significant difference in cost of living — with housing costs in San Diego nearly triple those in Siskiyou. This imbalance contributes to low tenure and retention within the classification, especially in higher-cost regions.  If the state were to establish automatic stipends or geographic pay adjustments, similar to those used by the federal government and based on GSA locality rates, it could make these positions more competitive and appealing to prospective candidates. This approach would support workforce stability, improve retention, and help ensure statewide operational readiness across all regions.

Working groups with our internal business partners in other divisions (ie. the financial office or operations division). It's hard to work together when we don't really know how our partners operate. Getting to know them on a more personal level and understand the innerworkings of their processes helps us to help them and vise versa. We meet monthly about a specific process and are able to explain what each team needs to be efficient. It creates better relationships and more understanding.
Knowledge Transfer in the workforce. Ideas I have to solve the problem is provide the tools and resources to staff to know how to transfer knowledge and measure success.

CDCR's hiring practices take a considerable amount of time from advertisement to start date.  Processes need to be streamlined, from background clearance, live scan, reference checks to approval to appoint process.   CDCR is under scrutiny for budget deficit however we are being tasked to do more with less.  Safety and security comes at a cost and that needs to be recognized.  the cost to house the incarcerated have increased significantly especially with an aging population needing costly medical care

I have been involved in process improvement and system improvement efforts. I also regularly engage with County staff and collect their feedback for future program and system enhancements. I would love to see more County engagement for the programs that impact them in the form of focus groups or similar.

consolidation of duplicated roles or positions, eliminating unnecessary steps in developing and implementing policies and procedures, cross-training and developing personnel for "next-level" decisions, and development of thoughtful succession plans.

I always look at certain tasks with a continuous improvement mindset.  I have improved processes and suggested improvements because of that mindset.  However, I believe there needs to be big steps, innovative steps taken to do the business of government differently and better.  This takes teams of employees.  We then become "we" instead of the "I".  We are public servants and in my opinion should work together to fulfill the needs of the public which means we need to create a culture that enables each employee to be encouraged, to bring their talents, skills and experience to the table.  We need more pathways to promote so employees dont feel stuck or having to take a position not well suited for the pay increase..  I think we need to look at the successes of other state departments, maybe city and county departments within California, maybe the Federal government, of other states and even other countries, public entities (corporations, nonprofits etc).  What about other leadership styles, combining ones that will work for us.  If you are not in a management or exec position it is hard if not impossible to make or submit suggestions for changes that are considered and implemented.  So, that might mean creating a situation requiring input, actional input, decision involvement from staff level employees up.  That situation would mean replacing managers with leaders and a culture supporting involvement throughout the department.
Agreed, most managers only have state service experience, and internal management training is lacking.  There are far too many middle managers, and most do not have leadership experience.

In my department the middle management has been slashed, now nothing gets done and things are falling apart.  The upper level management are out of touch and trying to juggle too much to keep things moving at the field level.

Our Governor has made important strides, but he is missing the mark on one key issue. If California truly wants to reduce its carbon footprint, the solution isn’t to force everyone into electric cars, it’s to reduce the need for cars and commuting altogether. REMOTE WORK is the future. It cuts emissions, lowers costs, and allows employees to be more productive while leaving face-to-face gatherings for when they matter most, social and collaborative purposes. The Governor’s RTO order ignores both technology and the cost-saving benefits that remote work provides. It especially harms employees with disabilities who cannot safely or reasonably commute, even though they have already proven they can perform their jobs effectively from home. California should lead by example and show that sustainability starts with the state workforce, by embracing remote work, not resisting it.
Purchasing and especially contracting procedures and restrictions inhibit our ability to do our jobs efficiently.

100%. It is so discouraging to be in a cities that are more widespread and have incomplete and insufficient transit options. Where I live there are hardly any options, and not viable or accessible to all.
Business process digitization, transformation, and automation.   Top-down and bottom-up open communication, support, and willingness to change and adopt to using technology.

I would eliminate unnecessary boards, commissions, departments, and agencies. California is a big state, yes, but our bureaucracy has grown without boundaries, and we add new organizations every year. Gov. Schwarzenegger tried to streamline government, that effort should be resurrected.
Helped to install two additional phone lines last December to greatly assist our customers during the busy layoff season.

California doesn't seem like it wants to be competitive anymore and I'm worried our they want too much control. They shut down way too many businesses, schools, etc. during covid. It seems like they want too much control over how you raise your kids. There are other problems that need attention. We have lots of tech companies leaving. We can't seem to build anything -- high speed rail, nuclear energy, new homes after fires, potholes on every road, graffiti is everywhere, etc. State employees are the ones creating, implementing and enforcing policies -- can't just blame the Governor's office.

I would love to bridge the cap between being about to Telework and keep loyalty and culture. While I am old school and love the in-person culture, I am so much more productive when I telework (most are). We need to find a way to balance it. Keep culture by improving TW communication tools. Can't wait for the Star Trek days where we can join meetings by visually adding our image into a holodeck and it will feel like we are meeting in person. 🤣

The state is spending billions each year on construction, purchase and maintenance of office space. By allowing all positions that can be performed remotely to be filled by remote workers, the state could save California taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars a year on office space, equipment, and IT services, while simultaneously expanding the applicant pool for state government positions, and advancing equity by opening up opportunities for career advancement to candidates living in economically disadvantaged areas of the state.

I agree with the above statement, but also another aspect would be selling buildings as well as taking care of the unhoused situation by converting some of those buildings.And get the unhoused off the street and to quit, throwing good money after bad cuz. This situation is not currently working. But it can improve the situation of housing. The unhoused, the elderly as well as Making a situation a lot better. some offices cannot be closed or so because of sensitive information, such as taxes.But the ones that can be sold can be renovated for better use that can save our state money as well as it can go towards surplus, which is greatly needed.

This is a big question!  A problem I would like to address is that bans on harmful practices, products or substances often are passed with enforcement beginning years later.  These delays often seem too long to me, and when it comes to practices / products / substances that harm the environment and / or public health, to prioritize the need of industry to transition slowly is to de-prioritize public health and the environment.  Things that are harmful, like dragnet fishing, or PFAS in dental floss, to give actual examples, should be banned as soon as possible, rather than as soon as is profitable.  If it were up to me, I would have banned dragnet fishing immediately and PFAS in dental floss within 6 months.  Both were passed with several years for implementation.

My number one complaint about my department is that it is 100% reactionary and not proactive. Even when the path is clear of what simple solutions there could be, no one is interested in being accountable for it in the leadership. It makes it difficult to provide adequate support to the public and unnecessarily burdens the workload of the staff.

There are very few state employes that work in my job classification, so I think there is a lack of understanding of what we can do under our scope of practice to provide safe, timely, effective, efficient, equitable, and patient centered care. In my role, I have developed new policies and protocols, but without proper understanding of what we can contribute, we will continue to be underutilized.

State employees who drive a state vehicle for their jobs, such as inspectors, investigators, etc, have an assigned WEX Fuel Card to purchase gas while on the road.  With the transition to ZEVs, why can't these WEX cards be used at EV charging stations?  Especially Tesla?  Departments must either have a separate credit card number to provide employees on their Tesla app, which then subjects the card to misuse and unauthorized non-state purchases, or employees must use their own personal credit cards and then submit a travel expenditure claim to request reimbursement.  If a WEX card could be used to charge an EV, it would be so much easier for state staff and less work for accounting staff to manage multiple cards, process travel claims, and management to review and approve so many different payment mechanisms.  If the WEX card could also be expanded to be used for small repairs and oil changes, staff wouldn't need to spend so much time finding a repair shop that will accept state payment policies, and can also get repairs done much faster without downtime.
Seeing our public officials in public outdoor spaces would be great to see. "Connecting the face to the place."

Full time telework solves so many problems.  Many private leases can be cancelled to save millions for the State.  For staff that still must come into the office for a legitimate in person requirement (processing mail, etc), multiple departments can consolidate into existing State owned buildings.  The Franchise Tax Board campus would be a great place to consolidate these staff.  There are multiple buildings to house different departments with free parking.  Staff that get to telework 100% would be much happier and more productive at work and at home.  It was proven to work during the pandemic.  There was never a problem with full time telework and it didn't need to go away.  Staff in positions that can't telework would have something to strive for in future positions.  The State government would be able to obtain the best talent away from the private sector and offer a new incentive to work for the government.  Taxpayers would be happy to see the cost savings.  I suppose the only people unhappy with full time telework would be urban business owners.  It is said that urban areas hurt when people telework.  But there are winners and losers in everything in life.  For every downtown business owner that is unhappy, there is a business owner in the suburbs that is getting more business.  Let people live and work where they want to.  Less commuting is less polution and traffic, which also benefits everyone.

As a former Federal Employee, and current state employee, I think there is a gap when it comes to holding employees and leadership accountable to their responsibilities. While there are a ton of dedicated and competent employees, there are also those that utilize the protections afforded to public employees and those in unions to not meet even minimum potential. To solve this problem, I think we should ensure that employees and supervisors are being periodically checked in on. I have had three roles within the state government since 2021 and have never had a performance review or worked with a supervisor on a plan for trainings or moving forward in my career. I also think supervisors should undergo a 720 degree review - where they are appraised by their supervisors, employees, and themselves.

Haha, everyone in my department is going to think this one is from me. XD I agree wholeheartedly, but also we need better education at all levels about what plain language is and how it benefits both the department and their constituents. Too often I get pushback about how something is "too important" to be rewritten in plain language, even though you'd think plain language would be even more vital in that case!

I think productivity needs to be constantly measured to see if telework is actually benefitting the public too. Most of us our civil servants & should expect to deal with the public frequently. Not every position deserves to telework (think DMV). Also, learning is often more efficient when it comes from direct contact, not just through a 2-dimensional screen. We share ideas and goals better in person than relying only on e-mails, instant messages, telephones and video calls.
Duplication of effort due to silos. Centralized process yet streamlined.

The streambed alteration permitting program (EPIMS) is extremely difficult for the layperson to navigate and complete successfully. We receive requests for assistance daily, which distracts Environmental Scientist staff from other priorities. The helpdesk is understaffed, and the phone contact is no longer operational. Aside from scrapping the current program altogether for new in-house designed software (should be a top priority), a virtual in-program assistant would exponentially improve the end user experience, and scientific staff would receive far fewer assistance requests.

One issue that deserves more attention is the disconnect between state employee compensation and the rising cost of living across many regions in California.  While I understand that salaries can improve over time through merit-based increases in line with the classifications pay scale, the reality is that many state positions, some of which require degrees and several years of relevant experience, start out with compensation that is classified as low income under both state and federal income limits in numerous counties. These are not entry level roles, yet the starting pay often does not reflect the level of responsibility, expertise, or the cost of living in the areas we serve.  Public service is deeply meaningful and essential work. Most of us do not enter this field with the expectation of becoming rich. However, when experienced professionals are struggling to meet basic living expenses, it creates an external burden that can impact their ability to perform at their highest potential. Financial stress can affect focus, morale, and long-term retention, ultimately impacting the quality of service we provide to the public.  Addressing this issue would not only support the well-being of dedicated employees but also strengthen the effectiveness and sustainability of our workforce. Investing in fair and competitive compensation is an investment in the quality and continuity of public service.

I thin the state needs more consistency between departments.  I understand that each department has different directive and challenges, but let just start with having each department follow the same foundational naming convention. For example, HR should be titled the same in all departments. Budgets should be titled the same. Let's get some commonality so it starts to feel like we are all one basic community made up of different families.

I will respectfully disagree to your response only because one, as a state worker we cannot work outside the state of California; what this does allow is people who live in rural towns to get state jobs because they don't have to live in Sacramento where the majority of state jobs are located. And two, are people being less productive or are they just not sitting in the office pretending to work? I get distracted at work because anyone can walk by my desk and start a conversation which then distracts me from my work. As "organic" as these conversations are, they aren't better than a scheduled meeting via Teams. Since I focus better at home in my office, I can finish my work faster than in the office.
