I know this won't be a popular opinion, but I'd like to see LLMs integrated into workflows with the objective of reducing labor costs over time. I wouldn't want to see it displace anybody already employed, I'd like to see a workforce reduction through attrition. I'd want departments to put teams together that consist of employees of all levels who go through every workflow function to determine what can be automated or streamlined with an LLM. I wouldn't want it rolled out until it was tested by folks not on the original team. I know for my job, about 40% of what I do could easily be automated.

Some of the biggest changes that I have seen during my tenure with the state are the improvements to computer infrastructure such increased bandwidth, newer access points and servers, and more. These improvements allow us to work efficiently in the office and even telework. Previously, there were times in my office where one person was able to bring down the network with updates because the bandwidth was that low.

I've created PowerPoints and videos to help our Applicants and Grantees succeed in the tasks they are required to complete, like our online application system and payment request. We're planning content to facilitate online classes right now to make ourselves available to those we serve.
Staffing shortages need to be addressed. Every public facing department does not have enough staff to meet customer demands.

Our inability build capital projects in a timely fashion as well as the incredible soft costs built in by the Department of General Services.  We need to be more creative with use of Public Private partnerships and buying existing buildings. The same can be said for facility leases, it should not take a year to execute  a lease.  DGS as an ISF control agency has no incentive to advocate for Departments and keep costs at a reasonable level.

Our Fraud Prevention Unit developed an Onboarding Training program for new hires.  It is an intensive 7 to 9 month process of 6 Modules providing orientation, definition, skills, guidance, and procedures to give each new hire a clear idea of expectations.  Our onboarding includes a significant amount of simulations - interviews and research presentation, mostly - to provide rehearsal and experience before engaging in an actual investigation.

While public service offers meaningful work and job stability, California's large footprint means state employees may work more than 30-50 miles or half hour to an hour from a state office, with California's high cost of living - often times outpace state employees' salaries. This creates challenges such as:  Struggling to afford gas going into offices more than 2xs a week. Commuting long distances (adding stress and reducing work -life balance), difficulty retaining skilled employees in state service, overall increased pressure on mental and financial well-being.  Solution would be to retain the 2 day a week in office work schedule for state employees without negotiating a reduction in pay in exchange (2026). This effort will demonstrate the value that our current government feels about out state employees and their overall well-being.
State Parks should use Cash machines at park entrances, which should accept $20 bills and provide change (i.e. $5 for $15 parking fee)

Use an intake process, such as a project management tool or SharePoint form/list, to receive and assign work, and to centralize all related activity. This approach significantly reduces email volume, keeps all project information in one place, and makes it easier for colleagues and managers to track project status at a glance; the latter removes the need to send email/Teams messages asking for updates.

Virtual training gave a great resolve for COVID, I feel like the classrooms need to come back now.  People learn differently, but as a manager, I noticed that more of my new hires come out of their virtual training confused and unclear about the topics that were covered.  Some really don't appreciate the electronic platform because it's impersonal and doesn't allow them to feel engaged in the lesson.  I also find that the electronic platforms do not offer the opportunity for networking, which is so valuable as you move on in your career.  I also find a lot of these trainings are being cut too short.  My employees don't feel like they are being given the opportunity to really retain the information, which only sets them up for failure.  I am a "hands-on" learner myself, and so when my new hires tell me that they would have liked to physically handle some of the example processes, instead of virtually working through them, I can completely empathize with that.  New hires are going out into their offices and causing even more exhaustion and congestion amongst those that already know the job and are trying to slow down enough to help the new hires catch up.  I find that there is much more "on-the-job" training needed, but we are already so stressed for workers that this causes a major inconvenience for the office to have to pick up the slack where the training is lacking.   Conclusion: Bring back classrooms for "beginner" classes and elect dedicated mentors for new hires.

I want to see a better network of public transportation, both from one geography to another (for example, better train connectivity) and within metropolitan areas (for example, metros and buses). As the fourth largest economy in the world, it's honestly a little embarrassing that we are all so tied to our cars.

Using technologies that were burgeoning 10-20 years, while not keeping up with modern stacks. Promote courses that allow staff to stay up-to-date with innovative technologies and provide them access to them.

I would like to see the gas tax lowered to make fuel more affordable for all Californians. It is absurd that much of the fuel is produced in our own state and that we have the highest fuel costs in the country.
The state is behind the times in use of technology.  Implementing simple technology solutions would streamline some of california's biggest problems, save money, and improve efficiency.

Less paperwork for every day functions.  For example, we have fuel pumps and paper sheets to track the fuel usage.  It is subject to human error, and extra time balancing the sheets every time we make a fuel purchase.  If the fuel pumps had electronic sign in for unit number, and PCA code option, we would be saving lots of headaches and potentially recover lots of money that otherwise gets lost from the emergency fund.  if you had to punch in your unit number every time you filled up, through some kind of key pad, it would streamline that aspect of our department.  Look in to a company called Link2Pump.    Another note  I don't understand why the process takes years for me to get a contractor to fix up my facility.  Our building is from the late 60's, and If I ever want to get something done or fixed, the easiest option for me is to do it myself.  I dont see why having the lowest bid contractor shouldn't be able to start work in a few months. Instead im told it takes 3 years.  It is causing me more work in the long haul instead of letting a licensed contractor do all of the work.

Have the Agency do a cross check on their policies and procedures.  Each policy references a law.  Does it exist?  Has it been modified? Are we over regulated?  Many laws date back to the 19th century.  It's time we double check our policies.

The biggest problem is a forced, in-person in-office presence wherein physical infrastructure (equipment, cubicles/offices, conference rooms, etc.,) is lacking and employees are often still required to participate in virtual meetings. It is a waste of time, money, and other resources. Morale remains low which contributes to lower productivity.
I'm always looking for ways to streamline what we do, get rid of the middle steps that aren't necessary.  It's hard sometimes because others have the attitude of "that's how we've always done it."

Ther needs to be emergency spending exemptions that remove the bureaucracy and allow the agencies that are responsible for emergency spending to get it done immediately. Emergency is the key word. When California is having natural or manmade disasters, emergency operations are bogged down by the control agencies that make the rules for spending. In my 37 years of experience in emergency response, the biggest hurdle in mitigating an emergency is the handcuffs placed on the response by the control agencies. When the control agencies are in the room with a seat at the table, they can't even figure out how to navigate through their own bureaucracy. I have personally had to remind them that they made the rule, they can change it. The control agencies need to sit with SMEs from response agencies and ask them how to make the processes more effective and efficient. We need people that want to collaborate and make positive changes, not just because it's the way it's been done for ever. California is the leader in emergency response and in many cases in the world, but we are handicapped by our archaic processes mandated by the control agencies.
I enjoy my work conferences; they are informative and make me feel like I do important work. It keeps me motivated.
I agree. This makes it very difficult to accomplish very simple tasks.
Lack of clear communication regarding roles and expectations is a huge problem in my workplace, too, and the problem comes from the top for sure.

CalHR needs to do away from having departments list positions, have people interview even though the position already has a name. If people have proven themselves to be worthy of the promotion, promote them without have to test, apply and interview. Promote in place and stop wasting taxpayers' money and applicants hopes.

Staff retention is a issue that comes up a lot, and back filling those vacancies can take up to a year.  Its cheaper and more efficient to upgrade positions to proper level that we keep the good employees.

1. Competing interests makes it difficult to prioritize resources. 2. Inertia and institutional thinking cause tremendous delays.  3. Hiring practices are slow and antiquated.  A possible solution is to implement more practices of responsibility/accountability.
I think it is important that we see the human through the process and not get locked into legalities. If the human is seen and their needs are met the ability to serve their customer is shifted.

Here are some steps I’ve implemented:  1. SharePoint Site Development -Centralized and standardized all forms required for my role. -Used Power Automate to auto-fill redundant fields, reducing repetitive data entry. -Migrated resources from local drives to the cloud in compliance with IT policies, improving accessibility and collaboration.  2. Interactive Training Resources -Built a Wiki page to consolidate and standardize the training I’ve received from management. -Created step-by-step work instructions with embedded GIFs (instead of static screenshots) so employees can visually follow the process in real time.

OK, I don't want to throw shade on other departments, but why does it take the Department of Toxic Substance Control 6 months to 2 YEARS to review and respond to reports that other environmental agencies respond to in a month? They have generally larger and more complicated sites, but many of their cases would have been closed years ago if assigned to other agencies. Sometimes it feels analogous to assigning a Homicide Detective to investigate a traffic ticket. Perhaps reducing the number of reviews and "draft Final Final" report reviews is in order? They do great work, but quite a bit of it seems like overkill.

Agree 100%. As a manager, I try and involve my staff as much as possible and solicit their feedback before making decisions on particular course of action that will directly affect them and their workload. I work at a smaller department and my team oversees a wide array of administrative functions, and I frequently try and remind myself that I am not always going to be the subject matter expert who has the answers to every question that comes up. We need to trust our staff because oftentimes they know things that us managers may not, and we must always embolden them to share their feedback, ideas, and expertise. This will not only strengthen our teams, but create a team culture where everyone feels included in the decision-making process.

I would like to see the California legislature make revisions to the victim compensation board laws to make it more equitable and modern. Particularly when it comes to mental health. There are so many available reimbursement sources that very few victims actually why not getting paid out compared to the number that are denied. There are a number of places where the program itself could make changes to regulation or their guidelines and policies to result in fewer denials. But I think the legislature and other governing agencies need to step in and ensure that they do so.

I would like to see more avenues for career development and cross training in state government. One specific idea I'd love to see is a more formal opportunity for employees to take temporary assignments or "details" with their own department or another department at the next step up on their career ladder. This is (or was) common in federal government and is a great way to give an individual some experience as a supervisor or team leader while also allowing a department to fill a temporary gap.

I notice many departments are showing some improvements with websites and being able to complete tasks with less need for reporting in person. Personally I've recommended hundreds of changes to improve efficiency and do see many items were implemented.  In many cases it involved creating manuals or text based guides that help direct people thru complex processes.

I recall that our Department gets people asking for help that we can't really provide. We once gathered lists of resources (food, homeless shelters, advocates, etc.) that all of us could send to those requests. Maybe other departments could try that?  I have a more specific suggestion, but it is very small-scale. I remember that some libraries have games or puzzles to play with; maybe it would boost public morale if some free TTRPGs were added to those collections?
Within our office we have been trying to create a training manual.  However it's crazy to me that this isn't something that is produced and available to all of the offices.

Eliminate purchasing requirements that cost the state more money.  Many vendors know the thresholds and come in on a low bit and then quickly up the cost to the max before crossing the threshold.  This increases the overall cost and ultimately costs much more than necessary.  Eliminate small business requirements to allow a competitive rate.

I like to see improvements in data sharing between state agencies. Most state agencies are cooperative, but the contact and data sharing process can take a very long time.  State of CA is the owner of the data, not the individual agency. I like to see more of the data integrated for better use.

As a state employee I've realized that there really is no precedent in place that dictates how we shall do our job. There are only OP's that show and ends to a mean but doesn't show how to get there. It is up to the managers and past employees (if you're fortunate enough to be enlightened by their strategies) to aide us on how to complete our job in the most efficient manner. To that I'd like to state that when an employee promotes, transfers, or leaves CDCR completely, there is no overlapping of employment of the predecessor and successor for training. When an employee assumes a position for the first time, that employee must learn to govern themselves. They must teach themselves to be efficient and make the most out of their time. With that said, I think all employees have had to invent ways or utilize methods to ensure efficiency, whether self-taught or passed down from their predecessor- nothing is put in place to give employees direction on best practices to ensure work is completed in a tried-and-true efficient manner. There is nothing for employees to utilize and build on to tailor it for their institution specific duties. Employees are overall responsible for how their day is managed and it can highlight ones' drive to do well or not and can increase turnover rates.

Outdated minimum qualifications and lack of ability to promote in place which leads to a lack of expertise in state positions.  For lack of expertise in state positions, low paying and low qualification positions see high turnover. In administrative units we lose someone with years of knowledge and experience so that they can promote. That person is worth more in their current position with the knowledge they have amassed. If they are eligible to apply to a higher administrative position, they should be eligible to promote in place. The high turnover makes state processes extremely slow as we wait for someone to be trained or wait for the position to be filled.   For outdated minimum qualifications, an example is the Water Resource Control Engineer position. It requires a limited type of degree from a limited set of schools, yet engineers at other agencies (such as CalTrans, air resources, CalFire, etc.) allow for engineers that have an EIT and are on the licensing path (which is allowed by the Board of Licensing for engineers). This limits our pool of qualified candidates, when there are licensed civil engineers who cannot be hired because of outdated qualifications. Circling back, the process to even get this looked at is slow because of admin unit turnover and lack of expertise.

Innovated technology. Update the systems that are causing unnecessary delays. The State's method of communication with the public is antiquated. For many wage replacement programs, the only way to submit required eligibility documents is by mail. We need to simplify the process for the public and create State service centers.
Redirect a portion of the state work force within each agency to serve as a point of contact or dedicated case manager/worker to help program recipients that reach out for assistance.

agree, we need standard, recurrent, staff evaluations and feedback of executive management int eh form of annual surveys.  In the agency I currently work at, staff have no opportunity to share their experiences with our board about senior Managment performance, leadership style, adherence to agency mission, etc.  A previous stat agency I worked at had an annual survey that resulted in direct organizational changes over time.
Working 4/10 would be wonderful. The state would save money, because at least no one would be calling sick on a Friday

Other ideas I would add include:  1) Encourage or expect more mobilization of standard operating procedures and automation of certain systems, where such automation is effective.  2) Ensure government website links and information are regularly updated as government websites are notoriously out of date.

the RTO is just all about politics and not the quality of life for state employees.  State employees are productive workers remotely.  Remote work allows for flexibility, and quality of life.  No, we are not spending all day doing household chores but we are spending the time that we would otherwise be commuting doing our family duties.  Commuting is a waste of our time.  Packing breakfast and lunch every day is a waste of our time.  Picking clothes to wear to work is a waste of time.  When the work day ends, we want to be home with the family not on the road.  Commuting is congestion, pollution and stressful to our health.  The building developers can figure out how to fill their vacancies on their own.  The restaurant owners can figure out how to serve more customers in the private industry.  These cannot be reasons end remote work for state workers.  As a remote worker, I have time to wake up and exercise, drink my tea, coffee or smoothie in peace and not in the car driving and make a healthy breakfast to get my day started.  It allows personal time in the morning that cannot be enjoyed while commuting.  For the state employees who take advantage of teleworking, they need to be held accountable for their work by their supervisors.  Don't take away telework for everyone.  For those who meet with the public, they don't get to telework.  It's that simple.  My building has been vandalized multiple time s and we had to go home because of no water.   No reimbursement for missed
Listen to the employees underneath of me and their needs. Decisions seem to be made from the top without input or buy-in from lower level employees
Recruitment of the most qualified employees for each job should be a state priority. Recruiting candidates throughout the state allowing for telework can put us closer to that goal.
As a California, I feel like the powers that control our State are not speaking for all Californians.  STOP THE FIGHTING OVER THE FEDERAL BUDGET.  Allow us to move on.

As a public servant: stress innovation (but not just for the sake of innovation). Also, stress research and collaboration with UCs/CSUs, not just for work products, but for thinking and sharing of ideas.  As a resident: thank you to our state government, and governor for protecting our education, public health, environment, agriculture and livestock, to the best of your ability. Please continue to do so.  Also, in the Sac region. Please understand that RTO has a negative impact on the quality of state employee life, pollution, personal finances, and more. Also, it may have the benefit of increasing business downtown, but it detrimentally affects local neighborhood businesses.  We need to consider a point in which CA will stuff financing the rest of the nation. We should consider withholding our income taxes.

The ability to work across the silos of state agencies.  The Children and Youth Behavioral Health Initiative showed some of the possibilities and that work can be expanded and improved with the Behavioral Health Services Act.

On a related note, there really should be at least one IT specialist at least in every county, if not in every office building. Having to rely on headquarters for all IT issues when some districts are 5+ hours away is ridiculous.

I haven't been here long enough to be empowered to make any changes, however, I feel that upper management should allow managers and others to make decisions. It sometimes feels as though most questions are "tabled" and takes quite some time to get an answer back. Some of the processes take extremely long to route through other departments, and when you ask for "timelines" they explain processes to you and avoid the "turn around" time questions. I've seen colleagues get reprimanded for quick responses to Sponsors and told by management Not to respond immediately. If you know the correct answer, that should be applauded and not reprimanded for it.

If a department is customer facing and requires information from them for approval or reverification, etc., and the customer is still having to fill out paper forms, then that department is about 20 years behind the times. The Housing Choice Voucher program relatively recently overhauled their yearly reverification process, and the online portal that utilizes digital forms and signatures has made the process exceedingly easy for the public to use. I have to applaud them for finally modernizing. Coming from the private sector to the public sector, I was able to bring many updated IT processes to the multiple departments that I've worked for, but nothing has been more effective and efficient than decentralization of our teams and workgroups through technology like Teams, SharePoint and other connectivity programs that allow us to more efficiently work outside of an office and keep productivity locked to a single location. This is how things have to change to keep pace with the modern world; CA government needs to embrace the change from a militaristic bureaucracy with "butts in seats" policies and a "because I told you so," leadership style, to a collaborative team environment that allows everyone to do their best work from where they work best.

I want to echo this, because i had to manually click the button to load 3 more comments over and over until I hit the end of the line to have all the comments viewable to me, and it made me realize how much it was burying newer comments

Currently every department has duplicative workloads. Every department has an HR team, every department has a Tech team, every department has a procurement team, etc. It would help streamline and optimize our overall performance if these could be consolidated down to at least an Agency level, or to have actual departments (CalHR, CDT, DGS, etc.) run these functions for every other department, and allow them to perform the functions that they need to.
Using Tempo has helped streamline things such as accurate leave balances. But waiting three weeks for an accurate leave balance still doesn't seem right.

Developed process and procedure documents that are routinely reviewed and kept up to date. A lot of time is wasted by staff searching or emailing to figure out how to do things that should be documented.
Communication from the top down is not clear.  Often times the message construed from the Executives is not the same message/meaning which makes expectations unclear.
At my department, we have been able to streamline the clearance and approval process while still keeping accountability and safeguards in place.
We're still using some antiquated systems and paper processes (for example, a paper timesheet required after month end). I would like to see a statewide initiative to modernize technology
Find adequate office spaces and accessible parking garage agreements downtown.

Remove communication barriers between departments and strengthen partnerships with California businesses to reduce fraud. Better coordination ensures benefit applications are verified efficiently, eliminating redundant checks and reducing fraud risk. Streamlined communication unites internal teams and creates more effective collaboration with businesses. This makes the government faster, simpler, and more trustworthy.

The biggest issue during my 5 years with the state as someone in IT is seeing computer illiteracy amongst employees. I often hear people say "I'm not a computer person" whenever they come across something they don't understand or have an issue with. I don't think this is an acceptable mentality when over 90% of their job is on the computer! I'm not asking them to troubleshoot everything but I would like to see some effort in at least Googling how to fix minor issues like adjusting a view in Outlook or their display settings.  Here's a few other common things I've encountered.  -Not knowing how to shut down a computer or the difference between shutting down, restarting, sleep, and closing the lid. -What file explorer is and how to navigate network folders. -How to use the search (Windows key) to find stuff. -How to connect to the WIFI and VPN.  That is why I think we need some sort of basic computer literacy exam before people can apply for a job. Maybe add it as a component in CalCareers.  Another big problem I see is paper waste. We spend so much money on printers/faxes, and supplies when most things could just be a PDF. In my dept, I think we spent over a million on a filing system that can be moved electronically.
Lack of proper training

As someone who has lived their whole life in different parts of California, I love to be able to say I work for the State but I sure would be able to live off my current wage...as an entry level position, barely being able to pay my rent. It's a bit disheartening to come in everyday, while folks just a few positions above me make far more money.
Creating templates to streamline reports/memos/letters but there is always reluctant to use them by other staff. The most common phrase I heard is "that's not how things are done around here."

When I worked for a specific agency they encouraged cross collaboration so we weren't all doing the same thing which led to collaborative results such as certain shared hiring documents all could use - but it was self driven.  I would like to see this done at a higher more organized statewide level.

There are artificial intelligence (AI) chatbots including Microsoft Copilot Pages, which many state departments have access to. An administrator can upload all of their written policies to this AI and the chatbot can answer questions. For example, all HR documents can be uploaded and a chatbot can answer all (or many) general questions that do not require a human staff member to pull information from different systems or database. Of course better training is preferred, but having access to an AI-chat bot that can search and give new employees answers about written policies would possibly be a big improvement.

I would say that a lack of functional knowledge is one of the largest issues I see in government work. I would like to see more comprehensive training regarding writing and research skills. I would like to see more comprehensive training regarding professional behavior and correspondence. Most of our trainings are self paced, online trainings, where if there is a quiz at all, it is easily defeated with a google search. I would like to see trainings structured more like college courses where there are not just multiple choice knowledge checks but reviewed responses to open ended questions at several stages in the learning process, and work completed for review, feedback, and revision. I'm guilty of sometimes phoning in a training myself but I also take time to continue my education and I take pride in my work. Not everyone does and then I have to explain to them why or how what they've submitted is incorrect or incomplete. That is not always appreciated and I shouldn't have to train folks that are my superior or at my same level. Also, I would like to see us not use AI very much as it will enable these folks to continue not knowing what they are doing. Plus, the horrific impact to the environment in a state where we should be extra mindful of our environmental impact.

example of better efficiency: keep, even bolster, the licensing aspect for Alcoholic Beverage Control licenses- but eliminate enforcement. Agents are expensive and the misdemeanors that they investigate are often times already investigated by local police and sheriffs- Salary alone is over 10 million a year this does not include vehicles, weapons, and other equipment.   If the locals handled the ABC violations and followed up with the ABC legal dept where would still be enforcement but millions in savings.

The primary issue I have experienced is ineffective management. Required oversight of hiring for management positions and required continuous management training would go a long way in reducing staff turn over for key field and office positions actually doing the important work. Once a manager is in place, they can promote and hire people without any accountability for hiring the most qualified people. It is also nearly impossible to get a manager demoted or removed from their position, even if they are unqualified and promote a toxic work culture.
That's all handled at the division level. I discovered this when we got a new Chief and all of a sudden vacancies were re-classed to facilitate internal advancement.

So frequently staff are brought on and there aren't clear processing documents or guidelines for how we do our jobs. I've helped to create some documents that spell out how our systems and internal signatory processes work, or provide resources for new staff.
A primary problem I would like to see addressed is vendors who do business w/ the finance side of the state understand the concepts of public fund accounting and how departments operate.

Specifically in Parks, I don't think anyone should be able to become a Chief in HQ unless they have worked a minimum of 1 year in the field.  This concept probably applies to many other organizations that have large field operations.

Could we find a way to encourage employees to do a better job since it seems the same paid among the people who doing a good work and the people who do not doesn't work. Salary increase can be based on performance review and customer service survey including units support each other internally and clear responsibility/goal.

I believe training is a critical issue that affects both new hires and experienced employees. To ensure consistency and clarity, we need centralized training guides that are regularly updated with real-time changes. Too often, I’ve approached different SMVTs or managers with the same question and received conflicting answers.  Ongoing training, regular reminders, and open communication between managers and staff should be a core part of our Wednesday meetings. Currently, these meetings often feel unproductive. However, they present a valuable opportunity to conduct reviews, discuss updates to tasks or procedures, and align on best practices.

The issues I see is those of every Californians are struggling with every day which are own/rent housing costs, grocery prices, gas, and taxes. Every year for the last 5 years people is moving due to these prices going higher every year. I have kids and family to take care of and when I have to go get another job when working at the state level there is a problem. There used to be a saying that if we got into the state we would be set to be able to live comfortably and provide for our loved ones and that's not true anymore. When I get a raise, something always goes up and takes it from me as if I never got it. To be able to buy anything whether house or car they are taxed to the roof and prices never go down. If they do something else goes up. California needs to be affordable to be able to thrive, more policing, and use of more natural resources that California has had for decades. You ask what ideas I have to solve these problems I address, well start thinking like the bottom person and American citizens of this state that are struggling to eat and live and put policies that create more jobs, businesses, and programs that help people. Less to those that don't deserve handouts or free assistance on the taxpayer's dime. Thank you
We have so many issues, start with more vulnerable residence, healthcare, better opportunities for all, cost of living, wild fires, etc...

There is also a lot of interest from the private sector for these kinds of jobs! Some agencies have Communications branches, and all agencies could model off of those. Additionally, it would be helpful for district offices to have public information officers as well, instead of one poor person in Sacramento trying to keep track of everything.

Sometimes I feel like we are working in silos and competing rather than working as one cohesive group. I think there could be better communication from the top down, and the burden shouldn't be solely on management who are already overwhelmed.

We like to do team huddles. A short 5-minute check in to see how we are doing and if there is anything we can do to help each other. They are also a good way to quickly say what may be coming in new that we need to be aware of.

As a first line supervisor, I have been able to identify a process, which includes unnecessary steps and forms, track down and understand the reason for the unnecessary work, and implement a change, eliminating some of those steps and at least one form.   This took hours of work to fully understand why we were doing it the way we were, then almost a year before I got a manager who would consider the idea and had the courage to let me implement it.  After a year, this one form we eliminated has zero negative repercussions and saved my office from completing it 2500 times.  We are only one office, there are dozens more still filling out the form.   Line Personnel, Supervisors, and Managers alike don't want to go against policy or take the time to find a different or better way and the few who do, only get push back from supervisors or managers who just want to do their time and move on and don't want to suggest change up the chain of command.   How do we incentivize managers from the top down to look for and implement productive change in our specific Departments?    I keep looking for ways to streamline and encourage others to do the same.  I found the best manager is the one about to retire, who will let us as first line supervisors make changes, because he doesn't care anymore.
Wasted and/or discarded resources.

Using CalATERS is such a hassle. I was delayed getting my reimbursement one month because 1.) My supervisor missed it and only approved it after I followed up with her 3-4 weeks later, and 2.) they are so backlogged and often working OT or weekends and it takes time to enter into the system. It's beyond antiquated!
A single tool for Emergency management, a tool that has been approved and aligned with all agencies to be the true source of real time data.

Laws the require a newspaper posting are outdated and costly to non-profit and state agencies. In my personal experience, this includes CEQA and social services/court postings. The number of delivered newspapers has drastically changed since those requirements were created. This needs to be reviewed and updated to save money, time, and streamline notifications of important topics.

I worked for the state 10+ years before I understood the class spec, minimum qualifications, etc. process as far as applying.  I wondered, "do I qualify?", am I understanding this correctly, etc. so I can only imagine the difficulty for many from outside state service coming in and asking the same questions and getting frustrated and abandoning the process which is sad too because there are great workers out there!  It feels like a little bit of "gate-keeping" if you will.  I do appreciate now that they have an SOQ sort of informational document and my department has made it a priority to list that on every job bulletin that requires an SOQ.  I'm only a little part of the process but I make it a point to be very clear in my explanations and answer any questions I am able to for persons, and they really appreciate that because many don't understand the process. I hope that they share, share, share and I hope all of you will too!

As a Californian, I believe health facilities need to continue being monitored by government to ensure patients receive proper care. As a CA state employee, one thing that has brought about engagement is the teleworking option. I believe that giving state employees the opportunity to serve California's from their home gives us work life balance and makes us more productive and engaged in helping others.

I’m very fortunate to work for a bureau, program, division and department that values its employees. Treats employees like adults and supports their personal and professional growth. However, not everyone has this experience. Being open to feedback, take action on it, review for achievements should be a standard practice. Continuous quality improvement t.

The lack of communication between branches. The staff seem to be okay with how the processes are set in place and are okay with things taking so long and even when they try to voice concerns about processes taking too long supervisors disregard and blame policy or say “that’s just how things go”

What makes me proud about my role in public service is the opportunity to serve and make a meaningful difference in people’s lives. I take pride in helping individuals and teams discover their 'Why' both personally and organizationally. Therefore, they can connect with their purpose, love what they do, and ultimately make a greater impact. Supporting others in finding that clarity and alignment is incredibly fulfilling, and it’s what drives me every day. My personal Why is to make my grandma proud.   To make California’s government more effective and efficient, we need to prioritize human connection in the workplace. By creating safe spaces, motivating our employees, developing their skills, and consistently reminding them of the value they bring, we empower them to become the best version of themselves. When employees feel valued and cared for, they perform better, contribute more meaningfully, and help build a stronger, more effective government. I believe in dreaming big, staying positive, and starting small, because small actions often lead to the biggest impact.  Yes, I’ve seen and contributed to more effective and efficient service within the State. One example from my own work involves helping departments align their workforce and succession planning efforts with their organizational goals. By guiding teams to identify their “Why” and connect it to their mission, we’ve improved employee engagement and clarity of purpose.

I would like to see less taxes on middle and lower classes.  I would like to see more benefits for California State employees, simple things like discounts on hotels, having funding to do things like monthly staff lunches, etc.  Things to boost employee morale.  I understand that we cannot get bonuses with taxpayer money but there should be a fund to celebrate and appreciate staff.  As of now, I pay out of my own pocket hundreds of dollars a year to buy lunches and do things to make my staff feel appreciated for their hard work.
All state employees should be given access to an enterprise version of ChatGPT.

Yes!!! I’ve even heard complaints from managers saying the mandated trainings don’t provide any practical leadership applications. And the person who mentioned this to me severely needs help but I also just think some people might not be a good fit/don’t understand what managing people is. I usually experience managers will only engage if you’re a problem. Yes men who over extend SOMETIMES get rewarded w a promo for more $ but are treated like a personal assistant. That being said, I know other agencies and sometimes just units/people within can really make a difference. But don’t be breadcrumbed into a miserable environment bc one manager is good at their job (note to self). I wish management had more required feedback sessions. Like read the Reddit thread, reflect, and make real changes.

The cost of maintaining office buildings and the cost to the state worker with traveling from home to work in office. This would be solved with allowing workers to again work from home full time. Downtown buildings should be converted to affordable housing which could in turn help sustain downtown business. The people who have worked from home can in turn continue to support their local businesses.
CA Lottery is a highly inefficient tax on the statistically challenged. Make lottery winnings taxable and earmark those revenues for a higher child tax deduction, especially for younger kids.

Processes for review and approval should be streamlined.  An online portal system should be created for each state agency vs requiring state employees to fill out a multitude of state and department PDF forms which would reduce the review time and time spent routing items for approval, returned for editing, etc.
Here! Here!

A modern HR System that allows employees and managers to document and interact with their progress at the state.  A lot of departments are still filling out Excel sheets or pdfs via Docusign.  My performance reviews and other personal documents are either in a filling cabinet or on a shared drive somewhere within the State.

Because of the Pandemic and the requirement for Teleworking. Electronic processes have improved significantly. Our HR Department Collaborates a couple of times a week ensuring we are  maintaining our training, growth, and retention of required legal paper documents. Our department has grown professionally while providing work life balance, and saving millions in Californians tax dollars.
There are many positions that can stay hybrid or remote.  If yoy are going to force workers back to office, please also compensate us more so thst we can afford the additional gas and parking costs

Waste. Regarding departments I've worked in and in talking with at least a half dozen other departments and heads of departments it seems a common theme. I was picking up something inter-office today and heard finger pointing on a department meeting that could be avoided with simple process improvement protocols. There's a lot of wasted time on meetings that have no clear goals/agenda/template/time constraints, redundancy in process due to lack of process awareness and documentation, no standardized document management protocols, no clear mission of waste reduction, hierarchical structures are preached rather than going direct to a solution which wastes enormous time and hinders solution iteration/revision/implementation, not offloading to contractors the busywork related to their contract housekeeping, etc. Lean culture needs to be implemented asap with everyone trained in Lean methodologies so the mission is clear and the Gemba is understood to be open and the org chart flat for these purposes. Many don't want to rock the boat but it seems like the dirty little secret of water cooler talk. Lean initiatives would save the taxpayer millions each year if done well.

Rather than having each separate agency be the custodian of record for employee fingerprint clearances, should that responsibility instead be delegated to CalHR? State employees switching departments would not need to submit to a new fingerprint clearance. Hiring agencies would be tasked with verifying fingerprint clearance with CalHR prior to hire. Hiring agencies would also be tasked with notifying CalHR when an employee leaves State service and submit an NLI request for submission to the DOJ.

The websites are hard to navigate for the public. Try to make a user friendly website or have a calling center so that the public can contact someone that can direct them to the appropriate department.
Different divisions working collaboratively towards a shared goal versus working in silos
The state work moves too slowly with too many layers. Remove some of the layers in order to make the work more efficient.

A problem I have noticed is that time is not taken to research and investigate problems and wastes that are barriers to improving processes. One of reasons for this is because managers and staff are overwhelmed with the number of improvements that can/need to be made. A solution to this is to create a Process Improvement Priority Tool where we list the process that needs improving and score it based on the impact it has on customer/patient care and if we already have a policy or procedure in place to mitigate the adverse impact. Based on the scoring we can determine what process/issue to tackle first.

I have not seen technology at the state level but i was able to help implement technological advances at an agency that received money from the state. The agency invested millions of dollars in new software and hardware to make our job easier and accurate as well as provided efficiencies as to how childcare providers and families accessed our services. The money was provided by the State and Federal governments, but if they can do it, how come we, as a State, cannot? State forms can be created with a QR code, linking the form to a family, state department, staff person, etc. When scanned this link and notification can trigger an alert for staff to work on. If mathematical calculations are involved the software can take care of that. If the form has to be completed the software can take care of that. There are limit less possibilities with technology now days.
I would address the issues of continual education for state employees. To keep workforce in shape we need encouragement and incentives to drive desire to professional education and training.

One thing I would like to see is less prison closures. Many employees are affected when this happens and are uprooted from the very communities they live in. Also, crime is out of control in California and we need space to house these individuals safely.

Ongoing training that would assist state workers to do their jobs. Not all state agencies are open to continuous skill training for non-supervisory and non-managerial staff.  However, support staff have heavy loads, and training helps staff work more efficiently and helps create a better use of staff as resources. For example, supervisors and managers are required to take certain trainings and they are provided great tools to become leaders. Not all state workers are going to be managers and supervisors; however, they will be more likely than not serving the state for more time as rank-and-file non-supervisory staff. Some agencies look more to trying to save on overtime, instead of focusing on ensuring that staff have necessary training. This would include technology and on the job training as well. Training helps staff want to stay in their jobs and helps them do a better job. This is good for the state and for morale of an employee.

For workers in Sacramento who are visiting other offices and who don't have a downtown parking space, we should be able to reserve and use empty parking spots that sit unused because they are reserved for people who are not in the office every day.  There should be shared/hoteled spots, and then there should be spots that can be used by any state employee who needs to drive to visit another office.

Providing psychological safety to my team and ensuring that we are providing a positive work environment. I cannot provide further details as that would allow readers to pinpoint who I am (I am not comfortable with that).

PROBLEM  There is no real-time visual summary of statewide sources of funds (revenues) and uses of funds (money spent on programs and services). The absence of real-time data on revenues and expenses may make it challenging for lawmakers, control agencies and constituents to manage/adjust their budgets based on the latest info.    SOLUTION  Create an online visual tool with real-time data of sources of funds (from CDTFA, FTB, etc.) and uses of funds (to the General Fund, special funds, and locals).   This would enable lawmakers, control agencies and the public to have a better understanding of the current financial state of revenues and expenses overall as well as to individual programs. A real-time (perhaps updated weekly) tool should also enable the State to better forecast revenues, expenses and surplus/shortfalls.

White supremacy is the primary problem that needs to be addressed. This  is an imperfect term that I use here as a catchall for systemic misogyny, racism, and ableism that promotes "rugged individual" myth. There needs to be a major culture shift in our approach to governance and resource management that would allow all people to participate in government. An inclusive government will more effectively serve all Californian's by promoting discussion and rational thinking over our current "follow the strongman" model. This survey feels like a box checking exercise that leadership can use a proof that they asked for input that will not be acted upon. State leadership would benefit from cultural humility training, however, it will take generations to bring about the cultural shift necessary to cause meaningful change. The State of California needs to own its racist actions, past and present. We need to acknowledge that we became the fourth largest economy through genocide, exploitation, and unsustainable resource extraction that continues today, and only benefits a few. Most state employees are ignored, especially scientists who point out that our resource extraction is unsustainable, and racial equity practitioners who point out how our racist policies are hurting oppressed communities. We need to stop being defensive and own our wrongdoing. We cannot solve a problem if we continually deny it's existence.

It is important that I continue to have a fresh perspective and keep moving forward. Just because it is the way we used to do it, doesn't mean we should continue to. I can show up to the place that provides for me financially with a grateful heart and expect it to be a growing environment. If it is not, I can use my resources to effect change.

Delivering and palletizing over 2 Million dollars in Swiftwater Personnel Protective Equipment for the 13-Swiftwater Teams in our State. Also supervised the new palletization of the replacement caches for the 13-Swiftwater Teams, over 3 million dollars in equipment. I also observe the Regional Taskforces MOBEX's and the FEMA Urban Search & Rescue MOBEX's.
Covid gave us the opportunity to move from paper to electronic systems. We need more uniformed electronic systems that make things more efficient.

There is much too much management that has nothing to do with the job we do here regarding actual patient care here in Atascadero state hospital. It is a huge waste of tax money. There are a lot of overpaid management positions I would eliminate or streamline. Maybe it is time for AI to make this place efficient. Also, we need to actually switch our records to digital after all these years. We still have paper charts if you can believe it.
personalized training for my own staff.  hands on training, while working with the staff.

Some of the laws and procedures that have been implemented with the intent to fight corruption and waste have been counterproductive and have in fact increased waste. This is a complicated subject that is beyond the scope of a simple comment and will require involvement with the legislative process.

As a California resident, I have to chime in again on the benefits of telework. It's been disheartening to see the traffic (and the rate of accidents) growing again on 50 and 99 since RTO kicked up. When I work from home, I'm spending money on my local mom-and-pop restaurants and businesses, keeping those dollars in the community where I actually live. We could convert all those office buildings downtown to affordable housing to encourage people to live downtown again—which would encourage more restaurants and businesses to open up there as well. I know it's a big change from how things have always been done, and change is scary for some of these powerful people, but a distributed workforce is better for our future in so many ways.

Also, at least at my department, no central database or resource where one can actually look up job functions. Everything has to be learned from other employees and they are not always the best source or available when you need something.

Wasteful government spending - such as return to office mandates. Also, spending resources creating a platform like this that is supposed to be for state workers but that is going to prohibit state workers/Californians from speaking on return to office mandates.

Creating an online platform for all California state-employees to submit timesheets.  All Departments throughout the state have a variety of styles of submitting timesheets. Gavin Newsom's goal to make sure California is moving forward with technology platforms.   Hoping the California HR can create an online platform to submit timesheets for all Departments.

Some state systems are really outdated and have workarounds built in instead of replacement. If we are looking at efficiency, there are many systems out there that need to be updated as these are the tools that workers use daily.

A problem I'd like to raise is the importance of providing timely and meaningful feedback. Strong managers use the STD 638 to offer the truly earned feedback, where mediocre managers often rank everyone as "M" and provide little, if any,  constructive feedback there or in day-to-day interactions. For those who have been over-achievers all of our lives, to have a mediocre manager provide this is frustrating and off-putting. Encourage managers to work hard on these as this engagement will motivate staff, support professional growth and ensure that high performers feel valued. Less effective managers tend to provide only average or generic reviews, even for excellent employees, without offering guidance on how they can advance. This lack of feedback discourages staff and can hinder development. Additionally, promotions should be based on demonstrated leadership qualities rather than circumstance. A stronger vetting process is needed to ensure promotions go to those who consistently model dedication and performance. HR should also allow and encourage higher rankings for employees who truly give 110%. When staff exceed expectations but their reviews do not accurately reflect their effort, it creates deep frustration and drives talented employees to consider leaving for agencies where their contributions will be recognized. By strengthening both the feedback process and evaluation system, the organization can better retain top talent and truly promote a culture of excellence.

I think people should do in person classes to build relationships for customer service skills or discrimination. For hiring issues, I feel more power should be given to the building manager or the supervisor hiring people. I also think the supervisor should get more power with upper mobility instead of it being people in Sacramento.

Agencies have shared contractual needs. Would like to see a repository of common services statements of work templates in DGS library as an appendix or  via a link in the SCM that can be utilized at different agencies understanding there still may be a need for customization to include specific logistical instructions for various facilities, frequency of service and other items.  E.g. for pest control, trash/compost, fire extinguisher testing/certification, IT server room cleaning, etc.   Would like an organization chart with email/phone information at various agencies available for state employees to access for networking and collaborative problem solving.  An activity or program may be new to an agency but is not new to another agency, example a new grant program authorized for an agency to implement that has not managed grant program funds for years or previously at all.  Having the ability to ask how a different agency has set up a program recently and leverage existing operating procedures would be more efficient than starting from scratch.

Creating a safe work environment for both upper management and subordinates to share the ideas freely. Working collaboratively with all levels of staffing helped me to improve the customer service experience with the department. I always include my management, peers and subordinates in decision making processes. It helped me to craft an innovative and efficient procedure. It is all possible when there is trust between the management and subordinates as a whole. It is a two-way street, and it takes time to build this bridge between them. It is possible through transparency, working side by side with your team, and authenticity of caring about each other. In my current position, it took me at least 1 year plus to have the great relationship with my team and management. A lot of patience, changes, and hard work on how my team fits in goals, mission, and vision of the department.

I think a great way to make California's government more efficient is to allow those that can to work from home as much as possible. This saves the state money, it often allows for a better quality of living and saved money for the worker and doesn't seem to impinge on productivity as has been shown since working remotely since the pandemic. Those in management would do well to understand a happy workforce is a productive one, and forcing people into working conditions where they have to spend more money to work will not help. You can entice better workers and keep those that are doing well by offering this kind of incentive that so many are doing away with. The primary job of the government should be to serve its people.  Working from home does this, it helps everyone in this State.

Cut the Red Tape, just because some training is applicable for one agency, doesn't means it will work for all.   Make policy and guidelines easier to find instead of having to bounce all around the internet.

Focus on policies that can retain the best employees. Internal promotions should be an option, instead of people having to leave agencies to get a promotion - it creates a brain drain. NOTE - I also think hiring outsiders is good and brings fresh insight.  But there needs to be a balance, and it needs to be based on merit, not seniority.    California agencies are supposed to serve all of California, not just Sacramento.  People from ALL of California should be eligible to work for the state, and there should be local representation. There needs to be a mechanism for geographic flexibility, whether that's full-time telework or a network of offices in all corners in the state.

As a skilled trades worker, the problem I would like to see addressed is obtaining and retaining other skilled trades workers like me. The State of California has and does promote individuals from non-skilled trade roles to skilled trade positions. While the opportunity for one to promote and improve their wages is a great thing, the flip side is that the non-skilled staff create a dilemma that highlights the destitution of knowledge which hinders the efficiency of skilled trade workers. Skilled trade staff are forced to pick up the slack, figuratively speaking, by correcting bad work or having to train individuals on how to correctly administer trade work, things that are usually taught through apprenticeships or trade unions.
It sounds basic, but staffing is vital to do the job. Personnel is policy. Without adequate clerical staff, our unit is paying Engineers or Scientists to do data entry.
Procurement. Master agreements across departments with uniform contract policies and procedures would streamline outsourced work and allow smaller departments to leverage larger department resources.

1.) Keep and Embrace the hybrid working environment. I don't need to elaborate on how bad traffic is in California. I'm lucky that I have an easy commute to work using Public Trans, but not everyone does. Gas and bridge tolls are insane! Having a long commute to and from work is not good for mental health, child/pet care, etc. 2.) Make starting and operating a business easier! In my daily work, I strive to ensure excellence in communicating effectively. This means utilizing reading comprehension and critical thinking in thoroughly understanding questions being asked. I also strive to maintain the quality of my work by calling out inaccuracies and/or deceptive/false/misleading statements, because if they are not called out, they will cause corruption in my own work integrity and morale at the workplace. As a result of the 'See something, say something' DHS directive, this protection emboldens people to speak up and say something when they encounter any kind of corrupt or false statement or action, whether small or large, whether discovered immediately or in the future. The importance of protecting whistleblowers will help to improve and maintain work culture, safety, and integrity. When state workers feel safe, protected, and heard, those they govern in the State of CA will also feel the same. This work of maintaining civility, integrity, and morale, starting at the State government level, will positively ripple outwards in maintaining a culture of civility, integrity, and morale for the residents of California as well. As the State of CA is a leader amongst USA states, this example, if executed successfully will help the other states who are influenced by the State of CA. This ripple effect could influence a positive outcome for the USA, as it currently suffers from a rapid decline in civility, integrity, and morale.

I'd like to remind California lawmakers of the many teleworking benefits, such as the potential for significant cost savings of up to $225 million annually from reduced office space, improved employee productivity and retention, and environmental benefits like reduced carbon footprints.

All of my department seems to behave from a place of fear and not from a place of continuous improvement. Each department head and director rejects any change due to its potential for someone calling attention to it. Thus, nothing is ever improved for the good of the California consumer. The upcoming reorganization of the Business, Consumer Services and Housing agency is a waste of money and time when the funds could be used to seriously address homelessness. My department spend countless thousands of staff hours and dollars on preparing for the 4-day RTO order. Ultimately, it was deferred. While we were working on this half-baked directive, we did so at the expense of our core work, namely serving our fellow Californians. Attrition due to this anti-worker mandate has also led to a measurable loss in productivity and has again diverted hours to recruiting and retraining instead of serving the State.

The State, in general, is quite inefficient.  Having spoken with many relatives and friends who are employed with the State in various different departments and agencies, there is simply not enough work assigned to each employee.  For example, employees are assigned a weekly workload that are able to be accomplished within a day or less and as a result, employees have nothing to do for the remainder of the week.  This may be caused by the fact that there are excessive number of employees assigned to a specific project/assignment/role.  Employees who speak up to seek more work are often frowned upon because their peers do not want to be assigned more work.  Employees who are comfortable with their low workload would not speak up (and sometimes even exaggerate how "busy" they are) in order to preserve their low workload.  As a hard-working State employee and a California taxpayer, I believe the State needs to do a thorough time study to evaluate the amount of work being performed by State employees and determine if there is sufficient workload assigned to employees before considering to hire more people.  Highly recommend that the time study is conducted by auditors or a third-party and not conducted internally or "self-assessed" workload analysis because there will be inherent biases.

Update Cal Employee Connect to be user friendly.  Managers spend a lot of time correcting timesheets and answering questions about leave balances, instead of working on program goals.  I suggest enhancing the Cal Employee Connect platform at SCO, to identify what payroll codes stand for and how to use them. For example someone could hover over the "HOL ITO" and a pop up would appear that spelled out what the code means, and state either how to use it, or link to information about how to use it.  The entry for "PH" has an information symbol that states, "This entry is measured in Units and must be used in full Units increments."  This is helpful to know, but many employees may not know what "Units" or "full Units increments" means. "Units" is capitalized, indicating there is a definition somewhere, but that information has to be hunted down. While I can find this information, it would save me time if employees could easily find this information themselves, and understand how to use the different leave categories, at the same time as checking their leave balances. While the information is out there, it could be provided in a much more user friendly/smarter way.  I'll add that Cal Employee Connect is already a great platform. I think it can get even better.

Expedited Purchases: CAL-Cards enable the quickest possible acquisition of goods and services. During a disaster, such as the Mammoth Snow Incident, The January Fires (2025), and the Texas Flooding (EMAC-HR K9 MRP), Traditional purchasing methods like purchase orders or contracts are to slow and can endanger public health, safety, and property.  Acquisition outside of normal business hours: Disaster often occurs at unexpected times, such as nights and weekends. CAL-Cards provide a payment mechanism that functions at all hours when supplies are available. Elimination of red tape: The Emergency Response CAL-Card ERC (Emergency Response CAL-Card) program is specifically designed to cut through bureaucracy for disaster response. It is intended for use after the Governor’s Office has issued a disaster proclamation and when other payment mechanisms are unavailable. Flexibility with vendors: Unlike standard purchasing, the ERC (Emergency Response CAL-Card) has a broad allowance for merchant categories, giving card holders the flexibility to purchase from vendors that are accessible and have the needed supplies and services during emergencies. Recommendation: Authorize and issue CAL-Cards to all Special Operations Assistant Chiefs to: •	Facilitate immediate procurement of mission-critical items during deployments and pre-positions •	Support fiscal accountability and streamline reimbursement processes •	Enhance operational autonomy for A-REPs managing complex field operations

We have 13 districts, each which has a DOS unit, which assists the VR teams. This is all basic information, but I didn't know any of this for months. We need documented current processes and *updates* for our unit work so that people can aim for the same goal.  This seems like it should be obvious and not difficult. Nothing is used to adjust written procedures used to train new hires.  This creates stratified production.  Managers each train to a different standard from when they last learned the work.

What can we do to foster employee engagement at all levels. Culture is hard to build and particularly during these times people are seeking community. We need to find ways to help teams from the agency to the unit level bond and connect over common goals.

Not a primary problem, but my most recent thought: CDSS has janitors coming to our floor every day and emptying wastepaper baskets that have maybe one item in them (and, as well, waste time passing by empty cubicles several days of the week). Office janitorial work is still allocated as if we don't recycle or compost our waste (I noticed this excessive janitorial wastepaper basket effort pre-Covid), much less take into consideration hybrid schedules. If we merely asked employees not to put anything smelly in their trash (place it in the kitchen trash to be emptied daily), the janitors could empty the office wastewater baskets weekly. Or, as CalEPA does, each person is responsible for emptying their trash, as needed, in a central hallway receptacle and the janitors merely empty that one, as well as the separate receptacles in the kitchen (compost, recycling and landfill) on a daily basis.

As a state employee, I am writing to propose an innovative idea to standardize specific statewide policies across all departments. Currently, many departments independently develop similar policies in operational, human resources, and administrative areas. Centralizing these policies would create significant efficiencies and result in substantial resource and cost savings.  This proposal includes leveraging technology to automate this process where feasible, developing comprehensive templates, and providing statewide training to ensure consistent implementation across all departments. It is recommended that the state centralize this effort for all general policies within the California Department of Human Resources.  Additionally, there is some statewide centralization for Information Technology (IT) and security policies. However, IT and security policies should be reviewed to identify if there are more opportunities for centralization. While many IT and security policies are proprietary, there may be areas where streamlining is possible. Statewide IT and security policies should continue to be centralized within the California Department of Technology.

There should be one statewide system for employees to have an account that contains their information. When needing to fill out any form, they should be able to log into this account, search for and select the form, then it would auto-populate with their information. Once complete, the form should be sent to the agency requesting it. Agencies should also be able to assign forms to employees to complete. Staff should be able to log in to this account and view every form submitted. A system like this should be available to all citizens in California so they don't need to type their name, address, etc., on every form to access services.

Implement and utilize SharePoint, OneDrive, etc. rather than a share drive (S://) and send links to files rather than attaching files to emails, that way the receiving party can view and/or edit directly, and you reduce the need for version control of an edited file.

The amount of approvals needed to get things done. One issue I have consistently encountered is the challenge of working with state procured contractors, especially in programs that involve direct public service like case management.  In my experience, onboarding and training contractors can be time consuming, and often their staff do not fully understand program policies or the scope of work. This can lead to inconsistent messaging and confusion for the Californians we serve. Many of these vendors are also based out of state and may not fully grasp the unique needs of our communities.  I believe we should explore bringing more of this work in house. For example, having state employees handle case management could improve consistency, accountability, and transparency. It would also allow us to better control outcomes, reduce excessive billing, and build internal capacity by developing staff skill sets.  While contractors can play a role, I think a more balanced approach with a stronger in-house presence would ultimately lead to better service delivery and public trust.

Telework is not utilized to its full potential. It makes zero sense to force people into an office when much of the work many state employees are doing can be done from anywhere across the state. Why spend millions on maintaining office spaces when Telework has been proven to work?

Yes, stop throwing money at new initiatives and improve processes that aren't working.  Slow down and re evaluate what we already have in place, take feedback from the staff who are working the process.

As a project manager, I want to see the state deliver projects more quickly, enabling earlier resolution of issues, faster realization of community benefits, and a quicker path to innovation. Focus on people, with a service mindset. What matters above all else are the people of the state, including state employees. Attentive to both internal and external "customers", as well as team members, always with the goal to make things better and easier for people. When I worked private sector we had a three-tiered SME spreadsheet. It was nothing fancy, it was just an Excel document that everyone had access to that showed who knew how to do what. So if Hannah was out of office and you needed to ask her a question about a specific thing, you could pull up the spreadsheet and see that Chris was the next best person to ask. It also meant that Hannah was only responsible for training Chris (and Chris was responsible for training the third tier) so the expectations were extremely clear and no one felt crippling anxiety about the deluge of emails that would await them after vacation.

Idea: Reform or eliminate CDT’s duplicative IT project procurement oversight process.  Rationale:  Inefficient use of resources: Current CDT oversight adds layers of redundant review and documentation that consume millions in staff hours and consulting costs, without measurably improving project success rates.  Delays delivery: The additional procurement checkpoints extend timelines, often by several months, discouraging innovation and responsiveness.  Limited accountability: Oversight bodies rarely bear responsibility when projects fail, creating a misalignment between authority and accountability.  Alternative Approach: Shift to agency-led, outcome-based accountability:  Empower departments to own their projects end-to-end, while holding them accountable, to iterate, hold departments accountable, for cost, schedule, and performance.  Replace CDT’s checklist-style oversight with independent milestone reviews (e.g., external auditors or peer agency reviews) tied to measurable deliverables.  Adopt modular, milestone-based procurement (similar to private sector best practices) that enables course correction without massive sunk costs.  Expected Impact: Faster project initiation, lower administrative overhead, clearer accountability, and better use of taxpayer dollars.

I know we are looking for ways to be "more efficient" (spend less) but  that has lead to poor service for the people of California.  We always look to reducing staff costs when the state budget is tight. The way we staff our smaller departments is not resilient and the shocks are killing us. As a result, analyst work has been pushed up to supervisory/management levels, because the available staff to do analyst work is getting smaller and smaller. I'm hoping that the reclassification of the analyst series on will help, but it won't fix it. AI and technology solutions can provide some help, but they do not replace thinking people. You want to know why there is no decent onboarding, or written procedures, just learn what you can? Why so many grievances? Why it's so hard to learn state contracting or Fi$Cal? Why no updated policy or streamlined procedures?  Why duty statements are over 10 years old? Why no innovation? Because the mid-level leadership and front line analysts  that would be part of the team that develops those things, that can point out the real problems in the system, can only do day-to-day survival tasks, jumping from fire to fire. We have positions that are vacant for months b/c of budget, the work is spread out over fewer and fewer burnt-out staff, then we lose those positions because they were vacant. Succession planning is nice but staffing resilience and system capacity would be better.

Finding information is staggeringly difficult. (Maybe AI will improve that.)
