I think California is a great state to work for and I believe that my department truly wants to improve. I work for CDCR and I have observed some areas where improvements can be made.  From my anecdotal observations, we have a poor hiring process for managers and tend to promote people into management roles without the skills, knowledge or abilities to be a manager. I noticed we promote those who may have good supervisory skills into management roles, but not necessarily management skills.  I would prefer CDCR to look outside the department to staff management roles. We currently tend to have an unofficial requirement to come "up the ranks" to staff management positions when getting someone "off the streets" may be of better value as a manager. Supervisors and staff must be technical experts; managers need to manage.   Additionally, we tend to undervalue education in this department. I believe having a relevant education should be strongly considered for promotion. Many studies have proven the value of education, and I never understood why CDCR's hiring practices put no value in having an education. If I were able to make the decision, I would require a BS degree and experience to be interviewed for a management position.  I am not implying all of CDCR's managers are horrible people, but I have observed a lack of critical thinking and poor management skills with many of them.

The primary issues I'd address would the ridiculously unbalanced authoritarian power structure that the politically motivated elected officials wield over State employees without taking those same employees into consideration and only considering their own political agenda.

Communication from management and upper management to rank and file employees.  Example:  There are two managers in one department; one manager will share information with rank and file employees, and the other manager will not share information.  Half of the rank and file employees report to one manager and other half report to the other manager.  When discussions amongst rank and file employees occur, there is confusion and/or concern for everyone not having the same knowledge.   Idea to solve problem of communication from management:  Departmental staff meetings once a week/month with all employees followed by an email to all employees with information, discussion, and outcome from the meeting.  Idea to solve problem of communication from upper management:  Upper management meetings with departmental managers at least once a month.  Departmental managers should have knowledge of pertinent information at the State agency (especially 24-hour facilities).  All-Hands staff meetings should be encouraged at every State agency.  Emails are only one way to communicate, and the most effective way is face-to-face.

Hiring practices often appear inconsistent and inequitable. On one hand, there is a strong emphasis on rewarding current civil service experience, while on the other, external candidates are expected to meet disproportionately high educational and experiential thresholds. For instance, some classifications equate one year of state service to a master’s degree plus three years of professional experience. This raises a critical question: how can a single year of internal service be considered equivalent to such extensive academic and professional preparation? This practice not only undermines the value of formal education and diverse professional backgrounds but also creates systemic barriers for qualified individuals outside the state system—effectively making the process exclusionary.  To improve both efficiency and equity in hiring, California should implement a transparent, competency-based hiring framework. This would involve clearly defining the skills, knowledge, and outcomes expected for each classification and allowing candidates—whether internal or external—to demonstrate their qualifications through a combination of experience, education, and performance-based assessments. Such a model would reduce arbitrary equivalencies, promote fairness, and ensure that the most capable individuals are selected to serve the public, regardless of their entry point into government.

Recruitment and retention of state peace officers is harder than ever over the last 10 years.  Many police agencies have adjusted to the times and now allow officers to wear well groomed beards and display tattoos that are of good taste and not objectively offensive.  However, the California Highway Patrol has not allowed tattoos to be displayed nor male officers to have beards, all for the sake of tradition.  Our modern culture has grown to accept both as acceptable in the workplace, and in fact, makes officers more relatable.  Many communities may be able to relate to an officer who has tattoos, especially younger people.  As the melting pot of the United States, many foreign cultures co-exist in California and universally respect male officers with beards as being elders with serious life, and job experience, particularly when they see gray in the beard.  This makes them more willing to listen and being compliant with an officer.  It's already permitted for religious exemptions, i.e. for Sikh officers.  It should be permitted across the board for all officers.  This may seem like a non-issue to someone not in law enforcement, but other agencies have noticed higher levels of recruiting and retention by allowing tattoos and beards.  It is also a huge morale booster and allows officers to express themselves as individuals and humans, rather than as de-humanized, monotonous, faceless agents of the government.  I would like to see State Personnel Board force this issue with CHP

As someone who recently joined the state from private industry I completely agree that more training and guidance is needed. While there is some HR specific training it is very basic. Even just navigating the building and finding what was available to us as employees was difficult. I was able to get some information from my supervisor (but they were also somewhat newer) and some coworkers once I had met enough people but it was a bit daunting initially.   Another useful thing would be to have someone gather information about the surrounding location and businesses. I know many provide State discounts but there's no resource to see that and you have to ask each individual business.

My unit has regular meetings to check in with each other and to collaborate. We are currently setting up a new ticketing system to more effectively manage our workload, so we have been in training to learn this system and to streamline customer requests. I strongly believe that updating some of our antiquated systems has been a great step forward.

As a state employee we are always told things are out of budget. I work in law enforcement and other agencies charge for release forms (an impound for unlicensed driver) they charge up to $500. My agency does not charge for release forms, but we could. Even if we charged $50 for a storage and $100 for an impound we would make a ton of money.

Why does DGS not consider a UC/CSU to be a state agency when it comes to interagency contracts?  One department can contract with another and they can do so up to $2 million without DGS approval. Why isn't UC/CSU part of this delegation, instead of having the same delegation limits as outside contractors?  The state is going to contract with them no matter what, but not giving them the same level of delegation just means the process takes longer and the contract has to sit at DGS Office of Legal Services waiting for approval.  Seems like a waste of state resources that can better be used elsewhere.  Why are taxpayers paying for DGS to see if the state can do work for itself?

Improved communication and collaboration not only between agencies, but within agencies and their divisions. One solution to break down these communication barriers is for division managers to foster collaboration beyond occasional social events.

Telework makes a ton of sense for IT teams, especially for those that are not customer-facing. A majority, if not all, of the tasks we complete involve remote meetings or remoting into virtual infrastructure. By coming into the office to sit at a desk to remote into systems makes little sense.

I believe there is a critical underutilization of the staff talent within the State, and before hiring additional personnel, the existing team dynamics should be analyzed to see how work can be better distributed amongst those already on board.

The state would save SO much money if it would revisit the mandatory new supervisor 80 hour training, 40 hour mandatory CEA training, and 40 hour mandatory manager training.  These used to be in-person classes where departments would pay CalHR approximately $1500 and staff would have an opportunity to collaborate with colleagues from other departments, get training, have an opportunity to ask questions and share ideas, etc. During COVID these classes went virtual and of the approximately 30 staff who have taken these courses since who I have personally discussed this with, they receive no value from the virtual trainings.  They are go-at-your-own pace, there is no engagement with others, and staff just have them running in the background to "knock them out" while they get their work done; yet departments still pay CalHR $1500 per employee.  Is there really a $1500 cost to CalHR when it's a virtual course with no instructor, no meeting room rental, no CalHR staff time, etc?  I understand this funds CalHR, but for industry-funded departments and programs who have to pay this cost, are they really getting any value for their dollar?  If CalHR would like to keep these courses automated and with no CalHR involvement the cost should be drastically reduced.  Or, to get more bang for their buck, it would be a much better investment if these courses went back to in-person.  Or at least allow departments that option.

It would be so much more beneficial for the WBA/MBA to be increased. People are seriously suffering and doing without. This will further assist them and their families until they acquire full time work.

Give State program managers more access to our lawmakers. This last legislative cycle, I spent weeks commenting on a number of bills that came out from the same handful of lawmakers who had good intentions, but didn't understand the real challenges, concerns, or road blocks and didn't know what was already happening on a State level. All of that time could have been avoided if I was allowed to have sit-down meetings with the lawmakers who drafted or sponsored the bills rather than having to go through our legislative affairs who are not technical staff and do not fully understand our programs. This barrier causes laws to be passed that are not helping Californians, but are actually hindering them. It also results in significant governmental waste because it causes duplicative or conflicting efforts.

I do not think there is just 1 primary problem.  I been with the state over 15 years, and have held positions as staff, and management.   Covid put restrictions on in person training. Yes, def. bring back in person training. Not all jobs can be learned virtually, at least not the ones I did.   As an employee, lack of mgmt guidance on growth, learning and promotions. They make you fill the IDP beginning of the year, and then what? It's not revisited till your next annual. Fancy document serves zero purpose.  Even as a manager, no support or encouragement for growth.  As a manager, you get to see abuse of time by staff clearly. Lack of mgmt support in documenting those staff for performance issues (lack of knowledge, ability, or simply abuse). The employees being written up have more rights than the manager who is documenting them for years, and years. So much time and resource wasted on documenting. Staff files complain against managers, and upper mgmt does nothing to support the manager. Then why would any manager want to waste their time and document ppl? the managers ruin their reputation by incompetent staff filing complains, and sadly upper mgmt. documents that on their annual, making it hard to promote for the manager, who is simply doing their job.  And so, no managers want to document and waste time.  Can't fire incompetent staff from state is the one benefits highly abused by ALOT of staff.  Huge waste of taxpayer's money, and state resources there.

Being clear on who is the project manager, which may sometimes be different than the org chart manager if the project is cross-functional.  Also fostering frequent, friendly connection with teams involved in a project that you don't have a lot of experience working with - a feeling of comradery and shared appreciation goes so far in making work feel satisfying and impactful!

Poor communication is common within many organizations and subareas therein.  Psychological safety is critical for employees to feel safe, heard, and free to express themselves without fear of reprisal, harm, or loss of job /resources /benefits.    Great comment.  Ty.

I would love to see something- maybe a series on social media? where the importance of government employees and what they accomplish is made clear- especially why it is fair to pay government employees a fair and living wage.

There is a big wage gap between Private sector and public service. The consultants that work for State make at least 3 or 4 times to the public service employees, while doing the same kind of work. That affects morale of state employees. There should be an effort to equalize the wages. I believe that will improve the productivity of state employees.

Public pension boards -- CalPERS, CalSTRS and the 21 CERLS -- need simple ethic reform: no free meals or gifts of any amount for board members or for staff. (The current limit can be legally skirted when multiple companies collectively split the group meal tab for staff and pension board trustees, for example.) If a ban on gifts was enacted, the free meals and gifts would mostly cease, and we would see fewer staff recommendations (and fewer board approvals) to send billions into costly investments that are proven to underperform low-cost index funds. Result: public pensions would improve their long-term investment returns by more than 1% per year, which would eventually translate into a reduced need to unnecessarily contribute extra billions into California public pension plans.
Improving technology always improves efficiency. Introduce new software and train users on how to use it, so they can stop using the old process and learn the new, more efficient one.

Improving processes and making them streamlined through technology has been the hardest thing to do with so many different higher ups and leadership staff needing to approve every little change, would work more efficiently if processes would not take so long to update.

I'd like to apply an equity lens and see more statewide opportunities extended to individuals living in rural areas of California. These communities include highly talented professionals who often face a lack of career advancement pathways. Without broader access and the ability to retain and develop this talent, we risk either losing these folks or having them remain in the same roles for extended periods of time without opportunities to grow. :(
more clarity of the rules and regulation we enforce. When it is unclear for us I can't imagine how confused the general public is.

Personally, as a manager, I think our departments need better access to reporting for internal productivity. Currently the tools that i have available to me, have a very limited view on what I can pull and it is not in an excel format. Because of this, I can't comb through the data in a meaningful way, remove columns I don't need. I have to manually look up information, which is extremely time consuming and even what I am able to pull, can't tell me the information I need. I have to manually track what I can.   And speaking of excel, previously my team would print out lists provided from HQ to do projects. Again these lists are not in an excel format, which makes it difficult to weed out other district office information and focus on my district. So manually, I have to find out what applys to my office.   In the areas that I can, I have since shifted some of our projects to a shared drive, excel format and we color code what stage of the project my team is working on. When it is ready for my review, I can clearly see which ones need my attention and I can keep tabs in real time with where they are at.   Using more digital tools could makes us incredibly efficient and be able to focus more on items like customer service. When we have good tools, we can focus on what matters.

After seven years with Caltrans, my problem is with private contractors. Since we are forced to award contracts to the lowest bidders on projects, we are constantly saddled with mediocre companies on multi-year projects. These companies often cause delays through dangerous practices, poor execution, and corner-cutting to save money. I propose the State implements a "blacklist" whereby demonstrably bad contractors are prohibited from bidding on some or all projects for a set time period, or until they can prove they are capable of greater responsibility.

The "one-size fits all" is antiquated and completely averse of what California stands for with our diversity and efforts to be ahead of the curve on things. Not even taking into account the fact that removing telework for state employees would cost the state (and thus taxpayers) such a large amount of money JUST to have butts in seats in offices. The fact that we were able to pivot during the pandemic, when Newsom then touted that this would be a "new normal" being able to telework, and to do so while still providing quality work and collaborating in a new digital environment is just a spit in the face to be told that the "old way" is the better way.  Bottom line is that local management should be able to make the call IF it makes business sense for staff to be in office.
Organizations are too top heavy. This creates resistance to innovation and progress. Get rid of middle management or consolidate and disperse.

I think part of the plan is that AI is better situated to develop comprehensive climate strategies than is an individual human. One hopes before long we will have enough net-negative carbon technologies in place to stabilize and reverse the present trend.

Many Caltrans processes still rely on PDF forms that require downloading, filling out, routing for signatures, and re-entering data into spreadsheets. This creates delays, duplicate work, and access issues — especially when PDFs are hard to use on mobile devices or when handwritten forms are difficult to read.  Instead of routing documents for signatures, we can use interactive online forms to collect structured data and automate approvals. Online forms are faster to set up, reusable, and mobile-friendly. They also ensure accuracy by requiring fields, validating entries, and feeding submissions directly into tabular formats like Excel or SharePoint Lists. This eliminates manual transcription, reduces errors, and cuts down on repetitive administrative work.  The benefits are clear:  - Saves time by reducing steps (no printing, scanning, or configuring signatures)  - Improves efficiency with real-time submission tracking and notifications  - Avoids waste by reducing paper use and redundant tasks  - Supports accessibility by providing legible, mobile-friendly entry options for both office and field staff  This small change could save staff and the general public hours each week and provide cleaner, more usable data for decision-making — aligning with Executive Order N-30-25’s call for operational efficiencies across state government.

The hiring and specifically the promotion process is broken.  There is zero or next to zero feedback.  There is no way to know how you 'scored' on the answers to the interview questions.  There seems to be favoritism all over the place.  That is my experience anyway.  The system for promoting employees needs to be more transparent and feedback, coaching and development for promotion has to improve.  Ten fold.  I say this as a former coach, manager and leader.

Leadership seeks out and promotes new ideas, rather than being tied to old ways that no longer further the mission. This open-door/ open minded attitude, from the top down, allows us to achieve our goals by being quicker, creative, and flexible. It also helps our work force thrive, even in difficult times.

Over my 10+ years in state service across three departments, I’ve consistently worked to improve processes and enhance customer service. At one department, training compliance was at just 35%. I created a clear tracking system, sent regular reminders, and worked directly with staff to remove barriers to completion. Within months, compliance rose to 82%. In another role, customer service request closeouts were stuck in the 30–40% range. I streamlined the intake process, clarified responsibilities, and helped implement better follow-up procedures, which brought closeout rates to over 60%. These efforts not only improved efficiency but also boosted staff accountability and customer satisfaction. I take pride in identifying gaps and turning them into opportunities for improvement.

Purchasing goods and services for participants is needlessly burdensome. A single library of vendors that work with CA, with appropriate documentation already in place and maintained, would have a major impact.

Agreed.  There is absolutely nothing that I can't do from home that I do from my work office.  It's a control/trust issue.  If there are employees abusing telework, they should be dealt with, as you would deal with any other performance issues.  I would actually get more work done because I would have less distractions and less "social time."  It would also make for a happier employee.

It seems far too difficult to start a small business in California. Too many regulatory hurdles, too many licensing requirements, too much compliance and too many fees and taxes always get in the way.  Public transportation is also awful. Far too localized and far too disconnected.

Staff are encouraged to innovate and think about how the work California does will lead the way for the rest of the nation. Staff take pride in their work and are encouraged by the position California plays nationally, and the impact that we can have to improve the lives and environment of California. So, this is to say, staff feel empowered to push for a better future. California is lucky to have an extremely talented and knowledgeable workforce that believes in the mission. They just need the resources and ease of bureaucratic processes to be fully actualized.

Direct supervisors should have more leeway in managing the day to day of their teams. All workers work differently and have different needs that impact productivity. When decisions around the workday are made at the top as blanket mandates, it heavily affects team morale and ultimately impacts hiring and retention. These decisions tie the hands of the supervisors that know the needs of their team best.   When turnover is high and hiring is slow, it impacts the entire team and service to taxpayers is slowed down heavily.   As the largest economy in the country and the State with the strongest worker protections, we should be leading the way in showing the rest of the country that people should always come first and that workers that are passionate, dedicated, and productive don’t always fit into boxes built at the top, nor should they have to.   The solution I propose would be to allow supervisors and teams that have proven track records to have more leeway in decisions around the workday. This would improve morale, increase talent available for hiring, increase retention, and put the focus on results for taxpayers over arbitrary outdated ideas around work.
Employee motivation - As managers, you don't have a lot of incentive to offer, as well as you don't have a lot of authority for discipline.

I think that there are really 2 major problems:  1 - we've over-regulated to the point that nothing can get accomplished and we're making it unappealing for businesses to operate in California. We can't even properly rebuild after the fires and we were unable to manage water to keep our people and homes safe. We're unable to properly manage our forests to prevent fires from being as destructive. We've even prevented police from enforcing current laws to keep people safe and we're seeing a surge in crime and violence.  2 - We need a stable power grid. We retired our nuclear plants even though they're the safest and cleanest source of stable power which our grid desperately needs - especially if we want to move towards all electric cars. Solar is great on existing infrastructure, but we've been clear cutting the forests to build those instead which destroys our beautiful countryside and it only generates power when the sun is shining. We should be developing fusion and building out a grid to support our efforts to reduce carbon emissions and cleaning up our air. We need trees and plants in the cities to help clean the air there and reduce the impact of brake dust and other particulates in the air. We can't claim to be wanting green energy while simultaneously clear cutting forests and countryside for something that results in brown outs and black outs because it's not stable enough to meet the core energy demands of the people.

I'm not sure I entirely agree. I've found that the loss of the human element has been devastating. The lack of "doorway" conversations, and "watercooler" chats has really impacted our ability to quickly problem solve and come up with new solutions that these natural and organic conversations and relationships bring about. As someone that was new to an organization during telework, I felt that I was never really a "part" of the organization. There are people that I've only seen on Teams. The relationships that they have with others that they knew "pre-pandemic" had a place to start. So they have no issue with IMs/etc to communicate. But when there is no opportunity to actually get to know people in the workplace, the team dynamic suffers. I'm happy with a mixed model telework program of 3 days in office.

The best way to increase efficiency, morale, and positive impact is to start with the facts (in this case, data). If data shows that one work method is more favorable/optimal than another, then that information could become an actionable item. If data is not immediately available, then look to your labor force for feedback. If your labor force is non-committal, then maybe it is time for a trust building exercise...these ideas are regularly explored in books regarding leadership. Read "The Five Dysfunctions of a Team" or Carly Fiorina's "Tough Choices". In this moment, millennials and younger generations have a lot to teach. They were born into the world of data. They know exactly how to improve their jobs. And having a platform to do so will not only increase productivity but save the state millions upon millions on labor force hours, lawsuits, and resource expenditures.
Mentoring programs, speed mentoring, or current mentoring program that I'm in.    I find it very rewarding to share some of my experiences with other employees.
I would like to see criminals incarcerated. Crime is out of control and we cannot cater to individuals who refuse to participate peacefully and respectfully in our society.

The State of California should only sign contracts with businesses who are physically located and/or physically operate in California.  Example: Most of my (and other staff) job duties have been transferred to a third-party administrator who is physically located in the states of Minnesota and Colorado.  CAL HR and Department of Legal should work together to keep all duties of civil service classification positions within the State of California.
I think the CA payroll system needs to be modernized and built to support evolving workforce needs while integrating the latest advancements in technology.
There should be comprehensive tax funded rehabs for drug and alcohol use with comprehensive mental illness treatment int he State of California and not just for lower income brackets.

I believe if we invested in the development of a user-friendly CDTFA cellphone app for business owners, CDTFA could 1. Gain more transparency with the business owners and 2. Become more efficient the collect sales taxes for the state.   For example, my collectors and I meet with the business owners with collection accounts at the field office and during our field calls at the business locations. Almost all the business owners we meet do not use a computer or own one and therefore, rely on their cellphones conduct day-to-day business activities like accepting a payment through Zelle for the sale of a t-shirt or food, business banking, creating a sales invoice to give to a customer, using Square to swipe a credit card payment, etc. Specifically, I would like to see that a user-friendly cellphone app is developed for CDTFA to make it easy for a business owner to register for a seller’s permit, make changes to the account (like an address changes or adding/closing business locations), pay sales taxes/state revenues, eFile tax returns for up to two locations, show past due taxes owed, setting up payment plans, and making a request for tax relief from penalty, interest, etc. I specifically would like this app to cross-register the business owner for other licenses and fee accounts under the authority of CDTFA.   The interface of this app should be easily uploaded to CDTFA's database in real time or within 24-hours. Add a chat function using AI to answer basic questions.
Consistency! Every office has their own interpretations of laws and policies. It could be frustrating to the customers
Efficiency in multiple areas such as the Hiring process, grant applications for partners, contracting, procurement.

Seems like travel is a issue - would be more streamlined if there was a travel department to handle all travel for all staff.  As it is now, there are people who don't want to attend work conferences due to the issues around knowing what form to fill out for what portion of travel. If this was centralized it would cut down on errors and really speed up the entire process.  Just leave reimbursement in the hands of individuals, and have them call the "travel dept" to arrange the rest!

We too often provide inaccurate information to customers, and management frequently instructs staff not to correct it and/or advise us it is not someone else's responsibility to make that correction. In practice, that someone else does nothing. This practice undermines trust and accountability, and it sets a bad precedent for the next generation going in to management. It’s essential that all employees, leadership in particular, embrace the core principle that our role is to serve. Strong job protections should never be mistaken as a license to neglect our responsibility to help others.

I really like how the DMV is trying to make the services they provide more accessible through different methods with the kiosks, on-line, etc. I hope that other agency/departments have done or working on doing the same.

The primary problem I would address is the delegation process. There are too many checks and balances which address the same liability and concerns via many different documents and protocols all addressing the same issues and concerns and not adding value to the process. In order to process design exceptions there are so many software, document types, sharing platforms, and not a cohesive process that streamlines and minimizes the documentation process and signatures required. There needs to be better tracking of documents, fewer software, and a more streamlined process followed by both the consultants and the reviewers to achieve any modicum of efficiency.  I would suggest singular core documents focusing on the projects and their exceptions with varied signature pages depending on the level of delegation. I would also suggest a singular software capable of handling the sharing and evolution of this document and the associated plans that would allow for real time sharing of revisions, corrections, and modification between consultants, delegated employees, and upper management with final approval authority.
Why are we frequently using out of state vendors to do work that we should be paying state employees to do?

I agree with all of those comments talking about the need to develop a resource hub and sharing information about the different programs and resources are available both intra and inter-departmentally. Being aware of and able to work with programs even in other departments that are relevant to your work should be a more common practice. More intensive onboarding for new employees should be part of it as well.

I have been a buyer, contract analyst and purchasing manager for some years. I think some of the excessive purchasing laws and policies make the State purchasing/contracting procedure unnecessarily complex. Simplifying the process and reducing the number of forms needed not only expedites the process but also saves taxpayer money. One example I suggest removing is the DVBE participation requirement in formal solicitations. Almost, 99% of the times, it's been waived due to highly specialised services or other factors. These types of laws and policies do not help DVBEs; they just add additional paperwork and delay the contracting process. Other examples are forms like Darfur, California Civil  Rights Laws Attachment, and Iran Contracting Act Verification that need to be submitted by bidders/contractors, or 113 pages of Telecom General Provisions included in telecom contracts. The lengthy provisions and forms that are never looked at or used for anything waste taxpayer money and complicate the process for companies. Some vendors, especially Small Business suppliers they do not have a lawyer on board to help them understand the State contract provisions and for that reason do not participate in bidding opportunities. There are a lot of requirements during the purchasing process that could be removed or simplified. I'm referring to the laws and policies included in State Contracting Manuals Volumes I & II and State Administrative Manual (SAM).

The functioning of FI$CAL is slow, clunky, and inefficient.  When entering line items for POs the number of fields to complete is excessive, and when you move from one field to the next there is a  lag.  The system also seems to slow when during heavy use periods during the work day.    Reducing the number of fields required to complete for each line item of a PO and improving the system's speed and ability to handle high number of users simultaneously would be helpful.
And I would suggest more accountability for staffs
Tax the rich, ban billionaires

Support CA HS Dropouts California currently has the lowest high school graduation rate in the nation—an alarming fact, especially for a state with the fourth largest economy in the world. We can and must do better for our youth and for the many adults who never had a real chance to earn a diploma. In California, certain vulnerable student populations—such as those who have experienced homelessness, incarceration, or time in the foster care system—can graduate with a reduced requirement of 130 credits under AB 216. I propose that this same credit pathway be offered to adults, age 18 and older, who enroll in accredited adult school programs. Many adults who dropped out of high school faced serious obstacles: poverty, family instability, violence in their communities, or disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Without a diploma, these individuals are often stuck in low-wage jobs with little opportunity for advancement. A HS diploma opens doors to job training programs, community college, military service, and promotions.  •	The state gains from increased tax revenue as graduates earn higher wages. •	Adult schools benefit from federal funding tied to improved student outcomes. •	Employers gain access to a more skilled and motivated workforce. •	Businesses benefit from the increased purchasing power of newly employed adults. •	Communities see reduced crime rates and greater social stability. Expand the 130-credit diploma option to adults. Its a low cost, high impact solution.

As a state employee, I have focused on improving efficiency and service. For example, I led the development of the Unemployment Insurance dashboard during the pandemic, which gave policymakers and the public clear, real-time information and improved transparency.

Working in a human resources division, the largest complaint I have been given from the public is the lack of communication. I find that many NEW to State service candidates apply to multiple vacancies and do not receive any feedback or notice if a job was closed. I believe communication from hiring manager(s) needs to improve; whether a candidate interviewed or not, they should be receiving an auto-email explaining why they were not chosen. There are options for this in ECOS (from CalHR), so I am not sure why it is not being used (at least in my Dept). I feel this may alleviate some of the frustration from those wanting to join State service.
I think we provide good customer service to the public in regard to interpretive (outdoor education programs).  The folks that provided this service are highly motivated and enjoy the work!
Active outreach to private industry for recruitment and the potential for a second career in government would benefit may state agencies and departments.
As a State employee and California resident, I would like to see greater transparency and stronger customer service support from State agencies.

Creating schedules were the work is spread out evenly and Not using the amount of time you have in state service to approve employee's request for time off. Respect is also very important. Treat adults as adults.

A lot of higher management are being hired from the Public Sector and they come in with the mentality to micro manage, add more tasks that are not needed, create unnecessary deadlines and dont understand how the state professionals are limited to certain things due to management approvals only. Managers dont respect other managers or employees treating them inferior if they come from the private sector. I think they should be limited at hiring people from the outside and let the people within promote since it is a difficult concept for outsiders to grab when coming into the public workforce.
I think people need to listen more and talk less.
I'd like to easily be able to see the most recent comments on this page, instead of having to click the comment button a bunch of times. Just to start!

Purchasing and procurement! I regularly have to manage the purchase of items that are distributed to youth. These items and their related youth program are a widely recognized public good with broad public support. To purchase these items I have to spend months submitting and waiting (and waiting, and waiting) for first quotes and then waivers from CalPIA and from OSP; if I am required to work with either, I win the privilege of having 10 times the turn-around time at almost twice the price available with commercial producers. I spend countless taxpayer-funded hours navigating statewide contracts and multi-tiered purchasing requirements, all with minimal administrative support. I have to ask proprietors of small businesses to submit mountains of forms, including one that confirms they never supported a 20 year old international atrocity, and then I have ask them to float their own overhead costs before I can pay them for their services. I loose weeks, if not months, of staff time and project delivery timeliness when vendors are unable to comply with our cumbersome requirements, especially when I am required to have multiple quotes. As it stands, I see almost no benefit to the people of California or the budgeting of their tax dollars.

In my role, I’ve taken initiative to improve how our department serves both staff and the public. For example, I’ve worked on modernizing outdated processes, streamlining communication, and promoting plain-language resources to make forms and services more accessible. I’ve also advocated for tools such as tutorials and online guides that help people navigate state services with confidence. These improvements not only save time for employees but also make it easier for Californians to access the resources they need. Implementing these changes hasn’t always been easy. At times, I struggled to get buy-in from my direct supervisor and had to elevate ideas above her to leadership in order to move them forward. Navigating those layers of approval—and the hoops that come with them—can be frustrating, but persistence has paid off. I believe these efforts demonstrate both the need for stronger leadership support of innovation and the real impact small, thoughtful changes can have across state government.

If the goals for the Engaged California project include to find challenges that undermine our ability to work efficiently and effectively, and to discover ways to better serve the people in our state, it doesn't make sense to take virtual work (or RTO) off the table for discussion. Additionally, this is supposed to be a deliberative democracy forum, as such reasoned positions are valid and should not be limited. Overall, as a state employee that is in a hybrid position working both in person and virtually at times, it is important to validate the values that virtual work affords state employees, state agencies, people in our state, and the state budget. It is also important to see how virtual work solves for problems in inefficiency and ineffectiveness, and can help to solve for ways to better serve the people in our state.   A primary problem right now is the position that virtual work shouldn't be part of the Engaged California discussion to find solutions to problems (because it is supposedly doesn't "stay on topic" - see Engaged California's "Sharing Guidelines" ).  It makes no sense to talk about workplace efficiency and effectiveness, and to talk about better ways to serve the people in our state without considering talent management, workplaces, work mediums/channels, and work spaces. A set proposed solutions include opening this forum to the topics of virtual work, talent and workplace management, and work conditions.

One of the best outcomes that has occurred within the department I'm employed in was due to COVID-19. We now have monthly all staff meetings across all branches in the department. Additionally, all of our field offices had monthly, now bi-monthly, meetings for all the field offices' PT IIs and AGPAs to attend. In those meetings we are able to ask questions and share any issues we have with processes, or ask for more guidance. There may be a SME in another office who is able to provide the information, or the facilitator of the meeting is able to find out or elevate the issue to leadership. Since these meetings occur via Microsoft Teams, the chat is open and anyone may ask questions at any time.
I would keep duty statements current and honest and not gray the lines between SSAs, AGPAs, and lower-level support staff.

I would like to see more attention and resources applied to the foundational infrastructure of our communities - such as roads, education, housing, food, and healthcare - over the "fluffy," feel-good projects that sap the State of resources while these other must-haves get more out of reach for many. I am all for new technology and protecting our environment! However, pet projects in these areas may not yield immediate benefits while the really tangible needs decline. We all see that - in the homelessness, hunger, bad roads, and declining literacy - around us. The high-speed rail line is a perfect example. To fulfill some desk-jockey fantasy, the design (even if well-intentioned) was very poorly thought out and neglects many realities on the ground. Sooo much $ is being thrown at it, when that $ could do far more good elsewhere. I *want* high speed rail, but not as it was erroneously conceived of and as the boondoggle it has become. Let's own up to the mistakes and correct them. Let's take care of more people's basic needs before embracing the next trend-setting pet project.

We have started using Charters to outline the goals and scope of our workgroups and projects and providing visual aids on the progress our project has made towards those goals for leadership to be able to see at a glance what the project is working on.
Considering a large portion of homeless population have mental illness, this sounds alot like reopening mental institutions.

The Lottery's rigorous SmartyStreets address system is much more detailed and rigid than the USPS's, which means we spend a lot of time investigating discrepancies on addresses we get from ID's. If the DMV were to use SmartyStreets I'm sure all state agencies would save time from the elimination of so many errors that are generated there.

I'd like to see an end to freeway expansion projects, and all that money get dumped into building robust public transit networks around metropolitan areas.  In conjunction with that, I'd like to see more incentives to build multifamily, mixed income housing around transportation hubs, including utilizing eminent domain to redevelop suburban neighborhoods into walkable communities linked together by public transportation. I want to see California kick off a suburban contraction.

I agree with so many of the comments that as public servants we need to be open to being the change we want to see! If you are doing the right thing and it makes good sense, you should never be fearful of shaking up the status quo. If we could reduce some of the massive waste in government spending (and I'm not talking about anyone's salaries, here), eliminate excess bureaucracy, and make smart choices operationally, we could improve so much in the way of efficiency! This is not new information.

State is not proactive, it is reactive. Consider DMV. The DMV is too small in most Metropolitain areas. No foresight in planning.  No parking, nowhere to sit, not enough people working. The workforce is discouraged by the inefficiency of the decision makers. Most of these decision makers have made changes based on outsourced companies' evaluations. The changes made are creating hardships and do not work. The recommendations that would work are not followed.
The way to reduce carbon emissions and save tax payer dollars by making full time telework permanent for state employees who have worked remote succesfully.

Favoritism and Nepotism in Hiring  Unqualified candidates getting hired or promoted due to personal connections, not merit.  Workplace morale and trust suffer when people perceive that opportunities aren't fairly earned. Erosion of public trust (especially in public or regulatory roles) when the public suspects favoritism in staffing.  We should advocate for more transparent recruitment and selection processes. Push for independent hiring panels, blind application reviews, or standardized interviews. Encourage whistleblower protections for those who report unfair practices.  Circumvention of Minimum Qualifications (MQs)  Some candidates may be circumventing qualifications by enrolling in quick, sometimes low-rigor or unaccredited online graduate programs, just to “check the box.”  This undermines the intent of MQs, which are supposed to ensure a candidate has a certain level of baseline expertise.  It can devalue the profession and create inequities against those who pursued more rigorous paths.  We should push for HR and classification teams to clarify standards: not just “enrollment” but substantial progress or completion from accredited institutions. Consider evaluating equivalencies in a more meaningful way — e.g., experience + coursework, or requiring specific coursework from recognized programs.  Advocate for quality assurance checks on accepted degrees — ensuring they come from regionally accredited institutions, not diploma mills or for-profit degree factories.

The primary problem with working for the State of California is the way staff are treated. Most supervisors receive thorough training on how to issue disciplinary actions, but very little, if any, on how to actually lead, motivate, and support their teams. This results in a culture of enforcement over empowerment, where employees often feel undervalued and micromanaged rather than inspired to perform at their best.  Suggested solutions:   Implement hiring and promotion practices that prioritize: People skills, Proven ability to develop others, and Desire to lead not just manage. Select supervisors based on leadership potential. The work can be learned on the job but emotional intelligence needs to be there before they become a supervisor and have power over peoples careers.  Build accountability for “how” supervisors lead. Tie supervisor performance evaluations and promotions to: Team morale and retention metrics (if there is a high turn-over then something is wrong that shouldn't be ignored), 360-degree feedback from staff (this is one I have implemented upon myself), and Demonstrated leadership behaviors — not just output numbers.  Shift the culture from punitive to supportive. Encourage a workplace philosophy that emphasizes: Employee engagement over enforcement Problem-solving conversations instead of automatic discipline, Psychological safety, where staff feel comfortable speaking up.  Invest in real leadership development not just a book club.

I would like to see better outreach highlighting the work State Employees do for the benefit of the public. One possibility would be a better social media presence sharing key projects and their benefits with the public.

Recent state audit report on Telework shows a very high office vacancy rate. To the tune of $200 million annually can be saved by consolidation of office space. As a citizen and taxpayer, this seems like a massive waste of taxpayer funds. Who is the Treasurer and Governor accountable to when it comes to these decisions? The Legislature? The People?

I wish we had more opportunities for control agencies to hold office hours after they come out with a change. For example, if there is a change to recruitment, CalHR could hold a series of virtual meetings to explain them and answer questions. If there's a change to procurement, an opportunity for DGS to talk through the update and answer questions.

There should be blanket licenses for similar departments. For example, why aren't communications teams all using the same email client, or social media services, or editing and graphic design systems?  The same goes for IT, data teams, etc. etc.  The licenses are very expensive and many departments have the ability to invest in that. It's a cost savings idea and one that makes it seamless if/when a staff member transfers to another department or team.
I want to make things more efficient and improve processes. I feel we are behind other developed countries in infrastructure and I want to help us catch up.

1.	Interview Skills Training I recommend implementing a course to help state employees strengthen their interview skills. This would provide valuable support for employees seeking to grow within the organization and ensure they are better prepared for competitive opportunities. 2.	Reporting Concerns About Leadership and HR There should be a formal process, separate from the union, where employees can report concerns regarding the conduct of Directors, Deputy Directors, or HR staff. For example, if HR representatives are dismissive or rude, employees should have a safe and professional channel to raise these concerns. Employees have the right to follow up on matters that directly affect them, and there should be accountability when those rights are not respected. 3.	Transparency in Hiring Practices I have observed instances where Directors or Deputy Directors appear to hire individuals they have previously worked with. While it is sometimes stated that leadership was not involved in the hiring process, those same individuals are still selected for high-level positions. To avoid the perception of favoritism, greater transparency in hiring practices should be required, including clearer documentation of decision-making and candidate selection.
Diet quality within California run state institutions (State Hospitals).
Push through with extensive public transportation additions (high speed rail, etc).  These projects support our economy and build better quality of life for Californians.

As part of the administrative credential for education, it is taught that administrators should use feedback from staff, stakeholders, and students when prioritizing areas of improvement and how to effectively address needed improvements/changes.  I have noticed that there is zero staff input when changes are made.  This makes employees feel unappreciated and unimportant as many of them hold the key to making effective change.  I often feel punished, especially when guidelines become stricter and the paperwork increases with changes.

A primary issue with the State is that we have geographically locked the vast majority of our jobs to a city that doesn't even rank in the top five of our State's population. Sacramento is less than 2% of the state's population; being able to recruit and retain talented individuals from across the the state would dramatically increase the quality of our workforce. To achieve this, we would need to implement more robust teleworking policies.

Many of our processes are outdated and rely on paper copies and wet signatures. It's time to move everything to online and digital signatures, which reduces paper waste and printing costs. It also helps with efficiency in filing/finding documents, etc... We have access to the Microsoft Power Suite and should be utilizing it to the fullest. SharePoint/Power Apps/Power BI/Power Automate etc... all lead to cleaner data and less time wasted. While there is an effort by CalData to move departments into the future, I think that there are people within those departments who are already making inroads into that space and that departments should tap them to help others in their departments get ahead.

I believe a standard employee/department directory for every district should be created and kept up to date so that when outside agencies, vendors, the public, contractors, etc. are asking for the correct contact-it can be found easily on Onramp.

My family lives near a controversial public use space. It feels like the California public agencies use access to/control of that space as a means of gaining political points and they do not take science and impacts to the local communities into account. It's quite disillusioning to see the government through that lens; a means for people to promote their own political futures/get money from special interests over being true public servants.

I would stop dividing people and bring them together. Our politicial system is not geared towards that goal. the hate expressed by those of both parties is just sickening. The salution is simple but not easy. Do unto others as you would have them do unto you. People need to stop blaming others for their failures and take responsibility. Averyone is trying to change others when the fact is the only one you can truly change is yourself, start there. Stop looking  for the speck in your nighbors eye and remove the plank from your eye first.

Why California has to always be the FIRST, BEST or Waymaker.  So many other States are ahead of us in efficiencies, but we can't seem to accept that and leverage their efforts to build our own. That wastes taxpayer dollars and state employees time and motivation.

First of all, I want to thank all the staff responsible for bringing this Forum into existence and the staff that are running and monitoring this forum.  Here's my contribution after working for the State of California on and off for 15+ years.  State salaries Certain State positions are pigeonhole into arbitrary (or based on outdated data) salary ranges without taking account location and parity with the private sector.  For example, the HFEN (Health Facility Evaluator Nurse) position. A comparable position in the private sector, in the San Francisco area, (according to Google) is around $155K (for a nurse consultant).  My compensation for 2023 according to Transparent California =$98,271.44 (not counting benefits as the average salary quoted by Google does not include benefits)  I've been with the State long enough to know that trying to ask for fair compensation is like trying to get blood from stone.  I get it. We are painted with the same brush. We are stigmatized as being lazy, inefficient, bureaucratic etc. What tax payers would reward State workers with a pay raise? (slim to none)  So here is my proposal. Don't reward my efficiency with more work and flowery praise. Compensate me financially. There's an Over Time budget within each department. Give me access to the OT budget, I don't mind writing a proposal on how I can increase your/my Department's efficiency or backlogs to solve your problems. I'm ready to kick start this in my Department ...Are any Managers ready?

Units that promote sharing of knowledge and expertise rather than insisting that specific roles need to be the sole knowledge base for a process make things run much smoother when staff go on leave or leave entirely.

I believe one of the biggest issues in most of the departments of state employment is the low morale. Of course, it may vary in the workplace and institution, but I believe it impacts directly the efficiency of our work. Low morale could be the cause of a variety of reasons and would be hard to condense it to a specific situation.  Maybe if there was a department which would monitor the level of morale in problem areas, it would help us want to go the extra mile in our work areas. if we really felt appreciated and that our work is making a difference.

The primary problem I see on a day-to-day basis is financial mismanagement and waste. Sometimes I wonder how much thought goes into whether my department in particular actually needs the things we contract for. I see a lot of money spent on things that I regard as questionable. I believe we really need to focus on using the talent contained within our own ranks. We contract out for services so often where I feel we can solve our own problems more effectively. Financial waste is a huge problem and I feel that we need to meet more to discuss options other than just throwing money at an issue. And we need to use the auditor hotline more frequently when we see waste such as this.
Usure at this time.
The DMV specifically is pushing people to use the internet .. But the website is confusing ..

As the State Auditor's Office showed recently, telework is effective. It is a great tool available to the state to foster collaboration and retain highly skilled staff. In my role, I engage with community based organizations, researchers, and local government all across the state. I would not be able to do that without teleconferencing tools and support for telework—even if we had the funds to support travel, I can't be in multiple places at once, and it is more effective to have everyone in conversation together. The State government of California does not only serve Sacramento, yet without telework I am less effectively able to serve communities outside of the Sacramento area. Telework saves money, reduces pollution and traffic, and makes state workers more efficient. I am able to do more work in the same amount of time if I don't have to run around a poorly planned building to find a bathroom or navigate a lengthy commute. When working at headquarters, my colleagues frequently have to interrupt meetings in order to move their cars because we don't have the infrastructure to actually support employees working in the office, even on a 2 day/week in office schedule. Additionally, I am less likely while working remotely to experience microaggressions and other behavior from coworkers that could lead to a lawsuit against the state.
Not about California, but this site. It only loads 10 comments at a time and I can't even sort by most recent.

As a 10-year state employee with 35+ years of building design experience in my field, I see the private sector passing me by.  Training to keep pace with my private sector counterparts is essential to managing their design efforts. Greater support (financial & time) for in-house training of design professional would be a great first step.

I am fresh to the State but have decades of experience in the private sector. I have always been a self-leaner and the way I learn is by reading as much (requirement, design, technical, source code, etc) as possible. The challenge I found as a new state employee is that there is nothing available and there is no clear path as to where and how to make requests, even longer tenure colleagues need non-trivial effort to help me out.

I very much appreciate the need for all State Employees to have a shared structure so we all have a similar experience with our State Employment through CalHR. Every department however has their own functionality and needs. Creating a structure that allows for more flex and takes into account the needs of each state department.  This would be parameters outside of the Union contracts.  Creating a framework that has less structure but provides broader guidance instead would allow different departments to create more tailored pay scales and position classifications enabling a more competitive recruiting position. This could include types of bonus plans, performance incentives, singing bonuses, efficiency creation, etc.

During my trainings, I have made sure to speak up to share ideas, and to ask questions. It continues to surprise me how many other people had the same question or think the question was good to ask but would not have done so. Ofcourse , recognition of what are safe spaces to ask questions or share ideas is a must.
I streamlined the process for developing a Community Profile as required by the California Health and Safety Code for Hazardous waste cleanups using Lean Six Sigma.

A small example of a common problem:  We need three padlocks for a new storage container.  These could be had for a combined cost of $35 and a 30 minute trip to the local Home Depot.  Instead, there is a ridiculous purchasing process which will require at least a couple hours and result in a cost closer to $200.  Although in the end it may be saving money as more often then not would rather do without then go through the process, or someone will just buy what they need with their own money.

I work in change management, and that puts me in a lot of unique situations and conversations. I try to implement lean methodologies wherever I can - suggesting ways to cut down on time waste and resolve issues more quickly. I (try my best to) model relational intelligence and put people first and attempt to understand (fully) their issues and concerns. I, along with others, have implemented a lot of human-centered design practices with in the DMV - prioritizing persona building and organizational input within projects. I've started a few affinity groups (or what we're now referring to as employee groups) to create more transparent and equitable communication pathways.

One of the primary problems I see within my department is the challenges involved in the hiring process. This is a great paying job and there are many qualified candidates that want the job. The merit-based system and layers of bureaucracy make it so hard to for individuals to get the job  and Cal/OSHA offices are often understaffed or put up with bad employees because it is so hard to hire new ones. My idea would be to designate a position in each individual district office to act as a liason with CAL-HR and give offices Autonomy top hire independently

A) Clearer more streamlined CAU, SCO, and HR activity directing ETR leave synchronization, CalConnect payroll changes and confirmations B) more accurate handling of State Disability Insurance and Paid Family Leave cases. C) Better collaboration of Federal Labor Law organizations at the county and local level to address complaints, violations, and accountability. D) Assistance with state employees leadership and local Boards when relationships falter. E) EDDNext into an app that improves customer self-service.

One example I'd like to share is the use of Community of Practice meetings with my fellow project managers. These sessions create a dedicated space for us to share ideas, lessons learned, and practical approaches that have worked well across different projects. With this form, we are able to improve consistency, identify inefficiencies, and build collaboration across teams.

Main Point: Need to Encourage and retain talent to improve effectiveness and innovation Problem: Advancement often depends on tenure, not performance or innovation. Hard to reward high-performers  and limits merit-based growth. Doing the bare minimum is often “safer” than pushing for change.Career stagnation becomes normalized. Solutions Incentivize impact, not just time served. Recognize and reward problem-solving, not just process-following. Build a culture of accountability, growth, and innovation.

Bureaucracy. In many spaces we’ve created workflows that are impossible to navigate and often create unnecessary hoops for people to jump through. Streamlining some of the duties that are cross-cutting would aide in getting projects over the finish line. Departments that are responsible for policies that are implemented statewide(DGS, CalHR) could benefit from months long job shadowing to see the policies they’ve created in action. They would be able to bring best practices back and hopefully use that information to process improve.

I lack of onboard training and lack of supervisors knowing the roles of their staff.  I think that each desk should have a desk manual and if each desk had a back up staff member who knows the desk work or is rotated to that desk work on a routine basis would assist when staff vacate the position and a new staff member is hired for training purposes.

I am concerned about latent return-to-office mandates.   I joined the state in November 2020, and have held excluded and represented positions at three different departments within the same field since then. I am now considered a statewide leader in that field. My work is best accomplished remotely; the same is true of my colleagues. I cannot speak for others, and many roles are critically accomplished through in-person attendance. However, a blanket return to office mandate is out of touch with the ground reality of the public employees who keep the state running.  A blanket RTO mandate also puts undue pressure on departments and individuals to justify exceptions, particularly when it comes to Reasonable Accommodations; especially those RA's addressing invisible disability. Although I am aware (as an EEO investigator) that bad actors try to manipulate these civil protections, folks who have engaged in good faith interactions with their employers for many years are extremely anxious. Although their limitations have not changed, the expectations surrounding their employment will if RTO moves forward in 2026 (which, despite protective statute, is common via employer-friendly interpretations of RA law and policy).  To me, the solution is obvious: reject blanket RTO so departments can TRULY treat each person & job uniquely. In addition to cost saving, the state will retain employees enthusiastic about their jobs and committed to careers that don't pay like the private sector.

While strongly adopting a vision is admirable, it has to be done in the context of what is feasible and logical. Lowering gas emissions and establishing programs to promote climate control is a great vision. But you can't simply say everybody needs to purchase a hybrid or electric car by year YYYY without considering the financial ability of each resident to do so. You can't forge ahead on the vision outcome without looking at what is needed to support the outcome (i.e. infrastructure).  And make it affordable for residents to "be" residents of California.

Many of the policies and procedures established and practiced currently by the state are not the most effective, especially when it comes to procurement. For example, we could only go with certain vendors for procurement of goods even if they are not the best in the business and overcharge. Going with vendors outside of the state catalogue would allow us to be more fiscally responsible and save the state some money.

Problems & Solutions: P1) People with state experience have too much of an advantage over potential candidates with no state experience, limiting the expansion and diversity of employment opportunities S1) Provide open training and learning opportunities to all potential hires to familiarize people with state operations prior to applying. Example: An overview video discussing FI$Cal which is a system that is heavily used by many departments but would be unknown to anyone outside of state work. P2) Management do not seek the opinions of rank-and-file staff when proposing changes, limiting the potential for innovative ideas S2) Implement systems like Engaged California on a department level. P3) State exams that test experience, education, and training do not accurately test whether a candidate is fit for a position S3) Phase out this type of exam, as it only provides unnecessary hurdles to qualified candidates, and give more discretion to departments to hire candidates. Hiring process would still check Minimum Qualifications for the position.
I would love to see designated areas developed to provide areas of shelter for the unhoused. e.g. empty lots, dilapidated buildings, or undeveloped land.

This platform is inefficient. You could only view a limited amount of comments without having to keep scrolling to the bottom and clicking and scrolling to the bottom. We cannot quickly survey the landscape of comments to see if our comment has been made already search for comments by keyword and be able to appropriately respond to enough comments because it’s painstaking to comb through them. This is one example of software that is inefficient. There are plenty of other forum like platforms that are proven that could have been used.

I completely agree - I don't even want to get in to how hard it was to get an interpreter for my Upward Mobility meetings with a deaf client simply because the client was not in my same division. And then the appalling push back I got from accounting asking "how could this cost be approved" - things like that. First of all, it should be as easy as picking up a phone to access a virtual interpreter and similarly as easy if I needed to book interpreters for in person occasions, and second of all I should never ever be asked how cost for an interpreter could have been approved. period. I asked for an interpreter and we pay for it. end of story.

Consensus building when making decisions or establishing new policies. Utilizing small pilots before systemwide implementation to refine the process with feedback. Establishing guidelines to ensure equal representation/involvement in a given department's workload.

I work in a process improvement department. We have a systematic, data driven and proven process to guide leadership through decision making efforts when it comes to process changes and effective improvement efforts. It is so versatile and it can be used for big or small improvement efforts. Some of the tools we use without even recognizing we are using them, like work flows. But from what I've seen, the State of California is growing this program and is continuing to train staff in different departments and some departments like mine and internalizing the training and building their own internal Improvement teams.

I am not in a leadership position but have had to take on responsibilities of my supervisor in his absence, and I was responsible for a specific run that required driving to pick up our caller service at the post office. I did it for 3 months and it got done between 11 and 12 every day. Upon my supervisors return from leave, he wanted control back (aligning with other comments about superiority complex) and instead of asking me about how its been working and issues i have run into, he did his own trial and error and his process wound up taking half of the day and multiple different people being involved to complete it. We still do it this way and it makes no sense to me. It is little things like that which add up, but not being a supervisor its hard to mention these things

There are also outdated administrative practices that waste time. Why do timesheets still require manual signatures? Surely there’s an app that can verify absence requests and sync with timesheet data. And why must managers handle IDPs alone? Could HR assist with this process? Not every employee seeks career advancement—some are content as subject matter experts. Forcing development plans on everyone doesn’t reflect individual career goals. Process for training, roles for managers and procedures for tasks should be maintained and updated so staff can be successful rather than set up for failure.

By far the largest issue I see in the state is the problem of turnover and employee retention. Our knowledge bases can take years to develop. Processes like contracting have extremely specific protocols and therefore very specific training. Whenever we lose an employee, that gap can take over a year to fill and the next person might take over a months to over a year to get up to speed. This issue also dovetails into the issue of severe under staffing. Some units are operating at well under 50% of the necessary staff, or even more. When appropriately staffed units need to interface with those who have poor staffing, that causes bottlenecks which lead to months of delay. There just are not enough people to do the jobs necessary to keep the fundamental processes of our bureaucracy moving smoothly. If we can improve retention and staffing, it will go a long way to accelerating timelines and improving efficiency.
chain of command slows things down. Telework works!

I try and keep it simple for providing customer service. Treat your e-mail like a phone call. If you are a customer and you make a call and the person doesn't answer or you are put on hold waiting, you become already agitated. Same goes with e-mail. So, if you get a call or an e-mail and you simply answer the call or acknowledge the e-mail and reply back as quick as you can. Even if it's as simple as saying, thank you for the message, I will research and get right back to you as soon as I get the answer. You will make the customer feel like they are your priority.
Agreed. It should not be so difficult to accomplish tasks.
WE should do better, our actions affect everyone in one way or another

increase in pay.  Better and cheaper healthcare pls. maybe stop cutting our pay to make up for the deficit. Do not understand, why only state workers have to take a pay cut  and furloughs to try and make up for the damage that was done by the entire state. does not seem very fair.  And even then we get labelled as lazy.

I would like the choice of where my income goes. Working for the state, as a sole income provider, with two children, is tough living in California. Our benefits are awesome and often times better than other agencies, yet I'm still struggling to pay rent and buy groceries/gas/essentials because I can't afford to live closer to work and a huge chunk of my income goes to retirement involuntarily. I also like working for the agency I work for, but I'm supposed to try to work elsewhere just so I can get better pay? That doesn't seem right.
Nepotism and the associated negative consequences to other employees in the unit should not be allowed, and should be investigated and corrected.

Current departmental structures exhibit overlapping responsibilities, resulting in duplicated efforts and suboptimal resource utilization. To address these inefficiencies, a strategic reallocation of roles and responsibilities across departments is essential. By streamlining operations and eliminating redundancies, organizations can significantly enhance productivity and operational effectiveness.  For instance, rather than maintaining individual warehouses at each worksite, we could establish centralized regional warehouses supported by dedicated distribution lines to service the worksites. This approach would reduce logistical complexity, lower operational costs, and improve inventory management across locations.

Accounting/Trust: Gobs of inefficiencies with a chain of command that doesn't know the details when I bring up better ideas. HQ does NOT understand what we do in office at institutions and policies contradict each other. We waste thousands of sheets of paper per month on statements when they could go out on the tablets. We spin our wheels answering GA22s for balance inquiries for hours a day when again, make it available on the tablets. We print monthly court checks for mandatory payments from IP accounts, however each court seems to be entered several times with a slightly different title (ie: Fresno US District vs. Fresno USD) and so multiple checks print out to the same exact place. This is wasteful and time consuming. Correct the duplicate entries so that one check prints per court. Also, SOMS pay sheets mostly print ONE IP per page. This is so wasteful and makes for lots more signing and takes up more room in storage. When asked about at HQ, no one knows how it works so it cannot be fixed. Someone has to know.

The need to push forward on something that clearly isn't working or needs more time in development. Hitting the pause button, while measuring implications, isn't a sign of weakness, it's a sign of self-reflection, accountability, and the want to do things the right way. So many times we have duplicative efforts and efforts that just aren't working, but rather than taking the step back we keep trying to fit the square peg into the round hole.

The modernization efforts that the state is undergoing have been great.  Change takes time and it is amazing to see so many change management staff who are leading these opportunities to tackle our challenges. We have bright and innovative individuals with the State.

Document/form management is a statewide challenge that could more effectively be coordinated centrally. In the previous century, everything went through the Office of State Publishing, and the State Library had catalogued copies of everything that was published, but now each agency has its own content management system and publishes to the web with no centralized coordination. Retrieval largely depends on private 3rd party services. Index each web address and tag with metatext; leverage librarians' expertise to structure a retrieval system facilitating public access. Track revision dates, ownership, and language translations within the same platform.
