Use AI document translation with a common lexicon, have a disclaimer and feedback mechanism to prioritize review (e.g. vital docs), ID bad translations, recommend improvements. Also flag items past a certain revise date. At present we have active standard forms owned by agencies that no longer exist and historic documents posted that pop up when searching for current policy. It is not always clear what is current and what is outdated. Systems like WorldCat and GoogleBooks provide models, and there could also be a concierge function for the public to punch in what they need and receive instructions along with any necessary forms and guidelines (perhaps compiled by AI and verified by human staff, moving to spot checks as effectiveness of the tech is demonstrated).

when staff is expected to complete a job or task. be sure they have the equipment or tools necessary to get the work done effectively. if they don't have time to do it properly the first time, when will they be able to do it again?  we need to be sure that they are ABLE to get their work done correctly the first time, by giving them the correct tools and training to get their jobs done right!

I would like state and local government to ask us what services we need and shift funding to them accordingly. No one ever asks us!  For example, in my city we've been asking for easy public transportation to the airport for years. Cars to the airport clog the downtown streets. But instead, light rail gets built out to wealthy areas. I wonder if this would happen if we knew how many people wanted a different priority.
Keep meetings straight to the point

Supporting, embracing and strengthening telework for CA employees. Understanding that not all CA employees can telework, but for those who can, telework has proven to be very productive with workflow, reduces congestion on the roads (every CA driver can support this, doesn't have to be a state worker), more environmentally friendly, and promotes flexibility. The recent independent audit about CA State worker telework states that CA could save up to $225 million in building expenses with telework.

The State has a penny-wise pound-foolish approach to promotions. "Promotions in place" are impossible to attain. The only way to be promoted is to find an open position req in a different department. I understand that we want to be good stewards of public funds, that we want to avoid even the appearance of nepotism or corruption, and that we don't want to promote without need. And there have been very public instances of nepotism and corruption in hiring and promotions. But the current system forces people who want a long-term career in public service to leave their departments to move up, taking all their "tribal knowledge" with them. It forces departments to cannibalize each another. The system does not consider the value of the months, or years, it takes to train the next person who eventually fills that loss. That value must be given more weight. And if a department is full of long-term people punching above their weight, there should be some sort of extenuating circumstances to make a PIP easier. It's worth it to promote people for their knowledge and ability once in a while, to encourage more people to consider long-term public sector careers.

Requiring employees to return to the office for an antiquated manner of managing staff is absurd. We have been actively completing our duties and flourishing with remote opportunities. Our agency has been able to complete more projects during remote work than ever before yet there is still a desire for us to return in-person. We should be allowed to continue remote work.

I designed and carried out a training program for my coworkers to learn how to use the version control tool GitHub for their coding projects. This allowed teams to more effectively collaborate by eliminating version nightmares that proliferate when multiple users work on a single file and manage them with an old-school approach (e.g., network drive, email, etc.); enabled greater transparency and accountability (at both the individual and agency level); and allowed staff to learn from each other's mistakes in a smarter and more streamlined way.
talking to inmates as a person and getting to know them. I also talk to other disciplines about issues with in the department.

The work can't stop when the 1 person who does the  task calls out sick. There are tasks for example several people can request office supplies but processing office supply refills that just 1 person handles & when that individual are out of office a backlog of requests not getting processed just waits. Management ideally should have a team for each task already designated so that no 1 person becomes a chokepoint and potential bottleneck stopping work from proceeding just for taking time off.

I would appreciate continued flexibility with teleworking. Personally, I am more productive at home. Teams and virtual meetings are just as effective as in-person meetings. Living here in California is expensive, and telework helps reduce expenses and improves work/life balance by removing unnecessary commuting.
Californians need more WALKABLE communities. Let's make strides to reduce our need for cars.
Wasteful spending and offering practical solutions to each problem.

Is there a State translation service available? If there is, it needs to be easier to find and if there isn't... well there should be one. I have been working on getting public safety signage translated and have had to scrounge around for native speakers. This seems like something that any agency that interfaces with the public would need access to.
Our management team lets us corroborate with others to identify and correct problems. In addition, the utilization of AI tools to complete certain assignments for a streamlined process.

Salay compensation for positions comparable to the private sector.  Ok, that's a pipe dream.  How about within $20K of the private sector.   I'm looking at my printed office phone number list from 2023 to now. 28 employees left (90% because of salary, 5% retirement, 5% others).  I've been here on and off for 12 years. It looks like management would rather spend money training new employees rather than pay more for quality.

I would love for California to be as affordable as the rest of the country. There is no reason we, as California residents, should have to pay so much in taxes!! I think we should have a change in the Democratic policies which have NOT been working for anyone who works and lives in California, not just State workers but everyone!

I would love to see California pioneer universal healthcare.  From both a workers' comp perspective and a citizen perspective, healthcare is untenable and unaffordable in the best of circumstances, and bureaucracy and limited insurance coverage in rural regions creates inequity, suffering, and inescapable poverty.  Also, better public transit is desperately needed across the state.  A high speed rail system is necessary to mitigate increasing flight costs with poorly regulated planes/maintenance and increasing aviation accidents.  We need greener opportunities to mitigate the irreparable damage being done to the environment.

Profit over people. There may be guidelines on discussing telework, but it is important to address because it affects not just state employees but all workers in California. Employees are more productive and effective when they have a better work life balance, and this should be recognized across the state. California should be innovative, technology driven, and worker first, leading by example. Stronger protections are needed for workers, tenants, and consumers. Citizens of California need safeguards against profit driven motives in all areas. People over profit for everyone everywhere in the state.

I have been with the State for just over a year, after working in the private sector for most of my life (with a couple of temp government jobs here and there). The biggest issue that I noticed from day one is the amount of bureaucracy that envelops almost every aspect of how the State operates. I pretty much knew that going in, but when I actually experienced it I was kind of shocked. Everything is just so difficult! I'm used to having ownership of my role and various tasks and getting things handled quickly - not having to go through 15 people for something or having to wait 8 months for a PO and then supervisor approval and to only order something from one specific place, for example. Also, I get a lot of emails and phone calls from the public and it can be incredibly difficult trying to determine who to forward to. I often go to our website and sit there scrolling through trying to find the info myself, with much difficulty.   Oh and the way people make payments online - the entire system needs to be overhauled. All of the phone calls I receive are either about duplicate payments on their credit card, or they couldn't log in to their account to make their payment. I then have to take down all their info and email my contacts to ask them to help. Takes a lot of time!  As one of my co-workers said when I first started: "It's about accountability, not efficiency!"

I would like to see Department heads that are elected and not appointed by the Governor. Appointment leads to Department leads being beholden to the will of each Governor and not to what is best for their staff and California citizens. It puts them in a position where they don't have much room to oppose when they find Governor requests unlawful, unethical, or simply against what will help their Department to run effectively. I would like to see more money routed towards affordable housing, affordable childcare, and lowering the sky high cost of living in this state and less money routed to unnecessary government real estate leasing. The citizens need assistance more than we need to sit in office to do work on the same computer we work on at home. Unnecessary office space is an unethical way to spend tax payer dollars. I would like to see more rent control so that folks aren't paying more than half of their income to private equity firms & corrupt landlords. I would like to see a maximum on how much real estate can be owned so that citizens can buy homes. I would like to see caps on what facilities can charge for childcare services. I would like to see expanded public transit so that California can operate like most of the developed world instead of being beholden to car manufacturers & insurance companies. I would like to see more regulation of insurance companies who continuously increases prices for no express reason while simultaneously refusing/reducing covered services.

I never understood why every agency buys the same product(s) at a different contract rate when DGS handles the Statewide contracts that do not have dollar limits for their use and can purchase at scale for the whole state? I realize there is always a cost concern. From the numerous Department I have worked at throughout my career, I  found many agencies were able to save money by not renewing their own Agency contracts and leveraging statewide contracts at scale . I think there is something to be said about the state as a whole consolidating services especially when most are moving to cloud/SaaS . It blows me away that each agency has their own contracts with the same vendors for the same service and one might pay 1 million a year and the other 200K?   Microsoft? Nessus? Cisco?  Apple?  HP?  DELL? RSA? Splunk? Just a couple of examples….

Collaboration between multiple divisions is needed to ensure all programmatic areas are considered before implementing a new benefit or transition. Being less reactive and more proactive will improve customer service and employee satisfaction.
The agency I work for trains the heck out of our new hires until you get to management then it's similiar to what you have experienced.

Problem: As state agencies and departments, we spend so many resources just sharing information between each other (drafting contracts, MOUs, etc.) We are all instruments of one state government, yet there are many data sharing agreements that get created to share what we all believe to be private information.  Possible Solution: Could we lower the restrictions for sharing information through legislative action or more global and general data-sharing agreements? Another option is to collectively share data to a central warehouse.   If we leverage all of our data together, we can be more effective/efficient in our individual mandates.

DHCS pursuing non-competitive bids to award contracts worth tens of millions of dollars. Urgency in procuring a vendor is manufactured due to poor planning by leadership and the only solution proposed is to circumvent the competitive, transparent procurement process. Current vendors who are not meeting their obligations (and who were similarly retained through a non-competitive process) are not held accountable. Leaders are awarding contracts which pay state and federal funds based on personal relationships with vendors and not as the result of a comprehensive, objective assessment of costs and capabilities.

The primary problem is that everything is politicized. Everything we do depends on who is in office, who might offended, and who's invested.  I feel like a pawn half the time. I don't have any sound advice on how to fix it, but I do know that as long as politicians are fighting across aisles with each other, citizens will always get caught in the middle.

I have personally tried. Unfortunately, bureaucracy, red tape, traditional thinking, resistance to change, and status quo is good enough tends to foil creativity and squash new ideas long before their potential is even realized. It's disheartening.

A primary problem I would address is the culture within the State departments. A lot of upper management have an authoritarian complex and seem to go out of their way to punish or reprimand their employees. This is leading to less employee retention and higher stress among departments. If the state wants to begin to hire a new generation of employees, the authoritarian style of management needs to change. Younger generations will not want to be treated the way most state employees are being treated now. I currently do not have ideas to solve this problem, but I feel this issue will continue to get worse as our workforce continues to age and retire.
Ha! that's why I'm here!

I worked at one agency where I worked closely with someone from the Records Management agency (Secretary of State, maybe?) to create a records retention schedule that eliminated this issue for us. I later changed agencies and was surprised to learn that the other admin staff had no idea this resource existed! The State has many good resources and references, and we need to be better about sharing them with each other.

Especially since we have so many positions that have similar duties. I get every agency wants to do their own thing but it gets to a point where I don’t know if any of them know what the best way is! Every place has so many forms but it would be nice if there was some general cheat sheet for typical processes— and which control agencies require what. Like invoices need xyz bc of DGS Sam reference and then each agency would have their own forms to list but it’s all the same! It doesn’t need to be this difficult or confusing

There is too much waste, redundancy and inefficiency.    A very visible example is managing the California coastline.  There are at least 6 agencies in the mix which include:  1. California Coastal Commission 2. California State Lands Commission 3. California Coastal Conservancy 4. California Department of Parks and Recreation 5. California Department of Fish and Wildlife  6. California Ocean Protection Council (OPC)  Additional government organizations with narrower or supporting roles include: • San Francisco Bay Conservation and Development Commission • California Environmental Protection Agency Board • Regional Water Quality Control Boards  I suspect that there are many more that I am not aware of.

First, a few problems affecting individuals with disabilities: 1. Currently, the ADA and other state laws do not apply to rental housing (especially single-family homes) as well as new homes. Because of this an individual with a disability cannot get a home that has a ramp, walk-in shower, light-based fire alarm, or tactile controls. Many of these adaptations are available by default when accessing public facilities and commercial organizations open to the public. Yet, in the context of housing people with disabilities have to spend tens of thousands to make these conversions. There are exceptions for affordable housing, not all people are eligible for these opportunities. The State should make an effort to make sure accessibility is improved, so that homes are available that meet these requirements and the option to make these changes in new homes by lowering barriers. 2. Many states including Washington, Minnesota, Tennessee, and Massachusetts have Medicaid working disabled programs that operate without income or asset limits. This assists individuals with disabilities would like to work but cannot because insurance does not cover services like long-term care. To ensure that these programs remain financially viable the states have imposed premiums of at least 7% of a person's income. California should consider similar programs.  Second, the State should encourage remote work for employees. It improves retention, mental health and employee well-being.

Funding and more transparency. I feel money goes in the wrong places sometimes and we have people making decisions that have no idea what works and what doesn't (coming from CDCR). I also think more schedule flexibility would be nice for state employees, as I often feel time constraints in my day-to-day life that are unnecessary and could be preventable with more flexible schedules.
I have actively provided information and presentations to the public and other state agencies and departments related to my specific assignment in commercial motor vehicle and related industries.

I think longer tenured middle management positions are unwilling to adopt new tools or technology that would assist in efficiency. While the adoption phase of new technologies may be inefficient at first, once people get used to them, it may make completing tasks much easier. I think this would require more top-down enforcement and accountability standards from the executive directors and branch chiefs.

Procurement process. Sometimes needed items for efficient work can take 5-8 weeks if you are lucky to get even if you are out or plan ahead. What about the items that you cannot plan ahead for? There is no way to get things quickly, even paper, pens, cleaning supplies, and other needs. This often results in people paying out of pocket for supplies. There should be a way to get needed supplies when they are needed. The procurement process is redundant, too many unnecessary steps to aquire easy things.

I like to see flowcharts on how processes are handled, whether it internal to the working group and how a request is handled from beginning to end.  this way I understand my role in the process and look at ways to improve it.
Prioritizing customer inquiries and providing same-day responses.

More affordable housing. It is disheartening that, as a state employee, I-- and many of my colleagues--- find owning a home out of reach in California. Despite stable, solid incomes, housing costs are disproportionately high, keeping us from achieving long-term stability. Only 15% of Californian households could afford a median-priced home in 2025 requiring an annual income of $232K.
High taxation percent of earners of more then $2 million/year.  Higher tax deductions for parents of kids younger than 26.

I believe that telework has improved efficiency and morale. It helps balance work and life. It provides opportunities for the disabled community to contribute to the State when they might not be able to otherwise.  It helps improve the environment. It has been shown over the past 5 years to be an effective option.   I would also like to see term limits set into the California Constitution for politicians. I would also like to see the politicians make what the average person in their district makes with the same benefits. That way, if they don't like it, they are more motivated to make the necessary changes to improve it.

Fewer barriers to receiving public benefits. Many more people qualify for benefits than those who receive them, often because the paperwork is just so onerous - too long, and required too frequently. A lot of information we ask for is available through other means, such as tax return data. If we design a system based on the goals of serving the least number of people as possible and catching every single moment of error or fraud, we end up hurting the people we are purported to serve, and conditions for Californians don't improve, further eroding trust in our mission.

It would be good if more forms and documents could be submitted online to our department, including an online payment option, when needed. The amount of paper docs we receive in the mail is huge, when most could be sent by email or online.

Again, updating antiquated infrastructure, such as not having an electronic health record, not having key cards (we each carry a ring of 10+ keys), outdated telephones and pagers, would go a long way in streamlining a demanding day.  It is also very discouraging to meet virtually with SAC staff who get "safety pay" for WFH jobs, while we are on the floor with patients with serious mental illness and aggressive criminal histories.  To hear that they often get more pay to tell us what we need to improve, is demoralizing at its best and infuriating at its worst.

Modernization of California's government is the best way to be more effective and efficient. There's so much waste and excessive bureaucracy that keep our constituents from the programs and benefits that they need and already pay for with their tax dollars. Telework, for example, frees up hundreds of millions of dollars to be spent on social programs instead, and yet for some reason we're clinging to the past of an office mindset from 40 years ago. CalFresh eligibility and paper applications and office visits, something I've seen firsthand, are incredibly difficult for people to get through. The application and reverification process that the Housing Choice Voucher program created online is incredibly effective and simple to use. It would be great to see all customer facing departments use a simple, online system that removes barriers and hurdles between the public and their benefits.

As a Californian and with my expertise as a state employee, the primary problem I would address is the lack of urgency and care in responding to public, as well as internal inquiries (e.g., a penalty abatement request to the IRS taking 60 days to process or internal budget approval requests interfering with immediate needs, such as the need to dispose of hazardous waste within regulatory timeframes, due to long processing times). My ideas for solving the problem I shared includes creating expectations for higher communication standards, such as through departmental policies or other methods, to encourage faster processing times and responses to email and other typical communications methods.

A primary problem to be addressed is the misunderstanding that UI is government aid.  It is not meant to be abused and exhausted ad nauseum.  UI is insurance to be leveraged while in between job opportunities and it needs emphasizing that UI works best for those who work, whether it be temporary, contract and seasonal work until they have obtained permanent work, thereby a new claim may be valid at the BYE so long as there was work lost at no fault of the employee in the most recent 12 months.  The public needs to be aware that they are tapping into the tax reserves of the employers when leveraging these UI benefits and that they should not be abusing the opportunity to benefit from these resources as a matter of sustaining our economic structure. Abuse begets further abuse.  Furthermore, there is a need for workforce localities to reinvest in establishing a new system for hiring that does not involve digital platforms that no longer vet job listing.  Local job listing need to be verified and documented as current, valid and verifiable and then removed upon fulfillment. Human resource systems needs governance and accountability and turning over a system that is respectful of the authority of our local workforce departments could be a viable option for building viable businesses in our communities. This is how it used it used to.
Cutting down on dependency of paper products

I liked that split-roll plan that was proposed awhile back to charge business market-rate property tax instead of including them in the tax controls that voters passed to benefit homeowners. Because reassessment is only triggered when a property changes hands and corporations never die, established businesses have an unfair edge against startups. Beyond having an existing clientele, the established business always pays way lower taxes under the current system.

The state needs to stop spending money on sending new hires to train at facilities that are far from their home office, especially for lower income classifications like the Office Assistant and Office Technician. Although these travel trips for trainings are exciting and refreshing, the return on investment is not enough to justify training trips. In most circumstances, lower paying classifications would benefit more from having a higher salary rather than going on a state sponsored training trip. Office Assistants and Office Technicians are more likely to quit or leave for higher paying jobs because these classifications do not make livable wages. California is expensive to live independently and there is more value in paying these classifications more, and less value in paying for travel and training expenses when employees in these classifications are highly likely to change jobs for something that pays more. The citizens of California would benefit more from having higher paying entry-level jobs in these classifications. Most people don't care about going on a state sponsored training trip when they are going to come back to a mediocre salary. They'll just leave for a higher paying job, thus resulting in funding and resources being wasted on that employee.

A primary way to become more effective and efficient is to meaningfully invest in recruitment and retention. Like many here, I've worked at different departments over several years and it’s become incredibly challenging to recruit and retain talented professionals. Telework and statewide hiring in the early 2020s helped us recruit skilled professionals from across the state. But now, with pay falling behind the private sector, few opportunities for advancement, and new in-office requirements, we lost dedicated employees who have years of experience and institutional knowledge, and try to replace them (if we can), which is expensive and slow.   One of the biggest reasons people choose state service is PSLF. Recent proposed federal changes that raise monthly repayments upwards of 500% and will likely disqualify employees from certain states have taken that recruitment/retention tool away.   I believe CA should create its own Loan Repayment Assistance Program (LRAP) for state employees. We already have successful models with the CA Legislature authorizing an LRAP through CalATJ for legal aid attorneys, and CalHealthCares using Prop. 56 funds to offer up to $300,000 in loan repayment for physicians who commit to five years of service. Building on those for a broader program that is for all state employees would be a powerful tool to recruit and retain talented professionals, keep expertise in-house, and strengthen the quality and stability of public service across the state.

Macro: The primary problem is the cost of running a government that has to balance the needs of the population it is serving without running out money to do so.  Micro:  - Management not promoting people who are competent.  - No proper training guides for new employees and/or training for people who are about to take    over from those retiring or moving to different positions  - micromanagement. especially with telecommuting

Not every duty requires a government worker. Imagine an adopt-a-highway program where residents pick up asphalt from their county roads department and patch potholes in their community. Think "Uber for potholes." Such a program would deliver nearly immediate response, increase general happiness and road safety, and build community pride through direct democratic engagement.

I've got kind of the opposite situation where we can't fix the underground regulation that's been in place 20 years because the advocates like it better than any evidence-based options we have come up with.

As a six-year employee, I've noticed that after training by a peer, information given and supported by "procedure" didn't match with provided *procedure documents* and sometimes did not match to *procedural sources provided by legal*.  There is frequently a disconnect between the legal definition of words and the perceived meanings of them by managers and workers as information is handed down.
More training and guidance, Third-party consulation in hiring and streamlining antiquated processes

Besides the challenges related to RTO, one of the biggest issues I’ve experienced as a state employee is that some salaried managers expect hourly staff to work on-call, weekends, or beyond regular hours without additional compensation. When I’ve tried to set boundaries or decline unpaid work, it has at times resulted in retaliation or a sense of “quid pro quo,” where cooperation is exchanged for fair treatment.  A potential solution could be to ensure that duty statements clearly define expectations around on-call work and overtime. Additionally, management should receive better training on employee classifications, what constitutes on-call/duty officer status, and how compensation for these duties should be handled.

Also from job posting, interviewing to hiring is too long and convoluted - some positions take over 6 months to secure - for an office technician - that is ridiculous. It doesn't need to be that complicated and convoluted.
Agreed, PIA is not the cheapest or the best quality.  This is a disservice to the tax payers.  And the fact that it takes an hour or more worth of accounting to buy one item is ridiculous.

One primary problem at the California Highway Patrol is our use of physical mailing services like the USPS and FedEX. Our department's policies often require original signed documents to be snail-mailed or overnighted to our headquarters or division offices. Money spent on these mailing services could be avoided by switching to uploading and emailing scanned documents. The money saved could really benefit our department by using that money to increase the salaries of some of the lower paying clerical jobs such as the Office Assistant and Office Technician classifications. Our office has experienced volatile position turn-around because we don't make a livable wage working in these classifications. So, it's really frustrating to see vast amounts of money being spent on sending papers in the mail when that money could be used to better the lives of the people working in the offices throughout our department. Our policies on utilizing mailing services needs to be changed.

I want the state government to operate as efficiently and effectively as possible with a sense of fiscal responsibility and excellent customer service to best meet the needs of California residents. I believe embracing permanent telework is one avenue to reaching these goals.

Concern: Cal/OSHA practices Political Safety almost exclusively, when the Citizens of California deserve Professional Safety.  Fix?: Professional Safety is all about evidence and fact.          Political Safety is not that.

We hold ourselves to a higher level of integrity by being supportive, responsible, engaging, and clear about our actions and decisions. At the end we all work to deliver a higher quality product/service to the people of California in a timely manner, and we do it diligently.

Contracts seem to be done without much public knowledge or oversight. There are significant pay gaps in contract positions vs state employee positions. It’s feels demoralizing to have contractors making three times the amount with better benefits. I no longer suggest that others work for the state. I also suggest that new grad work as contractors first since the state will not allow us to transfer into contractor roles.   Also, the benefits are not keeping up with the rising costs of healthcare, which makes paychecks lower ever as pay gets higher.

Telework can generate significant office cost savings for the State, provided state employees telework three or more days per week. » Under the Governor’s April 2024 directive requiring state employees to work in the office two days per week, the state auditor estimated that 19 selected departments spent almost $117 million in fiscal year 2024–25 on nearly 3.2 million square feet of office space that was often unused in the seven large state-owned office properties we reviewed. » If state employees telework three or more days per week, DGS has estimated that the State could reduce office space in DGS-managed state-owned and leased buildings by approximately 30 percent, which could generate cost savings of as much as $225 million annually.   Since the Executive Order that requires employees to return to the office 4 days a week, we have lost vital IT staff that were crucial to many important projects. To hire and train for their backfills, we have been set back years. Additionally, it will cost the agency more money to train and get them up to speed.   I would like to see agencies be given back the autonomy to set telework policies that work for their departments.

As a new employee in a large department, I'm already seeing some issues with siloing between branches and divisions that is resulting in duplication of effort, which leads to turf issues and confusion among staff and external partners. In some of these cases, we have consultants doing work in one branch that staff are doing in another branch, with no awareness between the two branches that the same work is being done. I think a few things would help with this: more communication both up and down the chain within branches, better communication between branches, and stronger leadership to communicate the expectation of collaboration and alignment between branches to break down silos, reduce duplication of effort, and clarify roles and responsibilities.
Bi-weekly meetings that allows everyone to talk about their tasks and challenges (if any) and work collaboratively as a group to come up with solutions.

As a newer state employee, I believe we waste too much time updating content on our internal and external websites. Every hour wasted has to be funded from the taxes of hard-working Californians, and so we should try to reduce that waste.   I believe the latest State Web Template is a great solution to get all of our sites using a similar codebase. However, our department is having to update HTML code by-hand, using nearly obsolete software.  I propose using a open-soure framework like Laravel, which runs on PHP. It would allow us to easily port the State Web Template components into reusable componenents that could be placed on web pages without having to painstakingly copy code. We also could probably provide much of the content in Markdown format, which could be converted to accessible HTML on the fly. Laravel also has some database-driven content management system options such as Statamic.  The end result is that we could save time and money for Californian, while also providing more consistent and timely content.

I do not disagree. But part of the reason we have an 18 page document is because there are layers upon layers of accountability and legislation that we are trying to adhere to. It's easy to say we need to cut down, but how to do so while still ensuring that: We meet recycled content certifications, bids, check if the vendor is delinquent on CDTFA or FTP taxes, whether SB/DVBE has a CUF evaluation, ensure there is backup for the awarded bid and solicitation, ensuring general provisions (GSPD 401) are incorporated if necessary, ensuring they are verified to do business in the State of CA (registered with Secretary of State), that they have a sellers/resellers permit through CDTFA, the Std 16 DFEH (complianceprograms@calcivilrights.ca.gov), Bargaining Unit Notices have been sent to unions for any contracts to ensure that state staff can't do the work, Bidders Declarations (FOR ALL COMPETITIVE SOLICITATIONS OR RFOS GSPD-05-105/GSPD-05-106), Bidders instructions, CalRIM approval, Certificate of compliance with State IT Policy (SIMM 71B-IT PURCHASES $5,000 AND OVER), etc.... there are literally two more pages of listed items that procurement staff need to ensure are present.  How do we maintain accountability to the public, and litigators, if we do not have these documents? I'm not a fan of all this either... I think we've just made things complicated because, government....

Implementing technologies such as learning management systems and human resources management systems to allow us to do more with less staff. However, these systems would be better if they weren't restricted by red tape, and they would be more efficient and cost effective if they were used statewide instead of at a department level.

Teleworking, or lack thereof. Look, I understand not all jobs can function properly through telework but for those that are more than capable to telework, it needs to be a full 5 days a week thing. If you want to go into the office, by all means, but it should be decided by the employee and the quality of work they provide. Full telework is the closest we can get to what I think is the perfect work/life balance - 8 hrs sleep, 8 hrs work, 8 hrs your time. Instead, my current schedule is train station at 615, in Sac at 705, at work at 735, back to my car at 530. That's over 11 hrs dedicated for my job. In what world is that balanced?

I know it's almost impossible to reign in at this point, but the favortism in my dept (CDCR food services) is out of control. There is a lot of seperation of staff due to a particular ACFM who breeds and encourages discord in my dept. I feel my dept doesn't do enough to show appreciation for the role that we play everyday in rehabilitating the incarcerated population. We tend to get left behind. We don't feel valued by our agency.

We now do a daily time sheet - sign in/sign out.  A daily work log, and must send a Teams message when we go on breaks - that we also put on the sign in/out sheet.  It's horrendous. And we have the ability to do better.

We were having the same issue. We established a committee that coordinated the effort of all sections within our Division to create an informational document about their section. It included and org chart of their section, roles and responsibilities, and a contact list. The committee reviewed and revised each sections information and created a one page document for each section and stored it in a centralized location. They also created an onboarding document that gave an overview of the Agency and detailed information about our Division, Mission, Vision, Goals, Values, and Leadership Team. As part of another effort each section created a Knowledge Exchange Session (KES) video of what their role is within the Division. We still have pain points for new hires but this is a step in the right direction.

I found many issues start with poor communication. Through several years in my department, I have observed management routinely fails to communicate down to the supervisors or rank and file. Additionally, I have observed management almost never looks down for answers to problems. I believe this is due to a consistent belief that only managers are stakeholders on departmental issues.  In my role as a second-line supervisor I have made it a point to know what is changing and keep updated on regulatory changes. When something does change, I make it a point to communicate the change to my staff and allow my staff to provide input on how that change is implemented.   I found through my career, CDCR management consistently fails to identify the stakeholders when programs change or get implemented. I try to overcome this failure by allowing my staff to feel as if their expertise and opinion have value. Though one-on-one and group conversations with my staff I ask how they would make it better, or how they could have handled issues differently in the future. Unfortunately, I cannot share this information with management as either they would demand staff to be "written up" for a minor mistake or explain management makes all the decisions.
As a long term employee I still feel and see this, especially if you switch departments as it is like entering a new realm but with same issues.

Technical, administrative, and leadership staff largely work extremely well together, with a great team and service ethic, and are genuinely good people.  The relationships and team dynamics of state government, especially when focused on finding and implementing solutions, are one of the greatest resources in state government.

GovOps innovation initiatives: Some Government Operations Agency (GovOps) projects succeeded precisely because they were executed outside the normal CDT oversight and bureaucratic layers. Freed from rigid processes, these efforts were able to test, adapt, and scale innovations more quickly.  COVID-era DMV innovations: During the pandemic, the California DMV demonstrated that when necessity reduces red tape, innovation flourishes. DMV rapidly deployed online services, streamlined transactions, and reimagined customer interactions — breaking away from the traditional government service approach. These efforts proved that agencies can innovate effectively when given flexibility and autonomy.  Lesson Learned: Innovation thrives when agencies are trusted to act, operate outside rigid oversight frameworks, and are held accountable for results rather than process compliance.

A problem I am seeing more and more is that we are receiving the employer's protest letter (for an Unemployment Insurance claim filed) and a note gets entered on the claim but no other action is taken - even when the employer clearly states the claimant quit or was fired (and the claimant told us they were laid off due to lack of work).  There needs to be an action list that the employer's response gets added to so someone can address the issues that the employer has raised.
As a California resident, I would like to see a decrease in taxes, more affordable housing, and a humane approach to the homeless population.

I personally think AWARE is the main cause of almost all the  Problems at the DOR. The website we use is beyond slow and takes up so much time. I timed how long it take to open a Attachments or a plan and it takes 32 seconds, and I open almost 50 documents a day in AWARE. I did the math and that equals 26 minutes  of waiting at the end of the day. That is precious time that I could have met with a participant, but instead I'm waiting for an attachment to open.   Also, each time they update aware it messes up almost everything, every time. In the last update it make it so I couldn't see SSN or any valuable information and it took weeks to figure it out.   secondly, I think "Activity Dues" (AD) are an awful way to delegate tasks. When changes are made or notes were left on the AD we don't get told at all. We have to remember to go back and check, and with a caseload of 200, that is almost impossible.   Lastly, The state need to live in reality and realize that people don't want to work/stay at the DOR is because our pay absolutely absurd!! For the amount of work we do, and the amount of situations this job put us in, we are treated and paid like our work doesn't matter. People at the DOR feel like the state of California doesn't care about their civil servants who dedicate their life's to helping the lives of people with disabilities.   If you care about this organization and want it to be better, act like it.

We've revamped our Upward Mobility program and the way it operates at our agency to cater to the clients we serve and to what works best for us as coordinators. Our clients have specific needs as our agency has many classifications most others do not have, so it's been key for us to make sure we're providing all of our participants with options outside of the typical (TPA) desk jobs like OT. Many of our participants are custodians, and there are very useful promotional ladders within classes like Custodian that serve our participants much better than anything in an office setting.

I think having a third party entity from outside the government assess our inefficiencies would be incredibly helpful. We can only do so much from inside the system, plus everyone wants to protect their own livelihood so few government employees would be in favor of cutting their own department/program.

In my role as a state employee, I have worked on several initiatives to improve efficiency and customer service. For example, I helped streamline the grant review process by creating a centralized tracking system, which reduced processing delays and improved communication between staff and grantees. I have also revised correspondence templates to make communications clearer and more professional, helping applicants understand requirements and next steps more easily. These changes not only saved time for staff but also enhanced the overall experience for the public and ensured that programs ran more smoothly.
Having weekly or monthly meetings with the entire team and showing others what you are working on and creating desk procedures anyone and everyone can understand.

Simplify TAX for everyone! Ideally, all taxes should be administered by ONE agency and only ONE phone number for help! Please get rid of all these fancy tax agencies in this state! Many people leave California because they are taxed on things like how much oxygen they consume on a daily basis!  Create a NEW agency called California Department of Tax! ONE phone number for taxpayers to call and get answers to anything related to TAXES and FEES.  Make it EASIER for businesses and individuals to pay their taxes. ONE PAGE tax returns!  This will create efficiency and effectiveness and make the 45 million Californians happy!

Compliance requirements are not evaluated by those performing the compliance check to determine if they are providing the intended value. There is no feedback mechanism to provide this information back to lawmakers to undo ineffective regulations.

DGS acts as the building department for state-owned facilities. If a department has a repair or modification that needs to be done, it must go through DGS and they will do the work themselves, contract out, or very rarely delegate the project back to departments. DGS charges an absurd amount for their overhead and project management costs, and takes several years to complete projects.  For example, our department needed a new HVAC unit that took DGS 4 years to complete and a new roof that took 5.  A private contractor can do this work for pennies on the dollar and in days vs years, saving the state millions.  Why can't DGS delegate some of this work to departments?  They say the government code requires them to do everything, but how long do we need to keep referring to these code sections without considering amendments to streamline government?  My department has had to lay off seasonal staff because DGS' costs kept going up and we couldn't afford to pay for a repair that was taking 3 years and also continue our operations.  And if DGS has vacancies, the work just sits there and doesn't get done until they hire and train more staff.  This is an INCREDIBLE waste of state resources.  Also, take a look at Unit 9's salaries.  The amount it costs to pay DGS for this work is WAY above what the state could be paying a private contractor, even at a prevailing wage.  Please streamline this process and allow/require DGS to delegate more facility projects to the departments!
Streamlining communication with staff
State Employees are incredibly underpaid. The entry level positions should be starting at a wage that is livable for a single person.

To this, I cannot agree more. I work in purchasing and an 18 page packet is nothing. In order to buy  4 packages (48 pens) of Sharpies it takes 3 bids and 51 pages, involves the actions of 4 different employees, and could take a week or more to finally dispatch the PO and there is still more work to be done after it goes to the vendor to actually consider this request finished.

A fair and unbiased review of telework for State employees should be completed. Departments should be allowed to present production data from before and during telework. Have them paint the picture of how the department's work is or isn't impacted by telework, and the cost savings associated with telework. A true cost benefit analysis needs to be done. Additionally, survey State employees to see how many in person meetings they have during their in-office days. Are they engaging in person more or less? Do they still log in to Teams or Zoom for meetings?
I am a problem solver. I would focus on what is working and what needs to be grown positively.

The rollout of Microsoft Teams at the beginning of COVID was a game changer. The integration with Sharepoint and ability to casually chat/ping coworkers has been a huge benefit. It has also helped improve the remote work experience because it offers a place to chat casually and can still offer good connection outside of the office.
Fewer "committees" to study programs and training and more actual dedication to improving the programs and training. If we could eliminate the waste, there would be more available funds for programs.

New Technology - More tools for employees.  Purchase one contract that can be used cross agency's so it allows for a seamless process.  i.e., Civil Rights Dept. uses Tempo but DOJ uses Workday to input timesheets.

Opening up the route of communication to the public. I am a receptionist and am often told I am the only human they were able to speak with. Folks like being able to reach us as an organization and feel heard. So actually taking the time to assist rather than acting as their opinions are an annoyance.

I have seen a number of large IT projects fail or limp along for years costing the taxpayers a lot of money. Rather than go out and have contractors propose solutions without fully understanding the ever-evolving business needs, the state should develop a "proof of concept" in house prior to going to RFP. This means developing enough of the tool to see system limitations and get an idea on its overall functionality. This would help develop requirements of the tool as we see shortcomings of what is developed but could also be used as a way to help contractors understand what is being sought out. I would suggest involving program (the internal state teams that would use the tool) early on to ensure the business rules are represented. At the discretion of the State, then we could move to a formal RFP and demo the proof of concept or we could continue development in house.  I will avoid referencing specific projects, but I can confirm that this approach would have ruled out proposals that relied heavily on tools that did not meet the need while saving a considerable amount of money.

The biggest problem in CA government is authority.  Authority is going unchecked.  I know several occasions where decision makers are overstepping their boundary.  Even worse is when low level (say AGPA) is trying to do the best job they can, but don't realize the negative impact they are creating or the laws that they are breaking.  For example, a AGPA needs data from another agency.  They are blanketly ask for the information.  The other agency, doing the best job they can do, says Ok and collects the data. However, collecting that information could have taken 80 hours, or require a "system" to be built to accommodate the request.  When looking deeper into "the information", it was never required by law to collect the data. This is unnecessary waste.  Times this by 1000's of request, and we're all working for each other, and not the people of CA.  State employees are very hard workers and try their best.  Sometimes, we need to step back and make sure we are doing what we should be doing, and not what we want to do.  This wasteful work leads to wasted time spent, delays in the work that should be done, and selfish pride.  Laws - we all have to abide by them.  However, many laws have "sunset dates".  it would be nice if the State of CA did a cross analysis of what policy was created for what law.  if that law was changed, modified, or unsetted, then the policy needs to do the same.  Laws aren't typically created from scratch; they take an existing law and totally rewrite it.
I wish all state forms used plain language. I have a masters degree and when I get a form I cant understand how to complete I wonder how someone new to working for the state would handle it.

Regulations are completely necessary only because for-profit businesses refuse to grow up and be responsible environmental stewards. We can not put profit above natural balance. We need harsher penalties for large multi-national corporations that do business in California and call California home, but pollute the land, air and waters around us. We need to rein in acceptable marketing practices, we need to discourage gaming the system, we need to preserve and maintain the natural balance of our State's great natural resources. Lastly, we need to ban artificial intelligence from existence. It will never live up to what is promised and it is cost prohibitive, both with the natural resources it wastes and the cost to humanity. California could lead the way for making artificial intelligence a fad, a silly plaything and have it fall quickly out of favor.

There is a wonderful opportunity through a COVID bright spot to redesign how state employees engage in their work. The recent legislative audit outlined several ways telework is a benefit to all Californians. I urge all state agencies to build on the efficiency, financial savings, recruitment benefits, and environmental protections telework affords. Don’t we want state agencies to recruit and retain the best employees from throughout the state? Telework is a golden opportunity to move forward to create the most efficient, productive, and inclusive workforce to best meet the needs of Californians.

Telework as default would also help alleviate housing pressures in metropolitan California, ensuring that there could be economic development and housing development across all areas of the state. Traditionally "left behind" areas could see much more development and it would be a more equitable California for all.

The primary problem is that the state tax system faces inefficiencies and risks due to data gaps, manual processes, and limited use of modern technology, which lead to: • Difficulty detecting underreporting or misreporting in a timely manner • Time-consuming manual work for employees • Limited taxpayer accessibility and convenience • Skill gaps among employees in adapting to new technology  The ideas to solve the issue as state employees are: 1. Real-Time Data Matching with Other Agencies • Build secure connections with agencies like FTB, EDD and IRS. • Use automated cross-checking to flag discrepancies before audits or deadlines. • This reduces underreporting, improves fairness, and minimizes manual comparison.  2. Mobile App for Taxpayers • Provide an easy-to-use app for filing, payments, and notifications. • Improves compliance by making tax obligations clearer and more convenient. • Reduces taxpayer confusion and the volume of support inquiries.  3. Training on New Technologies • Invest in upskilling employees in AI, data analytics, and customer service. • Prepares the workforce to handle modern tools efficiently. • Ensures smooth adoption of new systems and better service for taxpayers.

Excessive bureaucracy.  Outdated Technology, laws, statutes, manuals, etc. Dollar amount thresholds in many cases are not updated to reflect inflation or cost of living increases. Outdated software programs that create more manual processes needed to accomplish tasks.  Allocation of funding towards deferred maintenance of equipment and buildings. Everything turns into an emergency once it's broken because no consideration is given for deferred maintenance. Government is always reactive vs proactive, and this costs time and prevents employees from getting their jobs done when equipment breaks down and the bureaucracy involved to get it repaired.  Lack of resources or resources that don't fulfill their obligations or doesn't respond to emails or communications (Departments that have oversight not responding to communications in a timely manner or at all in some cases).  Better HR processes to allow new staff to be trained before exiting staff leave. The state has zero regard for this, and each new employee is left to fend for themselves and try to figure out what the person they replaced was doing. This causes a ripple effect with everyone this person works with and creates more work for all involved.  Departments not meeting their own requirements and posted completion promises. For example, a department quotes a 10-business day review time, but reality is 30-45+ days is the normal.

The Red Tape that management needs to get through in order to improve processes is very tedious. Although, management requires policies and procedures to be followed on a statewide level, local leadership needs to have more autonomy to customize policies at the local level.

Reducing government redundancies and bureaucracy would make state functions much less expensive in the long run. An overhaul of the system, while burdensome in the moment, would greatly improve employee and citizen experiences in California and could lead to better financial stability for the state.

As a Californian and state employee, one primary problem I would address is how we support and retain the state workforce. Too often, employees face challenges such as outdated classifications, pay that does not reflect the cost of living, and limited flexibility in how we work.  To solve this, I would advocate for three key improvements: first, expanding telework options where appropriate, since telework has proven to increase productivity, save costs, and improve work–life balance; second, raising pay scales to be more competitive so that we can attract and keep skilled workers; and third, ensuring proper classifications so employees are recognized and compensated for the full scope of their responsibilities.  By addressing these issues, we would not only strengthen morale and retention among state workers but also improve the quality of service delivered to Californians.
Not accepting "it's always been that way" as a reply.

The underlying problem is pretty straight forward in my view: California’s government is dominated by a single party that prioritizes ideology over practicality and common sense. Sky-high taxes, crushing regulations, and one-party rule have made it hostile to business and middle-class families. Soft-on-crime policies created safe havens for criminals, while homelessness is out of control despite billions spent. The state throws money at symptoms without addressing root causes like addiction and mental illness, and restrictive zoning makes affordable housing impossible. California isn’t broke, it’s just It’s failing because its leaders prioritize woke virtue signaling, radical environmentalism, and identity politics over law, order, affordability, and common sense. Unfortunately, I don’t think that’s going to change under a one-party rule.

PROBLEM: I work at the North Coast Regional Water Quality Control Board in the Cleanups Unit.  We transitioned to a paperless file system  back in 2006 when the State began requiring reports/data to be submitted and uploaded to the Geotracker database. There are still 100s of existing folders, reports, etc. (one estimate was that our unit's file room contains 1/3 of a mile of paper). Environmental pollution cases are unique: we're required to keep records of all sites, closed or not, in case land use changes in the future (also, it's the law). We routinely have PRA/FOIA requests to pull files for consultant review, and more than 75% of the time they'll ask us to scan and email them.  Our region is also vast- some of these consultants and landowners live 6 hours away from out office, and some have physical handicaps that limit their mobility, so we try to oblige. But actually taking apart a file, scanning it, categorizing it, and uploading it is extremely labor intensive. A small file will take a few hours, but even a medium sized one requires one or two days (the scanning is rapid, uploading and naming is laborious).  SOLUTIONS: 1) hire dedicated admin staff to do this work, 2) subcontract it out to a bonded document scanning service. BENEFITS: 1) Reduced labor costs for professional and admin staff 2) improved public access for these records 3) potential to upload to AI for detailed summation and analysis. Thank you,

The reduction in telework and fully remote positions is a significant setback for the state workforce. When the State allowed fully remote positions post pandemic, I was thrilled. For me, that meant I finally had the opportunity to be in state service, which is a career path I am passionate about. Because I do not live in Sacramento, my options for state jobs have always been limited and not typically in my professional and academic field. Fully remote positions opened the door for me, and I am sure many others who want to contribute but are limited by their location in California. With the new state mandate, an essential repeal of fully remote positions, my ability to promote or grow is almost totally gone. I feel that maintaining the flexibility to offer fully remote positions strengthens the state's ability to retain a diverse and talented workforce, which will only make California stronger.

PR. There is such a deep misunderstanding of why working in the public sector must be different than working in the private sector. All people hear about are the slow wheels of bureaucracy and government waste, not realizing that the design is purposeful. Obviously there ways to make things more efficient, like digitizing forms, modernizing ways to make payments, etc. However, my experience is that most agencies are working on these issues. Just look at the DMV, or being able to pay a parking ticket on your phone, amazing! However, due to the nature of our work, sometimes it's important to work slowly and methodically, with standard procedures. When we "move fast and break things" or suffer from burnout trying to "optimize" our workday into hyper-efficiency, those things effect people's lives very deeply and if we can be thoughtful, we can make them better than the original concept. When we do that, it always pays us back, fiscally as well as socially. Because the public is so focused on waste, instead of hiring internally, we hire contractors, and instead of hiring the best contractor, we have to hire the one with the lowest bid. This creates real waste that hurts the tax payers and frustration of employees. There's a reason why most private tech companies crash, and that's no way to run a government.

I think there should be more collaboration within the CA Natural Resources Agency (CNRA). CNRA houses many large critical Departments such as CalFire, CDFW, State Parks, and Dept of Water Resources. Each of these large agencies hoard positions and funding, often for overlapping initiatives. Greater collaboration on multiple issues could help address critical funding issues in the preservation and protection of our natural resources for the benefit of all CA citizens.

Amen!!!  I moved to CA 30 years ago and I needed to buy some shoes.  I could find what I wanted, but I would have had to go to two different stores, in two different towns to get them.  Why they wouldn't ship them since it was the same store is an enigma to me, but they wouldn't.  When I contacted city transportation, I didn't have my own vehicle at that time, it would take me two days to get two pair of shoes because of the amount of time it took to get to just one store from where I lived and I couldn't get to that store in two different towns on the same day.  Needless to say, I didn't get any shoes.  It baffles me that one cannot take a bus to a shopping mall.  It baffles me that public transit doesn't run more often, it baffles me that there are not at least certain consistent schedules to go to public places that everyone needs to go to, like malls, medical facilities, grocery stores, libraries, DMV, Social Security; these places have set hours so why can't public transportation run consistently with them?  Why can a person only go to one place in a day?  With public shootings and violence, I'm not sure I'd want to be on public transit anyway.  I try to avoid public places to start with even though I can drive there.

Nursing is grossly understaffed. Upper management is rarely if ever in the clinics engaging with their medical staff. Nepotism and favoritism are rampant. An SRNII told an LVN the other day that she should stop bringing up issues regarding safety because she, "won't get hired when she gets her RN license, because management doesn't like people bringing up issues." Education relies too much on staff to train new employees. There's zero continuity in the clinics, so that plan is fraught with issue after issue. Custody has become too complacent in regard to safety and security. A resident in C Yard was caught with eleven diabetic syringes/needles. That particular resident gets insulin twice a day, so they were able to acquire all those needles over a period of time. Residents bring their tablet to the pill window and in the clinic. The tablets aren't allowed to leave the housing units for obvious reasons. A patient reported to an exam room to complete their appointment with me this week with a hot cup of coffee. I didn't notice he was holding it until we were in the room together. The porters/residents in our clinic are allowed to "clean" without anyone directly watching them. The porters/residents are given access to areas they should never be given entry to.

Telework, when possible, is the biggest issue.  Telework works.  Consolidating office space (combine multiple departments/agencies into spaces) will save money, as per the state auditor's report. State Workers working remotely will also save money by reduced commutes and the associated climate change savings, which used to be important to our state government, and by putting money back in their own communities, versus being expected to prop up the communities around the office buildings their departments are located in.  It also increases employee happiness, and as a long-term state worker who has been in offices with both great morale and awful morale (both prior to the availability of telework, and not related to telework at all) happy employees make for more productive employees.  Telework works, the state has shown that.  Reversing course will only hurt the state going forward.

The Federal Patriot Act makes it very difficult for homeless Californians and Californians who have to live in cars, to open a bank account.  However, homeless Californians still need a bank account to apply for housing, obtain services, and apply for jobs and benefits.  I would do something to make sure every Californian can open some type of bank account.    My Idea: If that means providing an alternate way to verify the identity of homeless people, approved by the state, I would implement that.  I would not require a residential address to open a bank account if I knew someone had been homeless.  This may require federal approval.  Giving homeless people a way to identify themselves helps them apply for public services.  This is an important barrier to ending all homelessness.

Our meetings have no minutes kept or notes provided.  They are generally rambling.  If you miss the meeting, you miss the material.  After six years of being here, people yell "how much time for the meeting?" at the end of each - I have suggested a timekeeper and minutes - there is no traction there.  There is also little use of email for issues of substance.    It like we use oral history to run our processes.

The State of California fails to provide alignment between California State University certified degrees in Technology to the evolving needs of the state. Specifically, Computer Science Engineering where data optimization and web application development is learned fails to be supported by the state's second most influential union, the Professional Engineers in California Government (PECG).  As a Civil Engineer myself, I have had to learn these skills on the job, with no vision ahead supporting the recruiting of the necessary talent needed. I served in PECG as a union rep and I learned it's up to Department of Technology to change their ways, not PECG. Overall, this is the biggest misalignment statewide affecting our ability to remain cutting edge and adapt to the future with AI.

As a state employee with the LCO I have seen a lot of people promote to higher positions when they were not doing their previous position well. While others are not being promoted despite working hard and caring about what we do. Because of this I have seen us lose a lot of great workers and will continue to, as I am working on leaving the LCO as well. I have been here over 10 years with only a promotion from OT to MST. If we retained and promoted quality workers and not terrible workers, we would be far better off. I personally feel that the entire wage training team has been a waste of time and money because they do not appear to be effective or productive.
I agree with you! so many times I wonder why we can evaluate the supervisor without being afraid of retaliation.

I believe the core issue lies in the lack of employee responsibility and accountability. Government bureaucracy is structured in a way that pushes decision-making upward through the chain of command, concentrating authority in the hands of a few. This results in an overabundance of policies and procedures that strip decision-making power from the subject matter experts—the individuals actually performing the hands-on work.  Furthermore, this system fosters a dense layer of middle management that often controls decisions without fully understanding their upstream or downstream impacts. This disconnect between decision-makers and practitioners undermines efficiency and responsiveness.  To truly improve government operations, this overarching management structure must be reformed. Such reform will likely require legislative action to decentralize authority, empower technical experts, and streamline bureaucratic processes.

Provide two pool cars for the CSTI Team Members, and assigned CAL Gas Card. These folks travel up and down the State using their own vehicle. This needs to stop, and OES needs to start supporting these incredible team members better. This is great that you are taking input, but if great ideas to improve efficiency and support for these amazing hard working professionals is not implemented, Then change cannot occur. I hope whatever improvements are implemented by this process are shared, the ones that have been selected and "WILL" be applied.

Efficiency and sharing innovative ideas across departments - It has been proven in many cases that working in diverse team settings and across various projects helps individuals gain a broader perspective, encounter specific scenarios, and build the experience necessary for career advancement. At the same time, teams benefit from fresh managerial ideas and a willingness to take calculated risks that often come with different leadership styles.  Therefore, rotating managers and supervisors between departments can provide advantages on both sides. It fosters innovation, encourages the exchange of ideas, and allows successful practices from one department or agency to be implemented in another. This cross-pollination of knowledge and experience contributes to overall organizational growth and improvement.

I would address is the breakdown in communication, specifically how long it takes to report and resolve operational problems. In my experience, communication often functions as a buffer that insulates leadership from the daily realities faced by frontline staff. When issues arise, responses are frequently delayed due to layers of approval, bureaucratic hurdles, or vague assurances that “it’s being looked into.” This delay not only prolongs the problem but can exacerbate it to the point of creating liability or safety risks. Unfortunately, when these issues escalate, leadership may downplay their prior awareness, further eroding trust and morale.  To solve this, I would advocate for a transparent, time-bound communication protocol that includes:  •	A tiered reporting system that tracks issues from initial submission to resolution, with clear accountability at each level.  While some systems are already in place the emphasis should be on ensuring managers cannot minimize their role when issues persist.  •	Mandatory feedback loops where leadership must acknowledge receipt and provide status updates within a set timeframe.  •	Consistent process audits to identify bottlenecks and recurring delays, followed by actionable reforms.  •	And most importantly, a culture shift that values timely action over bureaucratic deflection, recognizing that unresolved issues create stress, inefficiency, and risk for those doing the work.  This should be done while respecting existing labor rights.

I would also like to see updated administrative practices. In my department, we are using an Excel Sheet that we export to a PDF and give to our manager. Also, although there is too much bureaucracy in some situations, in other situations, I find I don't have the answers and there are inconsistent rules...

I routinely create spreadsheets for routine actions because no mechanisms exist on a state level. My spreadsheets have personally saved thousands of labor hours. I am being 110% too. There should be state level tools to have staff work efficiently. I am looking at the thousands of forms where the top of the page has the date for a one-day sheet and every box below has another date box, for example. The person who makes those forms should be made to fill them out till they retire.

I've been a state employee at the prison for more than 10 years. These are the most common problems we see there.   -Overriding Inmates to a lower level when they don't deserve it. By overriding youth offenders, medical Inmates or non-violent offenders to a lower-level causes disruptions in positive programing. Inmates should be placed into an appropriate security level based on their security points only. -Promoting and Pushing the Suboxone program to receive time off makes Inmates that would normally not take it, sign up for the program just to get time off or sell the Suboxone in the dorms/housing area. Don't give time off for the program and you will have only the Inmates that really need it on the program or don't give out Suboxone because by the time they get to State prison they should have already gone through withdraws and be clean. -The overuse of medications to Inmates is out of control. We are no longer a prison but a medical facility. Most Inmates take medication in hopes to get time off of their sentence or get on Social Security when they get out. Thousands of pills are spit out or sold in the dorm. Have doctors not medicate Inmate so easily.

I've been involved in multiple efforts to improve internal business processes using the lean six sigma methodology. From hiring, to travel expenses, data processing, and a few others, some projects went well and some less well. Ultimately, I feel all these projects have helped me in my own process for identifying areas of improvement, determining methods of measuring these areas, and helping teams develop ideas for improvements that can work and will actually be implemented.
The problem is repetitive work (ie. data entry) that can be minimized or streamlined using readily available software and/or AI.
I tell the inmates what services that they can utilize so that they can be healthy.

Staff in positions that don't require them to be in the office every week should have the option to telework full time. Telework should be encouraged for the cost savings, efficiency, productivity and work-life balance.
Just bring the positivity to the workplace and leave the negativity outside of the workplace.

There is a huge range of income-qualified programs (IQP) and subsidies offered by the state. However, each one often has its own individual requirements. Centralizing coordination on streamlined/simplified IQP requirements would save a huge amount of work in terms of verification and avoiding having to replicate similar work across departments.   Here's the vision someone who is qualified for a subsidized electricity rate may also be qualified for CalFresh. However, the requirements are not aligned, which means that these two programs cannot automatically "talk" to each other. Ideally, it would be good to have a universal crosswalk of IQPs so that if you sign up for one, you are offered access to all of the others at the same time. This might look like a central hub for accessing all social/welfare benefits run by the state where you fill out an initial intake survey (limited to 15 questions *max*) and then have all programs you qualify for presented to you for sign up, in such a way that you can just check a box and batch-enroll in multiple at once.  Undoubtedly this would require some legislation to fully align, but doing the groundwork to understand all IQP requirements and set up the crosswalk is the first step. But that requires someone who can work across all departments that offer some kind of IQP.

I have to agree, when I was hired for my position, I asked what my job responsibilities would be and was told "we don't know".  I have been fortunate to be able to define and add services to my role, but I hope this will not be an issue in the future.

Lack of efficiency in our business practices. For instance, when I am purchasing supplies and services for my agency, due to the overwhelming number of rules I must abide by, the state is paying a significant amount more for the same product or service.  We are bound to only using “certified” small businesses that many times are off shore companies with physical address that comes back to a private parcel pick up location.  The majority of time these orders are fulfilled by the vendor through Amazon or Walmart.com.
