A significant amount of time and money could be saved if agencies were allowed to utilize local vendors or store fronts.

One step towards affordable housing, in my opinion, is to not allow corporations to buy up single family homes. It has been reported that by 2030, corporations will own fifty percent of all single-family homes in America. Single family homes should only be owned by single families. The New American Dream is home renter-ship rather than home ownership. This is just plain wrong.

Communicating to current and future owners of Mobile Home units on the proper and correct way to transfer ownership of these units. Multiple times I encounter situations where new owners bought MH units without proper documentation and without due diligence as to who the prior owners were, creating problems for them to register as the new owners.

From my perspective as a California resident and a state employee working in human resources over programs that deal with licensure processes, anything that reduces time at each step benefits both staff and the public. Whether waiting for a nursing license, or standing in line at the DMV, smooth and effective processes save time and reduce frustration. This requires processes that are efficient and consistent across all state entities, not just within individual departments. I think that establishing clear communication, and standardizing procedures across the state is essential for ensuring a positive experience for residents and improving overall efficiency.
Don't expand programs, first reduce costs by improving efficiency!
I would like to see California move to a 32-hour work week.

In that case we need to increase the number of permanent State Park Interpreters. As it currently stands, we don't have even part-time/seasonal State Park Interpreters at every State Park. We also need to have more competitive pay for State Park Interpreters, especially now that Interpreters have functionally taken over the management of all operations staff at many State Parks ever since Rangers have become Law Enforcement only.

While I understand that this is not where we are supposed to discuss work conditions, ignoring them is a disservice to all of California. Addressing these issues helps to ensure a happy and healthy workforce which is key to good customer service, performance, and efficiency. Workers need to have their needs met in order to perform at their best. The state should strive to provide the best work environment possible to each of it's employees. This should not be a one-size-fits-all approach as every human has different needs. Some people need more support than others. Some require more guidance. Others need less. The state should also do more to understand neurodivergence within the workforce as it plays a part in the needs of each individual. This is also true for each role, not classification. Each role has different requirements of technology, tools, communication, supplies, etc. Tailoring things to the individual and the role they fill will greatly improve efficiency, productivity, collaboration, communication, quality of work, etc.

Primary problem that I'd like to address is how to work around the forte of employees rather than their weaknesses. Employees need internal trainings to sharpen the skills they already have to make it more effective and strong. Roles should be given on the basis of their expertise and the bandwidth depending on their job duties. Mark their personal and professional achievements using different platforms.

I see that there is a huge waste in spending with the ISUDT program within CDCR.  The counselors that are hired are only required to run their counseling classes Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays.  Tuesdays and Thursdays they do not hold classes so they can "write case notes." However, you can see these counselors using their time to take breaks, walk around the institution for exercise.  I urge the state to evaluate the data and see if this program is genuinely cutting down on the substance abuse problem amongst the inmate population.  The funds for these programs would significantly cut expenditures for CDCR.

Classifications within bargaining units need to be thoroughly reviewed. I currently serve in a classification designated by the State as an Administrative Worker, yet I am exposed to toxins and unsafe environments approximately 90% of the time. Despite performing duties comparable to others who receive State Safety retirement benefits, my position is excluded from that designation.  I believe the State should evaluate positions assigned to agencies with inherently high-risk environments and implement reclassifications where appropriate, rather than requiring these changes to go through the bargaining process where they often become negotiation points. Employees in specialized or marginalized classifications—such as mine, which includes only 13 positions statewide—lack the collective representation needed to advocate effectively for these changes. A more equitable review process is necessary to ensure fair recognition and protection for all employees performing hazardous work.

We are leaders in tech in California, but our government agencies use outdated and clunky technology. Processes need to be streamlined, and technology needs to be updated. Investing substantial money to bring California's government agencies to the 21st century and partnering with successful non-profit organizations would be the first step in solving this issue. Then, offering training in the new platforms and technology to ensure employees maximize their benefits must follow.

Onboarding new employees is a painful process; especially gearing them up with the right tools, which are usually technology based. Since very few prospects start the day they receive the offer letter; imaging laptops/tablets/pads /cellular telephones/ computers so that they have the same imprint, days before an employee starts should be helpful; checklists to see if they have access to all of the right tools (HR/timekeeping, browsers, e-mails) should be part of the duty statement; there should be an automatic ticket created with IT, days before new employees start, for a check-in at the end of their 2nd full day; to put some teeth behind it. managers/supervisors should be evaluated on how fast their new hires get equipped (specific to the department & role) & as a further incentive, laggards (those in the bottom quartile) should have to attend mandatory training on proper onboarding processes.

As state employees we have been described as the backbone of California. We show up everyday and provide California's most necessary services. I believe a backbone to the human being is vital and is to be well taken care of.

First we need to reduce the amount of state employees and encourage private business to flourish. We're in a budget deficit and the state can't afford us. We need to provide efficiency solutions as competent thinkers and then we can look toward hiring.

Economies that are structured with a primary goal of concentration of wealth have unintended negative results such as poverty, isolation and scarcity and ideologically based conflicts.  One of the ideas to diversify economic security is a fairer flat tax for all (removing exemptions). This flat taxation idea also helps secures housing and jobs for all thru subsidies offset by the flat tax and creates a liquid cash flow (capital) to help maintain the economy as we shift to more sustainable systems not dependent so much on non-renewable resources with are finite. By broadening the definitions of success we can address phenomenon like corruption, toxicity, hoarding and emphasize values like sharing and improve empathy and caring generally. As we share intelligence and apply it to these common goals people experience and learn from the experience of others so problems that threaten societies are minimized as the cooperation crosses typical socio-economic and other common isolating conditions that threaten an optimal healthy form of democracy and threaten environmental sustainability.  The results are predicted to offer a more sustainable way of life where greater forms of equilibrium and harmony may thrive and the diversity of our intelligence more positively be expressed and celebrated.

I've found it so insane that we have to rely on another department to move up and/or down positions in another department all because of "seniority". One person who has shown and put themselves out there more than another and that person don't get anything because they don't have the seniority, but that other person will get a position they don't deserve.  It's not fair at all. Also, too I feel like if a person accepts a management position they should be required to takes classes and learn how to appropriately talk to and handle staff. Multiple complaints and nothing to be done because of "seniority" again. This program or "ways" need to be looked at again. Ultimately it should depend on management to determine who moves up or down.

The California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR) operates multiple firehouses across the state, but currently lacks a cohesive and standardized organizational framework.   To enhance operational efficiency and emergency preparedness, the department would benefit from implementing a clear chain of command. This could include appointing a Sacramento-based Fire Chief to oversee statewide operations, supported by Regional Division Chiefs and Battalion Chiefs stationed at each firehouse. Battalion Chiefs would supervise Fire Captains and ensure consistent training, coordination, and readiness.   Establishing this structure would significantly improve the department’s ability to respond effectively to emergencies, particularly during statewide crises

Too high cost of living and state worker pay too low. I should not be living paycheck to paycheck to just have the basics in life. Also, car registration for EVs needs to be dropped significantly. What's the point of buying an electric car if you're paying 3 times the amount to register the car to offset not paying the gas taxes...we still have to charge the car. It just makes it expensive for no reason.

To do my small part, I implemented and easily searchable index of procedures for the work done by my unit. I make it clear to staff that they are responsible for updating the procedures for tasks they are responsible for. In addition, I identified a backup person for all tasks. Sometimes even a secondary backup. This has worked well for many years as team members come and go.   Also recently, our department has been creating eLearning videos for new staff to introduce them to the different sections/programs and what they do. For example, an Accounting 101 class, Budgeting 101, Introduction to the Training Section, etc...
I find that texting as a way to communicate was effective and good at keeping people informed when we were working together.

I worked at an employer where all departing employees were invited to do an exit interview with a neutral third party and then the information was deidentified and used to make corrective changes. This helped address wage, management, and other workplace condition issues.

Right now, there are a lot of departments with good best practices, good processes, good policies, good technologies. The departments that don't have those things are too prideful to ask the other departments to share their secrets. We need a process where we share information more generously.

In my field, the lack of the implementation of current technology in almost every aspect of my duties becomes more and more evident.  Much of our personnel are used NOT to accomplish our primary mission but to collect and track stats, prepare memos and reports, and process literal paperwork.   Modern digital databases and internet-based solutions has the ability to eliminate much of this time-consuming work.  We need an investment in the right people and talent to find technology based solutions to eliminate the need for manual data entry, stat collection, and paper forms.

I was directly involved in a request from DGS to Caltrans.  DGS wanted to collect data on "every asset" that Caltrans controls.  That's a huge, tall order since we have millions of assets.  After looking into the "Why?".  It turned out that DGS wanted to find out all the vacant property that Caltrans controls.  Just by saying the word "all assets", creates a whole new meaning to this request.  It's a list of about 1000 properties that Caltrans has stored in a database, and not the millions of trucks, guardrail, nuts and bolts, maintenance equipment, etc....  big difference.  In addition, this was coming from an AGPA who interpreted the law to collect all assists.  Luckly, we elevated to much higher authority, and we all concluded it was a misinterpretation of the law.  This saved Caltrans millions.
Yes, I have been part of "committees" when I felt like one or two people could have made all of the decisions. Too many people involved with small decisions.
Make the workforce smarter, not larger.  Simplify task, take a few educated risk, sunset old processes, and modernize.

With years of experience in my field, I've had the opportunity to observe what works and what doesn’t. As a result, I’ve helped develop more streamlined processes to improve both efficiency and accuracy. For example, we’ve implemented internal logs, checklists, and verification systems that help double-check our work and reduce errors. These tools have improved consistency and accountability within our team.  I take a hands-on, supportive approach when onboarding new staff. I train them thoroughly and monitor closely while also giving them the grace to learn and grow. I’ve found that setting clear expectations and leading by example, especially when it comes to prompt resolution of issues, helps create a strong culture of reliability and trust. My goal is to avoid making excuses and instead focus on getting things done, which ultimately supports our field staff and leads to better outcomes across the board.  Our team also works very collaboratively, and we’ve built a strong understanding of how to support each other, share knowledge, and problem-solve together. That team-based mindset has made a big difference in how effectively we serve others.

Yes! Bureaucracy is a big hurdle - I come from private industry and am just amazed it has become very difficult to do "busy" on a daily basis. How can we cut the bureaucracy? How can we become more efficient and effective? How do we encourage and reward our employees for their efficiency and effectiveness?

>>Problem: The Six-Month Probationary Period for AGPAs is Inadequate to Properly Train and Evaluate >>Solution: Extend AGPA Probationary Period to One Year ------------ I recommend we align the probationary period for Associate Governmental Program Analysts (AGPA) with that of Staff Services Analysts (SSA), Staff Services Manager I (SSM1), and most other state classifications. The current 6-month probationary period for AGPA's is insufficient for thorough training and evaluation, particularly for new hires without prior program knowledge and experience. This short period forces managers to make premature decisions about an employee's capabilities, potentially leading to the rejection of individuals who could excel with more time. By increasing the probationary period to one-year, new AGPAs will have adequate time to become proficient in their roles, ensuring fair evaluation and comprehensive training. This change will also expand the hiring pool, allowing managers to confidently consider AGPA candidates, knowing they will have sufficient time to develop necessary skills. The 6-month probationary period should be retained for AGPAs promoted in place, as they already possess relevant experience from their SSA roles in the same program. Extending the AGPA probationary period to one year for new hires would be a win-win for staff and managers.

The state should invest as more in public transit to make access to where we live, learn, and earn more accessible. Paying $125 for a parking spot shouldnt be more attractive than a free monthly transit pass.

I think we should take look at the effectiveness of the Waterboard. They are in place to regulate water and pollution discharges. I believe they are failing, and this should be looked at. The fees are excessive, and their processes are slow and ineffective. They should do better, or relinquish some of their duties, including reducing fees appropriately.

Maybe. That said, completing the state application process means you have a certain level of tolerance for state bureaucracy. How many of those "best available applicants" would get frustrated and leave while waiting for their boss' boss' boss' boss' approval eight months into project development?
Tax Auditor Training.  Regular, relevant, and frequent training about auditing different industries and office procedures.

Built applications and KPIs for transforming and automating antiquated and labor-intensive processes that improve operational efficiencies and enable leadership to make informed decisions that improves business operation effectiveness.
Streamlining the process I'm involved with

Programming workflow processes, I have found, is one of the most effective ways to improve efficiency in the public sector (as much as the private). Unfortunately, supervisors have been of the mindset that we "do not have the budget for implementing that sort of software". But this point becomes moot if the work is primarily done in-house and when the number of labor hours is reduced as a result. Streamlined workflow processes can provide the same quality of work, and a return on investment is almost always achieved.
Bureaucracy. Also the amount of time it takes to hire someone.

1. Load balancing throughout the state by reevaluating what has changed post-pandemic. Many departments/agencies found more efficient ways to do things using technology. We should share any significant changes that might help others and redirect the extra bandwidth to help folks who saw an increase in workload, even if they work in a different department or agency. 2. Create a surcharge for vehicle registration based on mileage to ensure that people using the roads more than others help maintain them consistent with the wear and tear they put on them.

As someone who has been with the state for a few years, it appears that there is a culture where people feel its acceptable to neglect their obligations and duties without any real accountability. Most times the work is shifted to individuals who are actually doing the work and there is no real disciplinary action for those who don't. This attitude not only undermines productivity but also fosters a frustrating environment for individuals who are committed to their work. This disconnect can result in lack of motivation among employees who strive to uphold high standards. I believe we can do better in promoting accountability and recognizing the contributions of those who genuinely contribute to the team's success in order to have a more positive work environment. Employees should, in my opinion, have more ways to voice their opinions without fear of retalition, and they should be fairly offered opportunites for advancement based on their performance. Creating an environment that encourages open communication and rewards good work can make employees feel more motivated and involved.

The primary problem is excessive costs the State is paying for work from vendors and contractors that could be performed by full time state employees. Additional, state buildings should be state owned properties that are regularly maintained and updated instead of using third party real estate owners. The state can save tax payer dollars, be a good a steward of public funds, conserve and preserve our environment, and decrease traffic congestion, by implementing policies that are modern and utilize technology such as remote and hybrid work. The State used to maintain a website showing all the cost saving effects of telework.
I would like to have California's tax system be redone to not rely so heavily on high earners during wealthy periods. I would also like California to be able to put more money into its reserves.

I think that staff should have the ability to anonymously review management annually. I believe empowering staff to give management feedback would improve leadership and foster a culture of transparency.
Homeless. Convert malls to shelters and help people get back on their feet.

I understand that bureaucracy can be problematic pretty much wherever you go but it is very disappointing to see how wasteful and inefficient things can be. I am somewhat new to state service but I hope to help this problem along once I put more time in.
Thank you for saying that. Managers need to be held accountable if they do not give an employee a fair shake.
Having empathy, without judging has always helped me. Which allows me to understand and have patience and focus on the concern instead of taking things personally.

I have seen similar feedback shared. My time at my Department has highlighted just how hard it is to implement change. Workgroups, steering committees, SME participation, requests and requisitions, policies, procedures, IT procurement all making it nearly impossible for our programs to function in a modern sense. Why? It was always done ‘this’ way. Bureaucracy is good sometimes. Helps to stave off rash and quick decisions that could be costly. HOWEVER, this comes at a cost of being agile, providing better services and improvement.  Working in silos, being beholden to general fund and tax payer acceptance/willingness to fund our work is frustrating. Funded or no we are just trying to do our best to provide for you!

For those that desire the comraderie of in-office interaction, there has always been an open door policy to come into the office to work. Everyone performs better in an environment that they are comfortable in, not one in which they are forced to be in.
If the employees are not doing their job, it should be a smoother process to retrain those employees. Information needs to be more fluid between agencies within and outside of each agency.

I feel the institution staff should mirror the HQ staff, work wise, pay wise, and classification wise.  The institution staff are the boots on the ground and I feel have more complex cases and more interruptions, but we are in a lower classification which means we are compensated less, and we are not allowed to telework like HQ staff(which would allow us to focus and dive more into our cases without interruptions).

We can make California government more effective by implementing long term telework. With digital systems, agencies can process requests, respond to the public and complete requests faster. In emergencies, public health crisis, or severe weather, employees can safely and efficiently report to their home offices without additional risk. Cost savings for California is clear when telework is implemented. Agencies save money on buildings, equipment, utilities, office supplies, etc. Telework will eliminate daily commutes, thus improving air quality in California, reducing risks of accidents, and giving employees time back to improve their mental health. California can attract top talent by offering this perk.

As a state employee with 19+ years of experience, having worked in a variety of roles and at a few different departments, I noticed that lack of consistency and continuity have attributed to problems throughout departments. State employees and leaders alike need clearly defined expectations and guidelines to ensure accurate and timely service to those we provide services.

I report directly to the Deputy Director of my division, and asking lots of questions has proven to create more effectiveness and efficiency than anything else. In turn, I'm able to ask the right questions and effectively communicate the direction of the Division with staff. I've also created systems around ongoing projects to streamline executive review and approval processes (i.e. creating logs, utilizing reminders, prioritizing by determining urgency versus importance, etc.)

Problems:  - Lack of vision and commitment to achievement, growth, and excellence. This saps motivation and can lead to a public service workforce that's just "going through the motions" to get the paycheck / no longer spurred by desire to serve the public. - Hierarchical org structure that minimizes the ideas and opinions of rank-and-file employees. - There are few "senior staff," non-management positions. This results in many people being promoted to manager roles that they're either unprepared or not suited for.  Solutions:  - Opportunities for people at all levels to participate in developing organizational vision and goals.  - Foster a culture where staff are encouraged to share ideas even if/when they're contradictory to "direction" from above. - Creation of more senior staff positions where people can move up in agencies without becoming managers.
Maybe we get that budget under control first...

Hi. It is not a secret that in the next 5 years, technology will evolve at a much faster pace than ever before. Is our beloved State of California ready for serving our future generation? Do we know what that future may look like and what the demands are? It is certian, that If we do not plan for it now, we all lose. Thank you.

State of California should eliminate form/contract requirements for services under a certain threshold (e.g., $1,000 a year). This will reduce paperwork as well as allow more vendors who provide low-cost services but do not want to/cannot sign a contract for a minimal dollar amount.

CDT implemented the PAL process under pressure from the legislature to reduce costly failed projects, which means that extensive business requirement documentation is expected to take place before programming begins. Even assuming business users are able to fully articulate their needs up-front (big if), the speed with which technology and business needs can change means that by the time a big project is approved, there is a good chance the plan is already outdated. Such slow-to-launch projects also encourage shadow-IT, with analysts developing their own internal business tracking practices while waiting on IT. This leads to having x number of various conflicting half-solutions in place that make change management and clean implementation of a centralized solution more challenging.

Can we have an overarching State policy regarding using ChatGPT for training purposes? It would make researching laws, rules, and regulations much easier for analytical and attorney staff, as well as allow for more effective onboarding. This would allow for a more standardized uniform approach amongst the various State agencies that appear to be having trouble creating their own policies and implementation methods but would still afford individual agencies the ability to incorporate any additional policies/procedures relevant to their respective work.

As an overqualified woman who has gotten passed over for lesser competent, male colleagues, especially those with connections from within, I find it difficult to be able to respect management decisions fully. I also have seen supervisors favor male colleagues more and treat them with favoritism and coddling. They get special treatment; they are given respect; their ideas and thoughts are valued over women's perspectives. It's a trend in the office such that women are not even surprised anymore. This is a distasteful yet realistic aspect of working for state today. Perhaps it is emblematic of a larger trend of continued lack of respect for the perspectives of women and of their works, which is seen as of lesser value. We need fairness, impartiality, and respect.

I've been a teacher with CDCR since 2016. I never in my lift have seen so many "hands" being involved in the easiest of processes. For instance, to get student prior transcripts sent to us, I have student fill out transcript request, hand that form over to our OT, the OT then emails/mails the form to the said school, the school sends transcripts back. If student is a graduate, I fill out another form to request their removal from education, DocuSign it to my supervisor, and the supervisor then requests the drop from the institution's assignments officer.  Attendance works similarly. Within 15 minutes of class starting, I fill out a form showing absent students and email it to our education officer. Education officer spends his time calling each IPs housing officer, if they can be reached, to verify if IP is coming to school or not, then the education officer notes "A" time, "S" time, etc ... and returns to me to fill out SOMS attendance.  I feel there is so much wasted energy and time that could be used elsewhere to make our programs run more smoothly and with less time to process things.
We are constantly streamlining and improving the efficiency of our work through working sessions and ongoing discussion.
Digitize all records including Employee OPF's.  This would reduce the waste of paper resources, streamline the sharing of files, and reduce wasted time looking for OPFs.

Efficiency, cost-savings and environmental benefits. Based on the best available data (also supported by the recent State Auditor's findings) the state has the opportunity to leverage a hybrid work schedule of two days in office to create a significant cost savings by reducing unused office space, decrease transportation-related pollution, and providing significant health and financial benefits to state employees by helping increase work-life balance and reduce transportation-related cost such as fuel and parking. The data also supports a hybrid work schedule of two days per week as increasing employee efficiency by creating a work environment that is less stressful and one in which the employee is able to focus on the work without the distractions and stressors related to commuting and potential inter-office conflict.

Internally, the State of California and how it operates does not reflect that we are the 4th largest economy in the world. The fact we would ever have a budget deficit defies all logic and basic arithmetic. Since, in the United States, we are considered a "donor state" in reference to our relationship with the federal government, anytime California projects a deficit, we should just reduce our "donation" to the federal government to keep it balanced at the very least, and create a buffer of revenue as a means to be fiscally disciplined. Secondly, we need to take large corporations to task for boasting California as their home, but slighting the State when it comes to taxes and being disciplined environmental stewards. As an example, the oil and utility companies are running rough shod over the State and poisoning our lands and waters. Ultimately, this recouped revenue would go along way to make State worker pay, not only competitive, but superior to the private sector. Sweetheart deals between the State and big business need to be thoroughly scrutinized and contracts rescinded for bad actors.

The workplace culture needs improvement. Staff often compete with one another instead of collaborating. The mindset of “that’s not my job,” “someone else will do it,” or “I’m not volunteering” contributes to the negative stereotype of state workers being lazy. Unfortunately, that perception is often reinforced by reality. We need more people willing to step up, work together, and focus on shared goals.  I appreciate the effort to provide jobs and recognize the importance of accountability and stewardship to taxpayers. But we must also streamline processes, empower managers, and foster a culture of teamwork if we want to improve outcomes and public trust.

Effectuating change feels impossible due to how long rule-making, procurement, and other processes take. We should consider removing some of the bureaucratic and unnecessary steps to these processes to allow them to be accomplished in a shorter amount of time.

One of the biggest challenges I see is the complexity and inefficiency of internal processes. Employees often spend significant time navigating redundant approvals, unclear responsibilities, and siloed systems. This slows down work and delays how quickly Californians receive the services they need. Ideas to Solve It •	Streamline workflows by removing unnecessary steps and defining clear escalation paths. •	Invest in modern, shared systems so departments can collaborate more effectively instead of duplicating efforts. •	Empower employees with more training so decisions can be made at the right level, without excessive bottlenecks. By simplifying processes and fostering collaboration, employees can spend more time focusing on service delivery and less time on administrative hurdles ultimately improving outcomes for residents.

The problem of adding more plastics in the landfill. Caltrans is doing a great job picking up litter from or highways and freeways, we are filling up thousands of plastic bags every month statewide and all the plastic bags end up in our local landfills.  I started recycling the plastic bags and reusing them.  My idea is to ask Caltrans maintenance personnel, volunteers and contractor to empty all plastic bags and recycle them and send to the land fill just the litter they collected.
It's great to see the state is amplifying employee voices and co-creating problem statements and solutions with employees. It does encourage folks to think beyond the current needs of the day.
I agree. Also, I believe communication skills need to be improved across the job classifications.
Stop hiring employees for temporary projects only to have to keep them employed after the work is complete. Either utilize more limited-term positions or hiring more contractors.
Also frees up traffic for those that have to be at the office/on-site.

I think we should be able to work remotely. We have proven we can do it. I actually work more when I work remotely. But for those of us that have families, it gives us a great work/life balance, with less stress, more time for life and family.

Continue telework for the positions that can thrive with it. Build employee trust and loyalty that way. I'm more willing to work later as needed if I don't have to spend longer time on the road to get home for working late. Reducing traffic by teleworking benefits all and not just the worker. Let's help each other out.

The primary problem that I see are executives overloading lower management and analysts with projects and unrealistic goals.   I also feel like we as State Workers are not appreciated by our own government and we are used as the patsies when things go wrong. We end up being the ones to suffer when the government fails to meet their goals. Billions are being diverted for other programs yet State Workers get their pay threatened constantly by going over budget.   We need to be appreciated by our executives and our own governmental leaders. These are the issues I hear amongst coworkers.

There are so many silos and everything is decentralized. Agencies seem to prefer to do their own thing (and request funding for it) then share or overlap resources with other departments. Many jobs and layers could be centralized and be more efficient. Possible areas for centralization: IT support, HR onboarding (why does every agency have a different onboarding system), Recruitment,  Program management

Telework Favoritism  Problem:  Managers allow their favorite employees to telework without supervision and provide all these reasons why their favorite people are allowed to telework. The employees they do not like, they do not allow them to telework, and make up all these excuses as to why they are not allowed to telework.   Solution:  Telework should not be on a case-by-case basis, because that allows managers to create their own criteria for which employees can telework and which cannot. Telework should be based on qualifications. Can that position be done remotely, or can it only be done in the office.

Plain language requirements should be defined objectively in state law to ensure clarity and consistency across state communications. Currently, many state websites and publications are filled with jargon that confuses the public.  To address this, I recommend a peer review program where agencies evaluate each other’s websites and publications for clarity and readability. Internal experts often struggle to recognize how unclear their writing may be to the average Californian. External peer feedback can help identify confusing language and promote more accessible communication.

Create more skilled managers. Turnover is often the result of poor management, a lack of leadership skills, and/or a lack of experience supervising people. An 80-hour online training is not sufficient.

I think we are really trying to stay with the times in terms of software and AI even with the limitations. For example, our team is using a software that is a few builds behind what is standard, but we are pushing it to its limit.

California should stop virtue signaling and spending taxpayer dollars on things that may not be helpful to California residents. The state's resources have gone to many controversial items during this current governorship that would have been better spent earmarked for things that improve the lives of California citizens. I recently heard the governor wanting to spend millions on redistricting when I was under the impression that the state surplus is in the red. I work at an institution that is receiving less money than the years prior but with inflation and tariffs, it now costs more to operate-it does not seem reasonable to me that the state is claiming to be in deficit therefore withholding positions from being filled and money getting spent to repair much needed infrastructure all the while finding hundreds of millions of dollars for retribution acts in the name of increasing ones relevancy on the national stage for perceived bonus points for political aspirations.

Regarding state-issued vehicles that are controlled by the Department of General Services, I don't understand why employees operating state vehicles need to fill out a PDF mileage form and send it to all these people when there are telematic devices in the vehicle already collecting this data. It's redundant and unnecessary paperwork. Use the data from the telematics devices installed in the vehicles to gather information about utilization of state vehicles. Don't make us fill out a form just to fill out a form.
consistency in guidance
Finding sustainable solutions should be a primary goal from the beginning and I believe it's important to bring all the players to the table including the individuals impacted.
Collaboration between departments to create accurate and timely assistance for customers.
oh and then they increased street parking by 66%  from $6 to to $10... and WHO ELSE does it affect... no one... just us. If they won't take a pay cut, we'll just charge it out of them.

Continue to increase our income to match the increases in housing costs and inflation. Offer better or more opportunities for state employees to be able to purchase a home. A balanced state budget that doesn't affect state employees.

California Government Code requirements around maintaining a former employee's old position as limited-term while they electively go explore another limited-term position elsewhere in State Government. The idea that we have to "keep their seat warm" while they explore other options at their own discretion (for up to 2 years or more!) is nonsensical and does nothing to support the dedication and program cohesion of the employee who fills their old job. If the job is originally funded as a permanenet position, it's status should not change nor should any preference or "reinstatement rights" be granted an ex-employee who left of their own choosing.
Less tax, allow opportunities for CA employees to telework. We get more work done with telework then office time. Working from home is productive, less coffee breaks, chit chats.
Thin out middle management.

1. Eliminate parking fees on weekends and after 5pm on weekdays in Downtown Sacramento so more people can go to patronize restaurant business without the hassles and stresses of looking and paying for a parking spot.  2. Lower house purchasing costs for middle income earners to afford a house to live.   3. Increase middle income earner's salary to match inflation.  4. Eliminate or lower HOA fees in California.   5. Limit investors to buy 1 or 2 houses max for rental business and/or Airbnb business in California. Investors have been hiking up housing prices in California.   6. Lower house/apartment rental costs.   7. Increase dental coverage/have better dental coverage for low-income people that are on Medi-Cal. I volunteer at free dental clinics, demands for dental cleanings, extractions, fillings, etc. are high every time.  8. Erect Billboards (Dept of Transportation) along California Highways and major boulevards how to handle or avoid road rage.

Nepotism in hiring and/or promotions given to friends and otherwise unqualified persons. Maybe more review of hiring by outsiders? Like reviewing the application, interview, and selection materials by others outside the department to ensure the reasons for hiring and not hiring were fair and in alignment with the requirements management had chosen to score by?
Used data management software such as Airtable to organize grants and other program data. Has allowed us to efficiently respond to data requests, anticipate upcoming closeouts, etc.

Additionally, requiring everyone back into an office increases the burden on the outdated, insensitive, inhumane, and abhorrent accommodations procedures. State agencies become overburdened with accommodations procedures that also overburden our already under-resourced health system. The current accommodations process comes from a suspicious perspective that puts people with disabilities and those needing accommodations into a position where they are not trusted and respected. It overall devalues and dehumanizes our workforce. And, most people in their life will need an accommodation - so this process should be timely, respectful, flexible, and accommodating. People know what is best for them and if they are empowered to make decisions about their needs they are more likely to be successful in their work increasing worker satisfaction, productivity, and efficiency.

This is difficult, as we are limited by so many policies beyond our control.  However, we provide Trauma Informed Care in affiliated with current best practices, remain current in ethics surrounding gender care and provide our patients with the best psychological interventions we can given monetary and staffing restraints.

Yes; Mindful meditation is practiced in the unit every Monday morning and it's a wonderful way to start off the week. We were given folders in shared InBox that was labelled with our names. I added the Officer Number to the label for others associate the number with the name & we could better Identify one another, since the number is what we use in correspondence.

The primary problem is low salary scales. This isn't just my opinion: The California Legislature's Bipartisan Fiscal and Policy Advisor released a report with data that shows average monthly salary figures have continued to fall behind market averages even calculating for inflation, and top step for salaries has also been in decline. An employee will abide great discomforts if they're compensated handsomely. But, that same employee will pursue other employment if neither salary nor working conditions reach respectable levels. Getting "paid in sunsets" is insufficient to recruit and retain top talent. Field staff are repeatedly told we're the most valuable members of the organization. But, HR, finance, management, and safety policies loudly declare the true narrative which contradicts all niceties.

I feel the procedures are not well defined and are changed too often by control agencies, which makes it difficult for admin staff. I also feel that admin staff are not as effective due to pressures from multiple layers of management within departments. I also feel there is a growing usage of high level "specialist" jobs that are used to retain seasoned staff rather than for the actual business usage. This excess of high-level specialist jobs take responsibilities away from the supervisors and management staff, while putting more pressure on the entry level staff to do more with less (leading to more errors and more labor hours). This has also caused discourse amongst R&F staff. I feel there is too many middle management positions, which is preventing staff from receiving consistent direction and guidance. Decision making is taking longer which cause more delays.  I feel the HR Manual from CalHR was a good start, but the manual need to continue to develop that resource (and CalHR needs to be given the support to do so).
I work in the public education arena. Not so much a problem, but a way of doing work - too much talk and not a whole lot of action.
Maybe CalPIA will be more competitive since they won't be subject to tariffs.

Hybrid team meetings, which combine in-person and remote participants, offer a highly efficient approach to collaboration by leveraging flexibility, inclusivity, and real-time communication. When well-structured and supported by the right technology, hybrid meetings enable teams to maintain productivity, reduce travel time and costs, and ensure that all team members, regardless of location, can contribute. This format supports a more agile and connected workforce, making it an increasingly effective solution for modern organizations.

What’s worked well in my role is being clear about what really needs upper-level approval and what doesn’t. I’ve worked on teams where no one wanted to take responsibility for signing off on a public-facing document, so it kept getting pushed higher and higher to people who didn’t have the time to review it. That creates unnecessary bottlenecks.  On my current team, we’ve set clearer expectations: which types of documents need executive-level review, which can be approved by managers, and which can move forward at staff level. Everyone understands the process and the expectations, which has made things much more efficient.  We’ve also improved our editing and reviewing etiquette. Instead of slowing things down with multiple rounds of small changes, reviewers will often give feedback like, “Next time you do something like this, try it this way,” rather than holding up the current draft for minor points. That balance helps us get important materials out the door quickly, while still improving quality over time.

I believe the state of California takes as good of care as we should for our Police, Corrections, Fire services, Dispatchers, and EMS personnel. I believe more could be down to provide essential services as it pertains to substance use disorders and PTSD. We demand so much of these individuals and we treat them as a replenishable resource. They are not. If we do not properly care for them and maintain their mental and emotional health, it could destroy recruitment and retention, causing devastating results for the residents of California that rely on these responders for essential emergency services.
Doing part of the mission of the California Department of Real Estate is to safeguard and promote the public interests in real estate matters through licensure, regulation, education and enforcement.

I also believe the state must address fairness in compensation. Many state workers’ salaries have not kept pace with California’s rising cost of living and inflation, making it harder to recruit and retain top talent. Combined with restrictive workplace policies, this gap contributes to turnover and low morale across the workforce.

Having flexible work hours and work locations, I have been able to hire talented staffers from all over the state, and I have been able to get so much more work from working parents when I am allowed to use telework to accommodate asynchronous work outside of traditional state working hours. This is a great process improvement.

Procurement and contracting have onerous rules and are time consuming.  Quality and fitness of purpose should be factored into the equation apart of other considerations.  Shifting the responsibility of vendor evaluation and selection back to the authorities within the requesting entities would help reduce delays and minimize the risk of mis or inadequate procurement.

We have lost four of our best employees this year only to that. Finding and training good employees is costly, and it takes time. The public suffers when good employees are gone and we fail in serving them.
Strongly agree with everything you said here!

Working in a decentralized department, I believe greater standardization and improved tools for managing budgets, purchasing, and routine statewide assignments would strengthen efficiency and consistency. Providing shared systems and clear processes would reduce the need for individuals to create their own methods, improve program management, and ensure more reliable data reporting back to headquarters.  Department has started implementing better tools and more standardization in Human Resources program, but other programs still lagging behind - budgeting, accounting, procurement, contracting asset management, leadership training and much more.

less taxes as a California resident and employee we are taxed from ear to ear then because we gross a certain amount we do not qualify for income assistance programs. Many of us work for departments that have programs that assist the public however because we gross too much employees are left struggling. If the employee's are deprived the work is directly effected.

The ISO 9000 Process Standardization and Quality Management System would be a great place to start, with clear flow charts and process maps for the things that happen to every new employee like benefits enrollment, I9 forms, everything. And process maps would be available to the HR folks and the employee so that everyone can track the process.   I think New Mexico State Government used ISO 9000 standards in some fashion. California is too big to 'wing it' which is what it feels like.

Overly complex procurement and Bureaucracy. procurement processes can be slow, risk averse, and overly complex resulting in higher contractor cost, ineffective or outdated solutions. Not all IT projects need nor should take years. Leverage resources, systems, staff across departments. If one department has successfully implemented a process/system, establish an interagency agreement with that department to transition another department. Empowers staff, promotes professional development and saves money.

I would say we have more workload than resources. At times, we have lots of work with not enough staffs. And product output is expected of high quality and at times work is not balanced with peers properly. I will say balance each staff's workload and hire more staffs.

The primary issue I see is ineffective individuals in the same job for decades without being held accountable for the work they do or don't do. I believe that mandatory and semi-annual performance evaluations should be implemented for all roles. Continuing employment and pay should be based on those evaluations. Two under-performing scores in a row would initiate a Performance Improvement Plan with specific and measureable goals to meet by the end of the PIP period. If these goals are not met, depending on the severity of the underperformance, either a salary cut or termination.
Many attempts. No receptivity on the part of managers. Sadly, improving processes is simply not in their wheelhouse.

I've been a civil servant for over a decade, and having come from the private sector, the biggest improvement that we can make is removing unmotivated staff and sub-par performers. Managers need to jump through far too many hoops for progressive discipline with potential legal backlash, and even that doesn't provide sustainable results for improving staff productivity.   We need the ability to terminate staff that continuously fail to meet the expectations of their duties. For example, if there are at least three documented conversations about the same issue, managers should be able to move forward with termination instead of issuing a Letter of Instruction (LOI). The truth is that a lot of managers are hesitant to issue LOIs because these can hinder that staff's ability to leave their current role for another position. This means that the problematic staff won't be moving anywhere and will continue to be a problem in the current unit. Staff like this bring down morale and create more work for others on their teams. This inefficiency is costly and fiscally irresponsible to State funding, and hence, to California taxpayers.
Telework - The need for it to be widespread and standardized. Telework should be a given for a lot of positions not the exception.
I would hope that California government would not embrace AI technologies that are having an outsized negative impact on the environment.

During covid, I implemented and streamline process to reassign personalized plates to customers, even while we were closed to the public. I created a script and would call the customers. I would offer the service of exchanging the plates online if they were still interested in them. If they were not, I would mail them the appropriate forms to release interest, but if they were, I would inform them how we would move forward to exchange the plates. The reason why I did this was because we were closed, people could not come in to pick up plates, yet the plates were still being mailed to us. That posed the problem of having a flood of inventory, and not enough secure locations to retain the personalized plates.  This process was observed by one of our Regional Managers, who ended up implementing it within our region. She then went on to present it to Sacramento, and shortly afterwards, my process was now being done statewide. In creating this, it helped not only customers, but the DMV's inventory overload concern as well.

State of California should act as a consolidated Entity and Department for purposes of time reporting, procurement and Administration. Every department having these functions segregated, implementing their own tools and procuring software and services is wasting significant tax money. If everyone gets paid through SCO Payroll,  time reporting governed by CalHR and SCO should also be a central function and statewide portal for State of CA employees.

There is too much bureaucracy when doing basic things, like buying a printer that works with our computers. It takes too long to approve contracts with vendors and service providers.  How can we lessen or automate some of the hurdles put in place?  We need to audit the process to determine whether all steps are really necessary, and to the extent they are not or can be streamlined, work to do that. We need to invest in software and other technological solutions to improve our systems.
There's no inter and infra agency standardisation of operations, networks, software, etc

Everyone wants state government agencies to work together towards the same ends. Currently, staff within different agencies cannot see each other's calendars, work on shared documents, or use other technology that promotes fast and easy collaboration. A simple fix would be to allow cross agency calendar viewing and shared documents.

As a California resident, I am appalled by the idle time of staff at times. Staff downtime should be an opportunity to provide support to understaffed orgs. I saw this in Parks where some HQ staff was very underutilized at times (i.e. die to grant cycles) while the field is nearly always scrambling because of too few staff. It would certainly help HQ better support the field if they had experience/understanding of the field environment.

Make downtown Sacramento parking more affordable.  Make it part of the compensation package and provide free park-and-ride programs around the downtown area.  In Oceanside CA, (near San Diego) they have FREE on demand rides to a location you need to go to.  The rides are on electric large golf carts.  Its clean, easy, safe and FREE.   Downtown Sacramento parking must be addressed to bring people back to work.

I have seen significant progress when excluded communities (BIPOC, LGBTQIA, Immigrants, etc...) are actually listened to. Empowering these communities allows for actual progress instead of the usual responses that are aimed at preserving profits for a small, privileged segment of the population. Indian tribes throughout the state lead environmental conservation efforts that benefit everyone. A great example is the Klamath River in which Tribes are leading restoration efforts that will benefit the watershed. The Black Panthers and other groups conducted urban pollution monitoring to show that Black, Brown, and Indigenous communities are exposed to higher levels of carcinogens and are at greater risk of exposure to other stressors (extreme heat/weather, poor air quality). The work that these groups do highlight the need for environmental protections that will benefit all people. Unfortunately, they are often ignored or persecuted. We need to go beyond box checking and actually listen to, and empower communities that have the empathy and will to cause real change.

I would like to see more incentivization for companies to provide for the communities they serve. In exchange for these investments, companies could simultaneously enjoy tax breaks. This could be in the form of parks, sponsoring improved education programs, donation to public transportation improvements, etc.   This would act as a mutual benefit to the company and the community, thus allowing reduction of civilian taxation, which would mean greater money able to be injected into the community by civilian spending.   Tax breaks could even be tiered based on the area and type of community investment(s) made. For example, a company who provided funding for a state-of-the-art housing development for lower-income individuals would receive a different tax break than another company who donates canned goods. Incentives could also be stacked, this way a company could, theoretically SIGNIFICANTLY reduce their taxation by providing extensive contributions to the community.   I feel like this would make more companies want to move to and stay in California; plus, it could provide a mutually beneficial way to not heavily tax residents while still enabling California communities to flourish.

I created a resource for incarcerated persons (IPs) that highlights resources that are already available to them (Edovo).  This gives IPs specific courses/resources they can utilize in their rehabilitation.
As a California resident, I want my government to have a fiscal responsibility to wisely spend the money taken from me. I will gladly pay for great service.

I would like to see more communication from my department (CDCR) and the public. I do not see a large communication mechanism from CDCR to California residents. CHP does a great job of this and we could learn from that department on how to use social media, the web, and podcasts to communicate what we do well and what we are trying to improve.  I think more transparency is better. I believe the public would be more supportive of CDCR if they were more aware of the day-to-day challenges and how we strive to combat these challenges. I have noticed the public is very uniformed of what happens in CDCR, and the character or people who work for this department.
We have offered several changes in process and none have been implemented.

The current status of government limits the methods that can be employed to improving California.  We have to be open to alternative methods and do not dismiss ideas because "we do not do things that way around here".  Most of the leadership in the departments and agencies are career bureaucrats.  They only know one way to address issues.  When a new approach is brought up, it is almost always shot down before it can even be explored.  This happens because people in leadership are afraid that if they verve from the normal process, they will lose their jobs.

I would love to see more focus on updating laws and regulations that are outdated. We currently are required to post announcements in the newspaper and sometimes on the radio but there are very few papers left and not many people reading them. If the goal is to reach the most people the regulation should be updated to include social media instead of newspapers and streaming services like Spotify for radio ads.

As staff and a California resident having to deal with state agencies for things, we really need staff to get the job done, to many take their time, but then we also have some places that are severely short staffed. Everyone should be working hard and working together.

I have one solution that would save at least a billion dollars. We have over a dozen state operated law enforcement agencies. Collapse all of them into a 'Department of Public Safety' with one chief and several bureaus that specialize (ie. state parks, warden, narcotics, gambling, white collar crimes, highway patrol, etc). Less administration, less chiefs, less political in fighting, one academy, less infastructure, one uniform, better communication, and due to efficiency and communication since our current system the officers can't even talk to each other over the radio ----> ding, ding, ding -----> you'll probably need to staff less cops because they'll have more back up and they'll be less lonely on patrol.

Across two state agencies, poor communication has consistently hindered productivity and morale. In one agency, management prohibited cross-unit dialogue, slowing progress and isolating teams. In another, annual surveys repeatedly flagged communication as the top issue, yet leadership insisted on injecting themselves in every conversation or discouraging communication with other units and divisions. Instead of seeking answers from the sources, managerial direction has focused on the interpretation of resources that often prove incorrect. These decisions negatively impact morale, cause frustrations in a job that would otherwise feel ideal, and reminds of the axom that people don't quit jobs, they quit managers.   Managers often lack subject matter expertise, causing delays and confusion. Many openly promote a “fake it till you make it” mindset, prioritizing their own job security over the work required to excel when serving the public. The solution is simple: empower staff to communicate directly and collaborate freely, hire a strong human resources team to handle all of our regular issues, and reduce the layers of management. We can build a more agile, informed, and customer-focused workforce.

As a California state employee and California resident, I cannot overstate how important telework and flexible work schedules are to my family. Our school district mothballed its school bus fleet, so we have no bus service for our children, and must take our children to and pick our children up from school. Flexible work schedules and telework (at least twice a week) enable us to do what we need to do.

I think it would be helpful to have a clear pathway for interns/fellows to enter into employment after their program. The current hiring process is too slow to keep these students interested in working for the state.

From my short experience here, it seems the reps are left out of a lot of the planning, problem solving, and tasks to get projects through the system.  In our team, meetings are often cancelled when we are going through the heaviest of tasks like getting ready for ILC, I believe this is a time when management needs to be transparent about what is happening behind the scenes and getting reps involved to help speed up the process.  I will go days without having a substantial amount of work to do while specialists and managers are working overtime.   I have a feeling many of my peers are doing little to no work most days of the week and I believe there is a lot of waste here.   I believe our managers should empower and TRAIN the reps to be able to confidently take on more tasks.  It is taking far too long for projects to get approved and to closing. I am not sure what the process looks like to fix it, but it should not take this long and there is often no sense of urgency from anyone on the team.   I believe that many reps feel that they have the ability and the desire to play a bigger role, and they have the knowledge and experience to be able to do so but are often overlooked and undervalued

As a state employee, much of my work has focused on improving the efficiency and effectiveness of programs that support our transportation and freight system. I focus on process improvements, I created digital tools to enhance our programs and task force team work.

In my department, the restrictions on classifications and hiring can limit the upward career mobility/development of individuals without bachelors degrees. An individual with many years of experience can have a difficult time qualifying for a certain classification if they don't have a bachelor's degree, but are otherwise qualified. This is a barrier for entry for many people who want to come into state service and could contribute to the important work we do.

Within our Program we performed an extensive Business Process Innovation (BPI) project that looked at our processes and how they could be streamlined. We used processing mapping, RASCI's, subject matter expert suggestions, and more to build out a better and more efficient program.

I think there is serious lack of clarity in ownership between the different teams within the organization. It is sometimes very hard tracking down which team owns which programs and sometimes, the team that is listed for a certain legacy program is unaware they actually own it. There needs to be more clarity when it comes to defining which teams own what, and I think more teams ought to be proactive when something goes wrong with the processes they own by reaching out to other dependent teams before problems manifest downstream in production.
more advancement

When I first joined the state employee workforce, I was told how easy it is to advance through the ranks, but in my experience it was harder to advance unless I was willing to leave my branch/division/department. I think that promoting in place should be implemented more when employees have been in a particular place long enough. This requires management to be more open to and learned on the solutions available. But it also requires more of a team mentality and that is hard when people have to keep moving in order to advance. I think providing more genuine opportunities for colleagues to work and grow together will help.
3 to 4 teleworking days would be best since it would save the state millions of dollars in leasing cost and employees will save money from travel cost.

A primary problem that I would address is improving the state's budget and financial management, the high cost of living, housing and homelessness. My ideas to solve the state's budget problems would be to implement strategies to either increase revenue or decrease spending and improving budgeting processes. As for the high cost of living, housing, and homelessness, I recommend a combination of increasing housing supply (i.e., affordable housing), implementing tenant protections, expanding rental assistance programs, and lowering other essential costs such as public transportation and groceries.

Environmental compliance laws and policies exist because there is a history of resource degradation without regulations, and corresponding protective measures, like best management practices, have a proven track record of effectiveness.  However, when environmental restoration projects are constrained by environmental regulations such that the project must reduce the scope (size, duration, etc.), or they significantly drive up the costs (e.g. engineering, compliance, planning) of said projects, the public funds (State and Federal) go less to the intended use, and more to the churn of bureaucracy.  There should be more streamlining of statewide permits or more exemptions for restoration projects, and these should inherently recognize long-term benefits of restoration projects outweigh short-term impacts that follow standard BMPs.
This would help with employee retention!!!

There should be a system where staff can job shadow for upward mobility purposes. More agencies should be able to hire interns as support staff. If budgets are an issue, this is a way to minimize cost and get help with surplus of work.
Utilizing SharePoint so stakeholders can have real-time updates and increase transparency between the agency and the public on project status.
Tax revenue would increase dramatically if California taxed the extremely wealthy the same way it does the middle class.

One primary problem that often arises is the lack of streamlined processes and the underutilization of advanced methodologies like Six Sigma, especially in the context of AI advancements. Here are a few ideas to address this problem: -Recognition and Integration of Certifications: Advocate for the recognition of Six Sigma and other relevant certifications within your department. This could involve presenting case studies or data that demonstrate the tangible benefits of these methodologies in similar organizations. -Training and Development Programs: Implement comprehensive training programs that focus on process improvement techniques, including Six Sigma. This could be part of a broader professional development initiative aimed at enhancing the skills of state employees. -AI-Driven Process Optimization: Leverage AI to analyze current processes and identify inefficiencies. AI can provide insights into areas where time and resources are being wasted and suggest more efficient workflows. -Pilot Projects: Start with small-scale pilot projects to demonstrate the effectiveness of new processes and methodologies. Successful pilots can build momentum and support for broader implementation. -Cross-Department Collaboration: Encourage collaboration between different departments to share best practices and successful strategies. This can help create a culture of continuous improvement and innovation. -Feedback Mechanisms: Establish robust feedback mechanisms to continuously gather inpu
How about three fives? Pretty sure that's optimal for engaged productivity at work.
I've noticed an improvement in time management when working with shared digital files. This allows others to use past work as reference material and can adjust accordingly.

Problem: There is no uniform policy among the Dept of State Hospitals for their library programs. Ex: There is no policy on what type of books to buy for the patients nor is there anyone to report patron statistics to. What legal resources do we need to offer and what forms are patient's entitled to. There should be uniform and consistency among the library hospitals as well as accountability in the form of a Library department for the Dept of State Hospitals.

The practice of posting a job position at the DLSE, which is overseen by DIR HR, is inefficient, and damaging to the agency. Often, a position is posted, when the current employee wants to transfer to another office. When this happens, members of the public apply, and none of them are selected because the reason for posting was just a transfer. This is a huge waste of government resources. The employee should be allowed to transfer without applying for a new job. Also, the public feels angry when they are not selected despite their qualifications, and they decide not to apply again because they know that internal candidates will be selected. The same thing happens when promotion in place is difficult to gain as has happened at DLSE. HR spends dozens of hours reviewing resumes, interviewing candidates, only to turn everyone external down. Qualified candidates refuse to continue engaging in the hiring process because they get turned down so frequently. I have seen this happen, and because I am an internal candidate, I know that the internal employee gets hired. We would save hundreds of hours of work if we eliminated these practices. We would also increase the pool of qualified applicants if the hiring process was genuine.

Problem 1 – Customer Experience From a customer’s perspective, the State’s reliance on mailed notices and mailed responses is outdated and inefficient. Californians expect the same level of convenience they experience with banks, healthcare providers, and private businesses. Mailing forms back and forth creates delays, risks lost documents, and forces residents to rely on slower communication when technology could streamline the process.  Proposed Solution: Require high-volume departments to offer an online option for submitting responses or uploading documents. Provide funding to ensure these systems are secure and user-friendly.  Gives Californians faster, more reliable ways to communicate with the State.  Reduces dependence on paper, manual scanning, and case management bottlenecks.  Aligns government services with modern technology standards and customer expectations.  Problem 2 – Employee Retention and Knowledge Gaps State programs are highly complex, requiring years of training to master. While it is positive that employees advance through promotions, frequent turnover combined with limited pay results in ongoing knowledge loss and operational disruptions.  Proposed Solution: Leverage technology and AI to improve knowledge retention and training:    Real-time guidance systems for staff when processing cases.  AI-assisted training that adapts to an employee’s pace and learning style.
Working in a team.

Deregulate permitting agency and increase enforcement and education. Trust the public will build according to standards by increasing public awareness to agency standards and enforcing when compliance is not met. Too much red tape is working against necessary projects to combat climate change and incorporate multi-benefit solutions. Work smarter not harder endorse hybrid work solutions like telework.

Honestly, I am less productive when I work in the office, because people are distracting. Everyone wants to chitchat and people have terrible habits they bring into the office, and if my coworker keeps taking his virtual meetings without headphones I am going to scream... I get about half the work done the days I work onsite

I have been a state employee for 5 years, i have worked for two separate boards in the same department. A problem I have noticed is the lack of camaraderie and unity within departments and boards. A solution I may suggest would be quarterly employee enrichment activities. I believe such activities have a tremendous impact on morale. I think that happier state workers can produce more positive interactions with the public.

Many of the processes used at my department were not built with a focus on efficiently serving our customers. As such, there are often multiple wasteful and non-necessary steps both employees and customers are “required” to take before a customer transaction can be completed. We have failed to analyze and update many of these processes using new methodologies, ways of thinking, and tools that are already readily available to us. It has happened on several occasions that when an improvement is introduced it fails to receive the support that is needed for successful implementation because some members of management fear change and/or feel that they cannot devote employee hours to implementation and testing. I believe systematic and proven process improvement techniques (like Lean Six Sigma, PDCA, Total Quality Management, etc.) performed by state-employed process-improvement specialists that have the support and resources that can be provided by department heads and agency-level management could act to improve inefficient processes across that state.

A primary issue in state offices is the lack of open dialogue and willingness to learn from employees at all levels.  Current leadership lacks mentorship opportunities to provide management with the legal, communication and general human interaction skillsets necessary for optimal performance.

One of the reasons we can't retain the workforce is the pay-scales are not keeping up with cost of living.  We don't have significant reliable rent controls.  If we can offer housing to state workers or increase ranges and overall work on the bullying environment to make the experience more comfortable, we should be able to retain talent. I see business flight cited mainly due to politics costs and redundancy (red tape) so we need to make it easier to do business here and to move and get adjusted since regardless of the challenges CA is still a magnet and constant draw of new business and new people.

Our division-wide training program has been in flux, so we developed our own internal training program to enable new staff to learn the job. It has increased productivity, developed camaraderie, and made our team feel that we were investing in them. High quality training is extremely valuable, without it people will develop bad habits that take years to break. Investing time and expertise in excellent internal training programs requires a commitment from leadership and motivated subject matter experts.
Create a CEA position in each department whose main objective is to work with other sister agencies to maintain consistency and efficiency for the department they work for.

Consolidating the hiring process so that positions with the same job duties are all filled at the same time, creating a cohort that can go through onboarding and training together. Positions are filled much faster and you reduce the number of resources required. This saves a lot of time by not having to post multiple job postings, do screening for multiple positions, and holding multiple rounds of interviews.
Joint media contract pooled two state department resources.

This reminds me of something I read from women in Congress, when facing this same issue they realized if they banded together they were able to reinforce ownership for example in a mtg when a minority person makes a good suggestion, another minority person makes sure to back it up for the record like, "What a great idea Anika, let's make sure and submit that to management right away, I'll cc the group" and then when it doesn't go anywhere until later when Justin pretends it's his idea, whoever hears it should respond with, "Oh right that's what Anika came up with at the last mtg, what a great reminder" etc etc - this is the supportive behaviour we should all normalize.
Employee housing needs to be a priority, especially for seasonals. Housing is too hard to find and too hard to afford on a rank-in-file income.
I think some departments allow that, but I don't think it should be standard/mandatory.
As an analyst, I have researched and implemented additional tools that will automate my job comparing third-party datasets to internal datasets.
