In my role I've observed decades worth of files and data being digitally stored that no one has any meaningful use for or knowledge of to make the data worth retaining. There appears to be no interest, energy, or time available to reorganize, archive, and/or eliminate this unnecessary data and it's an accepted nuisance that any file search results may provide both current and 25 year old documents.   I see this as an inefficiency for two reasons: the monetary cost of securing and maintaining storage for these files that by default are considered valueless and the obscuring effect these unhelpful documents have when trying to find information.  I think files should be audited more regularly to ensure content is kept highly organized and easily discoverable, with unhelpful 'junk' documents archived or eliminated to reduce what is being retained year after year.

I am trying to partner with other state agencies that have solved the technical issue that I am currently trying to solve. The goal being to leverage the work the other agency has already completed, improve upon it, and then share with the agency so they get value out of sharing as well.
More upward mobility opportunities in other cities, not just Sacramento and have exams as open continuous rather than a cutoff date.

Within our state workforce, stress, divorce, marital issues, money problems are present and affect employees work perform, attitudes and relationships on and off duty.  Police officers, firefighters, EMS workers often commit suicide as a result of the issues mentioned above.    My solution to help state workers reduce or remove stress, divorce, marital issues, money problems is to provide EveryDollar as a benefit to all state employees.  EveryDollar is a highly effective tool that focuses on controlling personal finances which then carries over into all other aspects of life, resulting in tremendous growth in confidence, awareness, financial freedom, relationships, mental health, and much more.

Health expense account reimbursement is inefficient and should be moved away from a third-party administrator (ASI Flex) and just have the account transactions be directed by the employee themselves, such as with an FSA. The current system adds unnecessary bureaucracy for something that can be handled by the employee.

Our agency had a robust telework policy before the pandemic for professional staff.  We invested in more technology to make it even more efficient and expanded telework to support staff duirng covid.  We formerly spent significant taxpayer money traveling to conduct events in person, despite a regulation authorizing virtual events.  Since we've invested in the technology and nearly all events are virtual, we can reduce office space thus saving significant funds.  Converting the positions to telework permanently can allow for strategic planning.  For example, we can invest in training and  productivity tools to ensure taxpayers receive the best quality service while offsetting the unnecessary expense of partially unused offices and excessive travel.

Recruitment and retention. Newer generations that are not already heated and close to retirement seems to have little interest in applying for State jobs. If they do, they move on the other industries quickly. I feel like the State ends up training the workforce for other companies rather than retaining the talented staff hired.  I believe the State would benefit from focus groups to identify innovative ways to recruit new staff and improvement opportunities that would increase the retention of those staff longer term.

As a taxpayer and state employee the primary problem I would address is wasteful spending of tax dollars on unnecessary office space. Allowing remote work wherever possible will greatly reduce the amount of money wasted on building leases, maintenance, repairs, electricity, internet, gas, water, office supplies, soap, cleaners, paper towels, toilet paper, etc. Remote work allows for a more diverse workforce and provides opportunity to rural communities throughout the state, mothers, and people with disabilities. It improves productivity by reducing office distractions and stress caused from commuting. For neurodivergent folks working in the office environment can be very stressful and  downright overwhelming. The sounds, smells, lighting, temperature, masking, etc. impact the ability to focus leading to more mistakes, work being done slower, burnout, etc. Not to mention all the physical, mental, emotional, and personal issues caused by the stress of it all. It reduces carbon emissions, vehicle miles traveled, traffic congestion, and safety risks by having fewer people on the road, thus reducing funds spent on responding to crashes. It improves employee morale by allowing time that would be spent commuting to be spent with family, friends, etc. Shifting to the electronic/virtual world wherever possible will speed up processing times across the board. Emails are faster and save more money than snail mail & provide proof of delivery. Happier workers = better customer service.

For better collaboration and efficient work, having staff collaborate on teams and using various Microsoft apps for better efficiency. Able to give telework which helped the employees to stay with State and not leave state job.

Too many agencies seem to hire new employees without the proper training program in place for the job they are intended to do. New hires are brought on board and spend 1-2 days sitting at a computer doing HR related paperwork then join a unit within a department that seems to have no set program for teaching them their job other than "sit with someone" til you get an idea what we want.
Housing. Continued support and expansion of housing first.
Telework and digitizing processes and forms/paperwork. Embrace modern technology.

Departments that continue to allow their staff to telework full time are wonderful places to be with happy employees and great morale.  Spreading this logic throughout the state would greatly improve operations and save taxpayer's money.
I would like the rail system to actually be built. We could lead the country in building out a modern rail system that is the envy of the world.

When supervisors listen to their employees, who are on the front lines and therefore in the best position to know, and the employees are telling management the hurdles they are facing, and when those supervisors take that information, absorb it, process it, and pivot accordingly--that improves efficiency.  Instead a lot of managers refuse to listen, refuse to change, and refuse to believe they could be wrong.  Management often times is too afraid of losing their job or retaliation if they disagree with a higher-up or a policy that has come from the top.  Instead, middle management should be fighting for what is best for their employees (and thus what is best for all Californians-since they are almost always the same), even if that means upsetting people above them.  And Exec and higher-level management should cultivate and encourage dialogues and safe places to express ideas, again, even if it includes disagreeing with current policies that are inefficient, e.g. RTO policies.

Virtual work is also more accessible to a range of persons, including persons with disabilities. In-office centric positions are inherently inequitable and create additional burdens and obstacles reducing productivity, efficiency, and effectiveness.
I worked diligently with my team to move towards a more electronic process during the pandemic to meet customer needs while also allowing for efficient methods of submitting a request.

What if covid never happened?Then, what as far as working moms go, people make choices to have families, but it is not up to the workplace to adhere to their schedule. COVID was hard for a lot of people, but people seem to manage the workplace and motherhood or fatherhood et. Cetera worked out just fine, but now that COVID has happened. The workplace needs to adjust to people and their family. I don't think that's a fair practice.

I have worked for the same Agency for many years, and I can tell you that training has never being available. Learn as you go (swim or sink). It seems that management get the training and stays with them because it's not disseminated to the staff.

For my own unit, i have asked to be involved with the onboarding process to introduce new employees to our agency to our unit and what we do. I created a brochure and a small powerpoint and asked for time, but I had to ask for that. I think all divisions should be present at NEO for new employees. All agencies are so large, there's no way a new employee would know what everybody does. I have also created materials to be used when our employees are interacting with the public. I look at interaction from the customer lens. I believe it goes back to reinstating value to state service and re-instilling pride as a state service employee.

A major part of my work involves preventive maintenance. I have focused on teaching proper PM procedures to ensure our assets operate as designed and protect public safety. I partnered with our training department to create clear, standardized steps across the many areas of PM, which has made our processes more consistent and efficient. This improvement allows us to spend more time enhancing asset performance rather than troubleshooting recurring issues.

Implemented developmental opportunities - Leadership Development Program and Succession Planning Program. Implemented comprehensive planning for workforce. Implemented Change Management Program, including a org-wide governance committee. Improved training to address staff needs, incorporate values to tie in big picture, and are currently exploring learner support post-training options.

I agree that there is a need for review users accessing critical systems.  Too frequently, when a person changes positions, their prior access to systems is not changed accordingly allowing the potential for fraud. AI could definitely help monitor this.

I believe all members of leadership should be required to, and held accountable for, hosting at least one meeting per month where they share what the whole team has been working on, and share their expertise. There is way too much information hoarding within our division, and I'd like to see us become more collaborative and supportive.

As a California resident, I would like the state to treat its workers better and provide a healthier work-life balance. If state workers are treated well, it has a trickledown effect to residents and helps create a more efficient state overall.

We need to find a way to automate and manage our multifamily housing funding.  We are using archaic excel spreadsheets that often have multiple errors and trying to track the progress of a project is a completely manual and time consuming process.  We need to get a system in place ASAP that incorporates both the underwriting and pipeline management of these projects.  We should look to successful mortgage companies for this as the systems they have in place could very easily be incorporated here

Hiring exams - after taking an exam, the eligibility shouldn't expire. Nothing has changed with that person's experience (if anything, they'll just gain more and more relevant experience). Current state employees also shouldn't be required to take an exam to get on the eligibility list when they are already in that classification path and qualify - for example, someone with 1 year of AGPA should automatically be on the eligible list for SSM1, without needing to take the exam.
Still is! Best leadership I have ever worked for!
I wrote an step-by-step operating procedures manual for the Park Aides. Park Aides are the primary point of contact for visitors and we train them to be public relations ambassadors.

Outsourcing, private contractors, temp employees and or trying to implement an off the shelf product or project from the private sector.  The state has many requirements and regulations that are designed to protect, inform, safety regulations, IT, laws, privacy, etc.  The private product or program and or staff does not understand and trying to get it to work and it does not.  The state in the future no matter what the need is, pay no matter the cost for the ground up projects and ask the state employees how it is to functions and or work.  Buildings, Software, Computers, Desks, vehicles, tools, etc.  No outsourcing of any kind at any level and quit going with the lowest bids, it costs us and the taxpayers money over and over again.

There are too many people in the administration role. The state needs to downsize and consolidate administrative roles. A lot of their positions are redundant, ineffective, and have no meaning. They should remove all the nurse evaluator IV positions and consolidate the SSM positions where they oversee multiple offices.
Ongoing collaboration with external partner groups, e.g., assisted living advocates and provides, to help inform Department's work.

The department I work for had eliminated paper filing and has gone all electronic. Saving the department money on purchasing paper, folders, filing boxes, storage space to save the paper files, etc. It has cut down processing time, reduced processing steps, and improved workflow.

Increase community outreach programs so the public know what kind of help is available to them. Use data-driven strategies and run polls to understand what information reaches the public and what not!

Keeping channels of communication open and expressing candor when providing advice to agency programs is probably the single most helpful thing I can do. No motive technology or process can compensate for much-needed openness and willingness to work with people across organizations.

I've seen tremendous progress in being more customer service oriented and that's informed by active stakeholder engagement and listening to our customers.  At the same time, I find multiple, duplicative stakeholder processes do not add value and  some have become "performative" instead of informative.  Adhering to public meeting rules makes for very staff intensive processes so it's important that we see results from this work instead of simply checking a box.

Yes, we have centralized our administrative functions for our entire division. Instead of six offices having six administrative teams, we have one administrative team for six offices. I'd like to expand on our idea by adding additional administrative functions to our team so we can truly streamline and simplify our internal processes. Then, apply our model to our headquarters operations to see where we can further streamline operations and save money by reducing positions.

Managers in my department are always pulling their heads into their shells.  Not much consideration for improvement, just keeping the wheels spinning.  There is a defined process for evaluating a suggested change but managers seem to put them in a desk drawer to let them die - this is not that process.  I would like a process to move around the roadblocks.  But I am pretty sure managers are just hiding their own lack of knowledge.  People are move up on longevity (to qualify) and friendships (to get interview questions ahead of time) to promote.  Knowledge and understanding of process (or learning thereof) is not relevant.

Definitely agree.  I work in purchasing and the overlap/redundancy in information/excess documentation is ridiculous.  ex: each time we send   a Purchase Order to a vendor we 'kill trees' printing the same excess documentation requesting responses to the same questions over and over again.

There is a need to modernize data deidentification model and privacy compliance review to boost efficiency and unleash value of data. Current process to perform data suppression including secondary suppression is unsustainable and often involves excessive manual labor and subjective determination in excel spreadsheets. Over-suppression not only creates a bottleneck, delaying data releases for research, policy-making, and public transparency, it also renders public-use datasets less useful for researchers and community organizations.   This manual, subjective model represents a significant opportunity cost for the taxpayers we serve. We need to move to more automated systems and more streamlined privacy standards and technologies. Another area of investment is to upskill analysts in robust, open-source tools in R or Python to codify privacy rules and to reduce manual hours in excel compliance review.

OES needs to be more efficient, more streamlined. We can all do better-We collectively just have to step up and make the needed adjustments to improve process, capability, and teamwork. OES is made up of great people accomplishing amazing things-OES Management needs to reflect on that, and the incredible team members that make up this impact focused organization.

I have helped standardize several processes with the goal of thoroughly exploring all elements of the work we do to try to minimize the number of errors since these errors can lead to financial sanctions from the federal government.

Most of us can't afford to live where we work. Our wages don't keep up with the cost of living. Even when we're able to negotiate a meager raise, it can be taken away by the governor, on a whim. We put a lot of effort into fighting for our wages. That effort could be spent serving the people of California instead of fighting our employer. This conflict leads to a lot of  mistrust and kills moral.

I would say a primary problem is the lack of uniformity. There are times when a customer can go from one office to another and be told they are required to have different things, and in some instances, they can go from one employee to the next in the same office, and again, be given different requirements. The lack of uniformity shows that our online training, and on-the-job-training is not being done properly. People are training THEIR ways of doing things, instead of the way the state has drawn out.  We should have more of a "one office concept" where customers will get the same exact response from every employee, in every office.
The State wide Security Operation Center is a great exemple of a shared combined resource wher we can consolidate our experts in Cyber Security to better protect the State and it's IT assets.

Exactly--this bottleneck cripples so many good ideas. There have been ideas that I have had in the past that I considered sending just as a citizen, to my legislator because I knew it would be impossible to send up my chain of command--it would never get anywhere.

As a tax auditor, I try to make the taxpayers that I audit feel like they are not being targeted to squeeze more tax dollars from them. I try to make them feel like audits are routine and when they do lead to adjustments, that it is only to make corrections according to the law.

I would like to reiterate my idea of reevaluating State properties to see if all or a portion of them are suitable for housing redevelopment. Can parking lots on State property be converted so that parking goes underground and mid-to-high density housing goes on top?
Please increase access to all services for marginalized communities - not just for financial issues, but also for identification, mental health, and homeless advocacy.

I think one of the challenges that many departments face is a lack of staffing resources to provide this kind of support. Throughout the past 25 years of my state career, I have experienced several furloughs, and more hiring freezes and position sweeps than I'd care to remember.  Over the years, staffing resources have eroded away to the point that there is just enough support to keep the lights on. With each of these cuts, we lose capacity for the true in-depth training and development that is called for commensurate with the positions. This, coupled with being constantly asked to do more with less, means that many of our staff are hired and "thrown into the deep end". It is extremely difficult to get more resources to replace those lost to position sweeps/etc. In fact, many departments have even lost sight of some of the things that they 'used to do' because they have not been staffed for so long. This becomes a vicious cycle, as people get frustrated with the amount of workload and lack of training.   There has also been a noticeable gap in management training. Yes, it is required. However often times new managers start and are immediately thrown into fighting fires. The trainings turn into an inconvenience resulting in feeling even more overworked trying to make up for the time lost, rather than a respite to focus on growth and development for this exciting new career step.   And although this thought is unpopular, I do not think that Telework has helped this situation.

Many of government processes are riddled with inefficiency and redundancy, which causes things to take an unnecessarily long amount of time. Streamlining policies to remove redundancy and create one master set of requirements to approve projects would be beneficial. I believe it's possible to to reduce bureaucracy while still keeping protections for people and the environment in place.

We need to take a harder stance on crime. It is difficult to go into a store and see people walking out shoplifting with hundreds of dollars of merchandise and no one doing anything to stop it.   The State believes there is a lack of in-house shopping because there is a lack of people at work, however I personally do not want to shop where I do not feel safe.   Also, increasing the minimum wage will not decrease inflation. Instead of increasing wages, how about we decrease the costs associated with a fair living.

Diminishing institutional knowledge and judgment calls allowed by management. Management are not as free as so in the past to make judgement calls and that takes the "human" part out of customer service with the people we serve.

California desperately needs to fix the insurance crisis that’s preventing thousands from rebuilding their homes after the wildfires. The current Governor loves to talk about “inclusive decision-making” and “listening to survivors,” yet the number one barrier to recovery isn’t a lack of good ideas from state workers—it’s the fact that private insurers have fled high-risk areas, the FAIR Plan is overpriced and underpowered, and nothing substantial has been done to reform the state’s own outdated regulatory chokehold that created this mess.
The “IT” part. Self check in . Less paperwork

I think greater transparency from CDCR would help the public understand who we are and what we do. I would love to have a public who understands what CDCR does and the good work the people who work for this department do.

Remote work has made my job and my relationships with stakeholders stronger and more efficient. The privacy of my home office has helped build trust, and being in my own designated space (i.e., not a cubicle) has helped me focus better and provide more quality work products.

There's a saying as a state worker, sink or swim. It would be nice to have an onboarding process, academy perhaps, that trains newbies on not just policies and their role, but all of the amazing benefits offered to state employees. A lot of the times, new state workers are not aware and don't take advantage. It would also be nice for in depth training from staff members assigned to train and not take away from their regular duties.

Finding the policies and procedures and trying to get folks to understand that unless they are changed, these are what we follow so that we are all on the same page.  I know what I've done makes things better and now we can find things; however, it is unappreciated.

Environmental and financial stewardship. Our Sacramento area freeways are crumbling under the weight of too many vehicles generally and specifically during business hours. Invest in urban public transportation. Locate State offices near transit hubs. Stagger State worker schedules to minimize our impact in congested areas.
Lean Six Sigma training has been extremely helpful.  Team building through positive psychology trainings.

It would be beneficial for California residents to pursue strategies that reduce PG&E utility rates and insurance premiums across the board, providing financial relief ang long-term affordability for all stakeholders.

I have taken extensive trainings to learn more about SharePoint and the features we have access to. I have implemented automations and written down multiple policies and procedures so that others know how to create/update these automations. I also manage a team and meet with them regularly and make myself available to them at all times.
I agree! We are all here to work and we have a common goal together to get our jobs done. Nothing better than having a team that you can talk to.

I agree. I have proposed at least one idea (which was actually feedback for improvement I received from one of the entities my program oversees) which my managers have rejected on grounds of the possibility of "Public Records Act" requests. I think it is silly that a potentially beneficial idea that could better serve California would be rejected by what seems to be a desire to reduce the need for additional work or an otherwise obstinate mindset.

I think we need to (where appropriate, legal, and feasible) leverage AI and or machine learning to reduce the time spent on routine compliance and monitoring functions. For example, machine learning can be used to identify fraudulent or suspicious transactions for high volume systems (i.e., CalFresh). AI could be used to speed up user access reviews for critical systems by identifying users who haven't logged on for a certain period of time, moved to different position within the department, or are no longer on paroles. The biggest hurdle to this would be getting ever department access to ML/AI specialists who could appropriately implement these technologies as well as training existing compliance subject matter experts on how to use these AI tools. However, the potential cost savings arising from a reduction in manual compliance and monitoring tasks could be well worth the investment in AI technicians and new trainings for compliance staff.

A community-based program utilizing goats or sheep to manage vegetation on CDCR grounds could offer significant benefits, including reduced operating costs, environmental sustainability, & community engagement. This approach could also pave the way for a vocational rehabilitation program for inmates, teaching ranching skills. A viable skill to make money and raise meat for your family. Some of the benefits: 1. Reduced Operating Costs: Using animals to manage vegetation eliminates need for fuel, equip maintenance, & groundskeeper's salary. 2. Environmental Sustainability: Goats & sheep provide a natural, eco-friendly alternative to mowing, reducing reliance on fossil fuels & machinery. 3. Community Engagement: Partnering with 4-H or FFA youth groups provides a valuable community outreach opportunity & educational experience. 4. Inmate Rehabilitation: A successful pilot program could lead to development of a ranching rehabilitation program, offering incarcerated individuals marketable skills & a potential path to employment upon release. 5. Fire Hazard Reduction: Regular grazing by livestock can help reduce build-up of dry vegetation, a fire hazard, especially in California's climate.  6. Security: A thorough security assessment is crucial to ensure that program does not compromise safety & security of facility.  7. Long-term Sustainability: Develop a plan for ongoing maintenance, animal care, & program evaluation.
Being able to work from home has improved my productivity and mood by 200%. It is the single best thing that the state can do for its employees.

Our organization have the same processes performed in each and every department needing to fill the same positions in each department. Why not centralize the processes. It will bring us efficiency, cut service time and save wasteful spending.
That there is an open door policy for regular front line workers to share ideas.
Using more automation in my work.

I feel that there are way too many people at the top and not enough of us who are "boots on the ground" making the state run. I also think we deserve more appreciation than we receive. That alone might make the state work more efficiently.

State workers who commute to and from the office using public transportation who used to receive monthly vouchers for that expense are more recently required to submit reimbursement claims to the State Controller's Office (to CalAters Global) for review for each individual month and each request currently has to be reviewed forensically and approved as a unique non-travel expense for each individual commuter. This forensic review process and account reconciliation would seem to be waste of State resources if the commuter is going to continue to use the same public transportation each month. The suggestion is to bring the voucher system back. If the cost of a monthly transportation pass increases (which is infrequent) then the voucher amount would increase accordingly. Surely that would be less costly than CalAters reviewing every individual commuter's request for reimbursement every month by the accounting team.

As a State employee for the California Department of Fish and Wildlife, I am constantly stunned by the number of people who have either never heard of the department or have the slightest clue what we do. This means that as a Department, we are failing in our mission. We need to be much more transparent and need to reach a wider audience, and I feel that a better presence on social media platforms and taking more time to hold public forums, media releases, etc. would be beneficial. Of course, this largely comes down to a lack of staff and resources, and also policies that seem to prohibit how and what information we can share. As a state agency, one of our core responsibilities is to be transparent with our decision making - but another part of transparency is sharing the excellent work that many of our state workers are doing up and down the State and why the public should care and be paying attention.

I think the CDT PAL process is over complicated and costly and doesnt lead to better IT project outcomes. I think it discourages people from implementing needed technology updates and contributes to technical debt. I think the new PDL process was an attempt to streamline but ended up being equally confusing. I would recommend the state work on a new simplified process for IT project approval and oversight.
training and communication. Mentorships and specific training classes available for each job role in order to advance up the chain and do the current job better.

One would think that with being a trail blazing "green" state the California government would be all for hybrid work. Specially since we have the infrastructure in place to do it successfully, after all the investments done during the pandemic.

There are far too many hurdles in the required purchasing requirements and approval processes for equipment, supplies, and contracts. More streamlined processes and granted authorities are needed.  Additionally, utilizing large retailers would save the State abundant funds.

Lean into the possibilities of telework by creating efficient and inclusive work opportunities  for employees with disease and disability. In addition, examine which job duties are enhanced or prohibited by in person work.

One problem I have is my supply budget. The price of cleaning supplies have gone up significantly but my budget has gone down as in I have to add items that are not cleaning supplies like toilet paper and paper towels, thus lowering the amount of supplies I can order. I also believe that that PIA should have less say in what I can order. Some of their products do not work and yet I'm not able to get the supplies I know work.

As a Californian and a state employee, I have seen how telework creates opportunities to improve efficiency and customer service. In my own work, I have streamlined processes that once depended on paper files, in-person signatures, or lengthy office meetings. By shifting these tasks online and coordinating virtually, I eliminated delays and reduced errors that came from moving documents between offices. This allowed staff to focus more on completing core work instead of chasing paperwork, which directly improved turnaround times for the public.  Another example is customer service. When working remotely, I am able to respond more quickly to inquiries because I am not losing hours each week to commuting. I can give residents my full attention without the stress and fatigue of traffic, which means they get clearer answers and faster resolutions. Many constituents rely on timely help, and telework enables me to deliver that without sacrificing quality.  Telework also fosters accountability. Using shared databases, secure online platforms, and video calls, collaboration with colleagues remains strong. In fact, it often becomes more intentional and focused. The ability to concentrate without the constant interruptions of an office environment has increased my productivity and accuracy.
Better pay and getting paid every 2 weeks would be great!

Leaders in positions of power who can either support or discard an idea or suggestion for legislation should learn to LISTEN to those of us who make the suggestion. We are not just throwing out a wild idea for no reason. We are asking for support that is necessary for us to accomplish our mission. When you say "nope" and disregard the reasons and explanations provided, you are just killing an idea for the sake of killing it. Then, our jobs are more difficult because our idea can't be implemented.  We are the ones in the "trenches" doing the work and we KNOW what we need to be better or keep up the work. You're not even in the room, so you can't possibly know.  We are the SMEs! Please listen to us.

I implemented calibration meetings in my section. We independently complete a project and then come together every two weeks to discuss what was done differently and why. We discuss until a consensus is found and agreed on.

One big problem is the great brain drain. i.e. older employees that have been working the area for years are retiring and from what I have been seeing is that most of the time their supervisory positions are filled after they have retired.  And taking the wealth of knowledge with them.  There is also a bit of a disconnect between the age groups of the older staff soon to retire and the younger staff coming it.   If we could get new hires in place to shadow some of these great wealth of knowledge employees before retiring, that would help. And then some basic training on connecting different generations.  I know with is happening in other states already, as I've personally been to those trainings as an employee of another state. And seen them help.

How about something as simple as managers should talk less and listen more? In my brief time with the State, I have had (and currently have) managers who drone on and on and on at the expense of staff's time. Also, shorten the meetings. A meeting that can be an email should be an email. And if you've sent the email, it doesn't need to be restated and explained in a meeting. There is SO MUCH overexplaining. This relates to the numerous comments here about managers failing to treat their staff like adults. The amount of having to be a captive audience to managers who like the sound of their own voices is exhausting.

We should incorporate Airtable to facilitate communication between Headquarters and districts, keep track of large projects across the State, and have real-time data snapshots of each District. The main Headquarters base could have another base for each department, which would be able to inform other bases or be locked, and only editors or those given permission could view/use the data stored in that base. This model could be used for each District. Another good use at the District (or Headquarters) level is have a separate base for approved contractors within their district, so Maintenance, Contracts, and Purchasing could all see the same list, keep it updated, and confidently arrange services. This would allow Superintendents to review projects, adjust timelines, or give approval where needed. It would improve accountability and reduce the amount of separate apps required.
Greater collaboration with other teams, as well as involvement in projects outside of one's own scope of work can help further understand the processes in place, and help expedite project completion.
PACe should be make free to all State Staff, to support and enhance our career growth within state ecosystem.

I think there is problem in understanding the relationships between taxes and the public services they fund. I feel the state should work on a marketing campaign to help Californians better understand this relationship and the value we all receive from the public programs in the state.

At Mt. Tamalpais State Park, we frequently have lost or injured hikers/cyclists. Locating them and assessing their status is complicated by the number and length of our trails (approx. 60 trails, up to 7.5 miles in length). Our ranger staff is limited and serves a large geographic area. It would help our responsiveness to have a drone to fly along a trail to locate a hiker/cyclist in distress. Pinpointing the location would help reduce response time for search and rescue.

My department hears out new ideas from anyone, employees and supervisors alike. I have made many suggestions to improve processes and provide better customer service, which have been noted and/or implemented by my department. Providing this atmosphere of openness to new ideas is great for getting better work done!

California’s government could become more effective and efficient by embracing full time telework for positions that can be done effectively remotely. The recently completed audit showed that this would not only increase job satisfaction, and can even result in increased productivity but it would also save the state millions of dollars.
I have developed a specific documentation form for my job classification, a program to better serve my patient population, and a protocol to improve patient care.
Better access to mental health care.

Wow.  I'm sorry to hear that happening to you and your co-workers.  I thought that there were policies for things like this statewide regardless of where one works in state service.  I hope you don't take away that everyone feels that way toward you.  I hope you do have some folks that aren't like that and that you focus on them.  I am a strong believer that we "hang with people like ourselves", so if you are experiencing very negative things in your workplace, seek out and "hang" with folks that aren't like that in order to keep positive.  My experience is different, but I don't like the lies folks are allowed to spread about me or others I know, and I would like to see more hands-on training about this.  It usually goes that when you report it, you have a mark on your back and now you are a dart board for anything anyone dislikes.  I have a co-worker who works in another dept. and their take on it is that people who are angry with and unhappy in their own lives generally are the people that spread this sort of stuff.  It is still up to administration to take it seriously and do something about it.

I think state departments should encourage more flexibility, in general, when it comes to employee satisfaction.  This includes having exempt employees instead of hourly employees, that have flexible schedules based on their workload.  There is a lot of wasted time that is used on gossip and bullying, because employees are bored and become cliquish.

I have reached out to several other departments who insist on sending information by USPS costing the state hundreds of dollars a year when we could receive the information by email to an address multiple staff can access.  I try to inform staff of the flow of information so when they don't complete the work in a timely fashion it impleads the work of other members of the team.

Primary Problem: When state departments restructure teams or redistribute workloads without hiring additional staff, employees are often left managing the same amount, or more work, with fewer people. This creates burnout, inefficiency, and errors. Team members begin to feel like they’re constantly behind, unable to meet expectations, and working reactively instead of proactively. Over time, this erodes morale and productivity, leading to higher turnover and lost institutional knowledge.   Before any team restructuring, require a Workload Impact Assessment from management to evaluate how the redistribution of tasks will affect timelines, quality of work, productivity, and employee well-being. This should include clear metrics such as workload ratios, task priorities, and realistic turnaround times and involve direct input from the staff who understand the day-to-day demands. Departments should also implement temporary workload support plans, and training managers how to support their team when they are taking on a doubled workload.   By assessing impact before implementing a big change like that, California can prevent inefficiencies caused by chronic overload, promote employee well-being and reduce the likelihood of good employees leaving, and ensure high-quality service delivery even during tough transitions.

I am newer to the state, as are some of the commenters below, and I have to say I wholeheartedly agree with there needing to be more direction and guidance. We know that some people learn and work differently (it is standard practice to identify our "types" when taking entry community college courses) and that should be applied in the workplace. The bureaucratic comments may be to blame for a lot of the unwillingness to step outside of our role to assist a coworker who asks for help or something like that. I have always been like "we are on the same team," and will help any way i can but quickly learned that others are not like minded. Only in my state jobs though. I think rank-and-file employees have first hand experience and are kept far from the decisions about their own roles and what processes should be changed to save money.
improved backend systems to make the processing time efficient and meet the needs of the users.
Perhaps sending related printed material, flyers, FAQs, etc., with the annual registration or tax renewals.

Primary Problem Sales and use tax regulations are complex and often contain gray areas. True expertise usually comes from auditors who have dealt with specific, real-world applications of the law. However, there is no easy or safe way for auditors to share their knowledge across the department. Getting clarity on how to apply a regulation often requires layers of approvals, and managers may hesitate to elevate questions up the chain. This slows audits, wastes staff hours, and delays clear guidance to taxpayers.  Proposed Idea Create a safe, department-wide collaboration channel where auditors can directly share and discuss regulation questions with a large group of experienced peers. For example, an internal email group or moderated forum could allow auditors to submit questions and receive input quickly, without having to navigate multiple levels of approval. Faster feedback would reduce audit hours, improve consistency, and give taxpayers clearer answers sooner, all while fostering a culture of shared expertise and professional growth.
DOGE type agency independent of the State control to find the waste and classify it by dollar amount so we know which items to correct first. We aren't serving the taxpayer dollar very well.

I think the Cannabis program is great, but we should reduce the current tax load and allow the businesses to thrive a bit more, they still can't compete with illegal sales because it's expensive at the store. I'm sure the revenue generated is a tremendous help, but if the legal industry collapses due to taxes, there goes the enforcement revenue.

There is no room for promotion unless we want to move to a different part of the State. I was told once you are in the State, you are set but then if you want to move departments or reach your pay cap at your current position. There is no motivation for higher ups to move you. Which as an employee, doesn't motivate me to work harder. I work in Admin and I feel that often Headquarters and the Districts seem to be working against each other. There are so many systems that don't speak to each other, rules change without warning or training. The solutions would include either extending pay caps or make promoting or moving around your own District easier. We need less systems that actually communicate and work. I feel like once I understand how to do something, it's changed in Headquarters, we at Districts don't find out until we are told we did it wrong.

People in California feel that government isn't working for the people because government lacks representation. 40% of the population in California is Latino/Latina but most of the state agencies and department employees are non-Latino/Latina. There is clear disconnect between the community and those who are supposed to be addressing people's needs. I would solve this problem by making California government more representative of its population.
I worked for CALFIRE years ago and they really invested in leadership over management. It was the best work environment I have ever been in!

Because of inevitable turnover, all agencies should prioritize the creation of task specific guides, or 'desk guides', that describe how the employee actually carries out one of the many regular/repeated tasks; this is also where to share best practices (navigating software, interdepartmental timeline needs, formatting preferences, etc.).  Too often, the department is forced to burden the one person who knows how to do a certain task with training every newly hired employee on every step of that process, and field all follow-up questions, only to have the new staff member move on and be replaced by a new-hire and do it all over again. The desk guides also function to keep processes consistent from one employee to the next, and remind staff how to perform parts of the task when the task is performed infrequently.

We should be at forefront of innovation and technology. The state government offices lag way behind on these and the corporate business and companies and using them and are helping be more efficient. The workers if allowed to telework would be a great help as it would allow them to spend more time to work and also help Climate goals for California and save millions of dollars each year by not renting/ leasing office spaces. Use of AI adoption should be fast bureaucracy takes so much time and we then lag behind. Staff if called to office are not being provided with required furniture to work which in turn makes the employee feel out of interest to work for the state. The upper management would need to listen to rank&file and get their views on things.

I have created and suggested ways to stream some of the processes in my work.  However, I am much more interested in working on teams charged with creating big change in the way we do business.  "We" through teams can create more of an impact to meet the needs of Californians efficiently, timely, ensuring high quality and effectively.  I think we need to document the way we are doing business (processes, procedures etc) currently.  Then, implement continuous improvement process to remove and improve.  We might utilize technology more for those tasks that could be done by a software program instead of time and money wasted on manual tasks.  Time and money used in making our employees more knowledgeable about state government (the departments, their impact on the public and their community) as well as their immediate office/unit/division/department. Time and money can be used in acquiring additional skills, honing current skills ect. Creating a workplace culture that encourages employees to stay.

Sharing data amongst agencies is cumbersome and often requires emails and updates to multiple siloed databases. If we had interagency databases shared amongst the agencies that need access to that data we could eliminate duplicate databases and generate reports in real time automatically.

It appears that we don't have the options to purchase non EV vehicles. However, the charging stations at our office never work due to the fact our parcel has maxed out our electrical capacity. So we keep getting more and more EV cars and trucks with no easy way to charge them (quickly). Throw in the fact we are mostly rural, and fast public charging stations are few and far between. This could be solved by allowing state agencies in rural areas more exemptions to purchasing EV only vehicles.

I think we need to create ways that the public can contribute to solving our technical problems through open source, volunteering, or other collaborations. There are a lot of smart people out there who would be willing to help.

Support upward mobility from seasonal to permanent employee. There are countless hurdles that employees must overcome to get into a permanent position. Most will just go to the private sector and then we lose good talent trying to get truly qualified people "qualified" for a position.

It took several months, but now my department is allowing employees over 50 miles from the office to take the exemption from return to office mandates and that has increased morale and effectiveness of staff.

As a former private sector employee, I would say that state processes are much slower to change in order to keep up with existing technology. We have fewer instances of process documentation and very little consistent messaging around project processes and procedures. This is sometimes passed off as "nuance" between projects but the procedures should be largely the same for substantively similar tasks and no task is so nuanced that it can not be documented for the staff working on a specific project. Training is often one person showing another with no supervisor oversight or written documentation, so failures in a process persist through generations of staff. Some processes are intentionally obscured to mask waste or inefficiency, where they could and should be transparent and streamlined. Much of our technology was established in the 1990s and has never been updated or improved, despite being obsolete. Tech staff retention needs to be addressed and change management for technology needs to be better handled. Rank and file staff needs to be empowered to learn and understand technology. By reducing turnover in IT, training staff and providing written manuals for processes, and improving technological literacy we can bring our processes into the 2000s.

This is a great point. Often, in the spirit of innovating, people think about what MORE we can do to improve. Sometimes, the best way to improve things is by removing, not adding. Remove steps. Remove unnecessary approvals. Remove old guidelines and job aids. Remove processes that haven't been updated in at least five years and start from scratch. No, don't simply update. Start over as if this process were being created today. It's extremely effective.
Initiated in-person partnerships with like agencies/pension systems in the area to obtain and share best working practices to help better serve our internal and external customers.

Another ongoing issue is working with personnel.  It seems like no one really knows how to do things, maybe it's high turnover, but different people give different answers.  Being out stationed, we don't really have a contact person.  Going out on leave is super complicated with mis-information, or changing processes, and it shouldn't be that difficult.
Our crew lead developed a Survey123 app to track how the crew spends its time and in which specific parks, which has helped with reporting.
Less fear of technology. Trust your staff to find a way to test ideas. And if they work, find a way to implement them!
The most problematic part of my job is the archaic computer systems which cause redundancy in performing my primary tasks.  Upgrading SCO would be my primary focus.

The overwhelming amount of repetitive paperwork. I can only speak for my department when it comes to solutions (or possible solutions) but my attempt to even suggest some options seem to hit brick walls.
Improve communication and be a quality team member.

I work with my team to document everything digitally and cut the paper out of our workflow. We also use tracking for routed documents, so we don't have to call people to see status, and we get real-time feedback. We also use templates for as much as possible since there's so much "Paperwork" that goes with doing anything. We don't want to recreate the wheel.  The team I supervise also works well independently and meets on their own to calibrate which I think gives them more autonomy and buy-in to do their work with fidelity, accountability, and consistency.  We also rotate assignments when new projects emerge, and everyone is always willing to chip in. It's all very team oriented.  We utilize teams to share projects where multiple people are working on it, since we tend to have connection issues with our network occasionally (both in the office and out of the office). It allows us to keep moving forward when having access issues.  For some reason, we tend to have a lot of internet or network failings when IN the office, so we also use flexibility to meet offsite to complete projects when necessary. It assists with morale, but also gets the work done efficiently.

Consistancy overall, in information provided on the internet on the State Departments.  Should have one format for all departments and simple language.  Especially with Taxes, normal people are not lawyers who are reading the information, if anything we confuse them more.   Also the image State Workers have, like they don't like their jobs so they make it bad for the public, like government employees don't care.   Government sector customer service and very different from Private sector customer service, we should incorporate some Private sector practices. We should show some empathy, we care.  HR practices, can't be one generic for overall state departments.  Each individual state department is different and unique, let them run their own HR.  Example, Tax Technician and Compliance Reps are in one big bucket and pay range is the same.  But a Tax Tech and Compliance Rep in a Field office learns and knows more then one that is in a central office doing one duty daily.  Field Office staff should be paid more and location should be looked at also.  Ones in Los Angeles cannot be paid the same as one in Sacramento. That's two different areas and cost of living, yet the pay range is the same.  My pet peeve:  "We have always done it that way!"  We need to change with the times and technology.  We improve on the technology but its not embraced, because we have always done it that way.  Not being open to new ideas and/or suggestions.
Anytime you make a process simpler or just with less levels of approval, its a win.
yes.  If we provided state agencies with the resources to be able to produce things that vendors can we could use state employees to do the work internally.

The procurement process is overly complicated, time consuming, and often not the most cost efficient.  For example, we are required to purchase chairs from CalPIA.  CalPIA charges $500+ for one desk chair and then another $30 per chair to deliver.  The same chair could be purchased from another retailer for a fraction of the price.  In addition, the ordering time is outrageous.  Purchases go through many levels of approval before getting to the vendor and many times the required vendor's turn around time is 60+ business days.    Small businesses and disabled veteran-owned businesses get preference, and many times, these small businesses order from retailers like Amazon and then upcharge the State.  There is nothing cost efficient about the procurement process.

I agree. I left a position because I had a manager who is unwilling to listen to feedback from employees or take any accountability for her own mistakes. While they didn't make any errors that would cause them to be fired or reprimanded, they made a really uncomfortable working environment, and a bunch of really great staff keep leaving. According to her, the staff, including me, just couldn't take the job, and there's no accountability for her being a truly terrible manager.

Our pay which has a direct effect on our retention . We spend hundreds of thousands of dollars training employees, they work for us for years promote through the ranks with valuable experience and we lose them to local government fire departments. They get paid more money as a probation firefighter then as a seasoned fire captain with us. We can’t keep good employees.

Overhaul management training. Excellent analysts do not typically equate to excellent managers. The mandatory 80-hour supervisor training does not set up new managers well enough to be good leaders. They are often underprepared and have no idea what to do to help coach and train (especially new) employees. Many of them only promote for the extra compensation and don't care about their team excelling.

A more innovative hiring process. Update classification specifications, ensure salaries are competitive, provide incentives, expedite but allow for a quality way to screen applicants (i.e., applicants use AI and its difficult to assess their capabilities on a AI-developed SOQ).

(High-Speed Rail) Although I don't have direct experience with the High-Speed Rail. Admittedly, maybe I don't have enough understanding of the situation. But if there is still budget to put down some tracks. Why not start the High-Speed Rail between LA & Las Vegas. Could California not split the profits 50/50 with Nevada? I am sure that the casinos would love to assist paying for it as well since you would be bringing revenue to their casinos with the easy access between LA & Vegas. It is also a lot of desert between the two cities. At least then you would start generating revenue to continue the project. Aside from that I would imagine there would be increased revenue for the city of LA as people from Nevada may want to visit Disney Land, Hollywood, etc. with easier access.  Seems like it would be a win-win for both states and possibly a revenue generator for the program to get things going.

Instead of writing a mail station number on an inter-department delivery envelope, and then continuing to scratch out the previous one and write a new one below it, we should all simply just place a sticker with our intended mail station number ON TOP OF the previous sticker, and that way it would make the inter-department delivery envelopes LAST FOREVER, thus saving the state money by NEVER needing to purchase more inter-department delivery envelopes ever again. Think about it. If everyone keeps hand-writing mail station numbers below the previous one, and scratching out the prior one, eventually the envelope becomes full and has to be thrown away and more envelopes get purchased which wastes money. BUT if everyone were to simply place a sticker with the mail station ON TOP of the previous mail station rather than below it, then those envelopes would last forever without ever needing to get replaced.

In my division of my department, we have a database to track projects that is so old it uses a platform that is no longer supported. When we tried in the past to replace this with a more functional, modern system, there were so many roadblocks that it was impossible to implement the new system. We are trying again.  My suggestion is to make modernizing or upgrading old computer systems easier. While I understand that it can be costly to do so, having old barely functioning systems is even more costly to the citizens of California.
I'm a fulltime state employee and I was homeless for a while, WHILE working full time! It's too damn expensive to live here!
When I was doing process improvement and applying the Lean Six Sigma concepts, the process time for credit card refunds were reduced. Improving forms to be more user friendly.
I would add that we should not Return to the office, working from home indeed works.  Save our planet, save our sanity and save everyone's time.

This is so important. Our website has a Flesch–Kincaid average readability level of 'College Sophomore'! That's crazy to think the average Californian is going to understand maybe 20% of what is posted on our site.

Being new to the State, I feel that the biggest problem that I would address is misleading employees upon hire. I was informed that my position was 100% remote. There is not enough training, I'm still unclear of my duties. Lastly, there is talk about changing pay periods from monthly to bi weekly. They tend to make changes, and these changes are disruptive to employees lives, and that is not taken into account when upper management makes these huge decisions. These decisions have caused some really valuable state employees to quit and return to the private sector.
"The Mystery of Capital" by the Peruvian economist Hernando de Soto should be required reading for all public officials and and anyone involved with public contracting.

There is no motivation for workers to work any harder than anyone else.  The union ensures that all workers are treated equally if you do your job or not.  Since there is no reward for working hard and there is no punishment for not doing your job, this tends to ensure that even that most dedicated employees tend to tap out and stop putting in any sort of extra effort or even leave the state for a job that actually appreciates and rewards hard work.  This leads to a large disenfranchised population of workers doing the bare minimum since that is all that is required of them.

Tax law must be rewritten to equitably tax both the lowest income earners and the big corporations. Though California has a "millionaire tax" our wealthiest residents and corporations still often pay less taxes than our poorest. We must rewrite our tax law to accommodate the changes in industry since tax code was last revised and to reflect the extreme wealth disparities in our state.

This is a great concept and should be kept open indefinitely not just for a limited sampling. It’s important to constantly have a place for employees to report things from the bottom so a pulse check can be taken. Now with AI and technology these sorts of sentiments can be summarized and it just be a living pulse check so I don’t understand why this has to be a one time short-lived occurrence.

I don't believe it's fair to be charged for parking at a state-owned parking garage. I feel like I'm being charged unnecessarily, just for going to work. Can state garage maintenance be included in the CA budget? That way workers don't have to pay for parking directly. At least the financial burden gets spread amongst all taxpayers.

There has been a noticeable shift toward utilizing our online system for specific approvals and account close-out processes. To ensure greater efficiency, standardization, and cost-effectiveness, it is recommended that all processes - including payments, where applicable - be transitioned to an online-only format.
Implementation of DocuSign for completion and tracking completion of mandatory forms.

Better communication with the general public on government affairs. For example, legislation like California Jobs First, and Freedom to Succeed. These programs had significant impact, but I was the marketing content I found was lacking and didn't reinforce the positive impact they had on the community. Let's not fail to tell Californians how helpful legislation can be! :)
Leading trainings via tele-services. I am able to lead trainings on Teams and am able to spend more time with external stakeholders to help them understand things.

As California state worker once issue is parking and finding street parking  take the risk or pay for expensive garage which double the price.  To solve this problem I feel employees should get some benefit for parking when you can’t find spot to park.

Most people associate the EDD with unemployment insurance or disability insurance. However, it is much more than that. It is a government agency that provides resources, job referrals, referral to services, trainings, etc. to help people in need. We need to do a better job at informing people that we are on their side. The EDD can be a bridge to help people not only get by but literally change their lives for the better.

From my observations and experience, the misuse of consultants versus upskilling staff and providing a pathway for advancement.  Some CEA leadership not being qualified for their role and no way to address via HR or other pathway since they may be appointed. Poor leadership allows for poor moral.  Have noted leadership in some agencies unwilling to work with leadership from other.  While not the 'norm', it does happen and creates barriers. Would like to know that GO leadership encourages leaders from within agencies to work together and track for accountability.   I think that having a feedback loop that includes a 360 review tool for reviewing 'up' is really important for culture development as well as building trust within an agency. Even if some of the feedback sounds trite or personal, it is still feedback and encourages transparent conversations.   Encourage lunch and learns that focus on emotional intelligence and communication versus just via onboarding training. While not required as part of annual trainings that I'm aware of, could be promoted as 'optional and encouraged' - it is empowering for self-reflection and relationship building.

Having things centralized online onto the cloud would help tremendously when locating items that need to be found. The current system where items are located in file rooms creates delay in work. A solution would be scanning all documents in and having them in centralized online location.

As a tenured state employee with over 10 years of experience, one of the biggest problems I've seen is the retention of employees who don’t contribute to the mission, goals, or vision of the department. It’s frustrating to work alongside individuals who consistently underperform or show little motivation, especially when dedicated employees like myself are paid the same or often less. This impacts morale, slows progress, and weakens the overall effectiveness of the team.  To address this, I’d advocate for a more meaningful and transparent performance evaluation process that includes peer feedback and self-assessments, not just supervisor input. Raises and promotions should reflect both tenure and performance, so that strong employees feel valued and motivated. I’d also propose a peer recognition program to highlight those who go above and beyond, and development plans for employees who need improvement. Finally, training supervisors to actively manage performance issues would help ensure accountability.  These changes would support a healthier workplace culture and better public service. By recognizing effort and addressing complacency, we can build teams that truly reflect the values of public service.

The amount of paperwork required to obtain any service of the state should be streamlined. Forms should be revised constantly and redundant forms or request for information should be eliminated, making the way our constituents ask for state services easier to understand and the form easier to complete. State departments should be able to share information as to avoid duplicate requests from the constituent. In this age of technology constituents should be able to download, complete and submit forms electronically and these forms should be placed in a repository where all state departments can have access.
Telework works!
I have developed tools (Excel Workbooks) to help outreach workers track farmworker contacts. Currently working on developing guidance that may increase the provision of services to farmworkers.

I would like to see managers and supervisors provided with more adequate training to fill those positions. I would also like to see managers and supervisors trained in better ways to speak with subordinates and be clearly informed of job duties and descriptions.

Communication. Internal operational support units do not proactively communicate their procedures so business users cannot determine what is needed and in what order. Updates are made but not documented/communicated in a uniform, prompt, orderly process. Managers and executives do not communicate uniformly nor clearly with staff to set expecations and follow up with accountability. The level of safety for staff to communicate ideas and have them be heard objectively and considered operationally is often low.

I work at a regulatory agency, and some staff are working on improving transparency and guidance for members of the public who are going through our permitting process. This involved creating a guide in plain language and extensive rework of our website.

I see an opportunity to help all staff understand the customer they serve and to keep the customer's needs as a focal point as we do our work. I also see an opportunity to include our customers in the refinement of old and the development of new policies / procedures.    One idea for addressing these opportunities: a simple communication campaign to raise awareness and, in some cases, change people's minds.

Potentially, but also care would need to be taken not to disenfranchise those who lack broadband access. This could be a facially neutral policy that would disparately impact the elderly or particular racial communities.

I feel that so many positions are so closely tied to Sacramento that it negatively impacts other communities - especially small ones.  I would like to see state departments focus on spreading their positions to smaller geographies.  Since we've adapted to telework and remote work, we could really expand job offerings into communities that lack state employees.  This would not only bring good, stable careers to smaller communities, it would also bring the perspective and influence of smaller communities to state level decisions and efforts.  This could also include hiring those with limited means and/or disabilities that make work in Sacramento difficult for some.

The primary issue among state employees is the wasteful spending of having to use a small business. Small businesses are marking items up so much that it adds up so quickly and eats away at our lab consumable/supply budget. The small businesses also add a $49 shipping fee (why?) when items do not come from the small business but rather come from various vendors to us. They are the middleman placing orders with the vendors. $49 x # orders equal a lot of money. Small businesses are taking advantage of the state it seems to line their pockets. Also, the time it takes to process orders through purchasing takes a month to two months. We are not set up to conduct research in the lab as a result.  When I joined the state many years ago, we had a limited $ blanket and we called the vendor directly and placed our order. We received our orders fairly quick. We need to have the ordering better streamlined in terms of processing time and how to save taxpayer $ and get rid of utilization of small business and be able to go back to ordering from vendors directly.
Clean and frequent public transportation. Affordable housing and healthcare.

In my experience, more time is wasted on justifying a position, versus entrusting employees to get the job done.  Training aside (it is important), employees are micromanaged to the point of paralysis. Supervisors and managers end up editing each other's work because they have need to "add" their two cents, even when not productive.

Further efforts to increase telework according to California Code, Government Code - GOV § 14200.1 should be investigated and implemented. This will help reduce costs for California taxpayers, reduce traffic congestion, and reduce pollution. This will also decrease the amount of money spent by employees of the state on unnecessary costs like fuel, parking, and food.

I find that the primary problem is that too many large corporations take way too much from the CA taxpayers.  Many were not eligible for PPP loans and there's not enough law enforcement so it encourages criminal and/or misrepresentation in obtaining free funds from the State of California.   Some corporations illegally or inappropriately received PPP loans based on the honor system and took PPP loan deductions in their returns.  If the FTB shared this misrepresentation found during routine audits with other agencies such as SBA to enforce those (i.e. large and publicly traded corporations) that inappropriately received funds, the State of CA would be able revive the income.  When CA funds are inappropriately used to fund profitable corporations during the panddemic such as PPP loans and online criminals continuously stealing money from the State of CA's IT systems, more law enforcement is needed to avoid the illegal loss of funds .  Rather than cutting state salaries, budget cuts, and other reductions that harm the State of CA and our taxpayers, we should pursue the large corporations and criminals that illegally received the funds in the first place.  Placing more security on our IT systems is crucial for protecting our taxpayer funds from continual hacking and misappropriation of funds.  Instead of hitting the CA taxpayers with more costs and illegal use of taxapyer funds, the politicians should invest more in our IT crime prevention to protect the State of CA & its people.

As a state employee, my experience has been that the merit system has very few checks and balances and has largely failed. In my agency, cronyism, nepotism and favoritism run rampant. The rules speak out against these practices, but it seems that the system has slowly evolved to where it is not designed to encourage them.  One of the reasons this happens if SPB has a rule that examination results are kept private, so there is no way to know the exam results of others who have taken the same exam, and it becomes extremely difficult to prove when others rig and/or cheat the system.  Another reason is the heavy reliance on job references, which seem to these days be more important than actual work experience and meeting job qualifications.  Get a hold of all of the dishonesty and restore actual merit in the merit system and you will have better, more qualified, reliable, knowledgeable and more efficient state employees. I am tired of having to work for "the kids" of former executives who do their absolute best to ensure their next of kin get out of doing actual work.

I totally agree with this! There isn't a lot of guidance for newer staff on how to succeed, and we're left to either figure it out or find a coworker willing to help us figure it out. I'm glad you pointed out this issue, because I've been with the state for a long time and forget about things like this.

There is definitely room for streamlining the DGS one-time acquisitions process.  Departments must have DGS do their procurements if it's over their delegation.  It takes DGS several months to complete this process, even if it's for an emergency; DGS staff are unfamiliar with department nuances as they relate to their operations when needing a one-time purchase; and departments spend a ridiculous amount of time going back and forth answering basic questions from the one-time acquisitions staff as they try and learn about the need for the purchase, the department's business needs, etc. Why can't DGS let the departments still complete the purchasing process if it's over their delegation and just have DGS approve/execute the PO?  It would be faster for departments if they could just do it themselves, and DGS would still have oversight since they would need to execute the PO.  Also, if the purchase request goes through the DGS non-competitive bid process, why does DGS need to start from scratch and re-review the entire purchase from the one-time acquisitions unit?  If the NCB unit approves the purchase, isn't that good enough?  If an NCB is approved, can that just count as a delegation for the department to do the purchase instead of starting over again for one-time acquisitions to do it?  This makes purchases take several months when departments can do them in just a month or two. Sometimes these purchases are critical for operations and cause work delays until DGS approves.

Our exams/hiring process. First, there are extremely limited resources available to applicants to help them navigate a hiring process that is fundamentally different from most others. This means the most successful applicants are ones who either receive direct support from State Workers or who have the luxury of time and money to learn the slow way. This is a major impediment to hiring equity. Second, the almost cartoonishly strict interpretation of MQs regularly disqualifies intensely qualified applicants. The staff responsible for interpreting MQs are not experts in the fields they are judging and frequently discredit intensely relevant work experience simply due to the use of a synonym; I have seen applicants with decades of relevant experience have it all thrown out for using a slightly different word on their applicant than what the exam/application reviewer was looking for. Same too for calculating time of relevant work experience. Again, this only serves to exclude marginalized applicants.

I think a lot of times there is so much work to be done but so few staff to actually complete it, which leads to errors and issues. Hiring more staff to complete all the required work and making sure that staff is trained on how to do their job properly (and trained to look out for and share places where redundancies can be removed) would go far to fix this issue.

The return to office mandate for state workers is an unjustified waste of money.  The recently-released telework audit coordinated by Josh Hoover proves this.  State workers who can telework should be allowed to telework full-time.  This would save the state hundreds of millions of dollars annually in office leases and would increase the state's ability to recruit and retain qualified employees.

We have noticed how redundant and wasteful it seems to have each *program* in our office have their own printers/copiers (usually multiple per program). This is not an efficient use of resources or space. Why not just have a bank of printers & copiers per wing/suite/floor that all programs in that space can connect to? This would save $ on equipment, consumables (toner +/- paper), and maintenance while getting more out of each individual machine (less environmental impact). While I understand that programmatic budgets are distinct, why can't programs pay a proportional fee for use of the printing/copying equipment like we do for the office space, IT services, etc.?
