This would surely also save programs $ on wasted toner purchased for machines that become incompatible, outdated, and/or redundant. Streamlining in this way would also likely make machine maintenance and replacement easier.

My agency is chronically understaffed and people are asked to take on extra workloads with no solution in sight or any compensation for the extra work. I think this is contributing to burn out of staff and high turnover rates that make amplifies the staffing issue over time.

I'll also be really frank - this setup for the forum is terrible. We can't even view our own comments or posts readily. I would recommend something closer to Reddit and using an AI tool to group comments that are similar or related together so that those people are able to discuss details back and forth. Then others will be able to see a more comprehensive idea and be able to upvote it. This long list of comments and having to load 3 at a time more is inhibiting productive use of the platform.

Always have FULL maximum staffing for all departments and staffing at all levels and or skills.  Having a fully functioning infrastructure 24/7: Buildings, Computer and internet, vehicles, power, HVAC, printers, supplies, etc.  When you have this: less errors, more productive work, happier public they are benign served in a time and efficient manner.

A lot of funding is spent on maintaining State-owned employee housing. Employee housing is needed in many areas, but the maintenance costs are very high. A cost-benefit analysis may be worthwhile to determine if employees should pay more for rent to help cover maintenance costs. Should highly paid employees pay more for rent than lower paid employees?
Telework has increased work efficiency and productivity. Remote work flexibility and decreased response time.

1. Hiring Process It is my understanding that Directors and Deputy Directors may not go through HR & that reference checks are not always conducted. If that is the case, I believe reference checks should be required for all candidates. Additionally, I believe the current scoring process could be improved. In some cases, employees with many years of service in a department are not selected, which can be very discouraging. I suggest eliminating the scoring system and limiting interview panels to no more than two members to help ensure fairness and consistency. 2. Supervisor Evaluation For employees who are not in supervisory roles, I recommend implementing a survey every six months to provide feedback on their supervisor. These evaluations could be reviewed by the CEA to help identify areas of improvement. I have observed that not all individuals in supervisory positions possess the people skills necessary for effective leadership, and this type of feedback could support their professional development. 3. Open Communication and Feedback All employees, regardless of level, should feel comfortable sharing ideas or raising concerns about their department without fear of retaliation. To strengthen accountability, departments should provide feedback within five business days of receiving employee input. Too often, employees are told that leadership will “get back to them,” but no follow-up occurs.  4. When hired at a new department proper onboarding should be provided.

I would love to see various departments and programs integrated. Currently we are in silos with different departments doing the same task or money being spent twice for the same service.  For instance, we currently pay doctors to be on call for the incarcerated population(I/P), but since we do not have point of care testing, we send the I/P off-site for diagnostics. Looking at the data, I believe we spend an excess of $200 million that we could have avoided if we had point of care testing, telemedicine communication ability and a contract with each county hospital er for after-hours care.

California government often is trying to be too politically suave to its detriment.  For example, restriction on CalPERS on what they can invest in versus allowing them to do what is critical, which is protecting the CA pension program, not to take cigarette or oil companies out of business just as an example.

Agreed, I feel like something like a General State and/or Individual Department Wiki's would be a great way to help with this. Personally, for me the issue I have had is the lack of knowledge sharing. Not that people are not willing to teach and share but that they simply don't have the time to. Having some sort of knowledge repository that is regularly updated can help with new people coming in and trying to figure out how the system/s that they work with function.

I feel like one major point of contention as a state worker is the RTO policy that the governor tried to implement this last year. It has been proven that we are capable of doing our jobs while maintaining a hybrid schedule.  And as someone who does purchasing,  watching my agency waste money preparing for workers to return to office seemed like such a waste of money.  There is such a huge expense to bringing people back tomoffice that includes leading office buildings, the additional cost to workers and the additional traffic. Please keep workers well being in mind
I have offered solutions within the positions I have held. Some are rejected because changing what we do would mean laws would have to be changed or updated.
Exactly! As a state employee, free parking is crucial as parking fees add up over time. It would reduce our financial burdens greatly as parking, especially downtown, can be very expensive.

We in State service focus on implementing programs that distribute funds to solve a problem.  Distributing those funds are often under a regulatory time constraint.  The internal culture leaves little room to perform the Project Controls used in the private sector to hold grantees accountable.  Project Controls track the money and schedule progress to hold stakeholders accountable.  The current culture is to assume everyone is honest and playing by the rules, so we can hand out the funds and solve problems "efficiently" by skipping accountability.  But leaving standard Project Controls out of the process isn't an efficiency; skipping a step in basic project management is a problem.  It is an invitation to some to commit fraud.     This isn't a "poor performance on the part of some people" issue.  It is a cultural habit in our institutionalized processes, maybe because we don't have to show profit and loss.  Incorporating the principles of Project Controls in our contract agreements with grantees - mostly invoice format requirements - is a part of the solution.
Actively involving system users in planning out updates and improvements. Not assuming we know what users want just because we “own” the program!

As a newer state employee, I was shocked that I did not have a sit-down meeting with someone in HR to help explain the benefits and at what level I was eligible for.  I didn't even know what type of employee I was, and I could not talk to anyone, I had to ask co-workers what the differences were and how it would affect me and my future.  It seemed like this was so secretive.  I would think that would be an essential part of onboarding. In addition to overall better communication, access to information needs to be improved.

We brag about our state being the 4th largest economy in the world. But for the amount of work we do and services we provide to the public, our wages are not keeping up with the inflation rate. So many overworked public-facing employees who bear the brunt of the work are so underpaid (some examples: Motor Vehicle Representatives, Program Technicians, Office Assistants/Technicians, people in call centers, and more!). Also, telework helps the state save money by not spending on monthly leases, overhead costs, electricity, and more. Forcing people to RTO is a huge pay cut for many employees who are barely making ends meet in our HCOL state.

The levels of approval that are required for many processes and procedures are often way too long and laborious. We need to find ways to improve efficiency not only for internal processes, but for services that directly impact the public. I get discouraged that the general public thinks state workers are "lazy" or "incompetent" when often, our hands are tied and we cannot move any faster.
I would say hire more employees. Also, provide more training to the staffs. And offer more promotional opportunities.

Provide maximum teleworking to all state employees that are able to perform teleworking as a part of their job function as a codified benefit. This will result in the ability for the state to consolidate its building footprint into a few major buildings throughout the state which can be used for hotelling. Take the remaining buildings no longer in use and convert them into section 8 or subsidized housing for homelessness which will reduce the need to spend billions on homeless shelters/programs. Take the savings from those programs and rebuild the rainy-day funds. This will also reduce the impact of vehicle emissions with at least 100k state workers being taken off the daily commute throughout the state. Everyone wins. I understand this would require a lot of logistics, but if the state wants to play hard ball with state workers, then they could trade the 3% GSI (general salary increase) for permanent teleworking enshrined in major MOUs between the unions and the state of California. Please execute this ASAP. Thank you.
From what I've heard, some departments are running different regulations on how many days in office they have per month. Is it a per department standard or is it a state standard?

There is too much tedious and meaningless project oversight on IT contracts and purchases. Project managers in the oversight agencies add little value but create roadblocks with busy work to complete so that boxes can be checked. Many IT projects could be done for less money internally with good product management.

We need to continue to address racial and gender disparities in the workplace by recognizing the harms of diversity indifference in the forms of colorblindness, gender-blindness, and diversity blindness. Required reading can be assigned to state workers with a short paragraph essay on each chapter written by the state worker to acknowledge what they have learned. Acknowledging the history of vulnerable demographics such as Women, Black, Asian, Hispanic, LGBTQIA, and the disabled can help mitigate colorblindness, gender-blindness, and any feelings of resistance against understanding race and gender vulnerabilities. Required reading and writing can also maintain reading comprehension and critical thinking qualities which are rapidly declining even at managerial levels. Required reading and writing about diversity can also help to heal the injustice of native American genocide, racial indifference (and racism) against people of color, and gender discrimination that were unfortunately inherited from the beginnings of the USA nation and ensuing statehoods, California included. The book New Jim Crow by Michelle Alexander is a good start. Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee is another recommendation. By remembering the history of how the USA and CA statehood came to be, we can repair and heal these centuries-old traumas and the recurring injustices that continue due to ignorance of and indifference towards marginalized communities and state workers.
Leadership training has been a big improvement in our department.
Learning about the state budget. There could be much more time invested in training and onboarding staff to support fiscal stewardship.

With regards to customer service, I treat people the way that I like and expect to be treated.  I focus on the customer and not on delivering statistics.  I look forward to customer surveys that reflect that the time provided in civil service is rewarded in currency, that is time well spent.  Anytime I can impress upon a claimant that we are listening and respectfully so, I know that I am representing and honoring my team and their hard work and effort in training and supporting me.

Some things I have done to improve processes and provide customer service is within my education and outreach efforts. While working with internal and external state partners, I have created an open communication process and partnership through my interactions with them by allowing for honest dialouge and by being transparent. It has created a stronger partnership with a common goal, and has allowed for concerns or requests to be completed timely and accurately, with everyone's input. I have also done this with my staff. It has helped build trust and a positive report, allowing for more buy in and commitment to our shared goals, as we are all on the same team with a common goal and everyone has input and ownership.

One of the primary problems I would address is the outdated and fragmented database systems we rely on as state employees. The current infrastructure is antiquated (over 40 years old and is DOS), and because so many departments and individuals are involved in each process, with systems that don’t communicate with each other, it often creates delays and confusion. Even when tasks are completed promptly on our end, we’re left waiting for other departments to act, which can negatively impact the employees we serve. I'm speaking from within Human Resources.   I understand that there are efforts underway to create a new system, but past attempts have fallen short due to the complexity of the project. Training has also been limited to overly basic scenarios, leaving staff unprepared for real-world complications. When unique or difficult cases arise, there’s often no clear guidance or consistent answers.  To address this, I believe we need:  A centralized and integrated system that reduces dependency on multiple platforms.  Collaborative development of the system with feedback from front-line users during the build phase, not just after rollout.  Advanced scenario-based training that includes real-life, complex examples.  A dedicated support team that can provide timely and consistent answers when issues arise.  These changes would not only improve internal workflows but also ensure better service and outcomes for the public and our fellow employees.
Determine how to automate as many tasks as possible. Not for the sake or, but to actually allow for the human to do more strategy work and less manual work.

I work for a department with an outright BAN on the use of generative artificial intelligence (AI). I feel that this is a huge missed opportunity to improve public service and also efficiencies in day-to-day work. CalLearns has an amazing training, showing a variety of ways that AI can directly benefit public government organizations.  California State government should lean into AI, with more training, and introduction of AI tools in the workplace. The risks should be acknowledged and understood and mitigated rather than prohibiting AI altogether.

I just wanted to update you on the Trade Ready initiative. Well, it has been one year since the first I/P paroled through the Initiative and to date there has been 12 I/P’s released through the program. I checked with HQ, and I am proud to say, none of these I/P’s have recidivated. So, we are running at a zero percent recidivism rate, granted it’s only been one year, and we won’t have any hard data for two to four years, but so far so good. Also, there is a strong interest in Trade Ready amongst the Inmate population.

There is a lack of clear "Succession Planning" of current roles and potential vacancies within the departments, which jeopardizes the continuity of essential services.  There is significant importance in knowledge transfer because people need to know what to do and how to perform and answer the questions correctly.  Ideas to solve the problem:  Mentorship programs - pair a seasoned professional with emerging talent. Skill development for all levels (supervisor/managers) should be more involved with development Workshops aimed at raising awareness Use scenarios to anticipate potential changes Develop a plan with regular evaluations Ensure the team is diverse enough to get different opinions Collaboration work groups   Engaged California is a fantastic opportunity and platform that you have going, and I am glad to be a part.  Thank you.

Increase the number of public-facing offices (in any agency) with after-hours availability. So that California workers don't have to take time off work to report violations or conduct business with the government.

I bet they have steps that have no basis in the process whatsoever.  And I bet there are people that will defend those steps to their last breath.  And that managers will sidestep because they don't want to get involved.  I live this everyday - while out of state professional agencies are brought in to analyze out processes to create efficiency - but nobody will listen to the people doing the work.

I'm new to my department, but at least in my division, there is a strong emphasis on staff development, support, and recognition that has created a really positive culture. I feel like this is an emphasis throughout the department. I also feel the department does a lot to reinforce its mission and vision in communications with employees, which helps us feel connected to the purpose of our work.

This is not something I developed but I like the master services contact methods that have been used in the areas of planning, design, and environmental review.  Once awarded through a request for proposal (RFP) or request for Qualifications process you are then able to issue work orders in a time efficient  manner for a number of years.

Yes, it's always a bandaid. Things need to be built from the ground up, led by those who do the work! Exes make these decisions, leading to garbage software that does not work for those using it day in and day out!
Almost everything we do on paper can and should be done online. It is 2025, we had the technology to do all these things decades ago.

The biggest problem I've encountered is being pitted against corporate interests of the wealthy real estate developers with the return to work mandate.  Lobbyists of this kind should never dictate how state agencies are run.  Ignoring substantive reports of happiness, productivity, and culture thriving in work from home environments depletes the trust we have in state leadership.  Ignoring the benefits of less pollution, less time wasted traveling, less money wasted traveling, decreased risk of workers' comp claims from being in the office, less money spent on parking, less money spent eating out, less money spent on childcare, etcetera ad nauseum because corporate/real estate tycoons aren't willing to evolve is punishing workers for having less lobbying power.  My solution is to not ignore the data and productivity results from the executives entrusted with running our agencies.  My solution is progressive and not regressive thinking.  We can be a leader for change in this country by setting a progressive example starting with how we treat state workers - the proof is in the pudding, WFH works.

Yes, Departments aren't sharing ideas on how to align and make the platforms for timesheets. Department of Technology, CalHHS and others have online platforms for timesheets and yet other Departments are stuck on still using filling out paper document.

Strongly recommend investment in broad LEAN6sigma training for continuous quality improvement. Staff who work with the complex bureaucratic processes every day should be empowered to find ways to make them more efficient. Lots of examples in many comments, including hiring, ordering supplies, repairing equipment.

I think efficiency is a huge part of things for me. Being able to appropriately convey expectations in an efficient and effective manner is a challenge that I think we can all relate to in some aspect. Whether this means streamlining systems or revisiting process steps, I've long felt the impact of circuitous actions which, especially in repetitive tasks, limit the potential for more meaningful task completion, learning, and even have negative impact on employee engagement and morale.   Proper education in evolving with technology and developing less complicated means to accomplish required tasks enables big changes to be handled in a more incremental manner, which, in turn, allows more adequate training and mitigates the inherent aversion to change by offering what appears more like help, rather than a potentially overwhelming or burdensome addition/change to one's workload or processes.  This ultimately improves job satisfaction, thus improving morale and even reducing costs as work completion times not only reduce, but the ease and desire for employees to complete more work increases. Supplementing this with relative and engaging training invites staff to become more invested in not only the evolution of the process, but the overall objective(s) of the larger department/industry.

Speaking to a concerned state taxpayer, I would say my experience (in 5 units in 3 different agencies since Covid started) [still looking for the right fit], my co-workers do not abuse their WAH privileges. Responses to queries on Teams is almost always immediate. And, aside from that measure, our workload in these varied jobs has been such that any absence would be noticeable in work not getting done. Ditto my husband's experience at a different state department.

Need a weighed promotion system. This means it has to include time in service, time in grade, performance reports, interview, accommodations, and promotional test results all graded up to 100 points total.

Let employees continue to telework like they did for four years when the state needed it.   This saves money, improves morale, and gives state employees work/life balance that leads to better services for all of California.

How can we increase investment into meeting our forest health goals? We are not even meeting our current goal of 1 million acres/year (burning piles from several years ago doesn't count!), and can't expect to get to 2.5 million acres/year by 2045 if we don't do something different. This should include an all-of-government approach, but there are clearly walls preventing us from getting to real solutions (otherwise the private marketplace would have solved this!).

In my 17 years experience, the CalHR rules have become so rigidly enforced that our organization has many problems because CalHR doesn't allow flexibility for us to optimize operations. We end up keeping many positions that could have been consolidated, as certain work gets deprioritized. We used to be able to move positions around to meet division needs, but now we have to request a new position. We are constantly losing high quality staff because strictness of HR rules enforced means high quality candidates often fall outside the narrowness of the HR rules.  We would be so much more effective and efficient if CalHR could allow the flexibility they used to give to allow us to determine what are needs are and move around resources to meet them. Everything has become so top down in recent years, with no opportunity for discussion to figure out how to get the department's needs met. So this feedback tool is appreciated.

Permanent/long term tasks being done in small temporary structures.  For example: The Vacaville prison itself where inmates are is made of concrete, but the HR & clerical tasks buildings nearby are a couple of wooden portables. A prison is around so long it really merits a permanent office building for its administrative aspects.

There should be only one tax agency as in other states. Having several BOE, FTB, CDTFA, EDD makes for a data sharing and data consistency nightmare. We also end up paying the same contractors 4 times. It is good for vendors not taxpayers.

This!  This is what I came here to say.  As a relatively new employee to the State, I’ve observed some concerning disparities in management oversight across departments. While I understand that some areas utilize tools like 360-degree reviews and engagement surveys to support accountability and continuous improvement, this is not the case in my department.  It is disheartening to witness talented and dedicated employees become disengaged or leave entirely due to unaddressed management issues. There appears to be no formal mechanism for providing feedback on managerial performance—no 360 reviews, no engagement or pulse surveys, and no exit interviews. As a result, problematic management behaviors often go unchecked, with no accountability or opportunity for constructive feedback.  The high turnover in the department should serve as a clear signal that something is amiss. Without systems in place to evaluate and improve leadership practices, managers are able to operate without oversight, while employees are left vulnerable. Since managers control performance evaluations and career progression, employees are placed in a difficult position where they may feel unable to speak up without fear of retaliation.  Introducing even basic feedback systems would be a meaningful step toward a healthier and more effective workplace culture. Doing so would not only improve morale and retention, but also support the professional growth of both staff and leadership.

Deep and miring bureaucracy. I know this goes with the territory, but it's really hard to take sometimes. I often feel like I'm wading through molasses trying to do BASIC parts of my job. This manifests in too many ways to count, but a couple issues are top of mind:  1) The regulatory environment limiting restoration-- hell, even basic ongoing maintenance-- is stifling work when the need for urgent action is so high. The "cutting the green tape" initiative was good, but didn't really fix structural issues. For example, replacing a minor culvert under a remote road in the middle of summer when it's bone dry still costs $10,000 in labor before ground is even broken. Surely there could be a streamlined (no pun intended) process for this-- perhaps a straightforward checklist or rubric to determine if there are major concerns or perhaps statutory exemptions for which you qualify.  2) Basic tasks like purchasing and timesheets are so complicated that we literally need a TEAM of administrative staff to handle navigating the esoteric, bureaucratic backwaters of Sacramento. Even with their help, it's frustrating, time-consuming, and hilariously dysfunctional. This is don't have solutions for. Ours is a large and complicated state. I've seen too many failed attempts at systems integration to believe there's a single fix for this. It may not be possible to put humpty-dumpty back together again.

One big problem I see is the lack of geographical diversity in our state workforce. That creates enormous blind spots and group think, because the folks that serve certain areas don't know or understand the nuances or barriers/obstacles in the areas they purport to serve because they don't come from those geographical areas - thus there is a real gap there. For example, our state has 58 counties, yet most state employees (depending on the department) are concentrated in one county. We should make a concerted effort to hire statewide to better represent the state in its totality. Afterall, we know that representation matters. This would better mitigate some implicit biases that we all have.

I have noticed that innovation and technology are being implemented inconsistently and mostly for the benefit of the state employee, not for the public or registered users accessing the system or requiring assistance. Electronic payment options, integration with access systems similar to IDme, and more direct engagement with the public (which has declined over the last few years) would all be beneficial.
Not enough training available for State employees in the areas they are interested in.

I facilitated Communities of Practice (CoP) convenings throughout one of my grant's lifecycles -- transforming routine communications into a shared ritual of learning, alignment, and empowerment.  These convenings became trusted spaces where colleagues could gather across programs to exchange wisdom, build trust, and co-create solutions. We didn't just talk, we equipped. Each session served as a launchpad for new directives and federal guidance, offering timely technical assistance and practical guidance to support implementation. By blending relational connection with strategic clarity, these CoPs helped cultivate a culture of responsiveness, where innovation is rooted in relationship, and public service becomes a shared craft.

To keep California strong - we need to be able to attract businesses and high-quality talent, but taxes in this state are so much higher than other states.  Shouldn't we have economies of scale given our population and thus try to target a lower tax rate versus other states?
Let's put the tax money to work and keep fixing those roadways! :) Thanks!

I hear research suggests that interview success is not predictive of work effectiveness. We all know the eligibility exams are a joke. Why don't we have actual tests to measure fitness for the jobs we need filled instead of encouraging applicants to lie about how great their experience is? If we hired on the basis of exams that were predictive of role success, we could dispense with interviews, which in many cases present a non-job-related barrier.

Duplicated work within state government agencies remains a significant concern, leading to inefficiencies, increased costs, and delays in service delivery to the public. Overlapping responsibilities, siloed operations, and lack of coordination between departments often result in multiple teams performing the same or similar tasks independently. Addressing this issue requires a focused effort to streamline processes, improve inter-agency communication, and implementing integrated systems that promote transparency and accountability. Reducing duplication not only enhances operational efficiency but also ensures that taxpayer resources are used more effectively to serve the public interest.
Good pay for state employees. Employees staying in the Bay Area should get good pays as compared to private. more flexibility for workers
That is a great idea; however, as a hiring manager, I don't have access to ECOS.  I am sent the applications that are screened in from HR directly.

Allow state employees to work out of a state office of their choice.   The return-to-office mandate has created challenges for many employees—particularly those hired into remote roles. While some employees value in-office collaboration (myself included), requiring relocation to a specific office location is impractical and disruptive for many. Many people were hired for remote positions and are now facing the option to move to the specific location of their state office or find a new job. However, in many cases, employees live near a state office, just not the one affiliated with their agency. Forcing them to move or resign creates unnecessary turnover and hardship. Further, many offices that are designated for a specific agency/department are sitting mostly vacant because they have hired staff all over the state for remote work that do not live near their specific office. Therefore, state employees should be allowed to choose an office to work from, rather than office space being designated only for one agency/department. Providing more flexibility in where state employees can work solves problems for the employees who would like to work near where they live and solves problems for the state by filling currently vacant office space.   Side benefits would occur from this change by introducing state employees that would otherwise not meet, breaking down silos, and creating community based on location.
More affordable housing, higher wages.
one issue is the lack of communication to the general public about processes and steps individuals take to access services/programs.

As both a Californian and a state employee, I strongly support the continuation and expansion of telework. From my perspective, telework directly addresses the two goals of this discussion: increasing efficiency within state government and improving service to the public.  When state employees telework, we eliminate hours of commuting time each week. That reclaimed time translates into more energy and focus for our work, rather than starting the day already drained from traffic. Telework also reduces overhead costs for departments, with less need for office space, utilities, and parking reimbursements. Those savings could be redirected toward technology, staffing, or public programs that improve government services.  Telework allows employees to be more responsive to the public. With modern tools such as secure cloud systems, videoconferencing, and shared databases, most services can be delivered as effectively, if not more so, remotely. Constituents rarely care whether the employee helping them is in a cubicle or a home office. They care about getting timely, accurate, and respectful service. By avoiding commute-related stress and delays, employees are better equipped to provide exactly that.

Virtual meetings and work groups have greatly accelerated products and workflows. Moving away from physical processes to digital environments has helped mediate losses in productivity from high turnover.

We need better equipment for state employees. As workflows become increasingly digital, the shortcomings of our computers are becoming very evident. 16gb of ram is not enough to run the programs we need. Especially because many programs are becoming increasingly heavy in terms of memory requirements. If we want to integrate AI into our processes, we will need a significant upgrade.

I think it would be cool for my staff to be able to give me feedback about my management style in an anonymous or non-anonymous way. I feel staff get a lot of critical feedback from top to down and we need more feedback to go both ways, in whatever way they feel comfortable. The fear of retribution is real and the more we can have open dialogues, the better.

Through the DGS dashboard, we witnessed firsthand how telework benefited the environment. As both a CalEPA employee and a scientist, it is disheartening to see that management disregarded the data, the science and the environmental impacts, choosing instead to undue the good that's been done. This decision deeply undermined my trust in an agency entrusted by the public to safeguard our environment

Unfortunately, I have noticed most of the dangerous driving habits I witness are coming from seniors (aside from distracted drivers). I believe regular driving tests would be beneficial for all ages, especially for our elders who are struggling.

Waste is a HUGE problem. There should be independent 3rd party audits of state agencies and programs. Release these audit findings publicly for accountability and the pressure to act.  We should increase public transparency and accountability. Use an open data dashboard to show where our tax dollars go. Allow citizens to track state spending in real time. We should engage our citizens in participatory budgeting in certain areas like locally. Let citizens propose and vote on local budget priorities. This builds trust, sheds a light on new ideas and adds a check on wasteful spending.

Day to day, I keep meeting on point and not have meeting if they aren't needed. I try to listen to my team and address issues immediately. Always include relevant staff in meetings and emails, even if they may be from other departments, because the silo effect helps no one. On a larger scale, I have been working as part of a workgroup to improve Health Equity within my organization. Assisted with development and training for the Peer Support Specialist Program for the incarcerated population. This program has already improved the lives of many, and I believe will help make prisons safer and lower recidivism rates in the long run.

Adequate fund the State's review of environmental permits, or work to streamline permitting. The State holds up critical work on wildfire mitigation, housing, and other projects due to permitting.   For example, utility vegetation management should not be considered development under the Coastal Act. It is maintenance of existing facilities/development and wildfire mitigation that should be subject to review by the under-resourced Coastal Commission.
One of the best things about California is our ability to integrate government and community involvement in a productive way. I enjoy being able to contribute to this process.

The recruitment process is very cumbersome. The "exams" are quite lengthy and sometimes don't fit with the achieved purpose of the job. Applicants learn how to "cheat" the exam process just to get through. That's why there's not a lot of quality. SOQ process should be revised as these could be cumbersome-- 1 question max. Also onboarding is not really onboarding. An employee doesn't learn much about their job because their unit is so short staffed, its usually baptism by fire and they're so thankful just to have somebody show up, they're just thrown into their role without the proper training period. State service should be step above and employees should be compensated to attract quality so that employees want to stay and reduce turnover in order to serve the people of CA. I would love to see value reinstated in state service.

I would address the wasteful spending during procurement of goods services and contracts. It's so difficult to procure goods and services that the department doesn't factor in the cost of staff time to adhere to antiquated policies to make purchases utilizing SB/DVBE and low bid companies and contractors. Many times the low bid is the low bid for a reason and we get a subpar service and often times has to be redone or fixed in a short period. If a more qualified, higher cost contractor was awarded we would save money in the long run. This makes it difficult to be good stewards of the state dollar.

I would really like to encourage the state to look into facilitating a more remote or hybrid work force. I live in Los Angeles and would have never been able to join the state service if my position wasn't remote. I enjoy what I do, and I believe I bring a unique perspective to my team who primarily live in Sacramento. But something I notice whenever I visit my team in Sacramento is ignorance to issues that other offices in my department have. Issues related to California's extremely diverse geography, climate, and communities. California is a huge state and has a wide range of day-to-day problems and issues depending on where you live that require state resources to solve. Having a more agile and geographically distributed workforce would help with that.

It is really expensive to live in California. Half of my take home pay goes to rent. The other half is fully taken by bills and food. Creating space for staff to work from home is really important to reduce gas, travel, etc...

Agreed! As a supervisor, I am always asking for feedback from my staff and I encourage them to tell me areas I can improve. But I don't see my peers doing the same thing and I have noticed that there is much lower job satisfaction and staff retention in their units. I would love to have 360 reviews standardized, so that everyone is required to be introspective about their management style.

One of the most inefficient things my department sees is the push to transition to electric vehicles.  We have staff all throughout the state, and charging stations (at least stations that work) are not always available to our staff. Also, it takes staff several hours to charge electric vehicles. The Ford Lightning electric truck can take up to 14 hours to charge, so while it's charging we're either down a vehicle and that workload or we have to force other staff in a gas truck to double-up on their route and we need to pay them overtime. The First Purchasing Mandate says that we can request an exemption from an EV from DGS once we meet our 50% mandate, but DGS says they're being pushed to put more state EVs on the road because of the Governor's executive order so they deny the exemption requests.  What are departments supposed to do?  Pay their staff overtime to do the work a person in an EV can't?  Pay for a hotel and meals when field staff are stranded because they can't charge their vehicle?  Rent short-term rentals to try and offset the downtime with EVs?  None of this is efficient, and it costs double.  Also, has anyone done an analysis on the cost of an EV vs the cost of a gas vehicle?  Usually about 2-3 times as expensive for an EV when departments are also facing budget reductions. This seems like such a waste of taxpayer money, to make government more inefficient and more expensive so citizens pay more and get less.  Can DGS be more helpful on exemption requests?
Expansion of public transportation to state government satellite offices, such as those in Elk Grove, may reduce the traffic and congestion.

Any grants that are released from the state should require fiscal reports but just as important, progress reports.  We should not be handing out state dollars without specifically knowing how and what those dollars are used for.  This is inconsistent.  Some grants have it in statute that an independent evaluation is done and others do not, it makes no sense.  Require state departments to develop specific ways they are measuring the cost/benefit analysis of distributing funds

We have separation of church and state for a reason. We do not need religion in school, work, or politics. This is especially inappropriate if you think Christianity is the only "right" religion. Please research the First Amendment.

I suggest that DGS look into Enterprise contracts for the state so that smaller board, dept, commissions can use those contracts. You get a better bargain as a giant contract and small organizations that can't afford contracts on their own can tag in to make their work for efficient. For example, one news clip service, one social and media monitoring service, an outreach eBlast function, one that checks writing so that our communications are professional, etc. I think that would save the state money and improve work functions for employees.
The new CAMS system is outstanding!

You bring up a great point. Excess bureaucracy can really slow down progress and drain resources. I completely agree that it's our responsibility to identify and eliminate unnecessary steps. Your example about the 18-page document for an ice maker repair is a perfect illustration of how overregulation can hinder efficiency. Streamlining forms and simplifying processes, especially for routine tasks, would not only save time but also boost morale and productivity. Leaning into continuous improvement and cutting red tape is the kind of change that makes a real difference!

DGS makes it unreasonably difficult for departments with owned vehicles to replace those that constantly break down because of excessive mileage or such an extensive repair history that it costs more to keep them on the road than to just replace them.  I understand the need for DGS to review and scrutinize additional fleet assets, but why are replacement vehicles so difficult to obtain?  It takes DGS 3-4 months just to approve the purchase (and DGS recently said departments will need to submit their Fleet Acquisition Plans 60 days sooner than in the past), and then once a vehicle is identified departments find out DGS has updated the state contract and the replacement vehicle is no longer even available.  From the time a department submits a Fleet Acquisition Plan (April 1), DGS approves by June 30, and then it often takes at least until December or January for the vehicle to arrive.  So if a vehicle is broken down, a department knows it's going to take at least 9 months to get that vehicle replaced and they need to rent a vehicle in the meantime.  DGS only allows short-term rentals for up to 30 days, anything longer tmust also be submitted to DGS for approval. The long-term rental process for DGS, even in these instances, results in tons of justification and back-and-forth between DGS and departments and in the meantime work cannot be completed or staff with a vehicle must do double the work to make up for the vehicle shortfall. Can DGS streamline the replacement process?

Too much and sudden involvement of AI/Gen-AI in state; and this is taking away our old school lifestyle. Nothing seems real or genuine.  Soln: put a pose on too many incoming AI/Gen-AI requests. These requests are overcrowding our tradition workspace and workload.

As a resident, I would love to see the train system more useable. If I need to travel somewhere in the state I occasionally check the train versus plane option and planes pretty much always make more sense in terms of cost and time. I know the bullet train project is expensive and long, but I think it would improve the ability to travel between NorCal and SoCal in a big way for California residents.

Problem: Hiring excellent employees is a struggle and failing folks on probation is not common enough. let's reduce the waste in our largest spending bucket statewide - people and work to maximize the ROI on that expense by ensuring quality staff is hired.   Solution: No more SOQs or interviews. Instead, we have customer experience workshops where sprints are designed to challenge and assess potential candidates. They will be scored on their creativity, problem-solving skills, curiosity, collaboration, accountability, leadership, etc. Those scoring a minimum score or above are offered positions where they may be best suited within the department. Structured rubrics with behavioral anchors and blind scoring could be used to reduce bias. Basically, show me the value you will bring to our teams. Innovative sprint outcomes may be adopted at the department and accredited to the new candidate as part of their company onboarding and give them a solid start in their careers.
We talk about the environment, but our policies are not helpful. For instance, we incentivize electric vehicles instead of public transportation when our roads are already crumbling.

Yes! Its like they know they will be able to have a 1-on-1 with the higher ups that will be confidential. Even though we all know they are manipulative, I think everyone, higher ups and all staff actually, are constantly trying to undermine each other and I have noticed that it happens even more when inmates are involved in the conversation. Like it makes you feel like a hero or something? I dont understand either... Definitely a huge problem though and it is part of why the turnover is so high and then subsequently staff are getting hurt more often as there is more inmates than correctional staff, and its just a domino effect of safety and security problems. Yet complaints about this put you on the radar so everybody just does their best to avoid being in that spotlight. I definitely agree there is a lack of trust from exec staff to their ground level staff and they demonstrate more trust in inmates. It makes lower level staff feel undervalued when we carry alot of the tasks nobody else will do but are necessary for the institution and carry a lot of legal weight.

Some of the processes have not been modernized.  Everything seems so archaic.  Like even just the process of applying for a job is so complicated and not intuitive.  Our office has no clear onboarding process or training manual.  A lot of things are just word of mouth and vary greatly.  How each regional office does things is totally different.  We don't come together  as a team very often.

An extremely complex and expensive current problem is the over, unnecessary, and excessive use of the workers compensation system by state employees. Significant funding should be allocated to provide for streamlining the process, investigating fraud, and limiting benefits for questionable and unfounded complaints.

No idea how to answer this. I have tried 5 times now. Let's start with one initiative that affects us all, and FIX IT. Water? Immigration? Cost of housing? Rising Energy Prices? The list goes on. Whatever it is, even though we live in a Republic....multiple elections and voting by the people would be nice...as well as within the areas that are affected most. Such as water...does Northern California near Shasta really have a water issue...NO, so then maybe the Northern Californians do not make decisions based on where the water comes from, because they have a plethora...and etc... Such as Homelessness...what is the impact per census on the area...the area with the greatest impact has the larger say so?

As a manager with many years of experience, the first problem I would address is hiring. People are our biggest asset. The process has improved over the years with online exams but there is still a long way to go. It's difficult to understand how to get a job with the state. Many people apply for positions that they are not eligible for. This takes HR and the hiring managers time to weed through applications.   Fortunately, my department now has a recruitment team to help with the process. Maybe each department should have one or share one.

I have appreciated less traffic on the road since teleworking was implemented. Before that happened, I think having flexible work schedules was also beneficial to traffic and smog. Full disclosure...I am retiring soon so I don't have an ulterior motive to push teleworking. From my perspective as a manager of a small unit, both my staff and I are happier and more productive teleworking. I have not had any HR issues related to that. If you are a good employee, you will be a good employee whether working at home or at the office and vice versa.

As an EEO employee, I find this very troubling, but not surprising. Sadly we live in a time in which many people feel comfortable openly discriminating and harassing people. There needs to more training in these areas and when allegations of discrimination or harassment are substantiated, they should be dealt with quickly and seriously. There should be zero tolerance of bigotry at all levels of state government.

Our government websites are not built to meet the needs of the people. They are built so a hierarchy of executives in government are satisfied that *their* needs are met. This usually results in sites that are unreadable, topics the public doesn't care about, and services that are hard to navigate.  Sites and services should be held to the state's Plain Language Equity Standard, meaning grade 8 reading level or below. They should be built with a human-centered design process. And they should be continually tested with real users and improved.   The measure of success should be, "Are the people we serve happy with this?" We should frequently check user feedback, Google analytics, and participation rates to know if our delivery of the service is working or not. And if it's not, we should fix it.

I would love to see more free micro video on demand trainings, similar to linked in learning, available. A quick 5-10 minute video can be great to break up a day and learn about new topics or refresh on current procedures.

It might sound counterintuitive, but shortening the work week has been shown in many companies and countries to actually improve productivity. I've noticed at my organization that in groups where there's less strict time management, people are a lot happier and more motivated. California could be a leader in the movement to have a four-day work week!

A primary problem in the hiring of state employees is having to retake exams after expiration to rejoin the eligible list. If someone has already passed an exam previously, they should not need to retake the exam to stay on the eligible list - I think instead they can just be asked to confirm yearly if they would like to stay on the eligible list. I also think the exam should not be required for current state employees looking to promote and who qualify based on their years of experience. For example, someone with 1 year of AGPA should not have to take the SSM1 exam to get on the eligible list. They should automatically be eligible for SSM1.

One of the best ways to strengthen our communities is by investing in the people who serve them. Recruitment and retention have become real challenges across departments. Telework and statewide hiring in the early 2020s helped bring in skilled professionals from every region, but with pay falling behind the private sector, limited advancement opportunities, and new in-office requirements, we’ve lost experienced employees who carried years of institutional knowledge. Replacing them, if we can, is costly and slow, and the impact is felt directly by Californians through slower services and reduced program quality.  A sustainable solution would be a statewide Loan Repayment Assistance Program (LRAP) for state employees. CA already uses LRAP models successfully for legal aid attorneys and physicians serving Medi-Cal patients. Expanding them to all state employees would help recruit and retain talented professionals, keep expertise in-house, and strengthen the delivery of public services, like environmental protection, health care, and consumer rights, that Californians rely on every day.  Student loan debt affects more than 3.8 million Californians. I’ve seen colleagues delay buying homes, starting families, and saving for the future because their loan payments consume such a large portion of their income. Creating a statewide LRAP would not only help employees build stability and remain in public service, but it would strengthen the economic and social fabric of our communities.

Team meetings. We have department meetings, and park meetings monthly. These help us come together as a team and know what we all are doing. This helps us connect us as a team and support each other when we can.

One major issue is the lack of managers who actively manage their staff. This isn’t about micromanagement, it's about setting clear expectations, assigning tasks with due dates, tracking progress and holding staff accountable. Instead, agencies often hire expensive project managers, funded by taxpayer dollars, to direct the work. So what, then, is the role of the actual manager? Too often, it’s limited to signing off on timesheets, completing IDPs, attending conferences, and to often encourage staff to “get the work done when they can”, so 2-weeks later or never.   In my experience, when managers don’t establish timelines or hold staff accountable, tasks take significantly longer to complete. Project managers, on the other hand, drive progress and lead teams to results more efficiently than many state managers. If managers owned their empowerment and held accountable for directing work, we could reduce reliance on costly PM contracts and save public funds.

I think CalHR needs to revise it's policy of calling references before a job offer is made. What if an employee decides they dont want to take the job but you have alerted their employer that they are looking and then they get fired. It puts prospective employees in a really awkward position.
California doesn't have a revenue problem but a spending problem.

We have a lot of redundancies and yet still many inconsistencies from department to department. I often hear from staff who came from other departments how they function, and it is quite different. Some departments seem marred with duplicative red tape that makes it more difficult to function efficiently and creates additional work that takes up seemingly unnecessary employee time that is not the essential duties. Working so inefficiently and different from department to department appears to waste tax dollars.
Less taxes or a tax break would be great.

Lower level staff being used as pawns. Some agencies, not all, have too many executive roles. Also, it would be nice to practice less waste by implementing electronic files/work and not a need for paper files. Implement docusign more if a signature is needed. Update policies where a "wet" signature is not needed and docusign can replace.
State employees should not have to pay income taxes.

Changing the ideas from archaic times to current changes in the environment and equipment. Some older managements are not open to changes or new ideas, so it holds departments back in keeping updated with either new technology or new processes.  To solve the problem is to have continuous discussions on being open minded and reviewing new ideas, however, you would need the individuals to want to acknowledge change or want to make the changes.

I have had the privilege of being a proxy on the ICH (interagency council for homelessness) I also participate in California Connect that the AGs office started, and work in management on a statewide partnership team that works across departments. I hold a lot of knowledge about current admin priorities, performance available at the state and regional level,  and work hard to connect people in different departments that need each other. Once people are educated and know how to access a program, funding, or other resources they are in a better position to serve CA. It's almost like needing a connective agency; something like DGS but about programs, funding, safety net, and resources. A CA concierge dept 😊
Implementing automations, databases, and clear process documents to support efficiency
management can either be a conduit for change or a hindrance to change, but with  training, i believe management can be champions for change.

The State would benefit from better succession planning and diversifying staff roles. There is a lot of "siloing" in the State where one person does only one primary task or project. This means that if this staff person leaves, the majority of the knowledge regarding that task/subject is gone. If we diversified staff roles and allowed staff to branch out and learn new skill sets, then we wouldn't be scrambling every time someone retires or leaves State service.

I appreciate flexibility with working hours. This allows state employees to get things done timely and meet deadlines but also not be constrained by rigid, arbitrary, and/or antiquated workplace business hours norms.

One of the primary issues that I have observed during my 11 years of state service with the Department of Fish and Wildlife is the overall comprehensive need to establish new funding sources for fish and wildlife conservation, management, and research. Funding sources that were utilized decades ago will likely not be enough to fund the department in future decades. Hunting and fishing are still pertinent recreational activities for several sportsmen and women; however, the percentage of the California public that hunts and fish has decreased dramatically since the 1980's. The lack of funds coming from hunting and fishing tags has a direct impact on fish and wildlife conservation and management. At both a regional and statewide level, it would be pertinent for California state government to invest time and research into developing new funding sources for the department to support conservation activities.

The primary problem I have seen is low morale. This has been caused by at least 2 different things: 1) RTO policies and refusing to listen to state employees; 2) poor management and bad leadership that results in inefficient or unfair division of labor. Leadership, starting at the very top, needs to respect and listen to state workers. When policies, like RTO, are implemented without any real consideration of how it will upend the lives of civil servants--that is disrespectful and will always lead to low morale. I have also seen morale be impacted by poor leadership and bad supervisors (i.e. ones that do not listen to their employees and refuse to pivot when needed, or just flat out assign work unfairly). Once morale is low, people will begin doing the "bare minimum."  They will take very little pride in their work. They will not care about outcomes. They will be so stressed and they will lose their focus at work. This is what leads to inefficiency. When you have workers who are able to pay their bills comfortably (because they are receiving a fair wage), when they see management take on the hard tasks (because management is making more money and should be taking on the more challenging projects), when they are allowed to work in places of safety and comfort (such as their own homes where they are mostly shielded from inappropriate conduct such as workplace violence, racist or sexist comments, physical-micro-management, etc.), that is what will improve efficiency for all!!

There is a lack of available technical asynchronous training, including in programs used daily by employees, such as Microsoft programs. Many of us, including legal staff like myself, receive large amounts of data that could be more easily summarized and analyzed with advance knowledge of Excel and Microsoft Office programs. While Excel would greatly streamline my work, including summarizing data quickly, I have yet to receive Excel training because there are no Excel trainings available online, nor have these been available when I’ve checked for over a year.

The primary problem I would address is ensuring that personnel have the proper tools, resources, and support to effectively perform their roles. As a station captain, I’ve completed all the necessary classes for purchasing, but I currently do not have a purchase card, which means I must rely on other captains for essential station needs like paint, upkeep, and crew subsidies, slowing down operations. Additionally, technology issues with systems like the MDT on fire engines frequently require manual resets, which creates more radio traffic and interrupts workflow. To address these challenges, I would focus on providing the proper tools and resources for each position, clarifying roles and responsibilities so staff understand their scope and accountability, and implementing a mentorship program where experienced personnel guide and train newer individuals. These steps would improve efficiency, support staff in their roles, and ensure the station operates effectively to serve the community.

I would like to see CA State Parks add a Veterans Day use pass just like National Parks (open to all veterans - peace time, war time, active duty or reserve/national guard).  The current Veterans pass for CA State Parks you must be: A medal of honor recipient, Prisoner of war survivor or a 100% disabled veteran.  This is a very slim portion of the veteran community and not helpful.  As a Veteran i think the being outdoors helps with our mental and physical health and should be encouraged.

I agree.  I see a lot of executive officers worrying about their own jobs rather than worrying about what is best for their employees and the State as a whole.  They worry about challenging the status quo and refuse to change course and rethink processes when needed.  Middle management just follows whatever higher level management wants without any questions or voicing concerns.  Many supervisors are worried about the wrong things.

Legislators write laws to benefit their constituents (which is great) but without thought to how state agencies will be affected by these laws. Some of these issues have been noted in previous comments such as additional steps to a process that adds no value to the public and in fact delays work that would be of benefit. A possible solution is to get experts that work in the field (not HQ) from different agencies as an advisory committee to the legislature.
We actually separate out our work--one person, one project. I really like that.

More public transit, better public infrastructure, more affordable housing, better paying jobs and basic, humanity affirming benefits for everyone - healthcare, Universal basic income- a more fair tax system where EVERYONE pays their fair share to cover these benefits.

California needs to stop throwing money into it's useless GenAI platform. The data it was trained on is hilariously outdated and a huge waste of money. The use of GenAi makes State workers lazier and its impacts on the environment are vast.

I believe that the state should be taking more advantage of the buying power they have by having more standardization of product in use.  This would also allow departments to "borrow" another department's expertise if they lose a SME for a product.

Would benefit having dedicated funding sources for operational needs.  There are many services that our department provides that is funded with special funding or grants that are unpredictable.  There are also may funding sources that need to be spent on a 1-year cycle or expire.  This results in employees rushing to make unsound funding decisions or risk losing money for their programs.  Would be better to have funding allocations on a 2-3 year cycle.

One challenge in California government is that well-intentioned processes often pile up until they become bottlenecks. Ezra Klein’s Abundance talks about “bottleneck deserts,” and that idea really resonates with me. We spend so much time on checks, reporting, and auditing that sometimes the work of actually serving people drifts further and further away.  One solution I’d like to see is the idea of “bottleneck detectives.” These would be small cross-functional teams—made up of staff who know the programs inside and out—tasked with finding the points where work slows down unnecessarily. Twice a year, they would sit down with their teams, map out processes, and identify steps that don’t add value. If a new check or reporting requirement is added, an old one has to be removed. The detectives would track and report back on what’s been eliminated, making sure accountability is preserved without building endless new layers.  This kind of practice could help restore balance: keep oversight strong, but clear the path so the real work—serving Californians—stays front and center.
I've created manuals for processes to ensure that newly hired staff are all on the same page.

What does the government use to self-assess for accountability and how can that be improved with the goal to reduce fear and de-mystify bureaucracy. I'm ok with bureaucracy, it's part of the democratic process but it doesn't absolve us from accountability.

I believe the Prospective Payment System (PPS) methodology for Federally Qualified Health Centers and Rural Health Clinics should be reformed. I find that there is a lack of education/training/certification options for people to go into governmental careers. To help address the growing knowledge gap in State Departments due to more retirements and new employees lacking the program-specific knowledge of their Department, it would be helpful for the State to develop more government-related pathways at colleges/universities. Developing some self-paced, online certificate programs for government career paths would also be extremely helpful, particularly for those unable to attend/afford college or a university.
Adding new programs can sometimes make everything more complicated. Legislators could instead simplify or modify existing programs, rather than create additional loopholes or tax breaks.

1. Empower Citizens Through Outside-In Design Problem: Government services are designed inside-out, around agency processes rather than citizen needs. This leads to frustration, inefficiency, and loss of trust. Recommendation: Apply an outside-in design approach, mapping services around resident life events. Build direct feedback loops and co-design opportunities with citizens. Publish transparent performance dashboards focused on wait times, ease of use, and satisfaction. Ensure digital equity — designing services for all Californians, not just the tech-savvy. Impact: A government that is more human-centered, responsive, and trusted. 2. Modernize Laws and Require Continuous Improvement Problem: Laws and policies that govern service delivery are rigid, outdated, and typically reformed only after years of failure. Projects often stop evolving once deployed, locking in inefficiency. Recommendation: Require statutory/regulatory review on a recurring cycle to keep policies modern. Build agility clauses into law to allow agencies to update service models without full legislative resets. Mandate that all projects include a continuous improvement plan — with metrics, scheduled updates, and citizen feedback integration. Tie agency funding and leadership performance reviews to progress in modernizing both policies and services. Impact: Government laws, policies, and systems that evolve continuously with technology and citizen expectations — ensuring services stay relevant & effective

I would address the primary problem of departmental technology silos hindering effective digital government service delivery. Currently, departments solve similar problems other departments are solving or have already solved in isolation, resulting in inefficient and redundant workstreams. The digital service delivery is fragmented and inefficient, also contributing to a confusing and frustrating experience for Californians.   To solve this, I would propose the following:  1. Mandate Inter-departmental Collaboration: The state should create a framework that incentivizes and, where necessary, requires departments and agencies to collaborate on key initiatives. This could involve creating a statewide playbook and process that all digital service projects align and follow with a central oversight.   2. Standardize Technology and Data: We need to break down the technical barriers that prevent departments from working together. A statewide mandate should be put in place to standardize technology platforms and data-sharing protocols. For instance, all digital services should use a common API frameworks and be inter-operable. This would allow different agencies to easily share information, integrate services, and build a more seamless, user-friendly experience for the public.  By implementing these changes, we can move from a system of isolated, inefficient solutions to a collaborative, and cohesive government that is truly focused on better serving the people of California.

As a state worker, we have access to guides (for ex, DRE uses elicensing and we have instruction guides to help callers through a non user friendly portal). I have suggested that these guides be shared to the public to help lower elevated calls on the call center. The elicensing guides are supposed to be added to the public website in the next update. I would suggest we add similar instruction guides in regards to assisting filing out apps or guides to online portals to help the public decrease the processing wait times and with the call centers.

I am particularly concerned about the financing of Public Health services and programs in California. Local Health Jurisdictions (LHJs) rely heavily on grant money allocated by the CDC or the State. Most of these grants appear to be formula-based, while some are competitive. Problems: 1. Funding public health by grants is not sustainable due to factors such as the end of grants and new policies. 2. Allocations are based on factors that don't accurately represent the real needs of each LHJ. 3. LHJs are not usually part of the decision-making process on how to allocate funds to address the diverse and unique needs of LHJs. 4. Strict guidelines on usage, limits the ability of LHJs to address the specific needs of their LHJ creatively. 5. Not all LHJs possess the skillset and resources to compete fairly for competitive grants distributed by the CDC or CDPH. Proposed solutions include: 1. Updating allocation methodologies with modern economic models that incorporate factors representing real needs and adjusting for population variations. 2. Making the process participatory, allowing LHJs to contribute to the construction of formulas and the utilization of funds. 3. Building local capacity to secure merit-based grants. 4. Shifting funds from clinical services to Public Health, benefiting both Managed Care Plans (MCPs) and LHJs. I would need more space to elaborate on the details how #4 can be operationalized.

The absence of a flexible telework policy. Extensive empirical research links remote work to significant gains in productivity, higher job satisfaction, and reduced staff turnover. Furthermore, adopting a modern telework policy offers substantial fiscal benefits. It would enable the State to significantly reduce overhead costs by downsizing office space. The resulting savings could be reallocated to core mission priorities—such as our software and training needs—or invested in innovative downtown space utilization projects that better serve the public.

Starting in emergency response, my role has been to support regional field offices by identifying and delivering key information. Through data normalization and optimization, I have learned to build dynamic reports and dashboards to distribute information statewide in real time. Moreover, through the development of web application improvements, we have established reduced redundancy in data collection, and streamlined reporting processes between drinking water suppliers and responsible field offices. This process included training, user demos, and customer service process documentation.

Big Idea: Streamlining Student Internships at State Agencies  Right now, if a college student in California—say, someone attending CSU Fullerton—wants to do an academic internship at a state agency like California State Parks, they face a long and complicated process. Their university has to negotiate a legal agreement (a MOU) with the agency, often involving lawyers on both sides. This process can take months and discourages students and agencies from even trying.  My proposal: The Department of General Services (DGS) should create a blanket MOU that covers academic internships between all California public college systems (Community Colleges, CSU, and UC) and all state agencies. This would eliminate the need for each university and agency to negotiate separate legal agreements every time a student wants to intern.  Agencies would still define the details of each internship—like duties, schedules, and supervision—but the legal framework would already be in place.  This would: - Make it easier for students to gain hands-on experience in public service. - Reduce administrative burden for both colleges and agencies. - Create a clear recruitment pathway for state agencies to identify and develop future talent. - Expose students to careers in public service, helping build a stronger, more diverse pipeline into government work.
Ineffective leadership, antiquated resources, funding issues.

This comment is highly specific to my division. So, I am not sure how relevant this particular issue will be to others. The first thing I would do is get rid of or upgrade the two outdated Call Report forms we utilize and condense it to only one upgraded Call Report form that can be downloaded from NMLS and uploaded to our MTFD database. Before the transition to NMLS ( Nationwide Multistate Licensing System & Registry), the licensee was only required to submit one Call Report form. This form was powered by Microsoft Excel with macros built in.  The form was very glitchy and required the licensee to make multiple submissions at times when the wrong button was selected or the form was saved improperly. Now, the licensee must submit two Call Reports, one in an Excel format and the other using the NMLS format. The NMLS Call Report no longer has the built in error checking or data validation of the original Call Report. So now examiners have to waste time having the licensee correct and resubmit Call Reports for minor housekeeping issues. For example, the Outstanding Transmission Liability should agree on both the Balance Sheet Page and Permissible Investment Page. In the past, the Call Report could not be saved or submitted until the corresponding amounts are in agreement. Further, the NMLS Call Report should be updated to reflect both year to date balances and quarter-to-date balances. The licensee should not have to submit a second Call Report with this information.

Technology is way out of date; it's like being stuck in the 1990s. Like Salesforce, ASANA, or other type of communication database. 3) Approval processes are multi-layer and take WAY too long often causing work to be delayed. Having a way to make approvals easier, quicker, and in one application (as mentioned in #2) might move approval processes along more quickly.

Clarity, specificity, and guidance. I am fairly new to the state. My role isn't the easiest to define and probably can't be trained as such.
