An all in place for gathered information for ALL state employees that covers new employee info, paychecks, benefits, sites I need to log into etc. And an other one stop shared site for specific positions or departments that hold information, important links, documents, frequently used sites, applications, user guides, training videos etc. that are necessary to do your job.
centralizing this work will also bring consistency and more fair hiring practices.

With so many forms needed from any company to purchase products, or repair products we often go to the level of replace over repair simply due to the excess amount of forms required. If a repair of an item is $150, but a new one is $1400, many business will not spend the time required to fill out forms that don't really apply to the repair or problem. So the state ends up buying new and from a business that is charging a premium for simply drop shipping from major retailers only because they are willing to fill out the paperwork.  We should be spending money on quality equipment at a reasonable price. But all the red tape to purchase cost 2x as much for the same item that can be purchased with a credit card. Today's day and age with online shopping and shipping, three bids for items we can look up and know what they should cost is just wasting the retailer or employees time.   Trim the paperwork red tape, and allow online purchases with known items removing the bid process. Hold the person responsible for buying outside of approved items with Credit card.

My perspective as a California resident is that while we have a complex state for water resources, but we are confused about priorities because of the push and pulls of leadership. The degrees of separation from staff to leadership continue to create large gaps in efficiencies and agile communication. Young innovative professionals often are left without a platform to grow and further develop innovative qualities.  Meanwhile, staff are promoted in place to management without the necessary qualities of good leadership resulting in cultural inconsistencies from agency to agency, even from branch to branch. Additionally, little to no recourse for nonviolent conflict resolution works because of these cultural inconsistencies, and as a result, I see regular struggle between staff, middle management, and HR with supporting the state's mission, vision, and values.  Leading by transparency is the way to remain a leader in these new technological age, and I do hope that the changes necessary may still lie ahead.

Having worked for the state for over ten years across two departments and three locations, I have consistently noticed a lack of standardization and collaboration that affects overall efficiency. Even within the same department, different offices often perform the same tasks in completely different ways. This creates confusion, inconsistent training, and inefficiencies. There is also a widespread lack of clear and accessible documentation for processes and procedures. Without it, onboarding is more difficult, and new employees spend unnecessary time trying to figure out how to complete routine tasks.  There is also very little collaboration or sharing of knowledge between departments. When I have reached out for guidance or documentation, I rarely receive a response, and when I do, it is often not useful. It can feel like departments are operating in silos, keeping information to themselves instead of working together. I think focusing on standardizing processes and building a more open, collaborative culture would significantly improve how effectively we function as a state.

Two of the biggest problems I've come across in State Employment in three different departments are closely related. These problems are the the lack of standardized training, and that the allocated number of job positions do not scale based on each office's workload. The number of staff available to give effective training is impacted by the face that the number of staff in each office within the same department, branch, and division is not scaled for the workload within their respective jurisdictions. For example, every office has the same number of AGPAs and PT IIs while 35% of the offices had at least double the workload within their respective jurisdictions than the rest of the offices. Unbalanced workloads between two locations will lead to the loss in retention of staff. This eventually will require training for new staff that replace those employees that leave a busier office. When there isn't standardized training each employee, and office, will come up with processes that may be incorrect. Eventually an audit may be completed and the staff in the office find out after the audit that they were incorrectly trained and things have been processed incorrectly. Some of the shortcuts in processes occur because there is a lack of staff, which ties back to the issue of job positions not scaling based on workload.

Medicaid provides health insurance to low-income populations in the U.S. Because private health insurance premiums have become so expensive, many people on Medicaid would be uninsured if not covered by Medicaid, while others could pay for private insurance only by cutting back on other necessities that indirectly affect health. Extensive research has shown that cutting Medicaid coverage leads to worse health and increased risk of premature mortality. As a possible solution, the State of California could implement corresponding state-level tax increases to partially backfill federal safety net cuts. Since some of these cuts won’t take effect for a couple of years, there is the possibility that the control of the House and Senate could change in 2026, and then legislation could be passed to undue some of the federal cuts to Medicaid. Time will tell whether these cuts will have the devastating impact they are intended to have on people’s health.
I think reducing wet signature requirements, allowing electronic submission of documents (looking at you EDD), and having a statewide intranet would be helpful in streamlining work.

As a newer state employee with prior experience in the private sector, I have noticed a significant gap in leadership style and workplace culture. Too often, leadership at the state seems to operate from a place of fear rather than support. Leaders seem to focus on blame, micromanagement, and unclear expectations rather than encouragement, collaboration, and clear communication. It feels as though i'm working in my parent's and grandparent's generation. This has created an environment where employees feel disempowered, disconnected, and hesitant to share ideas or challenge the status quo.   To build a more effective and modern workforce, I think California should invest heavily in leadership development and hold leaders accountable for fostering a supportive, transparent, and progressive culture. Leaders should be given the tools to lead the same virtually as they do in-person. Leaders need to be trained to authentically care about their team members, communicate virtually or in-person with kindness and respect, and engage with employees in a way that feels human and positive, rather than robotic and forced. With new generations entering the workforce, leadership needs to adapt to meet evolving workplace expectations. Shifting from a punitive to a supportive leadership model would empower employees to engage fully, collaborate openly, and drive meaningful innovation across state government.

PLAIN LANGUAGE INITIATIVE:  The Plain Language Initiative aims to make California government communications clear, accessible, and equitable. Too often, state forms, letters, and websites are filled with jargon and legalese that create confusion and barriers. By adopting plain-language standards, we can help Californians understand information the first time, reduce duplicate inquiries, and build stronger trust in government.  In the first nine months, the initiative would apply to high-volume documents such as forms, notices, FAQs, and websites, piloted in key agencies like DMV, HR, and EDD. Deliverables include a Plain Language Style Guide, staff training modules, rewritten sample documents, and a feedback dashboard to track resident experience.  Key objectives are to improve readability to an 8th-grade level or below, train 500+ employees, reduce duplicate public inquiries by 10–15%, and boost satisfaction scores by 15% within a year. With a modest budget of about $250K and existing staff expertise, this project is small enough to implement quickly but large enough to show measurable impact.  This initiative directly supports Governor Newsom’s priorities to modernize government, increase equity, and improve service delivery—demonstrating that clearer communication leads to better outcomes for Californians.

CalEPA's Boards, Departments, and Offices (BDOs) routinely require regulatory data to be uploaded to public databases annually, or within days of certain events (e.g., a rain event). For example, the State Water Board operates the SMARTS database wherein industrial permittees upload data throughout the year to demonstrate compliance with the General Industrial Storm Water Permit. Other BDOs operate similar types of databases.   The state should strongly consider a system to compare the applicable numeric values in the self-reports against the regulatory thresholds. Automatic notices could be issued to the permittee or a report could be generated and provided to the enforcement unit of each BDO. This would improve compliance and accountability, while also benefitting human health and the environment. The opportunity for facilities to "hide and wait" for enforcement would be diminished.

Chatbots can be incredibly useful tools for streamlining communication and handling routine inquiries efficiently.  Here are a few ways a chatbot could assist state department:  Handling Routine Inquiries: A chatbot can answer frequently asked questions, provide information about licensing processes, and guide users through common procedures. This can free up staff to focus on more complex tasks.  Collecting Feedback: Implementing a chatbot to gather feedback from stakeholders can help identify areas for improvement. The chatbot can ask specific questions and compile responses for analysis.  Scheduling and Reminders: A chatbot can help schedule appointments, send reminders, and provide updates on application statuses. This can improve communication and reduce missed appointments or deadlines.  Providing Resources: The chatbot can direct users to relevant resources, forms, and documents, making it easier for them to find what they need without having to navigate through multiple web pages.  Data Collection and Analysis: Chatbots can collect data on user interactions and common issues, providing valuable insights that can be used to improve processes and services.

1. Use datamining to find broken or inefficient processes that need to be improved. 2. Rewrite process manuals with input from those that actually perform the job. 4. Provide basic process improvement training to employees no matter their position. 5. Process improvement requires employee time and engagement, so create a workplace where it is understood that time spent on improvement is the same as time spent processing. 6. Review regulations and policies for inefficient process to ensure that what is being required is absolutely necessary. 7. Allow for the fact that some processes are irreversibly broken and need to be rebuilt from the bottom up.

As a Californian, I believe one of the best ideas is to fully embrace telework as a long-term strategy. Fewer commuters on the road mean less traffic, cleaner air, and reduced greenhouse gas emissions, which directly supports California’s climate goals. From my experience as a state employee, productivity improves when staff are trusted to work from home, and residents receive faster, more focused service. Expanding telework is not just an employee benefit, it is a cost-effective, environmentally responsible way to improve how the state serves its people.

Reimagining Recruitment for Analyst Roles  The current recruitment process for analyst positions across state agencies is inefficient and outdated. Most new applicants just want to work for the State—they’re not necessarily tied to a specific department. Yet, they’re forced to apply separately to dozens of similar positions across different agencies, which wastes time and creates unnecessary competition between departments for the same talent.  Here’s a better approach: consolidate analyst hiring into a general pool. The State could recruit analyst generalists centrally, then place them at agencies based on need, fit, and interest. This would streamline hiring, reduce duplication, and help agencies fill roles faster with qualified candidates.  It’s time to rethink recruitment as a statewide strategy, not a department-by-department scramble.

Strategic investment planning for state buildings. Following the same standards we make private sector landlords follow. Currently state buildings are given an allotment that is the same year after year. The allotment is not calculated by taking any factors into consideration like inflation, rising interest rates, cost of living increases.  The process has slowly driven state buildings into the ground. Old carpet, failing and obsolete building systems all adding up to energy waste and pollution.   If you owned a home and rented it to the same tenant for 25 years and put 2% of the rent back into the property in that time, what would it look like? Not good is the answer.  Currently DGS only puts back 2% into state buildings! That number needs to be 10% annually or more on older assets.  Convicted slum lords in California hover around 5% reinvestment and are put into Receivership Court by their banks. We can do better! Currently DGS takes 98% of the rental income and spends it on unrelated programs.  The buildings should get the funding they need before the landlord takes the revenue to spend on other things. The income from a building should first cover its expenses before a landlord takes profits. The practice of a property manager spending the rental income of an asset on other things is called Comingling of Funds. it is illegal and the cause of run-down slums. The plan DGS has been to run them down and then renovate at 200 times the cost of doing regular maintenance ovr time

CDCR Fire needs a complete reorganization. Currently, multiple fire stations operate independently, answering to Plant Operations or Wardens. Each station procures its own PPE, hoses, tools, and follows local policies—resulting in a fragmented system with no standardization or unified effectiveness.  While CDCR Fire Stations at correctional institutions primarily serve an educational mission, that role should not diminish their potential to be a valuable resource for the State of California during emergencies  With proper structure, CDCR Fire could become a valuable asset in California’s wildfire, flood and disaster response efforts. Instead, its lack of coordination makes it a liability.  A centralized command starting in Sacramento is essential. Appointing a Fire Chief and Deputy Chief, supported by three Division Chiefs (North, Central, South), would create statewide oversight. Each fire station would have a Battalion Chief supervising Fire Captains, ensuring consistency and accountability.  This structure would allow Division Chiefs to standardize regional operations and report directly to Sacramento. It would also enable smarter use of state funds, prioritizing purchases based on verified needs. Battalion Chiefs would conduct assessments, Division Chiefs would review them, and Sacramento leadership would allocate resources accordingly.  If modeled after CAL FIRE, CDCR Fire could evolve into a highly effective emergency response force—ready, reliable, and unified.

I work in a department that trains new staff to do their role within our agency and we have been working to improve onboarding processes within the agency for all staff. When I was first hired the agency in work for only focused on onboarding for one group of staff and not the staff that support our agency mission, today it is better with more training focusing on onboarding and training for all classifications within the agency.   Looking at current practices for onboarding and training is the first step to improving how an agency moves forward to training and retain employees. Training departments also need to understand the importance of surveys/evaluations in their training to get real feedback on how they are doing with their training. However, surveys are no good if a department/agency does not have someone to look at the data and bring forth the results of the survey.   The second step is to have good documentation of current and past processes used within the agency or department.  I have found the lack of documentation waste time and does not allow improvement to easily happen. Understand that people leave and how they do there job is important for the next person who will continue that role within the department. If the role is new to the department, have a clear plan of what is expected for the new person and the resources available to them.   The third step is to have someone assigned to new staff as a mentor. Make sure the mentor understands their role.

As a state employee, one of the most rewarding projects I worked on involved streamlining the Caljobs benefits application process. The original system was cumbersome, with applicants often getting stuck in multi-page forms and unclear instructions. I collaborated with a cross-functional team to redesign the digital interface, reducing the number of steps and integrating real-time error checks. This not only improved the speed of processing but also significantly reduced the number of incomplete applications, helping Californians get the support they needed faster.  Another initiative I want focused on is improving customer service through technology. Recognizing the strain on call centers, I helped implement an AI-powered virtual assistant that could handle frequently asked questions, guide users through common tasks, and escalate complex issues to live agents with full context. This reduced call volume and wait times, allowing staff to focus on urgent cases while citizens received quicker, more accurate support.  I also would like a spearheaded a pilot program to digitize paper-based workflows for applications. By introducing secure e-tools (ChatGpt for customers) and cloud-based document sharing, we cut processing time from weeks to days. This was especially beneficial for small business owners who needed permits quickly to launch or expand their operations.   Finally, I think there are so many resources out there and we are just not using them, most of them are free!

Overlapping and sometimes duplicative permitting processes across different departments create frustration with the permitted community. Specifically, the California Department of Fish and Wildlife regulates substantial alterations to or diversions from streams. Similarly, the Regional Water Quality Control Boards regulate fill discharge to Waters of the State. The State Water Resources Control Board regulates water diversions. Sometimes all three departments are involved in permitting a single project, sometimes it is only two of three, or only one. But in the case where all three departments are involved, there are three completely separate and independent processes for submitting the project description and receiving state authorization (not even mentioning the local permitting requirements that are also typically involved). Combined permits may not be possible, but having a single hub for applying for state permits could be a start. Alternately, creating better mechanisms to collaborate across departments (maybe shared office spaces and shared virtual teams) would be extremely useful. Sharing resources across departments in general feels like a win for the state and the various departments doing similar work.

Problem: Managers are overextended and lack the capacity to coach and guide their teams effectively.  Why this happens:  -High performers are often promoted to management based on individual success, not leadership ability.  -Many managers have never received ongoing coaching (distinct from one-time training), so they may be unaware of their gaps or the impact on their teams.  -People don’t know what they don’t know, so they’re unlikely to seek out coaching on their own.  Solution: Provide ongoing coaching for managers, including peer-to-peer formats. This isn’t about formal training programs, but rather open, topic-driven dialogue. For example, live forums could focus on a key topic, with breakout groups (2–4 people) every 10–15 minutes to discuss real-world scenarios and share solutions. CalSTRS does something similar once per quarter for their managers, so that might be a template to start from in other agencies. It's not required, but I think that's a misstep.  Why it matters: When managers receive consistent coaching, they’re better equipped to guide their teams, set clear expectations, and connect individual work to broader goals, ultimately improving team morale and efficiency over time.

I would like to address the issue of recidivism at CDCR.  I have introduced an anti-recidivism initiative to CDCR, called 'Trade Ready' where we train the incarcerated people to be Tradesmen through on the job training maintaining the facility at Plant Operations. They are not only taught a trade, but more importantly how to be tradesmen, how to work with other Tradesmen to get the job done, under stressful time sensitive conditions. They learn the skills to be successful workers out on the streets. This is achieved by modifying the way, we utilize and train the Incarcerated. We want to release Tradesmen, not criminals into society. And all this is done at no additional cost to the State.

Most, if not all of California's prisons were built in an era before the current focus on robust medical, mental health, and rehabilitative services. Accordingly, few of these facilities have the physical space to accommodate these missions. One solution that has yet to be considered is repurposing incarcerated person housing units into spaces that could support the programming needs of the modern correctional mission. Given the continued reduction in the prison population, there's an opportunity to convert one housing unit on each prison yard into a space that meets these needs without massive financial outlay for new buildings. There would be an expense in performing the retrofit, but this is a far cheaper alternative to constructing new facilities.

As a newer state employee, one of the biggest problems I’ve noticed is the lack of proper training and clear guidance for staff, especially when it comes to understanding their roles, responsibilities, and how to grow within their careers. A lot of employees are expected to learn on the fly, but they don’t always know who to go to for help or even what other units or departments are responsible for. This creates confusion, delays, and sometimes discouragement, especially for new hires.  If I could address one thing, it would be to improve communication and access to information. I’d love to see a more organized, user-friendly internal directory or onboarding resource hub that clearly outlines what each division does, who to contact, and what training or career development opportunities are available for your classification. I think mentorship programs or cross-division shadowing could also be super helpful to give employees real insight into how other parts of state government work.  At the end of the day, I believe that better training and communication leads to more confident employees, better service to the public, and stronger teams overall.

I have brought my private sector experience to the agency and helped develop organizational policies and procedures on how to efficiently track and update workflows outside of full project management and provide a pathway for all employees on the team to participate. It hasn't totally worked because leadership did not recognize the value to the team, and I will continue to try.   Always encourage bi-lateral communication styles that allow for the free flow of information even when being told 'that's not how it's done' - this comment indicates a barrier to a growth mindset that limits change and does not provide the appropriate guardrails for a responsive government. How we work internally reflects on how we are perceived externally, and it matters! Building trust where possible should be a priority always. What works well is when an agency has a clear and guiding mission statement and sticks to it - not through self-promoting sounds bites and LinkedIn posts but also with internal communications with the teams to help breakdown real and perceived silos -

yes! Let's save money, time, and help California stay an innovative leader by allowing State workers to work from home. Not just two days a week, but at lease 4 days at home. Any plans to return to office more than two days per week is an economic drain on the state and a  demoralizing prospect for hard-working, family-oriented civil servants. I propose a permanent two days in office policy be put in place (although one or zero days would be even better).

The State's haphazard approach to RTO which includes dismissing telework is certainly a primary concern with my colleagues. The State's attempt this year to needlessly change to 80% RTO ended up with a huge amount of waste. Departments were moved around for ultimately no reason, and without proper research done. When an actual thorough study did come back, it was after things had already been postponed, and the study showed that telework saves taxpayers millions, and falls in line with California's goal of reducing carbon emissions to combat climate change. How many thousands of hours of State Employee time, and consequently, millions in taxpayer dollars, were wasted by this rushed and mis-informed decision? How many thousands of Employees lives (daycare, commute, carpool, home office investments, etc.,) were financially & physically disrupted, changed, and then changed back? All this because the State did not do proper research or go through proper channels. I certainly hope we've learned some valuable lessons and approach this issue differently next year. If not, there will be an exodus of talent, because a primary reason people come to state service is the benefits, and telework is a big one.

Caltrans Struggles to hire on new surveyors, especially ones with the specialized experience needed to do things to the Caltrans standard. This problem could be solved in two ways;  1. Short term, allowing people to telework from distances normally not practical to commute from will allow recruitment for office positions that are both hard to fill and do not require an in person role. This also incentivizes private sector surveyors looking to earn their License to join Caltrans for the hard to get office hours.   2. Long term, emphasizing recruitment in high schools and colleges through our JET and TET program will let us get people that would normally go into the private sector apprenticeships and expand the number of people considering surveys at all.

Allowing 2.5 or 3 days of teleworking would be helpful for employees with quadriplegia and other physical disabilities. Bringing awareness around using a quieter location in an office to utilize dictation software when typing would be great as well.

Government workers provide unique and often essential services to residents in California. We need to think of those who receive our services as customers, not hostages. If we are customer-focused in our processes, we will find ways to serve them better, faster, and with less resources.

I agree with other comments about training could be better and that some of our platforms and programs are outdated. I also agree with "too many cooks in the kitchen" even for small tasks it seems to have to go through multiple levels of management, which seems like it uses too many resources and takes too much time.

The most challenging meetings and problems I have been in are those that are trying to solve the problems of the 5th or 6th standard deviation from the norm. By doing so, we create so many exceptions and (my favorite word) nuances that a simple policy to would clearly affect 98% of the state is now confusing for 99% of the state for the sake of the 1% who we tried to carve an exception for. We are a large and diverse state. One size does not fit all. However, nuanced policies are extremely difficult to put on paper, create black and white rules, and thus subject to abuse. We must accept that there will be some who will be left out by policies we write, but also appreciate that a well drafted policy will help far more than will be left out. A poorly drafted policy, while perhaps well intentioned, often creates more waste and confusion than solutions.

I would like to address the issue of homelessness as regards housing resources. Right now, we have various service providers doing various things, and each organization has their own way of going about things. We need a standardized system of working that makes sense across the board and is uniform. The Access Centers seem to me on the whole to not be as efficient and helpful to our clients as I would hope. As a result, I have had to approach 1 or 2 organizations that I know to be reliable. This should not be the case. Each organization should be able to provide us with the resources needed to assist our clients in a way that is clear, functional, and pragmatic. We need to fix this system. It is broken, and people in need are not being helped in the ways they need. We need transparency about housing availability at each organization and at the various housing sites that they have. So much money has poured down into a problem that is not getting fixed. It is excruciating to be working with those who desperately need help but can't get it.
Upgrading to the latest version of operating systems is so vitally important.

Another problem I would like to address is the lack of knowledge sharing between technology teams. There is a bill AB869 in the Senate right now that looks to make each state agency implement a Zero Trust Architecture by 2030. I think this is a worthwhile endeavor and as part of this mandate funding should be made to have technology teams be trained in Infrastructure as Code and DevSecOps. Once technologists within the state are trained in these tools technology teams will not only have a more reliable and secure environment but also the ability to share how they built those systems via Git. Technology teams in different departments can fork/download the code that was used to build other department's systems and use it themselves, make/commit improvements, iterate to create other systems, etc. This can foster a more collaborative environment for IT professionals within the state service.

I work in state law enforcement and I work with many other state law enforcement agencies. The state of CA operates well over a dozen LE agencies and from my experience it greatly inefficient and the communication and partnerships with these agencies lack. Looking at other states, they have one single state law enforcement agency with multiple bureaus and I think this is a better model. Less chiefs, less administrative staff, less police officers, better communication and teamwork and producing better outcomes. I know this is the better way because currently we have over a dozen  agencies who don't communicate well and especially don't even have the ability to communicate their locations or talk over the radio, so it' similar to walking through a house in the dark playing 'Marco Polo'. Look at Texas, Tennesee, Colorado, and Arizona. They have a department called "The Department of Public Safety". Highway Patrol, State Detectives, Rangers, Wardens, etc. are all subdivisions of one agency and they communication and collaborate well to better serve there citizen's well-being and tax burden. I am citizen, tax payer, and public servant. Everyday I come to serve the people. I would like to give the people the best service and I know it can be done better this way at a better price.
The purchasing process costs the state tons of money.  We should be able to purchase from the cheapest vendor instead of paying double or triple the cost.

I would like to see my department utilize more up to date ways to share information. My department still has to produce binders with documentation for auditors who have access to our data and they have a SharePoint upload documentation. It would save hours of staff's time and save on supplies and environment. There are times we make 13 4" binders filled with documentation that they have already and can view before coming for the audit.

Each agency has a Mission, Vision, and Goals.  It makes us strive for a purpose.  However, some of these goals need to be cross referenced.  A goal for one agency maybe in direct conflict with another agencies goal.  There are countless examples of this.  Especially when it comes to Environmental.  We (the taxpayers) want a healthy environment, but at what cost?  We (the State Employee) want to do the best we can.  However, typically, low level employees are creating processes that increase regulations, aren't customer friendly, and drive-up cost for everyone.  They are not looking at the consequences of their decisions.  In State government, "everyone has a boss".  Just because we have Directors and other leadership with a goal, doesn't mean they have the authority to dictate regulations.  Many of them make decisions on experience and "the way it's always been done", and that's wrong.  They need to check the big picture.  Sometimes decision makers require unnecessary actions and these cause issues for others.  A great example are Governing boards, such as ARB.  They have good intentions of cleaner air for CA, but at what cost?  Should CA pay $10/gal when the rest of the world is creating global warming.  We are not the problem.  It seems like CA always has to lead.  It would be fine if the taxpayers voted on those regulations, but not when decisions are made by unelected officials.  They have too much power and are just doing what their boss wants them to do.

For our unit we work with foreign vendors to create trade shows or hire consultants in other countries. Our payment of a physical check has presented many issues and in some instances is not a legal payment (i.e., South Africa). Being able to pay via wire transfers is something the Golden State who prides itself in innovation should be able to offer.

We should be able to digitally automate a lot of these checks and notifications and opensource the code that does it. That way we can have a more streamlined process and the public can view, review, and make recommendations.
Absolutely! And housing costs can keep highly qualified employees from applying to positions in areas where they can not afford to live.

Allowing for flexibility in regard to telework. The implementation of a "one-size fits all" policy is inefficient and a waste of money. Telework has proven to be effective and a cost-saver. If it's not working for some departments, then that should be up to the department to make changes. More effective transportation options should also be available. The transit subsidy was a wonderful win, but it would add 3 hours to my daily commute to take public transit to the office. Additionally, collaboration between sister agencies should be encouraged and a focus of the agencies.

As a California resident, I believe our government should reflect the diversity of our state. Representation matters, especially in leadership. We need more diverse women in leadership roles so they can help shape policies and decisions that reflect the needs and aspirations of all communities, including future generations. In addition, we should embrace more innovative ways of working-leveraging technology, rethinking outdated processes, and encouraging creative problem-solving. Innovation, combined with inclusive leadership, can drive more effective, equitable, and forward-thinking public service.

Living in California has always been expensive, but it's just out of reach for many of us now. There is an extreme separation of upper and lower income families with the upper class families paying less in taxes than those who earn far less. Housing is not even close to being affordable for many of us. We also need more reliable public transportation. We also need to take a good look at how we care for our seniors. I have a family member who was recently denied for Cal Fresh even though he only has social security as a steay income and supports himself and 2 family members. They are barely making it yet he couldn't get any help. Perhaps it's time to reevaluate how much income is not keeping up with necessities in California.

Let's create a custom chat bot that resides on several of the most visited CA state websites. Have each state agency, department, council, etc. provide their mission statement and services provided to this chatbot. The LLM/AI could be trained using existing documents provided by each department.  Encourage the public to use this as a resource to find where they need to go to get the help they need. For example, if a citizen is looking for help acquiring health insurance, they would be directed by the AI to Covered California.

Process improvements in order to streamline internal efforts is always a great approach to making the workplace processes and procedures easier to tackle. It is important to get all impacted users input and feedback before adopting the changes.

Telework also allows us to work in safe environments, i.e. in our homes.  In my home I do not need to worry about witnessing racist things written on walls or on notepads (which I have experienced in my office downtown and reported to HR).  In my own home I also will not likely hear inappropriate sexual comments made to women in my office (also something I have experienced in my office downtown and reported to HR).  Working in my own home I also will not have to worry about cockroaches (something I have also experienced in my office downtown).  Working in my own home I also will not have to worry about workplace violence (something I luckily have never had to experience but many others have).  For those people who are not worried about the above (or do not care), they can go work in the office.  I am much more efficient, and less stressed, on my telework days.  Telework works!!

One of the biggest problems with working for the state is employee morale. I have come to understand that the "state" as an institution does not care about me. The beaurocracy is created to avoid risk, not create a good working environment.  One small example of this is coffee and kitchen supplies. I was told that it is against state policy to purchase coffee, filtered water, or even dish soap for employees. This is a little thing, but it makes such a big difference in showing employees that you care about them. I cannot imagine the public would think that employees can't have these basic office supplies purchased for them, when it is so commonplace in every other office I have worked in -- even non-profit organizations!   It is hard to do your best work for an organization that does not care about you. This affects efficiency because it affects employees' productivity.
Yes... less paperwork is always a win. Crazy how small changes can have such huge impact when multiplied over time.

One of the problems we have in our department is that we dont have the ability to purchase simple items such as counter pens for customers to use or clipboards. Its embarrassing for us to tell customers, we dont have pens for them to use or to bring a pen back to me, because its my only one. It also takes us even longer to explain that we dont have tools for them to use than for us to intake them into our department. Also training is so expedited, once we onboard and employee is to be cross-trained right away so our stats look good, but they don't get thorough training to make them efficient. Its all about looking good and having the rights stats, but stats can be manipulated.

We need to get the budget under control.  How do we go from $100 billion surplus to a deficit.  Spending is out of control.  We have spent $20 billion+ on the homeless problem and the homeless issue is worse.  We need to be smart on how we spend our resources!!

The online training is horrible. Placing an ems unit out of service so an employee can complete their cyber security training is unacceptable. Ambulance with paramedic  can’t run calls because of a training program

State agency procurement is unnecessarily complex, involving too many stakeholders in processes that could be significantly streamlined through modern technology. I propose establishing a state marketplace through Amazon's platform where departments can efficiently order goods and services. Within this centralized portal, vendors could submit competitive bids while ensuring compliance with all applicable state mandates and regulations. This system would benefit vendors by allowing them to register once with Amazon and become eligible to sell to all state agencies, eliminating the current burden of navigating separate registration processes across the multitude of agencies that issue requests for bids on goods and services.

1. Use automation tools to improve and increase the scope of testing. 2. Use checklists to ensure quality control. 3. Validate data and practice data migrations prior to any production change. 4. Document all changes made in any production environment. 5. Use version control to make sure only approved changes are deployed.
Smart spending. Communicating with the boots on the ground about their needs and wants instead of blind fully purchasing.

Let's get rid of the low income housing tax credit. It costs twice as much to build using IRC sec. 42 than it costs using market rate building. The exact same goal could be accomplished by 1. Allowing mom and pop landlords to rent to low income folks using either Sec 8 credits or just reduced rent but getting reduced or no property tax, and 2. Having developers build using market based terms not LIHTC, which adds bells and whistles to the units, like granite countertops.

I would address knowledge transfer. People are so concerned with getting promoted quickly, that they don't take the time to learn the job. Since they can't get promoted in their field, they go into supervision. Then you have people who supervise/manage and review the work, who frankly can't do the work themselves.  Then they promote people who aren't qualified to do the work at that level (because they don't understand the work and what it means to get to the next level), and before you know it, you have everyone at the top of the earning ladder and no one who can adequatley do the work. Promotion is important, but they should be merit based, because you demonstrate a higher level of compentancy. And those at lower levels should accept knowlege transfer from people who have put in the time to learn and quit being focused on being at the highest level without having demonstrated that level of competency.
I mean, or even set up offices to function democratically, empowering staff to generate proposals and vote on how to carry out goals instead of assigning an arbitrary supervisor to babysit everyone.
I am working on a project right now and came across RACI - there are different versions of it, but it is a useful tool.  People perform better when they know what is expected of them.

Honestly, giving my team more ownership has been a total game-changer! By really tuning into what each person brings to the table and creating space for creative problem-solving, I've watched my employees transform from just doing their jobs to being real innovation champions. Sure, not every experiment has been a home run, but we've learned so much along the way. The coolest part? My team is now super confident and actually excited about suggesting improvements. They're not just waiting for instructions - they're proactively thinking about how we can do things better. It's like we've shifted from a traditional top-down approach to this dynamic, collaborative environment where everyone feels empowered to speak up and make a real difference. Some of our pilot programs have been incredibly successful, and the energy in the office has completely changed. People are more engaged, more invested, and genuinely passionate about our collective goals. Who wouldn't want a team like that? By trusting them and giving them room to shine, we've created something pretty special.

1. Less training that doesn't apply to my job. The same online training every year is a waste of time. If certain behaviors are not appropriate, then reprimand the wrong doers. It is mentally draining to have to repeatedly do the online trainings when I wouldn't have been doing it without the training, reprimand the wrong doers. 2. There should be an easy way for employees to submit anonymous commits to their supervisors and managers for change. 3. Make it a priority for the State to pay their bills. There is no reason why businesses should go months and months, maybe even longer, without being paid. We as people can't get away without paying our taxes. 4. How about a large pay cut for those responsible for the budget? If we don't do our job we get reprimanded. But if the budget does work out, we get pay cuts. 5. Make the roads better. Stop making traffic lanes for the rich.

One issue I see in my department is duplicative efforts throughout our headquarters operations. I think we could save a lot of money if we looked at our processes, leaned them out, and really focused on streamlining everything. I see a lot of duplicity happening in areas that could be centralized to work more efficiently.

I would have sold my left kidney for a desk manual (or any guidance document, really) when I started with the state. Thank you for being on top of this, I love the idea of having seniors review different sections each iteration. I'm screenshotting this method to use when I next onboard someone ;)
Agreed!!

Software standards.  One example is ServiceNow. This could be used as an IT ticketing system for all state departments.  However, every department selects their own IT ticketing system and then they all pay differing licensing costs. One software where it makes sense, the state could realize cost savings and also continuity across departments, saving in training and add easier coordination.

Let the frontline / lowest level managers decide whether their staff needs to be in office to do their jobs or whether they perform at the same level or better remotely   Managers should know their staff well enough to know what works for their team. What works for one team is not necessarily what works for another   Stop this one size fits all telework mandates and let the managers at the lowest level decide.   Morale would increase, work productivity and dedication would increase and  staff would be happier, saving money on cost of commuting   Happy and satisfied employees mean productive and dedicated employees
Staff should be designated on site to directly impact the support they were designed to do.

When I first arrived, I focused on observing, listening and truly understanding what was happening in our department. Since then, I've been able to implement positive changes that have strengthened our operations. One of the first steps was addressing the organization. I created a RACI Matrix and lists that easily track all that my team has going on. We now have SOPs for each project and staff update them regularly, which ensures consistency and accountability. I also prioritized cleaning up of outdated files, archiving older versions so the most current documents are always easy to find--nothing is deleted, just properly stored. This has made our system streamlined and accessible. I've also modeled simplicity and clarity. I encourage staff to think not only about making their tasks easier for managers, but also about how our work impacts our internal and external partners. That means avoid unnecessary complexity--do not force people to open multiple attachments or links, we summarize key information and provide references as necessary. Our department now feels like a well-run ship because I consistently listen to concerns, take notes, pay close attention to details and operate with a growth mindset that is always focused on continuous quality improvement. Much of my early work felt like cleaning up messes, but through the foundation, it allowed for more strategic planning. I've helped to create a culture of efficiency and accessibility, and respect for everyone's time.

Address root causes for issues in programs, rather than adding more levels of review to catch errors after the fact. Allow staff and supervisors to be accountable for their work, while having autonomy to do it. Look at mistakes as learning opportunities and understand that no process is mistake proof.
I'm brand new to the state. My interests are in employee rights, benefits, training, and upward mobility.

Supervisors working together as a team is crucial.  There should not be 'gate-keeping' of information and we should lift each other up.  Also, confidentiality should be at the forefront in order to protect our employees.

WE are locked into too many limitations, when a decision needs to be made.  There exist certain rules or preset standards that limit the best product from being achieved. The only way to correct this is to abolish these internal standards or rules, and run this organization as a true business, and not as a state expenditure.  Another problem is the limitation or employees not being able to be held accountable at work, since they are protected by the union, and we all know how to correct that.

Using technology to improve services and remove over head with automation. State Agencies are always behind in technology solutions and have anticuated systems. By emprasing technology and find applications that can be used department wide and in several ways, would make agencies manual processes go away and be eaiser to maintain.

An example of work I have done to help improve processes in my department is streamlining our process for medical coding and billing. Supplying clear and concise instructions on how to code and bill appropriately depending on what is being billed. Continuing to provide modern processes to prepare for our transition from paper records to electronic health records.

If backed up by human operators who can review the results, this feels like a good and appropriate use of AI and machine learning. Instead I'm in a department where we're starting to explore the use of ChatGPT to speed up writing and editing original documents, despite LLMs being notoriously bad at these things. I would love to see effort put into exploration of how to use AI where it has documented benefits and usefulness with low margin of error, instead of charging ahead with the shiny Star Trek fantasy applications that the technology isn't actually ready for yet.

There's a need for geospatial intelligence to support State operations. The Federal government has the NGA, but California has no State counterpart. CDT could adopt the role if their staff was increased. Or, a separate agency could be established to acquire, analyze, and provide geospatial intelligence products to State agencies that need them for their operations. Without such a centralized hub, each State agency is on its own to develop a GIS cadre, contract out to receive overhead (satellite) imagery and/or drones. The decentralization ultimately costs the state more money and provides less support, as those with limited budgets might not even request something they need but cannot afford. Establish a California Geospatial Intelligence entity.

As a California resident and taxpayer, I'd like to see less wasteful practices (i.e., purchases, return to office mandates, new building leases, etc.). We are supposed to advocate for the health of the environment and the well-being of the people of California.

As a Workers’ Compensation representative, I’ve focused on improving recovery processes and negotiations to make our work more effective through careful case review, strong negotiations, and consistent communication with attorneys.  I’ve successfully recovered over $5 million in liens for the state. This not only secured significant reimbursement of public funds but also demonstrated how more efficient processes and proactive case handling can lead to better outcomes for both the department and the public.

I believe there should be a universal intranet site with agency-specific and subject-specific subsites.  The main site could include spaces for disseminating information (e.g. statewide policy), posting training and job opportunities, hosting webinars, sharing news on projects and subjects of statewide interest, and collaborating/idea sharing.  This site is a good start but access to a statewide community should be automatic, not opt-in. I also believe the state would benefit greatly from further standardization of web/software design and a collaborative community of engineers. (e.g. having templates for commonly needed software, like procurement, inventory, appointment scheduling, marketing/newsletter, learning management, certification tracking, mobile apps, etc.) Agencies could then customize templates to fit their unique needs. This could make software more accessible and affordable, encourage development of the state IT workforce, reduce reliance on private sector contracts, and create a more universal user experience, reducing the need for training when someone changes agencies. Lastly, I believe data required/used by multiple agencies should centralized to reduce errors/discrepancies and time spent on data entry. A first step would be auditing existing databases to identify what data is being collected by multiple agencies currently.

We use a combination of Microsoft Power Suite and ESRI ArcGIS to remove paper from as many of our workflows as possible. It's a powerful combination as Power Automate can bridge the two environments and allows for reminders, workflows/signature flows, and more. The issue is that the department seems like it would cut access (licenses) to these to save money when these are huge money savers in terms of people's time (hours paid) and costs saved from printing/office supplies. By using drop-downs/choice fields, data is clean and easy to pull into reports in Power BI or ArcGIS Dashboards, etc...
Consolidating files & manuals

Inventory of assets, which should actually be named office equipment: As state employee I receive multiple "Excel Asset Inventory worksheets" from different individuals/departments requesting information about the office equipment I use in my line of work. I suggest streamlining process by centralizing it, creating a dashboard, and give access to interested parties and or departments that need access the data rather than having staff completing multiple worksheets, which creates the risk of inaccurate data and unnecessary processes. Have one dedicated team in charge of managing the disbursement and disposal of office equipment as well as of the maintenance of the database/dashboard for accuracy and accountability.

State agencies and Departments should focus more on recruiting industry subject matter experts in their respective fields of oversight and regulation.  It is all too common for staff to be disinterested or lack knowledge of industries they regulate.
Agree. Onboarding is not complete and unclear. Often left with questions about what to do when you first start.

I will never understand why we are required to purchase from middlemen, just so we can say we support disabled, veteran, and small businesses. All this does is encourage new small businesses to just resell things. That doesn't seem like its adding any value to either the business owner or the state.

One thing I have noticed after working for CDCR for over 25 years is that they put unqualified people in administrative jobs.  An example would be: instead of hiring someone with a business/accounting background to be in charge of "Business Services", CDCR hires someone that worked their way from up from an officer or secretary to run that department.  This happens in the medical department also.

At my department I was asked to help implement data related tools and work to help cut the time to conduct work and be more efficient. We were able to identify crimes and theft much faster and see many crimes that went previously undetected.

Waste Watchers: I loved Gov. Schwarzenegger had a waste watchers type thing. Although the tiny savings of each one person turning off a budling's lights or illegal use of State vehicles (two stories I remember reported there), those individual savings probably didn't pay for the cost to run the waste department, but I think we need something like that. The State Auditor/Whistly blower, I called once and they said, "we are not Big Brother, we have 5,000 calls a year, you have to provide all the evidence to the State Auditor for us to do anything". But as a regular employee I can't access my bosses' records, I can't photocopy the subject state records, nor bring a camera into the place I had another waste/audit complaint. I think in the long run, the state investigating waste, even if not quote fraud, would pay off in long term efficiencies and cost savings. Maybe like a Mello-Roos Tax, if a waste if found the Waste Watcher department gets a cut of the savings to help fund the cost to investigate. Then the Department won't be cut in the next hard budget.

Personally, I do my best to be a responsive team member, and consider myself a teammate of every team.  One of the best things I have seen, though, is the onboarding process at my current department.  In many years of state service, it is the first time I have seen such a thorough (and enjoyable) onboarding process.  A full week of orientation, including all onboarding training (so you can focus on learning your job when you start, not mandatory training), distribution of equipment, assistance with completing HR forms, and presentations by senior management and others.  When it's all over, you are ready to go!

DGS Procurement rules that are same for different organizations.  It should be different for organizations that are buying papers/pens etc vs organizations that need to buy specialized equipment or instruments.   Procurement rules are not effective and efficient and  hinders other departments from doing their job in a timely manner.
Stop spending so much money on outside consultants, work with actual employees. Set up SME's (Subject Matter Experts) and make them actually accessible to employees.

I am a teacher and the process of attendance takes a long time, involves myself, as well as education officers and housing officers. It seems to me that it would be so much more streamlined if we could somehow use the barcode on each IPs ID. As IPs came through a building or left a building, they would scan their ID and their whereabouts would be uploaded directly to SOMS. This would eliminate the need for so many phone calls and such. Seems like a no brainer to me. Of course, their IDs would probably need to be changed to a bracelet or anklet of some kind so as not to be lost or used by a different IP.
The State lacks in succession planning and lacks in providing an environment / process for effective and efficient succession planning.

Providing excellent customer service to customers. Traveling to Norway twice and adding these items in rehab to the institutions for advancing rehabilitation, restorative justice programs, and progressive positive input.

We need digital (mobile-optimized) data intake. The state has SO MANY forms (applications, recertifications, licenses, grants, etc.). Californians should be able to do most of their interaction with the state on their phone (this will make backend data more accurate, too). Their identity should be known at the state, so programs across agencies should share their respective data on the backend so a Californian doesn’t have to enter the same data every time they interact with a new program.

As a state employee that has laterally transferred to different Departments, I've noticed a dramatic difference in the responsibilities and level of expectations for the AGPA classification. In one department, as a seasoned AGPA I was required to have every email reviewed that was being sent to an external source. Another department that I worked for places their AGPA staff in lead roles, facilitating and leading discussions with internal and external stakeholders and the management sit back and watch. These types of inconsistencies can cause people to struggle when they believe they are taking a lateral position but their level of responsibility dramatically increases in their new role, it affects efficiencies when AGPAs with multiple years of experience cannot effectively lateral into similarly positioned AGPA roles.   I believe there needs to be statewide accountability put in place in order to make the level of responsibility across classifications consistent. This cannot simply be done by reviewing duty statements which are broad and do not often reflect the management culture of the office. There should be statewide reviews of internal procedures for varying classifications to ensure that state workers are paid for the same level of responsibility, effort, and commitment.

As a DTSC PM in the office of brownfields I work closely with staff on my project and their supervisors to ensure that deliverables are reviewed in a timely manner and have elevated issues to higher level staff when they arise or when they are foreseen to get ahead of them.  Communication is the key.
I agree 100%.  Elegance and efficiency have left the building.  Managers don't know why things are done and are constantly steadfastly unwilling to change.

I wonder if this relates to the blind hiring they have been piloting that redacts PII from the app materials? It's definitely hard to send a rejection letter if you don't have authorization for the applicant's email address.

As a state employee, the primary problem I would address is to promote employees that really do the work on the daily basis. unfair promotions in those state departments. Those are doing the real work are left aside.

Recruitment - HR needs to work closely with hiring managers to set their process up for success from the start and reduce time-to-hire. Set a timeline, reserve time for application screening and interviews on calendars when the job is posted, not after it closes. Help hiring managers get to yes! Work with them on qualifications to understand the programmatic point of view instead of starting from no. When HR and program work together, it's better for everyone, including candidates!

As a HQ we are too disconnected from the facilities we are serving. We are unable to help them meet policy guidelines because we can't talk about it, record meetings or disseminate trainings or information without taking a year to discuss it first. We are leaving out colleagues out to dry when we are creating the resources for them, but aren't allowed to give the proper trainings on how to use them.

One of the most pressing challenges I see is the restriction on using AI tools in our daily work. This limitation not only slows down innovation but also prevents us from serving our communities with the efficiency, creativity, and responsiveness they deserve.  AI, when used ethically and intentionally, is not a threat—it’s a partner. It can help us streamline repetitive tasks, generate accessible content, analyze data for equity gaps, and even support inclusive language in public communications. These are not luxuries; they are necessities in a modern public service environment. To solve this, I would propose a pilot program that allows the use of AI tools within a secure, policy-guided framework. We could start with low-risk applications—like summarizing meeting notes, drafting outreach materials, or organizing project timelines—and build trust through transparency and training. My vision is not just to adopt technology, but to steward it wisely. With the right guardrails, AI can become a tool for justice, clarity, and care—reflecting the very heart of public service.

there are things most of us NEED to do, as a California Resident.  the DMV springs to mind... It seems that there need to be so, so many more offices to accommodate the number of Californians obligated to utilize the offices.  it's like the grocery stores.  there are so many, because we all need to shop. young families in a neighborhood? need more schools.  it's the same with DMV offices, but i don't really see that in practice.  it's the same few offices since i was a kid, many years ago.  the population is growing (and so is the line at the DMV!)  i would say it's time to do something about that across the state. please.  ☺

One of the biggest challenges the state faces is people feeling they will be chastised for speaking out and the lack of communication between high level management/executives and the people actually doing the work (not managers overseeing work being done, but the actual people at department and agency level doing the work) along with the vendor community seeking to contract with the state. Politicians pushing their objectives and the people making the rules and regulations have either never done the work or haven't done it in so long they do not understand the impact of the policies and procedures, or whether it will make sense to the end user applying the rule. Which also impacts having qualified training (or lack thereof). State training is normally developed and administered by people who are far removed from having done the work. Maybe there should be more in person, role-based training with SME's to assist. Maybe if each department had 1 non-management person (kind of like a SB/DVBE advocate) from each department/agency be a procurement representative to present department issues at a bimonthly forum (like SCAN).   There should procurement meetings for the department/agency representatives where new laws that have been enacted can be reviewed to ensure understanding where they can have a voice to speak about how those are impacting their jobs, etc.

Fragmentation across state/local systems that serve the same people. Programs in health/housing/social services work separately with different rules but serve the same people. They have fragmented data and separate funding/rules. This creates confusion for the consumers, duplication of efforts, and gaps in care especially for the people that most need it.   1. State depts should work together for shared goals and coordinate service instead of running parallel programs that don't connect. And leadership should facilitate that collaboration.  2. Agencies should secure shared data to see full picture of a person's needs and measure outcomes of wellbeing.  3. Give counties/regions flexibility to test local solutions using funding and simplified access to services.  4. Train/rotate staff across departments/agencies so employees can understand how other systems work and work together better to solve problems.

One primary problem I would address is the idea that supervision/management is just the next step in making more money. A supervisory position should be one that helps the team, not one that makes it worse by 1) removing an expert and 2) giving someone a position they're either not ready for or don't really want. Supervisors and managers need better soft, people skills. We need people in those positions who want to lead, connect, and improve their teams. We don't need someone who just didn't have any other way to increase their salary. So, start by fixing the salary system. We need good people in every classification and series, and we need to be able to reward them and their expertise.

Onboarding and succession planning. When joining a new team or department, there have been instances where I was thrown into the job with little training or onboarding materials. I've also noticed that when some folks leave, there is not much planning or knowledge sharing happening. This results in taking many steps backwards on progress previously made. I would also address flexibility in the workplace. Many polices are created for an entire department, but they do not fit all the working conditions of the individual branches and units. I would allow for more flexibility within each branch/unit.

The unnecessary spending. For example, in my line of work, we send people down south for training when the following month we do the same training her in Northern CA. I am all for training but when we are spending $20,000 to send four people down south, I feel like it is unnecessary money, especially when at times these are for new hires. Also, in my department, we have sent the same people year after year to the same training when the employee has come back and said that they didn't learn much more than the year before. Another example is the amount of time wasted on doing the same procedure multiple times, just different ways.

I created step-by-step procedures, including snip pics and highlights, for a few of my duties.  I trained a student assistant and a modified light duty worker to assist me when the work volume was high.  They used the procedures as a guide and found them to be very helpful.  Management commended my efficiency as this improved the process.

I believe our government could be more efficient by making sure funds are going to the places they are meant to go to and not drawn out of other programs to make ends meet for a current program, thus at some point making the program that had a surplus of funds at some point low on funds because the once surplus was drawn out from. I feel when this happens it just happen it becomes a snowball effect. I believe it can be taken care of by having more auditors to make hold our government accountable as to where funds are going and that the full amount of the fund was used and if there is left over that is put into the surplus so that if another program needs it it will be there for the taking. Hopefully not become unaccounted for.
There's a lot of egos to manage - executives and leadership... it can be hard to collaborate with other programs or agencies staff because everyone seems worried about themselves.

As a resident, I am stressed to my core by the amount of wasted dollars CA spends just to be the "first" or the "leader", for example with GenAI.  As a state worker, the hurdles me and my team have had to jump through is unacceptable for an emerging technology.  CA never partners, they try to lead and be in the spotlight, and fail.

I have pushed to use private contractors in addition to department crews to get fuels reduction work done. Due to the cost of pay/benefits/pension and the short length of the effective work day, it costs about $48k per acre for department crews to get fuels reduction work done. A private contractor can range from $3-8k per acre and will get it done much more quickly.

Here is a crazy idea: we actually promote people instead of forcing individuals to interview for other positions to obtain a "promotion." What is the incentive to perform well except to not get fired? I have witnessed people "quiet quit" because they do not interview well, and therefore cannot promote despite being exemplary employees.

When we started having training sessions remotely via Microsoft Teams, more people attended.  We should go back to this. I am not talking about total remote work from home but remote features of in-person work, where an employee can stay in their office instead of having to travel back and forth to a conference room.

Since we are being pushed to return to work, offering better in-person benefits. If I have to commute to Sacramento, I should not be expected to pay for public parking. That's ridiculous to as when they pay is already significantly low in comparison to private sector jobs. Maybe adding free charging stations where employees can charge their electric cars. On-site gym, lunch, etc.

I completely agree. That has been my experience as well. I was trained by a peer who didn’t explain the steps I was doing to complete the tasks. I asked management about a program that I was not “trained” in and I was told I should have known and they gave me a low score on my evaluation but proceeded to say I was knowledgeable. It really doesn’t make sense.
C alHR does not pay state workers enough, and is constantly nickel-and-diming us. I would like to see wages come closer to a livable wage for Californians.

Problem: We have really smart employees that spend years doing their job, but their institutional knowledge often gets stuck or siloed, so when they leave, or the work increases beyond their capacity, it's hard to step in to do the work. I think some solutions could include better documentation protocols, with staff dedicated to upholding them (i.e., making sure our network and SharePoint folders get insane, which they always seem to), and staff time to document/communicate procedures and innovate ways to improve processes.

Californians are often confused by state laws and regulations and often have difficulty understanding what steps to take to accomplish certain transactions. As such, they resort to randomly calling any available state number they can find and/or submitting large amounts of unnecessary documentation to random state email addresses. This frustrates both the customer and the state employees on the receiving end of the calls and emails. CA government agencies and departments must do a better job in creating easy to use websites, forms, and portals where information is presented in an understandable format.

Given the urgent housing shortage in California, why aren't existing vacant or underutilized properties being prioritized? One idea is to start encouraging the state to revamp tax code incentives and penalties to maintain, occupy, or repurpose spaces that are currently eyesores or not wisely used.

For my current department I think that a primary problem is some people are promoted without meeting MQ's while others are told they can't promote due to not meeting MQ's despite experience and relevant education. I would suggest making the field fair, either follow the MQ's or don't but it should not be unfair. Also why do we retain and promote non-productive people, a supervisor in my office has been the worst at every position she has held however due to favoritism/ nepotism she keeps promoting and keeps being a really terrible employee/supervisor. She is also friends or relative to at least 3 current employees and one who recently separated. How is this nepotism still happening?

I would want to address the career promotional process. There are very talented and eligible people who are often overlooked because of managment bias toward a friend or particular ethnic demographic to fill a position.  The promotional process, though intended to be standardized, is still manipulated by hiring managers for what appears to be affirmative action reasons. I would like to see the political bias removed and the practice of hiring/promoting be solely based on merit of work performed and abilities demonstrated.
Less "social engineering" and more  direct problem solving.
If given the opportunity I would like to.

If we have a huge deficit, why fix something that isn't broken.  The money it would cost to bring state employees back to office is extreme.  We downsized to save on rent and maintenance as well as cost to the state.  RTO will not promote collaboration because staff will still be meeting via Teams.  RTO also means more interruptions with staff walking to restrooms or breakrooms.  Noise levels will return.  There is no flexibility with RTO and managers/supervisors will wind up just micromanaging which takes away from better solutions and better results.  Gas is already expensive, and we took a pay cut for two years.  How is RTO going to improve collaboration, innovation and accountability when we are already doing it remotely?

Cross training always deepens the bench.  I work in a center responsible for the southern half of the state.  I, and others, have cross trained with the team responsible for the north half of the state, allowing for seamless coverage when staffing issues arise, with the field none the wiser.  Customers usually don't want to hear about the reasons for less than stellar service.  Keeping staffing options flexible and mobile helps keep the experience seamless.

A) Joint projects between county, city, and stare workforce partners that do or do not necessarily require a contract. B) Makeover and Updating public relations material, online presence, and in person presence activities to modernize our image and PR and events.

There is an urgent need to make all aspects of my agency electronic and remote. The effort does not take into consideration human knowledge and the multiple scenarios a customer’s record could have. There is not always an automated way to handle all transactions. And instead of realizing this, we continue to push out bad products causing confusion and frustration for both the customers and employees.

Administrative processes, such as time accounting, expense reporting, and field vehicle maintenance, take way too much time to complete.  This includes the software used to input information, management approval process, and revision of forms that need to be resubmitted.  Expense reporting, including receipt submission should be done all electronically (rather than having a requirement to hard mail in forms that can get lost).  The process for expense report is not intuitive and expense reports often get rejected, resulting in additional staff to correct these forms and correspond with reviewers.  An updated program, even if one created by a vendor, should be used for this.  The systems used for time accounting is very outdated and clunky.  I have used much better time accounting systems in previous jobs, which require less time to complete and are easier to use.  State vehicle maintenance is a nightmare - there is no fleet maintenance program for our state vehicle - we are required to track maintenance ourselves.  Getting repairs done is difficult, even if the repair is urgent, requiring us get procurement approval for the repair and to use a very limited number of maintenance shops in our area.  In addition, we have to use multiple maintenance shops (one for tires, another for battery change out), which are typically about 20-40 miles away from our office and require staff to lose at least half a day to wait for these repairs.

Eliminate the fraud waste and abuse in the state system. For example: cal aters program. This program charges 6 plus dollars for every reimbursement that a state employee submits. Even for 2 dollars. Creating “positions” for state government that are nothing more that other employees taking care of their friends.
