I think a lack of uniformity across state agencies and even within the organization creates a challenge. It seems each organization interprets the rules/regulations differently and as a result, the public is not necessarily receiving accurate information, and the red tape that our analysts end up dealing with causes major delays in our internal processes. Especially within the hiring process.

I previously asked CalHR for guidance on implementing 360 evals and was advised against having any represented staff give feedback to an excluded supervisor or manager in this manner. 100% agree with you that it would be nice to implement this systemically, but because of CalHR's response, my current org only practices this by CEAs participating in the Executive Director's review process.

I think that we have to fix the contracting process.  It simply takes too long to be efficient. A large part of the problem is the multiple hurdles that have been imposed on us from the Legislature, which passes these changes to the law, but never seems to revisit them to see if it's working. I had been working on a contract for months when I was told at the last minute that I had to use a different contracting process because of a legal change.  Madness.    My recommendation would be for the Governor to call a special session of the Legislature to focus on how the State conducts business, specifically contracting. Maybe include some State employees who actually do the work to testify, rather than just the upper management.
Training

I work for CDCR and notice we have a lot of vacant property and buildings. We have a ton of homeless and individuals in need of mental health care. I would love to see a way we could meld the problem with a solution and put the vacant property and the buildings into better use - assist with homelessness, substance abuse and mental health issues.

As a resident I would say all of the State's website need to be more user friendly for a lay person. May websites use State lingo or direct people in ways that only a person who works for that department would understand. The DMV website is confounding. I had to help my son sign up for his driver's test and it took a long time to figure out how to do it.

This is very true! Even during the job application process, it is incredibly unclear what exactly the roles I was applying for were. The duty statements were often vague and incomprehensible, so I had no little understanding of what the day-to-day responsibilities of the roles were.

Real estate is a huge industry in this state and should be scrutinized on how it affects the state and can be best used to benefit the state.  Real estate seems to be dictating its wants and needs to the State more than it should.  Real estate as an industry finds ways to run up pricing to benefit itself at the expense of everyone else and our economy.  The more money that is locked up in real estate the less money is in circulation in the state.

I've noticed that several agencies are outsourcing tasks like accounts payable and travel coordination to other states.  This reduces the number of Californians who work for the state and puts a burden on the remaining staff to train those workers from other states.  If I could I would like to have these contracts revisited, they are not saving the state money and from what I see are costing it more.

Agree!!!! If my duty statement is to make recommendations and be the subject matter expert, I’d like to see that in practice. Too many times do I fee unheard/not valued for the work when management strong arms what they want— which to me the person who does the work doesn’t understand the purpose or value. If you won’t listen to the person who knows the job, you won’t listen. Worst type of management unfortunately— well there is worse lol.

I am disillusioned on how much the state spends on patient care; it is out of control.  We should not be providing such expensive care.  The reality is that the patients get better care inside than we will get outside, irrespective of whether we are retired or not.

I would like to see better housing and someone to realistically look at housing.  It's way too expensive; incomes don't rise with the exorbitant rate rents do, what one gets for what has to pay for is woefully substandard.  I'd like to see statewide, consistent rent caps.  When folks are stressed out just by one of the three necessities of life, food, shelter and clothing, let alone the other two, it is extremely stressful, affects job performance and mental health.  Seems to me California should be able to do a better job in these areas.  After all, they are life necessities.

I offered and developed a training for all new attorneys in statutory and regulatory interpretation, including legislative and regulatory research. I also orchestrated tours at the local law library as well as the State Archives to inform legal staff of available resources. I helped devise a checklist for legal staff preparing for administrative hearings.
You're right.  Business wouldn't run like this either.  But most businesses grew up with email and consider efficiency valuable - meaning management suports finding efficiency to the ground level.

Many rural counties have school districts that are required by law to opt into our programs, but they do this individually and are overwhelmed with the administration and compliance requirements involved. It would be beneficial if the State offered the counties some financial incentive to sponsor the program for the many smaller districts, so that they would save $ on staffing at the small district, but also the State would need fewer staff for administration and compliance to run the program. This could be a one-time incentive or an incentive built into participation in the program. So, instead of 5-10 individual small districts, there would be one. Our programs are so complex, that some would rather not take part and collect the federal dollars than deal with the red tape.

The majority of the Mutual Aid system in California. Agreements between agencies that have been in effect for years. They only take review and small adjustments annually.  The state could save billions annually if they would adopt a different mentality. I am not trying to be political but the states processes need to be DOGEd.
Continuing California's groundbreaking work from home policy will increase government efficiency and help worker be more effective.

Efficiency. Working in different departments I find many departments need an overload, reorganization, and current policies and procedures. I would love to join a team to review each department and find the state savings. Salary and Benefits is a large budget in each organization; savings here would do much for the state.

Collaboration among analysts. Sharing knowledge and working through problems with colleagues contributes to more effective and efficient handling of cases. Working on cases with a co-analyst has contributed to robust and effective policy outcomes.

I have done a great job at providing better customer service resulting in getting a lot of accolades (from the industry I serve) for quick turn around, attention to details, being a problem solver, valuable team member etc. I bring over 20 years of private consulting experience to my craft at the State. However, I am at the most junior level in my department and my approaches for improving efficiency etc. is not being heard. I hope to rise to leadership positions (which seems to be a slower path due to positions being offered based on # of years of experience within the organization rather than who is more qualified for the position) one day and not only improve efficiency but inspire a whole generation of public servants to be there best versions.

I wish that those making the "decisions" would come to the realization that the option to telework has been so beneficial for state workers. People are more productive and the work life balance is almost even. We spend so much time at work giving our all, the ability to do so at home without having to make a drive in a few times a week is very appreciated.

State departments use each fiscal year to do reorganisation which seems like a cover up to get rid of lower paying positions, dumping extra work on the supervisory staff while providing less resources. State work is becoming less and less appealing because we are not even treated like valuable assets to the department, we are treated as replaceable and constantly fear the fiscal year ending if we are lower level, because it means possibly being furloughed or cut entirely.

I think this forum is meant for state employees to provide suggestions (based on their training and experience) on how to make the state workforce more efficient, not on how to spend more tax dollars.

From my perspective as a Californian, another area where efficiency and fairness could be improved is in the treatment of permanent intermittent (PI) electricians. Although many PIs work full-time for years, they do not receive the same benefits as their permanent counterparts, including boot allowances, regular pay dates, or timely raises. They are also last in line for overtime, unable to post and bid for jobs, and even when serving as lead workers, are not permitted to step in as temporary supervisors. Having spent 24 years as an electrician in the private sector, I can see how this inequity discourages skilled workers from staying with the state. Addressing these disparities would improve retention, morale, and ultimately the quality of service provided to the public.

Better training is needed on all levels. An online course with a quiz is not working for real life situations. Telework is great, but making sure employees are connected and feel safe to ask questions is important. New employees and counselors feel overwhelmed when trying to learn the job while also doing the job. Staff development should assess each person' learning style and have a safe and/or test environment before they are expected to do the actual job. And our structure has manager that have no idea what the role of support is. How do you manage and train staff if you do not understand their job? Our previous structure had management for clerical staff and management for counselors. It was better then than now.

I am vigilant about requiring my staff to write desk procedures for all their tasks, keep them updated, train a backup, and check with the backup before requesting vacation. Things run smoother and people know what is expected of them.

One primary issue j would seriously want addressed is routine employee reviews. Management needs to be more involved in how we handle ourselves when we speak to our customers. Some employees have 0 interaction skills to be helping a state agency or work with the public and these bad apple(s) make the the rest of the crew look bad. A QR code should print on all customer receipts so they can, within pressure, submit their our reviews of their office visits and is a customer asks for an employees name the employee should not hesitate to give their first name only for the purpose of a review, this way management can use this data for routine employee reviews.
Created templates to streamline
Communication and training are the biggest issues.
Stand-up meetings are great for keeping everyone on the same page and ensuring the topic of the meeting is efficiently communicated in a timely manner.

I feel a challenge which our office experiences are employer engagement and commitment for student/apprentice placement. We are actively forming partnerships and entering into agreements to address this challenge, but would like the culture to shift so employers are more actively involved in fulfilling roles through apprenticeship opportunities.
Disrespectful in everyway
Adhering to laws, regulations, rules and policy.

Departments work in silos, not together. There is no systemic way of sharing institutional knowledge, so innovation happens in uneven pockets and archaic processes persist.  There should be experiential learning opportunities across departments for people in job-alike roles (e.g., HR, budgets, accounting, contracting, IT, EEO, regulations, etc.) so that even new State employees can develop real networks and meaningful relationships outside of conference/workshop settings. We need to say "one team" less and act like one team more.

I can also speak as a California resident who sees the impacts of our policies and infrastructure every day. I believe we should also work to make our government more accessible, transportation safer and cleaner, work to reduce the excessive cost of leaving, and infrastructure more resilient and equitable for all Californians.

As a California state employee focused on educational improvement, I look to streamline cumbersome regulatory processes into collaborative support systems that better serve our local educational agencies. Federal Program Monitoring (FPM)  My most significant contribution has been leading the redesign of our Federal Program Monitoring approach, moving from a compliance-focused audit model to a capacity-building partnership framework. Previously, the FPM process created significant anxiety among LEAs, with extensive document requests and adversarial site visits that consumed enormous staff time on both sides while providing limited educational value. A key component of this transformation involved conducting a comprehensive review of existing FPM requirements to identify regulatory overreach. After systematically analyzing our monitoring protocols, several questionable requirements were brought to the legal team for review. This process resulted in the elimination of multiple requirements that exceeded our statutory authority and created unnecessary burden on districts without corresponding educational benefit.

I think people's perception of the prison system and what actually goes on inside the walls is dramatically different.  As a department we communicate the different ways we offer rehabilitative opportunities as well as the incidents that occur, but how do we communicate this to the public?  I don't know the solution but believe it's crucial for the public to be aware of all of it.

Perception. Often times there is a negative public perception of State Employees and the work we do. The public sometimes feels like State Employees are not in touch with reality or the types of issues they are facing. I feel this could be improved by being more human in public interactions, being honest and transparent, even if it is not a positive topic, and by having more consistent training for all divisions within the enterprise, allowing for more educated and positive interactions between the public and State Employees, regardless of who they are interacting with. By having honest, educated, open interactions, even if both sides do not agree, they can understand, which can lead to acceptance. This would also apply internally between various levels of leadership and staff.

All boards and bureaus under the Department of Consumer Affairs (DCA) share the same goal: to protect Californian consumers. I often see representatives from various DCA entities at community resource fairs, senior fairs, etc. Outreach teams from different agencies are constantly searching for these events and trying to join them. We pay registration fees, go back and forth with organizers to arrange everything, and travel to different locations.  Why don’t we organize a DCA Consumer Protection Fair ourselves? As many DCA boards and bureaus as possible can join and set up a table/booth. Members of the public can attend and learn about all the resources available to help keep them safe, from how to find a trustworthy accountant to staying safe online, what to do if they were sold a bad car by a dealership, etc. A big issue facing us is that consumers simply don't know that our resources exist until we actively seek them out and inform them.  An Annual Consumer Protection Fair would be a great event for the public and help bring together the work that the Department of Consumer Affairs does in an efficient and targeted way. We could host it as part of National Consumer Protection Week (March 1-7, 2026).
I don't need to be in the office to adequately serve the taxpayers and uphold the Constitution. We can redirect those funds into something that people actually need.
I have made templates that have streamlined paperwork.  It makes the use of time more efficient, especially as work does not need to be returned to correct errors.

The states contracting methods and purchasing are too bureaucratic   ,are difficult to navigate, and are too time consuming.  Make them more efficient by streamlining the process and allowing public works  and service master contracts to be awarded.  Once that is done time efficient work orders can be implemented quickly and efficiently.

While I am aware retrofitting office space into housing isn't as easy as it sounds, there is a massive amount of square footage in the middle of cities within easy walking distance of a large number of services that is currently being spent on people joining zoom calls. The reduction of traffic alone would massively improve causal visits into Sacramento and reduce the carbon footprint of California.
At my agency, staff are encouraged to be creative and reinvent or create processes; this is not the case at all agencies, many are stuck in their ways.

One primary challenge I would address is ensuring that state resources are used as efficiently and effectively as possible, particularly in programs that directly impact communities. Too often, valuable funding is underutilized, delayed due to administrative hurdles, or misused. To address this, I would focus on streamlining processes, improving interagency communication, and increasing transparency for both staff and the public. By simplifying procedures and making information more accessible, we can ensure that funds are deployed on time, maximize their impact, and maintain public trust.

in our present fiscal crisis, a consolidation of governmental agencies should occur to transfer expenditures to front line positions directly impacting and/or benefiting Californians. Consolidating departments and headquarters with similar, associated, or adjacent roles and/or responsibilities will consolidate headquarters locations and all associated Headquarters personnel positions. It will streamline operations to ensure the maximum number of fiscal resources are spent where it makes the most impact on Californians or on State Employees.    Supportive administrative positions should be carefully examined to see if an entry level administrative telework position could do the same work.  Offering those employees to reside in areas of the state with lower costs of living and eliminating their commute time and commute related expenses.  This would make the positions attractive to more prospective qualified employees and should reduce vacancies and amount of time vacancies remain unfilled.  Many agencies have duplicate departments or divisions and the agencies may operate in similar or adjacent fields, consolidation of the executive and managerial leadership, elimination of duplicate faculties, transition of appropriate administrative roles to more entry level telework classifications, will improve effectiveness and efficiency of operations, improve the quantity and quality of services delivered to Californians, and reduce budgetary spending for the state overall.

Bring a flat tax across all the people. Reduce money distribution for capable people. Hold social programs for their deliverables and holde people accountable for results as documented to receive funding.

If the state were to evolve and embrace telework it could save the state millions of dollars in operational costs associated with building and road maintenance, not to mention the environmental impact.  Consolidating state agency buildings to allow for in-office time of 1 day per week would allow the state to sell surplus buildings and reduce traffic, thereby also saving funds associated with road maintenance and helping the environment.

Right? Even though the consultants all say to improve employee engagement, morale, and productivity we should allow flexibility, even salaried staff are expected to be available during core business hours, which are set by statute as MF 8-5. This even though the huge majority of business is conducted asynchronously and I get maybe one unscheduled call per month. Limiting staff availability to core business hours if anything makes it difficult for blue collar Californians to access state service if they do need to talk to someone in real time; many would need to clock out and take a pay hit.

One idea to make California’s government more effective and efficient: "LEAN"  Reducing the number of steps to get the job done should take top priority for every department. Investing in training every employee in LEAN would be a starting point to transform how the State does business more efficiently and serve the public more effectively.

1. Enhanced Data Sharing and Matching • Worked on projects where CDTFA data was cross-verified with outside sources such as EDD payroll reports and FTB income filings. • Helped develop data-matching routines that flagged potential underreporting before audits were launched, saving time and improving enforcement fairness. • Result: Increased detection of noncompliance while ensuring compliant taxpayers were not unfairly burdened.  2. Training and Knowledge Sharing for Staff • Conducted internal training sessions on using analytical tools such as SQL and Excel for data reconciliation and fraud detection. • Shared best practices with newer auditors on reviewing digital records, allowing staff to work more effectively with electronic rather than paper records. • Result: Reduced onboarding time for new auditors and greater consistency in data-driven decision-making.

as a resident, the cost of living is too high, too many taxes, as our pay increases, so does the cost of our insurance and gas, and food.  as someone who is in a more rural area of California, my commute to work is 40 minutes. While there are vanpool options, they are few and hard to get into.  I love this state, the land is absolutely beautiful. the people are diverse and the energy is amazing. we are all struggling together though.

The State of California has many Agencies that do the same work, but in a different way. The Governor has talked about consolidating some of those departments, but that's not really being done according to the mandate. The main issue is that those that are in charge of making changes have a big ego that gets on the way of serving California effectively.  For example, in the homeless issue, sometimes it takes 3 to 4 months for a homeless to be referred to an apartment and receive all the medical, mental and housing needed at that time sometimes it's too late.

I would address the EDD Unemployment Benefits program. At a time when individuals need their benefits the most, accessibility should not be a factor. The system used to manage unemployment benefits is antiquated and the whole infrastructure needs to be modernized. Individuals having issues applying or accessing information about their claim are unable to speak to a live representative because their call center hours are extremely limited making it more difficult to reach a live person. Why can't call center hours be extended? With disability and paid family leave benefits, an individual is able to go into a local office and speak with an employee. Why was that option removed for unemployment benefits?

As a CA resident that enjoys living and working in CA and raising a family here, I would like to see policies that incentivize those individuals who remain in CA upon retiring from State Service rather than moving to another state.

I wonder if they should require executive staff to do a set amount of field days a year/per project relevant to their department (media/communications spend a day with an Interpreter, public safety attends a ranger lecture)

We need more effective systems for capturing institutional knowledge. So many folks are retiring/nearing retirement and their replacements--if the position isn't swept or reclassified--have to reinvent the wheel. Obviously we don't want to keep doing things the way they've always been done, but we could save a lot of time and energy by having comprehensive job aides and reference materials kept as living documents to support new hires.

Your suggestion is fantastic, but I wanted to let you know that many colleges and universities already offer credit for work in related areas (for example, you can't just have any old state job and get credit towards a medical degree, but if you work in a public information office then you can probably get credit towards a communication degree). It's usually a conversation between the school advisor and the department to determine what counts for what.

The cost-of-living is out of control.  There needs to be limits placed by state government on how much electric companies should charge, for example.  Electric companies hold a monopoly and have increased their prices by about 300% in the past ten years.  The use of microeconomics and budgeting may help obtain reasonable guidelines for cost-of-living expenses based on our individual net incomes.

I would like to see an improvement in paying local vendors faster to attract more in an effort to support our local economies. I would like to see 3rd party vendors i.e. DVBE be removed from the vendor list as they are doubling supply costs and gouging the state.  Directly ordering supplies from Amazon is a more fiscally responsible practice.
Making the websites easier to navigate. Make it easier for the customers that are not as technology savvy navigate the websites

I haven’t been a state employee long, but I work with a lot of people that have so I’m basing this on coworkers’ explanations/comments along with what I’ve seen so far. I would say address the repetitiveness/excess/disconnection. How many departments provide the same service to the public/have the same or similar program? Does that need to be provided in multiple departments? Do those departments work together or at least know of the other programs and departments? Are the processes as efficient and streamlined as possible? As mentioned in other comments, the purchasing process for example. Do we really need 3 bids for all purchases? Is that an outdated requirement? There seems to be a lot of oversight/"red tape" in some areas, yet huge contracts can be awarded with little to no oversight of the program/department/funding disbursements after.

Problem: Independent adoptions are often dealing with children who should have been agency cases, which would come with financial assistance, Medi-Cal, and no cost.  However, because CPS was bypassed, the family has to pay over $4000 and get no assistance. Solution: Have all guardianship or relative adoptions be at a reduced cost, and/or if there was a CPS history have AAP or Medi-Cal be available for more families.

One example of work I have done to make things more effective or efficient is setting up guidance documents and examples for future staff members to follow. There is a lot of turnover in State jobs and it took me about 2 years in my current position to put together the pieces that were left to me when I started this job after about a one year hiatus in the position. To save time for the next person, I've been putting together clear examples and guidance documents pointing future staff to work we've previously done, where examples can be found, and how to complete tasks that will be expected of them in this position.

At the very least, things would go more smoothly with less staff turnover. I have never worked HR but I have heard it is a micromanaged nightmare, and as a result no one ever knows how things are supposed to work because no one can stand to stay there long enough to learn. This leads to everything having to be resubmitted multiple times with multiple edits and approvals which is a waste of time and money, as well as a blow to morale.

How can we make or keep our public areas, freeways, public transportations clean?? California a 'leader' state, but not in public cleanliness. Homeless and unhoused people are on increasing trend, and their visibility in public areas is sad and disappointing to be a Californian.

We really need to eliminate arbitrary financial thresholds and create ways for state to look at more data points than just something like 'net income', there are so many other factors in a person's life, including some that can easily be quantified and some that can't, that impact whether a person should qualify for certain benefits or services. These thresholds were understandable back before we had access to so much more intelligent technology but now it seems inexcusable to not be able to take more nuanced looks at peoples' life circumstances and backgrounds. We have all experienced hardships we can't control that put us ahead or behind the curve and those things aren't even that difficult to quantify now that we have 'big data'. If the private sector can use all that data to market products to us, we should be able to use that same data to better support our citizens. Why is it that YouTube knows I'm shopping for a t-shirt but we can't tell that someone is struggling to pay their bills? To be clear I'm not advocating intruding into peoples' lives but surely there is more we can do to ensure that when someone is experiencing a challenge in life, one of the first things they think of is, 'oh wait, what if the state has any options to help me?' We are a high-tax state and I suspect a lot more people would be okay with that if they saw tangible benefits of that money in their day to day lives.

The State of California should implement statewide enterprise-scale master service agreements for common software/services used by multiple departments, saving a lot of time and money by eliminating the need for each department (and sometimes different divisions within the same department) to go through the contract/bid/procurement process individually for identical services, which is cumbersome, inefficient, and expensive. With a statewide service agreement, departments could easily procure needed services off an approved list.

There is a lack of cooperation between agencies that causes frustration on all sides. And there are not clear set guidelines on what procedure is, so we all have to navigate personal preferences with each person we need to work with. It becomes frustrating when dealing with items that need approval from other agencies. Items will sit for weeks just waiting for a waiver from them. It makes completing our jobs in a timely manner impossible.

I wholeheartedly support mentoring programs. In fact, I think that providing an assigned mentor to new hires should be a routine practice. This could be a coworker, someone doing the same or similar work in the employee's department (if not a coworker), or someone who is doing the same or similar work for another department who wants to serve as a mentor.
Love that one budget gimmick to sell all the building for a one-time cash infusion and then pay extra overhead forever...

Increase telework and boost morale for the employees.   Happier employees mean more dedicated employees that are willing to work extra hours if needed to get the job done.   It is a win, win for the state.
That the ideals and goals of serving our population sometimes get lost or distorted in the currently state apparatus, we should be more agile, adapt and react quickly to our constituents' needs.

Need to be more tech focused and open to improvements. Certain jobs in IT can be done completely from home which improves productivity and attention to detail. Open to exploring technical advancements for SCO and Medi-Cal systems.
Smart purchasing. Communicate with the boots on the ground with their needs and wants instead of blind fully purchasing.
I'm not sure the China-Europe Express would be that jealous that we can go from San Francisco to San Diego.

Strengthen leadership to increase efficiency, reduce turnover and reduce costs of hiring and training new employees by reconsidering classification levels; the only way to advance should not be through promoting into a management role. That leads to having the wrong people in management roles which can create toxic workplaces. (Think Michael Scott of The Office.) Instead, the state should establish advance levels of classifications with earning potential on par with managers, which will result in the retention of seasoned employees, decrease hiring and training costs of having to hire new employees when these seasoned employees leave the workforce for higher pay, and would be more efficient because the state would not lose those seasoned employees with advance knowledge and skill and historical knowledge and continue to be a valuable resource to newer employees.

Accountability for our appointed executives may be an issue. The politically appointed executives answer to no one except for perhaps the Governor's office, which may be too busy dealing with other issues.
Balance and falls. Exercise, community services that include exercising, and accessibility to physical therapy services (outpatient and home health).

Mt. Tamalpais is located in an area with a high cost of living.  Even with state park housing, it is unaffordable for park employees to live here (rangers and maintenance staff) - especially with a family. So, it is hard for us to recruit - and we are in need of staff. It would help to be able to offer a cost of living adjustment/stipend to make it easier for staff on a parks salary to live near the park.
Agreed, working full time for Dept of Veterans affairs but still can't afford to move out of parents house isn't sustainable nor attract more potential staff.

Government workers are often drawn to state service because of the stability, flexibility, and the mission of public service. That’s why the return-to-office mandate worries me—it risks pushing people out and discouraging new talent from joining. I’ve already seen good colleagues leave or begin planning their exit, and we can’t afford to lose strong employees when recruitment is already so competitive.  At the same time, I do recognize that some employees don’t always engage or collaborate well when working remotely. That lack of participation can create frustration and fuel the push for mandates. But instead of a blanket requirement, I think we should treat remote collaboration and remote work etiquette as part of performance expectations. If someone is showing up, communicating well, and delivering results, they should keep the flexibility. If not, then their performance review could require them to be in the office more often.  This approach keeps flexibility as a competitive perk, while also addressing real concerns about accountability and teamwork. It sets a higher bar for engagement without punishing those who are already working effectively in remote or hybrid environments.

Yes, Telework does work. Especially for working moms. Mom's want to work they just need flexibility and RTO took that away from them. We need to be better at allowing working moms to bring home a paycheck.

My experience as a state employee is that many managers—and the culture they shape—need a mindset upgrade. Gallup shows that office culture and morale flow from the top down, and morale is the foundation of productivity, engagement, efficiency, and retention.  Too often, I see managers: -Blaming staff for failures while taking credit for successes. -Struggling to delegate effectively, creating confusion and unclear expectations. -Avoiding leadership when it’s most needed, leaving staff to fill the gap. -Focusing on process over results, stifling creativity and growth. -Failing to empathize with staff as individuals, imposing unrealistic standards. -Resisting feedback, dismissing new ideas, or fearing innovation. -Managing by fear, micromanagement, or “command and control” rather than trust and accountability. -Prioritizing compliance and appearances over genuine outcomes.  The result is lower morale, weaker teams, and higher turnover. Spending the time to learn how to delegate wisely, listen actively, and lead with vision pays off with stronger, more productive teams. Far too many state resources are wasted replacing staff who leave managers—not jobs.  For inspiration, I recommend Simon Sinek’s leadership talks on YouTube.

Californians often do not know about the great work our state does, especially in areas like healthcare. Many Californians do not even know about their health care rights, or what Departments are available to assist, or how successful they are at helping people obtain health care. As health care is increasingly politicized, and the federal government is making it more difficult to get care, it would be wise to demonstrate what the state government is doing, and how it helps actual Californians.

Retention and recruitment is a major concern as departments are quite dependent on experienced staff and their institutional knowledge.  Constant turnover can be disruptive to program needs and if staff are just using entry level positions as just a way to get their foot in the door, supervisors can't make any long term plans to improve processes.  There needs to be more promotional opportunities and analyst positions to motivate staff to stay within their departments.
As a California resident- I wish that the home insurance and the property taxes can be lowered.

Other than how expensive CA is (I think only HI is more expensive), my biggest complaint is the lack of Veteran support in CA. CA is one of 16 states that tax military retirement. There are many states that offer more benefits to veterans, CA is minimal. It is almost insulting. Veterans only make up about 4% of the adult population in CA, ranking it 49th-highest per capita of the 56 U.S. states. There is a reason veteran's leave CA when they retire or separate. I speak at military transition workshops, and I always ask how many are planning on staying in CA, only 1-3 people out of 25ish raise their hands, and they all say it's due to the taxing of the military pension.
Trying to embrace all technology, for example, participating in cross-team MS Teams chats instead of communicating issues via email

I have worked as a State employee for approximately 7 years now and I feel the lack of accountability in departments and individual employees contributes to the burn out of highly productive employees. I also manage employees, and the current performance management system makes supervisors and managers feel unsupported to the point where it is easier to let an employee do what they want rather than hold them accountable. Prior to working in the public sector, I worked 12 years in the private sector and find it difficult to understand why it is so much more difficult to hold employees in the public sector accountable than in the private sector.

We have an opportunity to create content about the positive impact we have on the entire state.  We can take a page out of Newsome's marketing campaign and make waves.  In our case, positivity can rule the day.
Did you work with your Legislative staff? Ours has fairly frequent contact with the offices of legislators.

One example on improving efficiency within our department is the move to scan and digitize paper documentation. Many existing files are old, difficult to search, and cumbersome to manager. Creating searchable PDFs and storing documents on a shared drive, staff can quickly locate information, access each other's work, and reduce time spent hunting for physical files. Virtualizing documents in this way is a significant time-saver and greatly improved our workflow and collaboration within the unit.

Cross training on workloads and allowing lower classifications the ability to lead different tasks when available. Prepare them for their next level and give them the ability to show what they can do and give credit for working on the task.

As a Californian and a state employee, one primary problem I would address is the gap in consistent internal training and the redundancy that often slows down our processes. Over time, new employees receive strong onboarding, but tenured staff may not always get the same opportunities for refreshers or updates on evolving policies, technology, and our mission. This can create uneven knowledge levels and inefficiencies in how we carry out our responsibilities. To address this, I would advocate for a structured internal training program that includes regular refresher sessions focused on our core duties, our mission, and the ‘why’ behind our work. This would help reinforce a shared sense of purpose and accountability. Another problem I would address is the overlap and redundancy that can occur between agencies or divisions within our department. While each unit has an important role, sometimes our responsibilities intersect in ways that create duplicated efforts, confusion over jurisdiction, or inefficiencies in communication and data sharing. Additionally, I would look at streamlining redundant paperwork and leveraging technology to make our processes more efficient — for example, consolidating overlapping forms into a single digital system or using data-sharing tools between departments. This would reduce administrative burden and allow us to focus more time on the impactful parts of our job, like serving the public and ensuring workplace safety.
Stop buying so many computers. We waste hundreds of thousands annually to replace good, working equipment. Not to mention all the e-waste.

Spending the time and effort to improve data handling processes pays huge future dividends.  Cheaping out in the near-term creates major time-wasting problems in the future.  Prioritize data and systems!  "Turbo-Tax" all the input forms for people who need to report to the state - it should be dead easy for them, which requires major up-front investment.

California's permitting system is inefficient and often tilted in favor of large agencies and well resourced companies. Small landowners, community groups and individual applicants frequently face overwhelming barriers- long delays, unclear requirements, and inconsistent communication. Everyday Californians struggle to participate meaningfully in this process and many simply give up. Meanwhile, agency staff- stretched thing and bound by unclear, outdate (some Basin Plans) - often seem unable or unwilling to help.  The system is not just slow it is inequitable. There are major structual issues driving the dysfunction: fragmented authority, a legal inablity to rely on sister agency reviews, and a risk-blind permitting process ( small projects get similar requirements to big projects).   These isuess can't be solved overnight but having a way to measurer the effects and inequities would be a start. There could be a few steps to start:  -Create share reivew systems across agenices so they can work together instead of having separate sources of data on permits. Identify repeated work across agencies.  - Change/update laws to let agencies rely on high quality review done by partner agencies. - Build tiered permittig process that matches level of review to actual risk of the project ( driveway, replacement of infrastructure without increased foot print), versus new industrial center). - Invest in accessible guidance and staff support. Similar to CDFW have scaled permit fees based.

Better training. Even though I am not staff development, I often train field staff. And I work diligently to make sure our vendors understand our invoicing procedures to ensure timely payments, even though I am not in accounting. Ensuring all staff is adequately trained and/or know who to go to for assistance is the key to quality customer service.

Increased efficiency in State procurement for information technology needs. The two control agencies (CDT and DGS) need to simplify and streamline IT goods and services approaches. Many of these are antiquated. CDT could provide cost savings by being the front of many basic IT goods and services procurements, then leverage this out to state entities. Also, although the focus on small business is important,  for complex IT goods and services, most small businesses need additional support from DGS to develop relationships with vendors, skill sets, and expertise to support technical procurements. DGS could rely on technical staff to develop enterprise and mandatory agreements (with CDT) to reduce overall risk. Another area is GenAI and AI procurements. We need to get faster on understanding risks and benefits. Reliance on private data centers, as well as the global impact of GenAI power consumption, need to be examined.

I joined this "discussion" today and have to click through 495 comments to engage with one that I resonate with. I have been "loading" more comments for 10 min and not even half way through the forum.. I gave up reading through since it became too repetitive with Telework and "NO to RTO" ideas. All of which I agree with given the many costs saving to tax payers, work life balance and increase in staff productivity when working from home!.. this platform tool is clunky and hard to navigate given the volume of commented ideas.
Work from home until the HWY 50 and other major infrastructure projects are completed.

I have been with the state for 9 years and 3 months. As a state employee I feel that the new hires are not getting the proper training to succeed in their job, that is why we have a lot of turn around and a lot of mistakes.  I believe that our state should train these new hires properly, with in classroom training and not just virtually on the computer. The state would save more money by just investing in sending these new hires to get the proper training instead of having them retake the virtual classes again and again it’s just a waste of money and time.
While I generally like this idea, it may not be feasible in all circumstances, for instance where state agencies are subject to different federal regulations.

My department is similar. Instead of looking at ways to streamline our processes so that more people can receive the funding manage, we come up with more barriers and make it more complicated because management is afraid one person will use the funds incorrectly. If we simplified the process and made the guidelines extremely clear, it would be easier for people to receive funding and use it properly, and it would be easier for staff to monitor the use.
Cut or eliminate excessive bureaucracy, not everyone or the population has to have a say in an issue. Take some autoreactive action.

I have learned to become a SharePoint site manager to collaborate more effectively with outside stakeholders in order to more quickly share identified deficiencies and have them corrected, while still maintaining data safety and security. Due to our specific use case, our department's SharePoint administrator had to learn how to use a broader range of features in order to provide secure access to users outside of State service.

Taking paper, faxes, and Adobe PDF forms out of business processes and collecting data via secure web forms reduces the number of errors. That may not work for every business process, but, where it does, it eliminates unwanted queues and manual data re-entry. Complaints go way down when you do that, plus you often save  money.
Crosstraining and team work are essential to our department. Communicating current issues with the entire unit also allows for a united front when dealing with issues.

I agree with the excess bureaucracy, and I feel like there is a disconnect between the higher management like the chief of staff and the lower management like supervisors. I don't see why we have set days in person or reorganizing when there is no feedback for us to give.

To build a more effective and future-ready State workforce, we must address outdated systems that hinder collaboration, innovation, and talent development.  Leadership Culture The traditional chain of command may suit high-risk environments, but in civil service, it often stifles collaboration and trust. Leadership based solely on tenure can lead to silos, disengagement, and missed opportunities for innovation. Incorporating 360-degree peer reviews and influence-based leadership models would promote accountability, humility, and a culture of shared success.  Classification System Our current classification structure, designed for factory-style work, doesn’t reflect the dynamic, cross-functional nature of today’s roles. It limits mobility, professional growth, and alignment with modern competency-based hiring practices. A shift toward a flexible, skills-based framework would better support recruitment, retention, and continuous improvement.  Technology Barriers Outdated systems discourage younger, tech-savvy professionals from joining the State. Investing in modern, user-friendly tools is essential to attracting talent and signaling that innovation is a priority.  These changes are critical to creating a more agile, inclusive, and responsive public sector.
Agree, work on team building,training

Primary problem with the department that I work for is that it is a "reactive" department and not "Proactive" when it comes to decision making.  There are so many things implemented based on what upper management thinks is right but then changes when someone gets injured or something goes wrong. If upper management would work cohesively with their staff, they would be able to implement better policy and procedure.  There needs to better communication and work ethic with upper management and staff.
Modernize our payroll system, PLEASE!!!

I suggest the state adapt a “classification roadmap” that guides state employees on a general career path, differing from the Upward Mobility Program, this roadmap guides from classification to classification, i.e, as a Staff Services Analyst, what courses CalHR, higher education, training events, and skills are recommended to progress to Associate Government Program Analyst.  Naturally, this would lead to how to progress from AGSA, to SSMI; from SSMI to SSMII; etc. the training, courses, education, recommended reading. Another example, how to progress from Office Technician, to Business Services, etc. The classification roadmaps could include the Departments that have the specific classifications and recommendations for “assignments” as part of your career path, i.e., a new to the state employee may want to start at a smaller department, then progress as an AGPA to a medium department.  Granted this would be a massive undertaking and a classification duty statement can vary greatly based off the agency and its mission, however, I think it could be beneficial to provide that general path as some employees may lack the mentorship from their current department or supervisors or generally not know how to create a path to career within the state.

There are too many agencies doing the same thing/same type of work. Unfortunately, many of the agencies are led by politicians who needed to be placed somewhere by the governor. We should consolidate agencies to streamline funding and combine expertise.

As a DTSC PM for affordable housing projects it would be nice if we could work more efficiently internally and not cause an undue burden/cost on project proponents by potentially delaying projects due to our some times slow turn-around times and multiple iterations of document review necessary prior to approval.  I would propose that in general more scoping meetings should occur, and more up front requirements should be expressed by DTSC technical staff to proponents as early on in the document review process as possible.  It would also be great if supervisors and staff at higher levels could provide priority lists to staff with large amounts of work requests in order to prioritize for faster-paced projects with more aggressive timelines.
Roles of support staff working from home doesn't seem to make it to those of us with boots on the ground.

Yes, there have been reports of inadequate oversight of public and private landlords, leading to issues like fraud, corruption, and substandard living conditions under HUD. Public housing has been criticized for trapping families in poverty, limiting their access to opportunity, and perpetuating racial and economic segregation. For example, some landlords have the ability to charge and collect application fees. This may provide an incentive for them to continue accepting fees while failing to accept a resident for an un-occupied apartment.

We are very poorly trained and lack operational consistency.  Every office is doing something different, every agency does the same process different ways, there needs to be a smoother process on how we do things in each agency.  There are too many hands in the pot, just to get something approved as simple as office supplies, it has a minimum of 5 people processing an order, we are spending more money in labor then what the supply request cost.  There should be statewide system for things like procurement, timesheets, basically any common function that is takes to run an agency.  It's too hard to come up with a solution to the problem because I don't know if anyone above rank and file want solutions.  There are to many EO, AEO, Deputy this and that.

The cost of doing state business is too high. We pay contractors ridiculous amounts to do work state employees could do and  the amount of money we pay for leases and office space that we proved was not necessary for 4 years from 2020-2024 is outrageous. Every department could hire more staff to do work for the people if they weren’t paying so much for unnecessary business leases. Additionally, forcing employees to return to office has reduced morale because employees have less money and time to spend with their families, leading to less positive customer service experiences for the public.   If the people delivering the service are miserable, they aren’t going out of their way to make that experience positive for the public.   Lastly, exempting employees more than 50 miles away but limiting their ability to promote is a guaranteed way to lose staff that hold critical institutional knowledge. When I leave my department as a result of this limitation, I will be taking with me the knowledge that only I possess. I support systems that save my department millions of dollars each year and there is one else in my department can support these critical systems.  It would take at least a year and a LOT of money to hire and train someone such that they can fill the gap I’ll be leaving behind.   I don’t want to leave state service but the governor’s return to office mandate leaves me no other choice because uprooting my family is not an option.

I suggested we work to streamline processes to make them more efficient and easier to remember.  This also allows us to work as a team to understand different perspectives and approaches.  This is still a work in progress - but its hopefully moving in the right direction

I just really hope the information we are sharing in this forum will be collected and evaluated to identify themes and opportunities.  Then, I hope there are meaningful improvements to our processes and work as public servants.

Something that I have found useful, especially in working in a remote/hybrid environment is the creation of an internal communication guide. Something that tells people, especially when they first start, how communication channels work internally. Something that explains when to use an email, IM, support ticket, etc. With all of these new ways to communicate and especially in a remote/hybrid environment having a clear and explicit document on which form of communication you should use, how you should format your questions/requests and who/where you should submit that to can help immensely with stopping crosstalk, misunderstandings and delays in requests.

Need to reduce law enforcement spending and get the currently employed people in public safety sector out doing the actual job. too many of them are gaming the system with overtime, 3 or 4  differentials each and retiring early.  The system allows for the abuse. Reduce the overtime by scheduling staggered shifts and don't allow them to get paid to drive patrol cars to their residences and back (2 hours each day in drive time + fuel x how many people doing it?).
The primary problem that I would like to address is ensuring that proper preventative maintenance is completed on State Park infrastructure to avoid costly repairs and replacement.

State workers need to acknowledge the foundation we stand on. The state should work with our California State Universities or University of California's in collaboration with Historians to document how each Department was ran and operated in previous generations (as well as our current generation). This would provide oversight and a framework for future generations to build on and acknowledge the overall direction of each department. This would also allow public record for our tax paying/voting citizens to have informed knowledge on what these departments have provided over the years, as well as give insight to how we can improve. This in effect would lesson reactionary politics and allow further positive growth towards democratically guided agencies in a show of absolute transparency. Some agencies like the Department of Rehabilitation have had leaders which fundamentally shaped our state for the better. Having that history fully spelled out for the general public would also strengthen loyalty and ensure that our leadership today and tomorrow can embrace the foundational values of these departments exist in the first place.

The underutilization of the pharmacists. Pharmacists can play a transformative role in California Correctional Health Care Services by expanding their clinical, operational, and educational impact. They can contribute more effectively through a Collaborative Drug Therapy Management: 1- Work closely with physicians and other healthcare providers to optimize medication regimens for chronic conditions like diabetes, hypertension, mental health disorders, and substance use disorders; 2- Patient Education: Provide direct counseling to incarcerated individuals on proper medication use, side effects, and adherence strategies, especially for complex therapies; 3- Protocol-Based Care: Use approved clinical protocols or collaborative practice agreements (CPAs) to manage drug therapy independently in certain cases, improving access and outcomes.
Upgrade financial systems to me more efficient and transparent.

The amount of paperwork and approvals needed to make a simple purchase of essential items for our office.  Release budgets to the local unit itself, so that state BSO approval is not necessary.  Local units are able to spend effectively, abiding all state policies and guidelines.

The rigid and structured processes to obtain and use new technology for state workers create a detrimental bottleneck. While barriers exist for a reason—such as security, cost, functional risks, and employee training—these issues can be addressed to allow the state to take advantage of improved tools and processes.  Security Concerns: Instead of defaulting to denying every request, talented security teams should provide a plan on how to use the technology safely.  Cost Control: Why should software or cloud services be marked up by middlemen who provide little value? Direct procurement could reduce costs significantly.  Functional Risks: These can be alleviated by having capable, trained employees who have expertise in the technology being implemented.  Discussions around these barriers to entry, why they exist, and how to minimize them are essential if the state of California wants to be efficient and effective in serving the people.

I believe that state employees should have a higher degree of data literacy. Most (if not all) of my colleagues work with data in some way - whether it be simply reading/reviewing reports, to complex data analysis. Yet, so few of my colleagues possess modern skill sets to analyze/process data, and limited understandings of statistics (which is often the most key aspect of regulatory science!). I have witnessed piecemeal efforts to increase data literacy and train employees to use modern coding tools (e.g., R, Python, GitHub, etc.) across CalEPA BDO's, however such efforts often require significant internal willpower to overcome inertia (which sometimes is due to deliberate resistance from management, but often is simply a product of good ol' fashioned government inefficiency).

There are too many levels of management and things are lost. I started about 5 years ago before the salesforce platform. Now, with salesforce, the ONLY thing that matters are numbers. These numbers did not exist a few years ago and now they are the only thing that matters. The employees don't matter. JUST the numbers. Managers are very secretive and things are kept from everyone.. very us against them mentality

As both a citizen of CA and a public sector worker, I see an issue with each state and county departments/agencies/boards being siloed with their data. This means I have to submit my information to each department every time I need services or to update my information to continue services at every stop. I would like to see all CA state depts move to a centralized data warehouse. I want to add or update my info 1x and have that info accessible by all state and county departments/agencies/boards. This reduces the burden on me to manage, increases data integrity, and allows for beneficial enhancements such as leveraging AI to review my info automatically and inform me when I qualify for a services across the state, and auto-populating my global data when I apply for these services - potentially doing all the work for me. It would also improve statical reporting statewide as the data would be pulled from one global system. CA citizens should have a CA profile, not a DMV profile, FTB profile, EDD profile, etc.

I think we need to streamline our processes. It seems like we keep adding additional steps, systems, rules, etc. to everything we do. I think the steps we need to take to make our government more efficient and effective are: 1) question every requirement, 2) Delete any part or process we can 3) Simplify and optimize 4) Accelerate cycle time and 5) Automate.
Indeed, and it leads to wasteful spending.

People often blame CEQA for slowing fuel reduction projects, but the real barriers are limited capacity, planning inefficiencies, and overlapping regulations. Even when CEQA has been waived—such as the 45-day priority projects or the 2025 Secretary’s suspension—we still must comply with all other environmental laws. That often results in more paperwork and delays than if we had simply gone through CEQA. For example, CDFW frequently requires a take permit, which adds 90+ days to a project, making timely fuel reduction even harder.  A more effective solution would be to create a 4(d) rule under the California Endangered Species Act (CESA), modeled after the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service’s approach under the federal ESA. These rules allow targeted exemptions or modifications to take prohibitions for threatened species, so beneficial projects like fuel reduction can move forward without lengthy permitting when impacts are minimal or positive. This is especially critical for California’s fire-adapted species, which often benefit from vegetation treatments.  Currently, CDFW offers Memoranda of Understanding for take, but these are case-by-case, drafted after listing, and far less efficient. A 4(d) rule would instead be established at the time of listing by the Fish and Game Commission, ensuring consistency and streamlining the process. Where federal 4(d) rules already exist, the Commission could adopt them directly, avoiding duplication and aligning state and federal protections.

The State's hiring process is confusing, cumbersome, and inefficient for applicants AND hiring managers.   From the internal perspective, hiring managers are inconsistently trained, some not at all, on the process. When will we hear back from CalHR with an offer? Do I have to/can I write to people who didn't get the job? Am I required to contact references? Can I give a verbal offer before I get the go-ahead from CalHR? Once when I was hiring, HR screened the applications, I interviewed people, chose a candidate, and then HR told me that person wasn't qualified -- that shouldn't happen! The whole process takes a very long time, and we lose the most qualified applicants because they start new jobs before we even finish interviewing people, or get the $ offer from CalHR. The confusion and lack of communication around the process causes extreme inefficiency and time wasted.  From the perspective of an applicant, the process lacks transparency: When will I hear back?; How high do I have to score on an exam to be considered?; I got a 95% on the exam, was highly qualified for the job, but I didn't ever hear a word from the agency or CalCareers after I submitted my application. Applicants shouldn't need to go to Reddit for answers to these questions.   Staff need consistent-across-the-board training and guidance materials. We need to give applicants better, transparent guidance and communication. We need to make the hiring process more efficient and less cumbersome all around.

The purchasing system at my organization is very difficult and slows down our work a lot. All purchases have to go through small businesses, which makes the process of purchasing quite slow. Sometimes it takes up to six months to get lab supplies that we need. Additionally, the small businesses are much more expensive. I like the ethos behind the idea of buying from small businesses, but these businesses are basically just someone in an office ordering from large companies then marking up the prices and reselling to us when we place our orders with them. It's really inefficient in terms of time and money.

As someone who has been with the state for many years, I find Upward Mobility to be a challenge. There are trainings that are available, but how do you train for a position you have never done before? I would like to see management take an active interest in investing in those who want to promote, by providing job shadowing, mentorship, and also providing projects where the person can actually acquire real knowledge and skills to get to the next step in their career.

The use of Lean 6-Sigma under the Brown administration was working well.  There were many proven strategies that streamlined the processes for many agencies.  We lost that program once COVID hit.  If you want to make significant improvements, use tools and techniques that actually work.  A measurable approach to efficiencies.    Efficiencies should come from the ground up, not the top down.  As Managers, challenge your staff to improve their workload, workflow, and decision-making improvements.  If there is a high demand for rework, your process is broken.  It needs some simple fixes to drop the error rate to zero.  It's called mistake proofing.  Don't allow mistakes to carry through a process until the end.  Stop it in its tracks.
Policy revisions, streamlining procedures and increasing response timelines.

As a California state employee, I’ve focused on making data processes and services more effective and efficient for both staff and the public. One example is my work on modernizing DMV’s data pipelines and integrations during our transition from legacy mainframe systems to Salesforce. I led efforts to clean, map, and validate large datasets into standardized formats. By automating parts of the validation and transformation process in SQL and Python, I reduced manual review time from days to hours and improved data accuracy before migration.  Another improvement involved documenting and streamlining the change request and deployment workflow for the DVM environment. Previously, approvals and scheduling caused delays due to unclear communication between teams. I restructured the process with clear ownership tracking, ensuring deployment jobs were pre-approved and ready for execution without back-and-forth emails.   I always try to improve collaboration across teams. For example, I created shared dashboards and data dictionaries that made it easier for both DMV and vendor analysts to trace field mappings and data lineage, cutting rework and confusion across multiple projects.

California's state agencies often have different interpretations of the same policies set by entities like CalHR, the Secretary of State, and DGS. This decentralized approach creates a lack of uniformity in business processes across departments, particularly in areas like Human Resources.  A recent project aimed to identify a "golden image"—a consistent, shared process—for the departments within our agency. However, we discovered that each department follows a different process for the same core functions. This forced us to develop a separate, customized IT system (SaaS) for one department and then hire a consultant to modify the code to fit the next department's unique needs. This constant customization is expensive, with each new system integration costing between $250,000 and $500,000.  By mandating a single, consistent interpretation of state policies, we could achieve significant efficiencies and save millions of dollars. A standardized approach would allow for easier cross-training of staff and eliminate the need for costly, department-specific customizations of IT systems. It would ensure that technology solutions developed for one department are readily usable by others, creating a more cohesive and cost-effective operational model for the state.  Furthermore, it may be beneficial to centralize human resources at the agency level and have one  HR system across the whole agency to save even more money.  This centralized idea can work for other admin areas as well.

One problem I have seen many times is silo-ing where programs do not talk to each other even when their actions will affect one another. This could apply to many situations but one I've seen a lot is during regulatory development, the regulatory team does not always reach out to other programs like admin/finance, enforcement, community outreach, etc. They also do not always provide resources for those groups to help implement the regulation via positions or money. I would suggest improving collaboration across divisions/agencies, and doing so as early in the process as possible. This will also prevent needing to make as many changes to the reg or process in the future.

I know state agencies aren't supposed to have contractors long-term, but almost every agency has contractors in their IT department because it's hard to offer a competitive salary for good talent and the infrastructure for getting good IT contractors is robust. It would be great if there was support for integrating contractors smoothly when they come on board.  My team acquired two IT contractors in the last year or so, and I wish some kind of training had been available to help set my expectations for what contractor teammates are like. They were highly skilled, but needed much more specific, hands-on direction than I expected. They also had different expectations for interactions and I think there was some confusion as to who their directions were supposed to come from.

Telework should be seen as a strategic system improvement that enhances organizational efficiency and public value, not just an individual workplace accommodation. Implementing statewide telework reduces overhead costs like office space, utilities, and operational expenses—freeing funds for critical public services.  Studies show telework often increases productivity due to fewer distractions and more flexible schedules. This flexibility supports better work-life balance, reducing burnout and turnover—key challenges for the State workforce.  Telework also expands the talent pool by attracting skilled workers regardless of location, which is vital for hard-to-fill positions. It enhances inclusivity by making State jobs accessible to people with disabilities and those in rural or underserved areas.  Additionally, statewide telework adoption demonstrates environmental responsibility by cutting carbon emissions from commuting. Less commuter traffic means public savings through reduced wear on roads and lower maintenance costs. Telework ensures government continuity during emergencies—like natural disasters or health crises—making services more resilient. Overall, telework strengthens institutional performance and public service delivery.

Also, FYI, the list of class codes and which ones an employee is eligible for related to that class code for AGPA includes everything from Ferrymaster to Attorney. I don't think that's correct! I wish they would update it. What other jobs should I be training to move into besides SSMI?

The State of California has a multitude of leased and owned office space that spans the entire state. Given the return-to-office mandate by the Governor (N-22-25), the state Department of General Services should allow State agencies to create a 'Hoteling' service/platform whereby office-based state employees from any agency can work 'in-office' at a State location convenient to them or for operational need.  The benefits could be numerous:  Reduced commute times and easier schedules GHG and emissions savings Lower commute costs Greater inter-agency collaboration Greater state representation in the State's 58 counties

The system of CEAs, or Career Executive Appointments, and appointments to heads of government agencies is perhaps the single largest problem in California government.  The appointment of people with little to no direct experience in the work of an agency results in these CEAs hiring teams of consultants to advise them on what actions to take, which bill at rates of $400-$600/hour ($800,000 to $1.2mm FTE salary).  Then these political appointees hire people that they know who also are not experts in government or the agency's business and use consultants to teach them how to run the business.  Then, anyone with actual knowledge of the agency's business leaves because they're not valued and they see the waste all around them.  They know that they would make more money as a consultant instead or have less frustration working for an ignorant boss and being a punching bag for the general public who don't value the work of government either.   Many state employees are just contract managers and have little or no private sector experience.  The state needs to be serious about paying people what they are worth so they can attract real experts to run departments and to eliminate the system of appointments that destroys expertise.  Politicians are unwilling to pay for the true worth of a worker that knows what they're doing and instead they pay multiples of a true, market-rate salary to consultants and appointees that produce no actual work.  Furloughs also kill retention efforts.
As a state employee and a Ca resident I hate seeing my tax dollars spent the way they are. I only work for one state agency and imagine the problem exists across all agencies.

California Governor’s Office of Emergency Services Executive Memorandum To: Fire Chief Brian Marshal-CALOES-Fire Rescue From: Dave Norman, Assistant Chief-CALOES-Special Operations-US&R Date: October 12, 2025 Subject: Request for CAL-Card Issuance to Special Operations Assistant Chiefs Purpose: This memorandum requests the issuance of CAL-Cards to CAL-OES Special Operations Assistant Chiefs to support operational effectiveness during emergency deployments and pre-positioning of specialized response teams. Background: Special Operations Assistant Chiefs serve as Agency Representatives (A-REPs) during high-impact emergency operations and pre-positioning missions involving: •	Hazardous Materials (HAZMAT) Teams •	Swiftwater Rescue Teams •	Regional Urban Search & Rescue (US&R) Task Forces •	FEMA US&R State Teams deployed in-state or out-of-state via EMAC These deployments require rapid, on-the-ground decision-making and logistical coordination. Currently, the absence of direct purchasing authority via CAL-Cards limits the ability of Assistant Chiefs to procure essential resources, services, and supplies in real time—impacting mission agility and service delivery. The CAL-Card can be used for unexpected costs that arise, and that the assigned IMT might not be familiar with, such as the N95 mask needs for US&R Personnel during the Wide Area Search Operations at the January Brush Fires. Currently several agencies provide CAL-Cards to their supervisors, in some cases to Company Office

This is so true! I really struggle with all of the racism in the office and hate that I have to either bite my tongue and accept it, or face retaliation for reporting it.
